Great Views over the Thames. Queued on Sunday afternoon but it moved fairly quickly. Took the concession ticket price as we all over 60. Don't be too proud! The main draw for the Tower Bridge is the walk along the glass floor. We did it, but it does make you feel a bit vulnerable. Only one side was open to do the walk, which is a shame as it was the weekend of half term with loads of families. Great views of the Thames and surrounding iconic buildings - take your photos through the open small windows for a clear picture. Lots of information on other bridges round the world, some we'd never even heard of. Time was short for us so we were unable to check out the engine rooms, but we enjoyed the visit very much.

beautiful. Beautiful place to take pictures in the evening beautiful lights in the night its great if your wanting a romantic strool its great I enjoyed seeing all the light lit up in the evening there are restaurant s along the road side but no very many
one of the best bridges in London. This probably one of my favorite spots in London to see. The view from boths sides are worth taking. I would suggest going there by sunset or during night time.

Must be one of the most photographed structure in the world. Of course Eiffel Tower might be ahead here - but surely the amount of crowd, the views from and to it from far, and close across the Thames bank are wonderful. If you get a chance stay at the Tower Hotel (Guoman), with views to the Tower Bridge. A must see if you are in London and take 100s of photos around it :-)
very nice view. especially at night. this magnificent historic bridge is worth watching. At night view is just amazing. you should have good view to take pictures and enjoy the baeuty

Worth seeing, but nothing that amazes you!. As the title above reads, It's great to see but nothing that will amaze you. I actually found it quite boring to be completely honest.. We paid to see the glass floor which is around 170ft above the bridge itself.. That was actually quite cool to see as your walking on the glass floor. It did feel somewhat weird as we walked along it, all in the mind..So to sum this review up, I'd say definately go see it whilst your in London, but don't expect it but amaze you.P.s We went in the day time, maybe at night when the bridge is lit up may be a completely different experience!.

Fantastic. This famous bridge is impossible to miss out when you are around the Tower of London. It's massive and very impressive. You can get the most beautiful view from the garden of the Tower of London. Amazing experience.

Amazing views from a beautiful bridge. This was an unplanned trip so didn't get the opportunity to look around for offers on the door price. After purchasing our tickets at the door, we had to wait five minutes for people to fill the lift, as you are taken to the top in groups. Great informative "show" explaining the history as to how the bridge first came about, the design etc. At the very top there are numerous information boards and photos of its history and other bridges around the world. It was an eye opener to see so many unusual designs.The glass floor was impressive and it took me a couple of minutes to pluck up the courage to walk onto it, having failed to walk the glass floor in the CN Tower, many years ago. I was so very proud of myself for walking onto it and then wondered why I was so scared in the first place. There was a member of staff who was very helpful in answering the questions we had and was able to show footage of the view through the glass floor when the bridge opens, from using his tablet on a QR code printed on the floor.We visited the engine rooms afterwards, but not being into engines, found it less interesting.Overall it is well worth a visit; a beautifully designed bridge with spectacular views from the top and the staff were very helpful.
Little bit bored. At the beginning it was interesting then I get bored a little. I think it is alright to see but for older people and kids, not for man in late twenties (when I was there).

Amazing to see but a bit of a let down. To go inside this historic London building was amazing experience, we already purchased our tickets online but still had to queue but we were soon at the front desk. You basically then get a lift up to the tower bridge itself where a curtatior in the lift explains how to get to the exit after your initial crossing of the bridge with the glass floor.As soon as you come out of the lift (which is like something you find in a council flat), there is a film been played on a loop with a few benches to sit and watch the history of how Tower Bridge was built. The film was ok played by over acted actors where it should of been more informative, to be inside Tower Bridge is amazing then you walk along the top of it seeing the views of London and come to the glass walkway which is a weird experience looking down to the Thames. Please note a lot of people have lots of photo opportunity so try and go at quieter times if you can. Also the information inside was a bit dull, it seemed it was more interested in showing you other facts of London rather than the bridge itself. What about more information on how the bridge shaped up during the wars and how it was constcuted with more pictures and films about it?.Then you come down the other side in the council lift again a but dull and you are told to follow the blue signs to the engine rooms which again was nice to see but what about real people could be stood in there and pointing and showing more on how the engines use to work in living up the bridge? again there was nothing apart from signs a but of information and the odd couple of vending machines.Of course then you come out at the shop hoping you spend more money, so overall a great experience to say you have been in such a iconic landmark. I felt it needs more information and be a bit more creative which it lacked on.
Great place to walk on sunny and bright day. Its great place to walk, especially, when there is sunny and less breezy day. You see loads of people walking.I just had great walk with the family.

Fantastic Views. We were visiting London for the weekend, travelling down by train, so were able to get 2 for 1 tickets. I'd printed out the voucher ready to use on a previous trip but lost my nerve after spending too much time looking up at the walkways. After flying by myself last year I felt ready to conquer the glass walkway.The exhibition about the history of the Bridge and how it was built was very interesting. I find it amazing that the engineers of the day were able to come up with a plan and actually build it. The exhibition in the Victorian pump room with the equipment originally used to operate the lift mechanism was also interesting and again demonstrated the amazing engineering history of the UK.As well as information about Tower Bridge there were also an exhibition of different types of bridge found all over the world and an exhibition of buildings in the London skyline.Then there's that amazing glass walkway, looking down to the bridge crossing the Thames. I did manage to stand on it briefly but like a lot of people I spent most of my time skirting around the edge of it. You can download an app for you phone and watch the bridge as it is raised and lowered. If you actually want to see the bridge raised while you are visiting the lift times are on the website so you could plan your visit around that. The view from the walkaway of the London skyline and up and down river was good - we did visit a nice sunny day. For those of you into photography there are small windows on the walkway you can open so you can take photos without getting window glare. Only one glass walkway was open - the other was covered by a mat which I quite happily walked over, even though I suspected what was underneath it!

iconic landmark. It's only a bridge surely? No! It's a bridge with a gap in the middle that you will struggle to pass by without putting one foot on either side! Childish I know but it has to be done! Also the amazing architecture and if you can be bothered to stand in line and pay the entrance fee a walk across the glass floor gantry. A small tip as well there are stairs at the northern end in the bridge that lead down to an exhibition of the bridge but also back on to the edge of the thames near a ferry pier.worth a trip away from the central london shops to see this and remember the tower of london is right next door so the bridge offfers a good photo platform for snapping the tower and skyline including the shard.

The view makes it. While I have an interest in engineering, that port of the exhibit was not quite as good as it could have been (and part of the exhibition was undergoing renovation).The view up the river from the top part of the bridge is spectacular. If you want to take a photo, you shoot outside a small window (and it probably makes sense to have a telephoto lens so bits of the bridge don't end up in your photo).

great views , try it!. we were lucky A beautiful sunny day last Sunday 8th Feb, the views from the bridge were great, the glass walk way was cool, unless you don't like heights!interesting info on bridges across the world , we also went to see the engine room and how it worked well worth a visit....Definitely one 'to do'

Good but crazy ticketing. we visited the monument and tower bridge today we're not tourists in London but extensively travel the country the world and like to do the touristy things which category these obviously fall under and never at any of these has the cash price on the door been the same as the online price and never have I booked online received a scannable bar code and then had to queue with the cash paying customers that have just turned up , so in short a combined monument tower bridge ticket online £10.50 on the door £10,50 ?? By the time you've used paper and ink to print it your actually worse off ?? Add to that the fact you don't have a dedicated queue and have to wait ages although you've already paid please tell me what the advantage of booking and paying in advance is , if the bridge was at its capacity it doesn't even guarantee you entry saying that well worth the money just don't bother with booking online

an Architectural becauty. we decided to do a walk around the London bridge on weekend, and that was best decision. Its not only about beauty but also about the civil engineering in such old time. You can literally see bridge opening to allow tall boats to cross bridge and then close. Its good to walk around with side walk & few other things, you can see the fishes also in the calm water. There is also an old prison. Overall a good exp with friends, normally there is good crowd over weekends.
A must. I've been there several times, really great place to walk around, take pictures and of course is one of the main attractions in London. If you go there go at night, amazing.

Nice view!!!!. I was with my husband and child of 8 years old and she recebível a passport with stickers to glue in...the gloss part of the Tower is wonderful..everybody watts to take a picture latina down on it...also there are pictures and a short sumaré of the most interesting brindes all of the World.. I fóruns one from Brasília which I was not aware of... Very Nice...

Symbol of London. Impressive from outside as well as from Inside. The museum is interesting with a little extra sticker collection for kids. We were lucky to see the bridge while opening by night. All in lights.
Great views. What a great experience! It's really great how you can have great views on the city, learn about bridges in London and bridges of the world!

It's got to be done. Visited here after visiting HMS Belfast. well worth the effort as the views from the top are great and the glass walkway brilliant. Pity there was only one walkway uncovered, but the reason given was that they weren't prepared to employ enough staff ! Still expect you to pay full price though !! Bit of a cynical approach though, considering the amount of people going through even at a quiet time of year.....
Amazing. This is again a must do if your visiting the great city.. but best advise is wait till its dark. Wow looks so pretty at night when its lit up

Excellence in its presence. An artistic beauty where the bridge separates to give way to the ships to sail and unites again to restore the road traffic is an excellence in itself. It is a pride of a moment to walk on the tower bridge and feel the past glory.

Enjoyed it. We purchased our tickets online which offered a slight discount. The see-through section of the floor was fun, and the videos educational. Our tickets included the "Engine Room" which would appeal to engineers and men.

Great experince on the glass floor. I was mostly interested on the glass floor walk and I troughly recommend it. Approaching the glass floor might give you chillies, but one you get to step on it and see people walking on the bridge and cars and sometimes ships it is actually great. I have visited it in a week day, so not so croudy and could take lots of pictures.I felt a bit dissapointed that only one path has the glass floor available at once, but I understood is for safety reasons, in case you are affraid of hights. A bit strange as you anyway have to cross the path with the glass floor availble to get to the other one. Before and after the path you get to see short movies on how the bridge was built. The views towards London not so impressive.I have visited the engine room as well;not really wow for me,however I was impressed by the moving wheels through steam, specially considering this was built more than 100 years ago. I took a joint ticket with The Monument, but I recommend only if you are up to go up and down 311 stairs in circle! The view from the monument was not really impressive, however it was a great feeling beeing on the top.

Loved it, would like to go again!. Amazingly beautiful bridge with breathtaking view. We took a walk trough the glass walkway, educated ourselves in the engine room where we saw how exactly the bridge works. It was maybe the second best spent money for an attraction (after Stonehenge).
Amazing!. Just the most beautiful bridge I have ever seen! Try it at the sundown then at night... It's so amazing...

A visit to London Bridge. I had a wonderful experience. First of all, city of London itself is very nice from all aspects- neat and clean, well dicsiplinned, well behaved people. Beauty of London bridge cannot be explanied in words. After I reached there I was feeling that I had come to a different world altogether.

Great View!. Value for money? Yes. Views were amazing. Went specifically for glass floor. Have to say thought the glass floor would be longer, however still great. I think you can get alot out of it in a very short period of time. A 2 hour job no more needed. Definitely worth it and would recommend.

Got to see it open for the 50th Anniversary of Churchill's funeral procession. By pure dumb luck, our trip to the UK coincided with the 50th anniversary of Winston Churchill's demise - meaning, we got to see Tower Bridge open for a reenactment of his funeral procession!We had found the website that lists Tower Bridge opening times, and knew it would be open the 30th, but didn't know why until we were in London. Scoped out the spot where we wanted to stand to watch and manage to get that spot - just moved over "two peoples' worth" of space by a sweet couple from Essex (who had also scoped out the best spot to stand and watch).The whole process of the bridge opening, the ceremonial passage of the historic boat with a bagpiper, and the gun salute from HMS Belfast, was awesome!Next time we're in the City, we'll definitely tour the inside of the bridge, which my husband has already seen, but I haven't. Gorgeous at night, too, with all the lights!

Beautiful. Tower Bridge is by far amazingly beautiful especially at night when all the lights have lit up on it, it was quite romantic for me and my partner to walk along the Thames with this in view. Worth taking the tube or walking to it to see!

Brilliant joint ticket. We purchased a joint ticket with the monument for £10.50 which we thought was very reasonable. We took the stairs rather than the lift which was a lot quieter but allowed you to have a great view going up and see more of the inside of the bridge. The glass walkway was a great aspect of the bridge and seeing the road and river below was great. I was a little too scared to fully walk over it but people were laying down on it so I don't think you're ever at risk. My partner is slightly scared of heights and found the glass floor no problem at all. There is a lot of info on various bridges of the the world and windows that opened to get great photos down the thames without the reflection of the glass which was a great addition. The engine room at the end which you need to walk to is very informative and great to see how the bridge actually works. Can't believe how they come up with it so long ago. Great day out!

Cool Bridge. Not sure it was worth the walk across (just to have to walk back outside in the January cold!). But it does have some little tidbits about other bridges around the world and a scary glass floor to take a picture. Just did it because it is a big touristy thing, but not extraordinary.

Tower Bridge. This was a great tour. If you have done The Monument tour and can show your ticket you get this at a discounted price. There is no climbing of stairs, but you are taken up to the top of the bridge by a lift. Very informative staff, and do this tour at you leisure. The walk above the top on the glass bottom bridge was very good. Bit unusual to look at, And the view is great. A nice little shop at the end of this four. I didn't go down to the engine room, as this was already crowded with a group of tourists, but the whole tour was great for 7pound.

Different view!!. We walked up the steps rather than just taking the lift as you get to see more of the inside workings of the bridge. There are information films at the top which are very informative and worth a look. The glass walkway was why we went and it was worth every penny. Standing above the roadway and river looking down is a weird experience and once you get over those first couple of steps you'll be surprised how brave you suddenly become and walk the full length in one go. My girlfriend was so impressed she is taking her friend back on their annual London trip for another go!! Excellent and only £9.

A seagull's view of the river. The staff are very helpful and, for London, good value for money. It's an astonishing feat of engineering, that in the days when there were no huge mechanical excavators that such a construction could be undertaken. I looked at the line drawings and found myself thinking that someone must have had a really vivid imagination to dream it up, the actual building it (thanks to an animated film) left me stunned. Speaking personally I wish I'd done the tour the other way round - by starting at the steam boilers and mechanical aspect and the explanation of how it all works and then moving on to the 'view from the top' - those wonderful walkways way up above the road and the river. The walkways have large glass panels in the floor - doesn't matter how thick the glass or to what standard they have been tested, not everyone wants to step onto them. The views up and down the Thames from these vantage points are fantastic, but part of me felt that is only window dressing for what is an amazing concept brought to fruition by very clever, far sighted Victorians. I wasn't impressed by the initial film - it was 'bitty and not all that well done and I found the dialogue poor.

Fascinating. Visited for the first time last week. Was pleasantly surprised to find it was free for people with disabilities. However if you have to pay, then there are lots of good offers about. In my opinion you miss out by not visiting the exhibition. The views from the top were spectacular. The glass walkway - a nice touch. You also get the bonus of a good view of the Tower of London. Anyone with even a vague interest in the ingenuity of the Victorians would be very impressed. The engine room was fascinating - objects of true beauty, brilliantly cared for. I will go back. I spent about 2 hours there, but could have occupied myself for longer.

Perfectly organized and good price. me and my 11-year old daughter visited London in January, and we found most of the attractions very expensive! But Tower Bridge was absolutely GREAT!!! Professional and gentile guides, decent prices, and very interesting....

Walk over Water!. Only takes couple of hours, not too physical, reasonably priced! Well organized! Definitely one 'to do'Buy ticket on day, or save money with internet vouchers. The lift up to walkway is accompanied, so any questions the very helpful staff seem to have answers.m( I believe walk up stairs is more interesting) the views from the top are amazing...helps if u choose good weather day! You don't have to walk on glass, but once you do it's amazing, lots of photos of lying down on the river ensued. Lots of interesting facts around, and short films with History of Bridge!The second part around the Engine Rooms probably appealed to men of party, but interesting to see for everyone! Souvenir shop at end. Excellent value, loved it.

Must see landmark of London. This Victorian masterpiece which is the landmark of London is a must see. Either just walk across it or go in it. With the right brochure you get a 20% off. The exhibition is, uh, well, not much really but has interesting aspects of this and other land mark bridges. Don't take the elevator up, walk the steps and admire the Victorian masterpiece. It's unfortunately no longer operational steam engine is a masterpiece to admire and shows you all bits and pieces on how this bridge was once operated by it.

Area brill . The bridge us worth a visitBut it's the history around this which is fashinating Walk along the river up to the modern art museum and shakepears playhouse And learn loads about medieval London

Views From The Bridge!. Stood on the bridge and took in the views on way to Tower of London. So many amazing buildings to see from bridge and the bridge itself is lovely. Cool mix of viewing the new and modern from the old and historic. Great place for a walk and picture!

Check the schedule to see it open up for a ship!. This is a spectacular bridge at any time, but seeing it open up for a ship is even more impressive. Before your trip, it’s worth checking the lift times schedule to see if you would be able to see the bridge open while you are in London. Here’s the link to the schedule:http://www.towerbridge.org.uk/lift-times/There is a nice viewing area on the same side of the river as the Tower of London, but on the other side of the road that goes over the bridge. (It’s northeast of the bridge, if you are looking at a map or have a compass.) This is a good place to view the ship going under the bridge if the ship is going down river, because you see the front of the ship as it’s going under the bridge. (The schedule says whether the ship is going up river or down river.) For ships going up river, I would recommend finding a place by the Tower of London, which is on the other side of the bridge, so you see the front of the ship.We bought tickets ahead of time, but that didn’t seem to be of any benefit. If I were to do it over, I would just get my tickets there.
Well worth the money.. Tower Bridge is a great part of london's history and for 9 pounds it's well worth the money to have an inside look into this great attraction.
Interesting exibition. Interesting exhibition about bridges and good view of below through glass floor. Also good view of local landmarks on clear day. Good value on 2 for 1 deal.

Well worth the money. We didn't pre book we just paid on the door and to be honest I thought £9 for adults was a good deal knowing how some tourist attractions like to overcharge. Lift up to the top of the bridge and walked over the glass walkway funny how many people were scared of walking on the glass some brave souls would only put one foot on the glass and then others were doing press ups on the glass..... short walk to the end at was a short film explaining the reason for building the bridge then walked across to the other walkway showing all the other various bridges in the world. Downstairs and outside across the bridge to have a look at the engine rooms. Really enjoyed the tower and for london prices cheap for nearly 2 hours enjoyment.

Construction Marvel. Always wanted to take a walk! on this bridge, though it was very cold! I did it! right from the Queens walk till the end! loved it!A must see must do when in London! One of the finest walks you will ever have in life!

Excellent. What a beautiful structure. Fascinating. Views are great, glass walkway is wierd. Part of your mind thinks you're nuts for stepping out! Very informative tour. Well worth the money, book online for a really good reduction.We took about an hour and a half to see it all. I'm not particularly into engineering but I found it all really interesting. Its a really good example of how inventive and clever the victorians really were.
Not just a bridge. We were lucky to see the bridge in service,its close from Tower Hill tube station,there are also some tours provided for a fee, a lot of restaurants and tesco express nearby

Good but quick. Interesting visit but didn't take much time to see it all. Short film,walk over higher levels and engine room visit. Not as good and long as thought. Nice bridge to visit and great views

Victorian Pride. For those like me who are into engineering this is a must, First you get to watch a video which is really engaging about the history and planning of the Bridge plus some of the problems London was facing and why was the Bridge important. Then you get to walk along a translucid floor 42 metres above sea level and the view from there is utterly breathtaking. After that there's another video (again 4 minutes long or so) explaining how the engine room works. The engine room is one of the most amazing things i've seen and it's definitely a proof of the magnificent things human kind is able to do. Definitely a must in London, not only for History's sake but also cos is really anjoyable and the staff is really friendly and helpful.

Iconic. Very reasonable at just £9. The videos about the history of the bridge are amazing and transport you back to another world. The new glass walkway is brilliant and you really feel your heart in your mouth as you step onto it and realize you are literally walking above a road and the Thames with just glass between you. Really cool experience.

Iconic . Period. If you come to London and do not plan to visit this Iconic Structure, it worth not visiting. Should be on the visit list. The place has Tower of London nearby, so one hour for the bridge with nice photo opps would do good.
Awesome exhibit. The exhibit is very interesting and informative. You go up inside the tower bridge and learn the history of the bridge. There's a glass floor up there and it's amazing!

Lovely Bridge. The best way to view this bridge is by the Big Bus, on the top deck, it drops you of at it, then take the tour it is absolutely stunning, the workmanship that went into it and the views are great.

Great place to visit and must go to . To be honest I didn't think this would be that i testing but I was wrong. It was fantastic especially being on top of the bridge looking at some staggering views of London and looking threw a glass window to the sea and roads was fantastic
DEFINITELY WORTH A VISIT

Great New Clear Glass Walkway at Tower Bridge. I went with my daughter to Tower Bridge last weekend and we went on the new glass floor walkway which is 42 metres above the bridge road below!
Great fun.......but not if you have a fear of heights!!

Tower Bridge Museum, High Level Walkways and Workings. An hour or so spent discovering how the bridge works, the steam- driven pumping engines with the old boilers, the views from the two high walkways - with the glass floor - and some interesting short films - few minutes long - all help to make this is rewarding and fascinating glimpse into this wonderful bridge. The Souvenir Guide Book is well worth the modest price - I love this Bridge as much as I love the beautiful Big Ben, Wren's St Paul's Cathedral, The White Tower of the Tower of London and so much more in our wonderful Capital City of London! (aka Michael Brightman author The Mystery Factor ebook)

London's most iconic bridge. It's a bridge and it's beautiful. Walk along it, see the views of the River Thames, stand on it during the London Marathon, walk along the walkway at the top (not free) on valentine's Day, stand beside it and watch the bridge open etc etc

Pretty. In the summer, missing Australia, this is one pretty bridge to have a look at. Its funny the London bridge is the most famous because of the children nursery rhyme but this is the most spectacular! I loved looking out at this at the pub overlooking it having a stella!

Engineering marvel with wonderful views. Visiting the inside of Tower Bridge is like entering another world. It is great value at just £9, you can even get a 2 for 1 deal if you have travelled here by national rail. The bridge opened in 1894 and the exterior is very church like with gothic windows. You enter via the North tower and get your first look at the steel skeleton within. Steps or a lift take you to the two upper walkways where you have outstanding views of the city. There are a couple of places where you can slide open the glass windows so you can take better photos. The city view changes every couple of years with the addition of The Shard, Gherkin, Cheesegrater etc. The other walkway faces towards Greenwich and Docklands. In November 2014 parts of the walkway were replaced with a glass floor.You descend via the South tower but hang on to your ticket. You are back outside again but follow the arrows to a separate building which houses the steam engines used to raise the bridge. The bridge doesn't get raised very often over winter. You can check the website or they are listed beside the controllers kiosk on the bridge.

A Beautiful Bridge!. We visited this bridge today and really enjoyed it. It's an absolutely gorgeous structure and the detail in the architecture and paintwork is stunning.We didn't take any tour on this bridge, just walked around and over it.

Lovely sight, so majestic.... The world famous Tower Bridge was so beautiful and royal. We merely walked on the bridge, not the museum. The river and the towers add to the ambience. Not much to say. Must visit. The footpaths on the side overlook the Thames.

Enjoyable. It was the first attraction we visited in london and it didn't disappoint. It was great to learn about the history of the famous bridge throughout the tour as well as take in great views over the Thames. The glass floor walkover was quite cool.

A good day with wonderful views. To start with we wondered what all the fuss was about - but once we got into the history of the bridge, watched the various screen presentations and found the cleaver sliding windows out of which one can photograph the stunning views up and down river, we were hooked. We were there for two hours and loved it all. DON'T miss the engine rooms at the end of the visit - a real highlight - and don't skip the screen shows. The only thing we didn't rate was the installation of perspex images of other London buildings on the walls as you go down the stairs in the South Tower - a bit tacky compared to the rest of the displays. The glass walkway is interesting and not too scary for people who don't like heights as they glass is dotted so you can see it is there ... I think it is best visited with someone who knows London and can point out various things ot see.

The alternative Tower Tour1. I had not realised that you could tour Tower Bridge, until the news a while back mentioned somebody on the tour, breaking a glass walkway.We did it on a freezing day in January, but thankfully the inside areas are at least not cold, and some are warm!Really nice to see the views, know more of the bridge's history, and visit the workings of a Victorian icon. Well organised and easy-paced.
Great visit . What a great place to visit insight into the history of the bridge with access to the glass floors above given great views and photo opportunities well worth a visit for the price
Walk on !!!!!. As it is every body can see just beautiful but if you have a little money you can walk on new ( renewed ) path 50 meters from Thames river.
Impressive sight!. I didn't enter the museum only walked across the bridge itself - the little gap in the middle was quite a thrill!

The glass floor is an added attraction. Scared of heights, but this is a must to tick of the bucket list! The glass floor is not all the way across, there is solid ground too! Although very busy and you have to grab the photo opportunity when you can, this was a great experience. Videos showing the bridge from initial thoughts through to completion. Great view too.
Great view. It was a great experience. We really enjoyed the view. You can see Tower of London just right next to it. Great!
Impressive!. Give yourself time to really appreciate its beauty, even with the onslaught of tourists its worth the time to take a deep breath and really take in the scope of the bridge.

Iconic London. Forget the hideous London bridge and make sure you stop in and see this one. Truly spectacular and has some great photos. If your tight for cash just walk across it and look at it from either side. If not do the tour it is good and never listen to a whining Pom say it cost to much,they whine about the beaches in Australia being to hot.
Spectacular sight. What an amazing bridge. I had seen it on movies and things but seeing it light up at night for myself gave me a real buzz!I say, if you are in London - go see it.

Great stroll day or night. Yes, the iconic bridge that identifies London (most people confuse and call it London Bridge). Yoy can enjoy the architecture from a river cruise or trip, walking along the river bank, from London Tower or a stroll on it.It is beautiful day or night when the colours come on.If you visit London Tower, make sure you walk the Tower Bridge across.

Worth a visit. Very interesting going up inside Tower Bridge, seeing how the bridge was constructed and used to operate (you see the old engine rooms), seeing how it compares with other bridges built worldwide, and walking on the glass floor and looking down on the traffic and Thames below. For an extra 90p you can get a combined ticket which includes going up the long spiral staircase of the Monument. This is also well worthwhile

An excellent attraction. An excellent attraction, so glad we made the effort to go.Starting off in an elevator up, you next watch a small movie explaining the history to the bridge. Then you get to walk around the upper part of the bridge itself, which is well cool. This now boasts the glass floor that you can peer down through, which is very cool. Although it's a bit of a cattle mart queuing up for it and then moving away quick so you give others their go. At least that's how I felt. Maybe I should have just taken my time.The engine room part is very cool too, so make sure your follow the signs to get from the bridge to that. I really liked this section of the tour with it's brightly painted piping. Book online for a discount before you go.

This is London!. Tower Bridge=London=Tower Bridge. Bridge is London's identity.The Bridge on river Thames gives mesmerizing view of what the city is. The view of this part of London satisfy you to be in the city, any time of the day/night.I was lucky to witness the Bridge in motion twice :)

No fear at Tower Bridge!!!!. Can you do it? Can you really do it? Walk on a sheet of glass at the Tower Bridge Exhibition at the top of Tower Bridge looking down at the cars driving far below you and the waters of the Thames rushing by even further below? It's a rush but it's FANTASTIC! My daughter laid down on the glass for her picture! So cool! My friend was hesitant to walk on it - gave her a bit of a light heading moment... but she did it and then relished in *no fear*! It's just a wonderful moment in life to walk on a glass floor so high up and view the Thames River and the Tower of London and all the beauty you can see from your perch atop Tower Bridge! We were so glad we went there. Just not your ordinary day or experience. Special moment in life to walk on glass at Tower Bridge Exhibition! Buy a London Pass & travel card as it saves time waiting in line for tickets and saves a lot on the price of the tube!

Interesting, but with a cringeworthy film thrown in.. Overpriced and with a truly embarrassing film that wobbles on the screen as part of the tour, this is not a shining example of how to add value to a national landmark. In fact the displays and staging are generally poor and make me embarrassed to be British considering the price charged. However the bridge itself is impressive and interesting and due to it being a London icon the 'tour' is a must. Just grit your teeth as you hand over your hard earned money and ignore all the flimflam.

Worth a visit. Went here on a sunday as something to do as although we have walked over it lots of times ive never been inside. It was very reasonable at £9 or £10.50 for a combined ticket for monument too. The lift going to the top took longer than i thought and it was cool to walk across the walkways. The glass floor section was really good and it felt really strange and scary to stand on but it was just a small section of the walk way so a lot of people tended to spend ages on it taking loads of different photos which could be a bit annoying if you want to have a turn too! The exhibition was not too busy which was great and you are free to explore at your own leisure. I found it very interesting especially the engine room! We all enjoyed it and glad we went.

Fascinating. A great variety of short videos, pictures, displays, history as well as practical--how the bridge was built and why, and how the bridge is raised for ships (about 1,000 times a year). It is self-paced and easy to move about.A highlight is the clear 'glass' skylight on the upper level looking down at the Thames [especially when boats pass underneath], bridge traffic and pedestrians.

See it in the day and at night!. In my opinion, the most impressive bridge in London (so many people think this is London Bridge though!) Definitely worth a walk across when in London, and it is perfectly located to get to other sights such as Tower of London and the South Bank.

Tower Bridge Exhibition and glass walkway. Thought the whole experience was well worth it, booked on-line, saves money, soon through the queue and up to the top by lift, information really good, at the first and the tower across the other side, walked along one side (solid floor) then down the other side over the glass floor, great experience seeing thre traffic and boats below.Then down the other tower and a short walk to the Engine room, really interesting....well worth the visit

Good couple of hours. London attractions can cost a fortune and you soon notice much you're spending. So I approaching the Tower Bridge experience with a apprehension of being fleeced again..... but refreshingly it wasn't too bad. £9 per adult or £18 for 2 adults and 1 child. We went as a couple and found it really interesting, there were two fairly concise videos about the design and construction followed by the walks down over the bridge. The walks treated you to excellent views and the mind bending glass floor which forced a slight hesitation when standing on it followed by some jumps for re-assurance. it really did give you a kick. We were on the tour for just under 2 hours but had to leave for the train, I think there was another hours worth of milling around the engine room if we had time.After you descend you walk to the engine room which really is amazing to see. Victorian engineering at it's finest.Well worth a visit and good value for money.

Great views. We took the London Bridge tour and loved it. I was kind of hesitant about taking the tour but am so glad we did. We enjoyed stunning views from the high level walkways to the Victorian Engine Rooms where we learned about the inner workings of the most famous bridge in the world. Very interesting! Great photo opportunities from the outside as well as on the top walkway.

Plenty of History. A different tour, as you guide yourself. Plenty of history to understand, how the bridge was built, how it works, how the engines worked, etc. You can zip through or take your time, its up to you. Mostly indoor save a walk to the engine room. You can buy a ticket for this and the monument to the fire of London, so if its a fine day, worth doing both. With the monument, simply no access for anyone who cannot walk up 311 steps and then the same back down.
T. It's a wonderful tourist attraction any time of the year always very busy I love to take loads of photos and I did , loved it

Must be seen. Even if you do not enter it to see the Victorian engines who used to lift the bridge, it is quite an attraction on the outside. Walking on it, beautiful views can be seen, and the whole experience is fantastic.

Really good. It's one of my favourite landmarks in London so worth a trip, to think they engineered a bridge so huge to lift up and down back then is amazing. Part front the science the views are great, cpl of little talks given, loads of quite interesting facts about other famous bridges and then my favourite part the glass bridge, my hubby made me lie down to have my pic took it makes your legs go a bit shaky but it's pretty amazing up there

To-do at London. Great experience for low money. Nice exihition with films, images and a great view. Use the TB App and see how the bridge will open under your feet. It is an attraction for the whole family.

Great views. My partner & I took the tower bridge walkway experience on a recent visit to London. We really enjoyed walking across the glass floor and took lots of pictures of the views.I now see how fantastic it would be to actually be standing on the glass floor when the bridge opens. We thought the £9 entry fee was reasonable. However I don't understand why they don't have both walkways uncovered.

Iconic. This one of those places that Londoners and other Brits think they know. Until you visit..... And learn so much you didn't even know you didn't know.Its a fantastic photos op and feels a but special at opening time.Go, you will not be disappointed.

What make it ticks!. We opted to see this as we had 2 for 1 discounted by booking via the train. Tickets are £9 per person, I must admit, I'd be happy to pay £9. It was great to learn how the bridge worked. Amazing views for some GREAT photo's of London skyline. I would say if you have a spare hour - GO! Especially on a clear, crisp day :)

Walk the bridge!. It was a great experience walking across the bridge. We didn't take any formal tours. We just enjoyed the experience. You think about all the history and you feel you are back in another century.

Great value and great view's. Walked across Tower Bridge many times but the tour up the towers and the amazing views are worth the £9 (we had 2 for 1 with train tickets so only £4.50 each) entry fee.The new glass walkway is agreat view straight down of the river/bridge but not for the fainthearted. Lots of history and the engine room is a must.
Okay... It didn't make me go WOW.. it was a nice experience.. nice huge bridge..The glass walk was kinda cool..

Couldn't brave the glass walkway. Good value for money - staff were helpful and plenty of time to linger and look at the sights. The Glass walkway is popular ( if not terrifying if you don't have a head for heights) - overall I am glad I made the effort to visit this attraction.

Brilliant and a bit scary!!!. We loved this the glass walk way is amazing! If not a little scary. It took me a while to walk over it .... It just felt wrong. It was fun watching other peoples reactions which varied from lying down across it to grabbing on to the hand rail like their life depended on it ... we were somewhere in between. The history of the bridge was also really interesting. It's all done very well and at £8 if booked online was completely worth it!

Good value for money. Given the high profile of this iconic London landmark, the entry price is very reasonable. There is lots to see, and lots to read if you have the time. Of course the view is stunning, and a very nice touch are the little "port-holes" in the windows through which you can poke your camera to get photos, thus avoiding shooting through the glass/perspex. One a cold windly day, you get a nasty blast of cold air when you do this, but in order to get the best photos, you have to suffer a bit.Not only do you get to walk across the famous walkway, now with a few glass panels giving a view to the river and road below, but the ticket also includes a visit to the old engine rooms, now defunct but beautifully preserved showing how it was back in the days of steam.For around £25 there is a more comprehensive guided tour which also takes you down to the huge chambers which accommodate the counter-weights of the cantilever bridges. But for most visitors the basic £10 tour is very good value for money.

the best bridge for me. we went there at night. We visited one of the restaurants near tower bridge across the Thames. we walked all the bridge and before we looked from afar to it. it is amazing. when you are standing on it you are breathless by its magic. there is a museum inside it. we could not manage to enter but i think it will be interesting.

Well Done Experience. A tip on a busy day is to buy tickets inside the gift shop and visit the pump rooms first and then you'll already have tix and should be able to skip the queue by the tower lift/elevator.The pump/steam/engine rooms are very well curated and really interesting (explanations written in many languages). A real effort has been made to make the "Experience" interesting, from the welcoming film to the Bridges of the World display along the walkways.One disappointment is that the glass walkway is already scuffed up, and it's much shorter/smaller than I expected.Usually I am averse to attractions that involve paying a fee to see a view from up high, but at 9 pounds 50 p this is a relative bargain (39.90 to go to the top of the Shard?!) The walk along Thameside is always enjoyable. Easy to combine this with a tour of the Tower of London.

Great attraction and value for money. Very interesting, liked the glass floor and animated story at beginning of tour. I don't think anything else could be added to make it more interesting to be honest, there wasn't a major amount to see but all in all worth a visit.

Good value, especially if you book with City Cruises. If you book online it's £8 which is very good value for one of the world's most famous sights. One of the main attractions is the glass floor which you will either find terrifying or mesmerising. When we visited only one of the two floors was visible, the other had carpet over it. You will probably spend between 1 and 2 hours here if you are interested in learning about the bridge itself. If you just want to se the views or are in a ruch you can do it in an hour, once you are inside. I booked tickets through City Cruises who are currently offering entry plus a 24 hour river roamer ticket for only £10 in total. That is unbelievable value. TIP 1 - be expected to queue even if you have booked tickets in advance. We had to wait for around 45 minutes. of course it will be busier at the weekend TIP 2 - Make sure you find out when sunset is before you go. I would advise going an hour before so you can see the view of city transform.
Nice walk.. We walked from the tower across the bridge. Nice view. At the opposite end of the bridge there is a nice cosy restaurant/pub underneath the bridge where I had dinner.

The bridge of bridges. Great views are commonplace, but there is an amazing exhibition of bridges of the world on the top and it's so in place! Besides, it's a stone's throw away from the Tower and one can do two in one))

Falling down, falling down, London bridge is falling down. Never ever thought that one day I would be actually seeing this wonderful bridge and even move through that in a coach. It was really crazy viewing this in the now extinct view master and anyways it took my thoughts back to almost 50 years.

Pay the Money!. You definitely have to pay the money to go to the top of the Tower Bridge. It is such a gorgeous view, and as silly as it seems, is really special. I felt like I was part of London when I was touring. There is a great video to watch on the history of the bridge - watch it, it's informative. I think it's also great to go to the room to see where everything functions. Seems silly, but the only souvenir I got at the Bridge was a pressed penny - small, but a perfect memento.

Fabulous experience. Decided to do the steps and not the lift... hard work but fun. Great views, lots of interesting facts nicely presented. Glass floor section is a must. Don't miss going to the Engine Rooms.
tower bridge. sightseeing in london must do tower bridge as well as london bridge was good day weather was cold but dry

Really well thought-out display. Except I managed to begin with the bit that I should have seen last as they're in two separate spots. It didn't matter though, I just thought, at first, that the entry fee was a bit steep for what I'd seen - beautiful though the mechanisms are. The starting point is on the bridge. Staff are on the ball if you've pre-booked (I recommend that you do) or if you have a pushchair or wheelchair and they guide you very promptly - with that all important smile - to the front of a very long queue. You will be told the drill in the lift, so pay attention. Then you wander at your own pace with really good, clear information and attendants on hand, should you need them. Bridge fans (not the card game) will love the information about other famous bridges as well as the Tower Bridge and there are great opportunities for some spectacular photography of the London skyline. There's even an app. What doesn't have an app? The glass floor is 'fun' (as we English like to say, apparently) and there is good information and various points of interest on the way down to make your way to the bit I'd already done. After all of the experience I considered it very good value, especially having bought a combined ticket for the Monument, the ascent of which might be termed London's other Marathon.

Excellent View. What a lovely place to see all the major attractions of London in one place especially all the new high rise buildings in recent times (The Shard etc..). The exhibition of the tower is great it's uniqueness of building and history is very good. Its main attraction for me this time is that it just opened a GLASS FLOOR so you can see through from the top of the bridge to the cars and visitors below. Its amazing!!!! Would not miss it as there are many special offers available now to visit London attractions on - 2 for 1 if travel by rail. Two adult admission for the price of one excellent value for money and best of all no long queues.

WELL WORTH THE MONEY. £9.00 THATS ALL If your into visiting one of Londons most iconic symbols then this is a must & its a steal for £9.00. You get a guide for half the tour, You get 2 film shows that each are very informative & dont last too long that your so bored that you've forgotten everything half way thro'. You get to go up the tower & across the bridge looking down thro' glass panels at the crossing traffic & the boats passing under the bridge. You then get to visit the mechanics of the tower & then the shop. I must admit we were very pleasantly surprised at how quickly 2 hrs went by including the waiting on the bridge to buy the tickets. It can be a little claustraphobic in side so wont be for everyone & i suppose that was'nt a worry back in the late 1880's?1890's when it was built.
pretty. It was very pretty and cool to see. Though not very big, and not worth a separate excursion. Good to see though

Hard to rate: it was a bridge, with a view, but it was London Bridge!. We took the kids here on 21st December. We live in the provinces so I'd foolishly thought that all Londoners and tourists would be at home wrapping presents or something. Wrong: most of them seemed to be at London Bridge. Still, we didn't have to queue for too long, it was easy to find and near to a transport stop, but a bit far for anyone whose walking is challenged. I went up the lift due to the latter, and the kids and husband went up the steps. You go up the lift, along the bridge and down the other side, out, along, to the engine rooms and out again and that's it; it took us about an hour in total. It was interesting and the best bit - of course - was the glass floor. The children loved it, I hated it! Only one (heavingly busy) side had a glass floor. The other (empty) side just had a long black carpet. Why? the kids wondered. We looked under the edge of the carpet and there, sure enough, was the Thames. I asked the staff why it was covered up and was told that there weren't enough staff to open the floor. Hmmm. I told my friends when we got back and they said that someone had dropped a beer bottle on the glass and cracked it, so they weren't letting people see the crack. The experience was interesting but asI have no interest in engines, don't like heights and don't like crowds, it wasn't the time of my life. My engineer daredevil husband loved it and so did the kids. I don't know what it cost or if it was 'worth it' as it was included with a boat trip. Having seen it I wouldn't go again but I'd say go and see it at least once in your life.
Glass floor had great views. Very interesting great that the public can view the city from and different angle and bring in tourists

good. went up the bridge with my son, very cool view from up there, also there is a piece of glass floor in the middle of the bridge where you can see the road belowl. the engine were a good visit the bridge is an amazing feat of engineering the british at there best well worth a visit.
no need to pay. I would not recommand the visit. I believe the bridge itself is enough to be plenty satisfied, especially on a sunny day.

lovely views. was lovely to have a look round the tower and go down to the engines at the bottom. lovely views, and good fun looking at the people underneath you on the glass floor! well my daughter thought so, me not so much cos im a chicken!!

Lovely experience. The Tower Bridge is one of the most beautiful and well-known bridges in the world, and it is really amazing that they let people inside to learn its history and discover its "core". For those who are fond of learning new things, there are good videos and stands with lots of information about history of London and other bridges in the world + the engine rooms are worth a visit. Those, who love spectacular views, will find spots for photo shooting, especially at dusk, when skyscrapers turn on lights. Tips - there are small windows which can be opened, so that the reflection of the glass doesn't spoil the picture. And those who want to tickle their nerves, could step on the glass floor and see small people, cars and red double-deckers pass by under your feet :)

Glass floor. We were a little bit disappointed as I though the glass floor was the whole walkway but in fact is only a couple of windows in the middle of the walkways and one was shut when we come. That said you still had good views on the bridge below and boats coming through, and it was an enjoyable experience.It has little windows along the bridge that you can take photo's through which is a great idea!Would recommend for the novelty

Its a place you would like to visit atleast thrice.. One in sun and one in moonlight... abd one when it opens for a ship. This is a place to be.. You cannot , I repeat you cannot just describe this view... And there are more than 5 to 6 different spots which I can name , from where you need to enjoy the view.. Just mesmerizing !!!

Excellent tour and Prices. I admit before visiting I wasn't expecting much due to the price of the tickets, think it was £8 each when booking in advance off internet. How wrong I was! From the moment you walked into the lift to go up to the tower/footbridge you were being given information, upon leaving the lift you were shown a video about how/why the bridge was made/built. After this you are shown to the footbridge, the views are amazing, then when you get to the glass floor, WOW! A lot of people are huddled around the outside of the glass and a few are walking over the glass! You are given loads of time to take pictures on the glass etc. at the other end there is another video or you can just walk to the other bridge to take pics on the other side of the river (there was another glass floor on this side but it was covered over). After you've had enough time up at the top you can descend the stairs and head to the engine rooms to see how they used to work the bridge, some components still work now simply to show you real life. For the money when compared to other similar tours it was brilliant cannot fault it.

Great view from the glass floor :). The bridge is very nice, very cool view from up there, also there is a piece of glass floor in the middle of the bridge where you can see the road below. It is very nice to take pictures from up there above the Thames River. Also, as you are there, it could be a good idea to make a river cruise, it is fun. On the tower bridge, the engine rooms are very interesting to see, and they have a very nice gift shop.

Great view from the glass floor :). The bridge is very nice, very cool view from up there, also there is a piece of glass floor in the middle of the bridge where you can see the road below. It is very nice to take pictures from up there above the Thames River. Also, as you are there, it could be a good idea to make a river cruise, it is fun. On the tower bridge, the engine rooms are very interesting to see, and they have a very nice gift shop.

Glass floor is amazing! . I've always loved Tower Bridge. My favourite London sight. But after living in London for 18 years this time I've been inside it and seen the Exhibition. We got a combined ticket with The Monument To The Great Fire Of London. (£30.50 for 2 adults and two children - bargain! ) The views from the bridge were stunning and the videos and engine room as informative as I'd expected and wanted. The new addition of the glass floor is FAB. Very weird trusting it and walking over the road and river below but once you get used to it, it's brilliant. We have had a fun, family day out. Our children were given a 'passport' at the entrance and collected stickers on the way round which they enjoyed too. Highly recommend a visit.

Loved it. Loved tower bridge, walked right along the river to tower bridge from the embankment (long walk) and it was well worth it, really enjoyed it. I think this was my favourite area. The bridge was changing colour that night it was red blue and white, much better to see at night time, all lit up. We didn't go across the bridge or to the exhibition but the view of it lit up are stunning, even in the rain.
must visit. It's a great experience to walk on the glass walk overlooking the bridge and learn about the history. The engine room is another highlight of the exhibit.

My favourite place in the world!. I just had to write a short review on my all time favourite place in the whole world.. Tower Bridge will always hold a place in my heart and is hugely special to me. I visit Tower Bridge almost every time I go to London and I'm always in awe of it's stature and beauty. I visited the Tower Bridge Exhibition a couple of years ago and thoroughly enjoyed it - what a pleasure to be able to say that our country is home to this beautiful bridge!
Tower Bridge. Walked across this bridge. The bridge is beautiful, especially at night!! Don't miss photographing this when you visit London!!

A worthwhile visit. I've been to London dozens of times, but this was my first visit to The Tower Bridge Exhibit (with the new see-through walkway). We had a very long wait, but it was well-managed. You're first taken to an area to watch an introductory video; I liked it and found it informative, but many of the others left (I'm guessing language issues). Then you walk across the bridge. The views are amazing and the walls in the middle had some very interesting photos and facts about bridges around the world. I really liked that! And then there's the plexiglass area. I had been expecting a huge, long walkway, but it's really just three smallish sections, and you do have to wait to get your turn to stand. It's a bit disconcerting (the view) and I saw many people freeze. Definitely a good place to take kids.There was a second part of the tour, to the mechanical rooms I think, but we didn't have time to see it. We did make time for the gift shop, and it was a good one.[Note: insanely long line for the WC]

The most stunning bridge. The Tower Bridge is a marvel, it's so stunning! I have been there before, but this last time I also had the chance to walk on the higher parts of the bridge and enjoy the scenerie from up there... toally recommended!
Great Views. We had a London Pass and entry was included. The views were great and it was very interesting learning about the history. The steam engine was fantastic and very well presented.
Excellent!. I thought the £9 ticket was well worth it. Beautiful views of London and the glass floor was amazing! I recommend it.

Good value in London. My 12 year old grandson and I visited this exhibition over the Christmas/New Year holiday. I thought it provided wonderful views of London, gave a real insight into the bridge and its mechanisms, history etc - with good short videos and an most interesting exhibition of famous bridges across the world. Well organised, modest entry fee = good value - and grandson loved the glass walkways!

Stunning views. We very much enjoyed our visit to the Tower Bridge. The reception was friendly and the brief lectures were informative, but nothing prepares you for the stunning views from the newly glazed walkway. We could have spent all morning there. The exhibition along the walkway of internationally important bridges was very good. The mini film about the designers of the bridge was a little stilted. The engine room had some beautiful machinery (and some subtle introduction to the physics involved). A good shop, too.

So worth the visit. I've lived in London for 3 years and never went up in Tower Bridge. And I must admit I'm glad I waited as the new glass floor made it so awesome! The views are spectacular. I really enjoyed the information on the walls about various bridges around the world. The chance to visit the pump museum was definitely worth the time as well.They have done a wonderful job making this exhibit informative and fun. I highly recommend visiting Tower Bridge.
A Great Site. A superb, aesthetically pleasing piece of engineering. It was an experience just walking across from the Tower side and relaxing in a nearby pub enjoying a beer. Worth visiting

Great views and bridge facts!. The ticket included a few videos explaining the history of the bridge and how the bridge lifting mechanism works. You are also able to walk from tower to tower, experiencing great views of London, a section of transparent floor and some beautiful pictures and information about famous bridges around the world. 10/10 would recommend, one of our favourite experiences in London at half the price of everything else.

Fantastic history. The Tower Bridge is a beautiful, old bridge filled with loads of history! Also located close to The Shard, Tower of London and the Government buildings and is a nice area to walk around in during the day

Magnificent, must see.. Being British, we had never done the tourist thing, but went with friends to show them. We were awed by the magnificence and engineering masterpiece, and the elegance of the whole structure. Everyone should go see it, and go round the exhibition.

Great Views, Unique London Experience, worth braving the heights. This was my 4th visit to London and surprisingly, I had never set foot on the tower bridge! Simply walking across the bridge was incredible in and of itself. It was just such an iconic experience. And the views of The Tower of London, the Gherkin, St.Paul's, & the Shard were stunning. But what was more impressive, was the Tower Bridge Exhibition, which recently opened. Now, I'm afraid of heights, but I am glad I overcame them in this case to walk across the glass walkway at the top to see the Tower from a most unique perspective with the road and the Thames below. The walkway is strong enough to hold at least 6 elephants, so that was somewhat comforting to know. Not only did I walk across the glass, but I (and others) sat on it and laid on it. I mean, when in Rome...er uh...London...right? That's a story for the grandkids some day! They have awesome little window flaps as well along the sides that you can slide open for unrestricted camera shops of the amazing city scape split by the River. You'll be SO glad you did this. Also, we were there about 3:30 and the sun just began to set. I'd recommend trying to be there around that time or around 4ish in January at least.

Really interesting & great views!. The visit starts on the south bank of the Thames where you visit the engine room and see the beautiful Victorian boilers and engines that lifted the bridge before it went electric.The workmanship of the engines is fabulous - lots of polished and shiny brass! The gift shop is here also and is well worth a visit, they have some lovely items to suit all pockets.For the next stage you have to walk about two thirds of the way over the bridge and then you are ushered into a door at the base of the furthest pillar. You then go up in a lift - yay! - to the top of the bridge where there is video to watch about the construction of the bridge. Quite interesting and entertaining. And then you are free to walk across the top span of the bridge where there is an exhibition of bridges around the world. The exhibition is really interesting and the views from the top of the bridge are amazing. It is all sealed and safe, just like walking down a corridor in an office - only the views are better. Unfortunately the glass panel thingy you can stand on hadn't opened when we visited but I wouldn't hesitate to go back!
LOVED...Skated at Tower of London. Was so much fun after the actual Tower tour shared some spirits and kids skated at the Tower. Amazing experience and just a lovely time!

Beautiful and Unbelievable. This was a sight to see! You can tour it but we did not. We were touring the London Tower and it got too late. I just loved looking at it and reading from our tour book about it. It is very interesting.

Great history. Loved the bridge!
Especially the new glass walk away above traffic.
Loved the history and the views.
Right across from the tower of London
Most beautiful place at London. The best spot in London to take pictures. Better at night. Worth visiting the interior (about 10 pounds) and seeing the history of the construction.
Beautiful sight of London from here. Lovely place to take a photos of the London view and also the castle. But it was very busy. The bridge itself is beautiful and ornate.

Surprisingly great. Visited Tower Bridge, only because we had left it a bit too late to do the Tower of London, but what a fantastic surprise.it is an amazing attraction and finding out about this incredible engineering feat left us in awe. Wonderful to actually get inside the bridge and walk along the top with fantastic views was amazing. Really enjoyed seeing the actual machinery from Victorian days & the whole experience surpassed our expectations. Loved it.

An iconic bridge!. As a family with limited time in London, the tour of the "Tower Bridge" was worthwhile. You get a chance to take in the view up and down the Thames , look down at the cars below through the glass floor as well as see displays on how it was built and how it works. As it opens approximately 3 times a day I would time your visit to see the bridge in action. A great thing to do that won't break the bank.

Worth a walk across. No trip to London would be complete without a walk across this iconic bridge. It's a very easy walk from the Tower of London. Then you can walk along the south bank and take in all the sites.

Iconic. Very pretty bridge. Take the boat from westminster to Greenwich, its about £12 and it's great fun during summer time. The boat drivers usually give u a talk and it drives underneath the bridge which is pretty awesome. You can also take the bus across the bridge.
A very beautiful bridge. This place is very beautiful, always filled with tourists and traffic.Crossing this bridge transports you to another era.
New year celebration on Tower Bridge. Welcoming the New year on Tower Bridge with thousands of people was awesome. If you are there on NYE, you must do it. It was fun & really nice experience.

Tower Bridge and Towern.. There are some "must-see-places" in London. These are two of them. So much history, but even if you're not interested in history, you can still enjoy these places. A walk on the bridge, both in daylight and and at sunset, can give you really nice pics.A visit inside the walls of Towern will give you some of the history of London and Great Britain.Maybe a pic with one of the Beefeaters?

Fantastic London icon - book the full tour (behind the scenes) if possible!. My husband bought me tickets to the Tower Bridge exhibition for my birthday, as I'm always taking photos of it when we walk past. It is so stunning on the London skyline so he thought I might want to find out more.He purchased an additional tour, for which you have to book in advance. As far as I know, you can buy tickets to the Engine Rooms and the Walkways on the day, both of which are around £10 I think - but don't quote me on that. Our tickets (£50 pp) included a guided tour of both of these sections, but also of the working engine rooms below sea level. They only run a small number of these tours every year, only in the winter when the river is less busy.Our guide was very interesting, enthusiastic, funny, and incredibly knowledgeable. Our group was roughly 8 people, with my self any my husband being by far the youngest, and perhaps the only ones who weren't engineers or super bridge geeks. Anyways, we went up to the walkways, and the glass floor is dizzying but interesting. We then followed the usual tourist route back down the other tower.The best bit of the tour started now, as we went off the usual tourist trail and down into the working engine rooms, which also house one of the old original steam engines. Most of the science stuff was lost on me but what I did understand was still fascinating. Then, down further we went, eventually finding ourselves in the chamber where the actual bridge moves to when it's opened. Wow. If you can get on one of these tours, really do, as it's an outstanding pit of work.We then went back up (not suitable for people with walking disabilities unfortunately - it's all on steep stairs in original, and working, Victorian chambers) and along to the rest of the tour, including the Engine Rooms, where our guide gave us additional bits on info that weren't necessarily on the info boards.Highly recommended!

You can leave London without having visited the Tower Bridge, but walking over the glass floor is fun.. Have been to London several times, did the Tower Bridge this time. We enjoyed visiting it, but will not go again. we can now say that we've been there, done it.Must say the glass floor makes this attraction; it really gives you a strange feeling when you see the traffic passing beneath you.

must see crown jewels. The bridge is big and amazing but best part is the crown jewels. There is always long line to get to see them but it's worth the wait. It's a big collection and it's quite amazing.

My second visit so speaks for itself. Came back for a second visit and o see the new glass floors which is amazing. The service and staff again was lovely and the self guided tour is very good. I really enjoy the new glass floor.

Photo opportunities.. Walk across it, take a river ferry under it, see it lit up at night, hope to be lucky enough to see it open and do go inside. You can stand on the glass floor, get a great view of London (140 feet up), watch presentations on its beginnings and how it operates. You can even go down to see the beautifully presented steam pumps in the engine room. There is also a shop on exit (south bank).It was much more interesting than I thought.

Great half day trip. This is a great half day trip! Me and a group of friends came here to see see the poppys all around the tower and it was amazing. We also took the tour inside and saw the weapons and armor exhibits as well as the crown jewels. Crown Jewels were pretty cool to see however to eliminate traffic you are put on a moving walkway so you get some time to view them but not a lot. The bridge itself was also a good walk and good place to take pictures and see down the river. I would recommend this as a half day for anyone in a group or alone. I dont think kids would like the tower tour too much.

So interesting, does not take too long so easy to combine.. We did the Tour and the Engine Room, I don't know a hammer from a screw driver, but even I was enthralled, the view from the Bridge is incredible, and the newish glass walkway spectacular and a little scary, watching the boats and River rushing underneath you! Not expensive and not time consuming.

Must see!. The Tower Bridge is another of those famous London landmarks that everyone has seen in movies and on TV their whole lives. We took the tour and it was well worth the admission fee. Be prepared for lots of walking and bring your patience because the lines can be long, but it is worth the minor inconvenience. We walked up the many stairs to avoid the long line for the elevators, and this probably saved us at least 30 minutes - and also provided us with our daily exercise requirement! There is a glass floor that allows you to look straight down, which is very impressive. We were also there when the bridge opened to allow a tall boat to pass underneath. This was a great added bonus to see the bridge in operation. After taking lots of photos during the day of our visit we returned at night for more photos when the bridge was illuminated.

Tower Bridge - Must visit attraction in London. Tower Bridge is one of the must visit attractions in London. You can either take a tube or a Hop on-Hop Off bus or a Cruise to reach Tower Bridge.We took the Hop on/off bus till London Eye and then took the Cruise to reach Tower Bridge. The bridge makes a beautiful sight from a distance. Once you reach the bridge, there are many things you can do, The bridge is special because it opens when there are big ships that needs crossing. So walking on the bridge and locating the part of the bridge that 'splits' is a good exercise in itself. Overall worth a visit though it is a bit away from the other famous attractions like palace, Big Ben, London Eye etc.

Very historical. We always enjoy going to the tower bridge to take the tour.
It was very educational and there is a part that has glass floors! There are short films that give a history about the bridge that many will enjoy.
Great view. You should really don't miss that. It's better if you visit it by night the view is great and it's very romantic. It'is also near the highest building of London

Iconic landmark.. Often mistaken for the London Bridge, this Tower Bridge is so beautiful. Towering over the Thames, its majestic and grand and an engineering marvel. Up close you can see all the rivets and steel, but from a distance its so elegant.We walked this in the rain, which was great - less tourists! As we were there near Christmas, the attractions were closed (the glass floor, etc, but maybe we'll try that out next time).
Must see in London. Tower bridge was very nice to see in night as well as in day. Try and get a look from cruise it will be fascinating.

Pleasant surprise. Given complimentary tickets for Tower Bridge, and to be honest we would more than likely not have visited the attraction as it was not on our list of things to do or see in London.But we were in for a pleasant surprise as the tour was very informative with a short film at the beginning giving the background to why it was built, from there on in you can take as long as you like to admire the views from the walk ways high up between the towers.Great photo opportunity with a glass walkways offering a unique feature to the attraction, the tour carries on below the tower in the engine house, all in all was better than we anticipated even though our visit was free, the £9 entrance fee is reasonable for the experience.
Fun tour. Great view of the city along with a nicely put together history lesson. Short and sweet. Nice morning trip.
Impressed. No doubt that is my fovurite atraction in London. Great view at night when all the lights are one. Must see.

great experience. I visited Tower Bridge Exhibition in London this year. Glass floor is great experience. You are 42 meter high from the bridge and can see the all people and cars passing under your feet. it also thrilling experience. you can see very good panoramic view of London. you pay 9 pound for it.

Glass Walkway was fun!!. Fortunately I bought discount tickets on Discount London (or you can get 2 for 1 with your train tickets) as I don't really think it was worth full price.The glass walkway is a 15 metre section in the middle of one of the walkways and it was great fun to look down and take photos. The rest of the tour was interesting but didn't hold my 9 year olds attention for long. I think if you allow 1- 2 hours for the visit including queuing then that would be plenty.All the staff were really, really polite and helpful and were genuine in taking care of the visitors - that definitely deserves a special mention!Don't worry about buying your tickets in advance to save time as it's all one queue, tickets or not. Also walk to the top - saves waiting ages for the lift and is actually fun.

Symbolic. We got here when it opened to avoid the queues which can be extensive, it can be very windy while you are waiting....The experience takes you up in a lift and provides you with a short video on the bridge's origins, you then go through a walkway which includes the glass looking down over the street below. It is only a small section of the walkway but once you stand on it you see why. It can be a little disorienting. I would highly recommend finding out the bridge opening times so that you can be standing on the glass walkway when this happensThere is then a walk down to the next level and onto the engine rooms. If you are interested in engineering this is the place for you, a fascinating look at how the bridge actually worked This is probably one of the cheapest attractions in London at £9.
