I used Discount London and would high recommend if going to multiple attractions

Exciting to look from aside, not worth of 9 pounds. It is a true symbol of London but is not worth of spending money for inside tour. You will be lifted inside one of the towers of the bridge where they show you 2 3 minutes movies and you will have a chance to walk along the galleries between two towers. That is it. The only interesting moment is Bridge engine that moved the part of the bridge in the past

Great views . We attended tower bridge in early January. We had to queue for about 20minutes and it was quite breezey on the bridge. We paid about £10 and got a joint ticket for the bridge and monument. The bridge had a glass bottom and fantastic views of the road below and the London skyline. Highly recommend and think this is a good value attraction

Tower Bridge. We were lucky enough to be visiting the Tower Bridge when we had to scamper across the Bridge to allow the bridge to be lifted so a Tug Boat could pass underneath. We understand that this only happens about 900 times a year.

On High !!!!!!!!!. This is a must see whilst in London, obviously the iconic Tower Bridge is a tourist attraction in itself but the new glass walkway is just the business ......... although I wish it had been a longer stretch of glass walkway because the views and the photos ops are just amazing !Quite inexpensive for whats included in the ticket price - screening of the history of the bridge, the walkways themselves and also a tour of the engine rooms which is down the street from the bridge itself but well worth a visit ... a must see !!

One time only visit. This is the kind of place that you visit once in your lifetime. Whilst the views are amazing, that is all that can be said about this attraction. Fairly good value for money and the introduction was fun and engaging. I can't see myself going back again but still had a good time.

Fabulous Attraction. This bridge is spectacular in the day but even more impressive by night. There are a lot of bars/restaurants around this area so I'd highly recommend grabbing a drink/coffee and just having a minute to full appreciate the beauty of this well known and well loved sight!

Great glass floor!. Standing on the glass floor in the Tower Bridge is certainly an interesting experience. This was a unique way to "see" Londoners going about their daily business. The story of the bridge and her builders are along the walkway, adding to the experience. Highly recommended.

Great walk. Walked on the tower at night, despite it being cold I enjoyed it. We didn't go inside the tower. You can get a lovely view of the bridge on the path along the Thames towards the Mayors Office. There were also nice restaurants and lit up decorations including a small floor water fountain near there.

Nervously good!. We went here this week and not one to be a fan of heights I was determined. Great views, very cheap admission price and a stomach cherner over the glass walk. Conquered the fear- although sheet white. Would do it again!!

AWESOME!. We were fortunate enough to cross over the bridge just before a large vessel prompted the bridge to stop traffic and allow the vessel to cross under/pass it. This bridge had such beautiful detail adorning it that it's such an awesome sight to take in. Due to the immense size of the bridge, it's quite impressive to see it fully function when large boats and vessels have to pass through it. Traffic halts and pedestrians wait.. but not for as long as you'd think. Definitely worth a vist and walk over. Makes for great photo opportunities, especially for those that a love a selfie!

iconic wonderfull history like it. first of all the price is fair and fine. the view is wonderfull. the infrmattion is ood abut the bridgs in the world and about the history if the bridge. I didntlike the movies and the engine room....
but it was nice aatraction

A must see when in London. I had read about the new "Glass Floor" and was intrigued. I had been here once before but that was a long time ago.We had booked tickets online and saved a pound a piece. The ticked office was busy when we got there at about 3pm, after about a ten minute wait we got our tickets and decided as a group (there were 6 of us) to walk up to the cross walk, rather than wait for an take the lift. The cross walk is 42 meters (138ft) above the river, so the climb is not that bad.At the top of the stairs there is a short film about the history of the bridge, worth the time to stop and watch.Then from there you can walk over the river and back. the Glass floor section is on the Western walk way only.We were fortunate in that the day was sunny and one could see for a long way. There are small panels in the glass windows that you can open to take photo's from without having the glass in the way. Along the way there are numerous panels about other bridges around the world and their claims to fame. These are really interesting and whet your appetite to go and see some of them.Needless to say the area with the glass floor was the most crowded, but if patient you can get on and experience the eerie effect of people walking a 100 ft below, or as a number of people do lay on the floor and have their photo taken, the only downside of taking a picture through the floor is that the glass has a grid of small black dots...After you exit from the South tower you must go and see the Engine room. This is a walk outside, surprisingly quite a long way from the tower. Inside you will find a magnificently maintained Victorian steam engine room definitely worth the visit.If you are a planner, check the "Bridge Lift Times" and arrange your trip around that, see in the bridge being raised from above would definitely be worth it.

Great value, great fun. We visited with 2 adults and 3 kids. Prebook your tickets online and you will save quite a bit. Cost us £22 which was great value. On arrival the ticketing/queue system is a pointless joke.Even though you have pre-booked you have to queue with everyone else to get in. But if you have the london City card you can jump the queue and get straight in.This is one of the few attractions not run by Merlin, if it was it would be a lot more efficient!So you can go in the lift or walk the stairs, we did the stairs as quite a wait fir the lift. Wow, a lot if stairs! But you can pause and look out the windows on the way up.There is a short film introduction at the top, good to get your breath back during!Then you walk over the top of the bridge. This is where the value is.Great views, and amazing, long glass floor. You feel totally safe on it and just an incredible view of the bridge in action. Kids loved it. Plenty of space for photos and taking your time moving back and forth. You can sit on it, or lay and do selfies with no pressure to move on.There are photos and details about the bridge dotted about, but not of much interest. Then you go down the stairs the other side (or take the lift). You leave the bridge and walk across the other side to the engine room exhibition beneath the bridge. I expect a lot if people don't bother with this, but it was quite good. If you can time your visit with a bridge lift that would be a great experience. You can see lift times on their website.So great value, the kids have talked about it a lot since. The real value is the glass walkway so spend your time up here! We walked round to the other side and found much less people this side so make sure to do both sides. And you can go back again, it's not one way so before you go down the stairs go back fir another look!

Glass floor view. I should have thought about it beforehand really. What else would you expect to see through the glass floor but of course a road and the Thames not very far below.The over hyping of the glass floor aside there are interesting facts to read about bridges around the world and of course to be up and inside the Bridge is something worthwhile. Maybe £ 9 is a few pounds overpriced so look out for discount vouchers.There is also the steam engines that operate the raising and lowering of the bridge if you enjoy Victorian engineering. Overall it's worth doing but not really for the view down to the road beneath.

Fab!. Visited on our recent trip to London. We got discounted tickets on the web before we went, otherwise quite expensive. We chose to climb the 300+ steps! not for the faint hearted! But you can take the lift. You are first shown a short film how the bridge came to be built and then proceed to walk down the eastern side of the bridge, back to one of the towers to be shown another short film of the building of it, then to the best bit, walk down the western side with great views and the glass floor! This is brilliant and feels a little un-nerving, not for anyone who is scared of heights. Great photo opportunities.Would recommend, but don't pay full price.
Good photo ops.... Great location for photo opportunities and well worth taking the elevator up to the top of the tower and take in the view from there as well. Went in Nov. 2010 w/my sister.
Iconic. This place is one of my favourites in London. To go up you should get 2-1 tickets when you travel by train. The view is beautiful specially if you get a sunset.

Interest and exercise. We were pleasantly surprised by how interesting and how large the exhibition was with real steam engines running. Loads of stairs, but good exercise. Is shows information about bridges around the world, so not just interesting for the english. Need a head for heights as you walk across the glass walkway. If traveling by train - look out for 2 for 1 deal.
Don't Miss it!. The tower Bridge is iconic. You must see it and walk across. In the middle of the bridge is a visitor center and stairs to get to the top, which I would recommend.
Great photo opportunities. On a crispy cold day we had great views up and down the Thames. The glass floor worked well for our 8 year old

It's lovely here. I love this area especially in the evening it's very charming. Just prepare yourself for crowds as it is very busy place!! But if you into people watching that's best spot for you. I don't mind crowds but after a while it can be annoying but definitely worth the visit. It is beautiful bridge :)

Very interesting. It was interesting to learn the history of the bridge and how it works, however not that impressive as the bridge itself. The glass bottom corridor is quite nice, even for people who are afraid of heights.

Must see. We decided to take part in the London Bridge exhibition which cost £24.30. In order to reach the exhibition there is a lift, however one of the members in our party didn't want to go in the lift so instead we climbed up numerous amounts of stairs to the exhibition. Part of the exhibition involves walking across the glass floor which is 11m long, 1.8m wide and 42m above the River Thames. It is an incredible experience which I would thoroughly recommend. They also take your photo which you can then buy. It is a great way to pass on an hour.

Wonderful engineering amazing views. Did a tour of the "Engine Rooms" ie the motive power source that lifts the two spans of the bridge. Victorian engineering at its very best. Topped off literally with a walk along the glass floored upper walkways giving views to the road and river below. Good photo opportunity - no good for those with vertigo.

Iconic. We booked a self guided tour for tower bridge it was about £12 for me and daughter. It was very busy but great views all around and of course down thru the glass floor a great opputunity for a selfie Very impressive structure My advice would be to go up by the stairs rather than the lift less queueing and more in feeling with the era it was built

a different view of the city. I saw a feature on the BBC news about the bridge and hadn't realised that you could actually walk over the bridge at high level before let alone with a glass floor in the walkway! maybe I just wasn't paying attention to the report but I definitely got the impression that the entire walkway is now glass... It isn't - it is just a 10-15 metre section on the Middle so be prepared to wait your turn to stand/lie/take strange-angled selfie's on the glass bit! There is a lift up ( interestingly an original design feature and not an addition for modern tourist needs) although if you do not have any mobility difficulties, you will have to walk a few steps down on the other side before you can get in a small lift down to ground level. Otherwise staff will bring the 'down' lift to the top floor for you. There is a lot of information about the bridge itself as well as other bridges in the world as you move around and you do get some amazing views of London that you can't get from anywhere else. The high level tour begins and ends with a video - the first of which I found to be a good demonstration of early 2000's video techniques but factually quite 'dumbed down' and not really to my taste and would be a total waste of time for non-english speakers. That said the guide book is reasonably priced and is available in Western European languages and Japanese. Overall, admission prices are not expensive and even cheaper if bought online. This won't get you far-tracked through the queue though but will help at busy times and will save a few quid. You also get to visit the engine room - interesting and never noticed it before tucked away beside the bridge in the south bank. Original engines preserved and do actually 'run' on air/electricity. Make sure you follow the line at the exit and get the full experience. Overall very glad to have done this.

Thames from a different view. Easy to find well known London attraction. Several tube stations are nearby, the closest is Tower Hill. Entry prices are reasonable. If you buy your ticket online it's even cheaper, just make sure you buy it at least 24 hours in advance. We visited on a Sunday and the queue was about 10mins from the entrance, so was ok. You can go via stairs or by lift to the top. There is a lovely exhibition about famous bridges as you walk from one tower to the other. The newly opened glass floor is a great addition. There is a gift shop at the end of the tour with a good selection of gift items.
Nice Bridge!. One of the nicest bridges I've ever seen! You can get across the bridge in many ways of course just get there early because it get crowded really quick! It is iconic site to see!
Iconic must see!. No trip to London is complete without a walk across the bridge! It is next to the Tower of London so kill two birds with one stone!

View is awesome. Went to Tower Bridge to view the glass walk way... It is awesome... Definitely worth and one of the major London attractions.. The engine/pump house isn't that all.. But visiting "The Tower Bridge" is one of must attractions in London.

Excellent exhibition. Very well presented . Displays of so many bridges around the world with information on location, designer, architect, and technical details.
The engine room is extremely interesting for people with an engineering interest. Kids loved the glass walkway. A worthwhile visit as a London attraction, and not expensive.

Well worth a visit. Personally I thought entry to the bridge and new glass walkway was reasonable. The cost is £9 per adult and £6.30 for a student (with a valid student card). There are other concessions available and it is marginally cheaper if you book online.The bridge is iconic. Absolutely stunning architecture. I have admired it for years but this is the first time I have ever visited inside. There is a lift that takes visitors to the top however we opted to use the stairs - this isn't for the faint hearted as it is around five or 6 flights of stairs but worth doing if you are fit just to get a close up look at the construction.At the top there is a short film explaining how the design came about and how the bridge was constructed. From the film area you then move to the glass walkway - this isn't quite as big as I was expecting but never the less it is great fun (providing you don't have a fear of heights) looking down on the London traffic and the Thames. The views across London are fabulous. Once you have finished on the walkway you can visit the engine rooms.There is nothing about this trip I didn't like. If you love architecture, construction and views across London then this is a brilliant place to visit at a reasonable price. I would certainly visit again
Glass walkway -wow. One in our party was very apprehensive about the glass walkway. But had no problems at all. Interesting museum exhibition. Staff very child friendly
A Must See!. A must see attraction if you ever come to London, even if its from a far distance away! It's also very beautiful at night!

The Bridge is iconic. Although there is a museum there, I onl went for the bridge itself. Great to look at from all angles. It is next to the Tower of London so take the time to walk on and about it. for free .

Excellent. Myself and 3 friends went up to the exhibition last week. We had a 2 for 1 ticket so saved a few £'s.We didn't have much time as we went at the end of the day, the video's looked very interesting and informative, we didn't stop, we walked along the first walkway then on the the other. The views are really good, totally different to any other different perspective on things. (after going up the Shard I didn't think the views would stack up but they did) We saw the most incredible sunset too, and of course the glass floor! Not for the feint hearted I tell you, It took a while to actually step on to it! Once you get used to it though it is really amazing.Definitely worth the trip up there, lots to see am=nd listen to, even in the boiler rooms.Worth a visit!

Enjoyed the visit, great views and interesting history.. A great place to visit and wasn't too busy. The views are great along the Thames and the glass floor is fun. I also enjoyed the videos, info and bridge s of the world posters. The engine room is also impressive.
Great night sight. It is worth to visit during the day but make sure you see it in the night from further. The light make it spectacular.

one of the most famous bridge. It worth to visit, you can walk about 20 min from big ben to the tower bridge and see one of the world's famous bridge!! The view of Thames river from the bridge is amazing!! Don't miss it!!

Only £22.50 for family of 5 for Walkway and Engine Room. We visited The Tower Bridge Glass Walkway on a beautiful sunny December Saturday. I cant believe there were no queues, no stairs and really friendly helpful staff. The views from both walkways are stunning, but the best bit is the new glass walkway. Its 42m above the bridge and you look down on to the people and cars below. Get the "Raise Tower Bridge" APP for iPhone/Android before you go - and with clever tech you see the bridge raising on your phone. There are free stickers to collect to keep the children amused. After the walkway - its free to visit the Engine Room, which was interesting and amazing to see how they use to raise the bridge. The steam engines are beautiful in design and colour. We really loved this attraction - the glass walkway is a must - just for the views of London.

World's most famous bridge. The Tower Bridge is one the most iconic structures in UK. It is also the most famous bridge in the world & definitely a must-see London attraction. Our family had a great time exploring this suspension bridge over the River Thames. The views from the bridge is breathtaking & beautiful. Great photo opportunities but be early to avoid the crowd as it is a very popular tourist attraction. We brought back beautiful memories of the Tower Bridge.

Looks better in the night. I've seen pictures if Tower bridge during the day and it does look spectacular but by night it looks brilliant. Night life in London is great. The river thsmes looks to romantic during the night in fact I think London looks bettet in the night thsn the day.A lot of traffic around this bridge as it must be gateway into and out of the city. Very good place to visit.
Looks beautiful!. Looks beautiful. We visited near sunset and it was beautiful.I wonder how it would have been in the night, or actually during the day.

Delightful Surprise. Three generations visited - 3 Londoners and three visitors and everyone thoroughly enjoyed their visit. The staff were delightful and facilities for children were excellent and of high quality - the passport with stickers was of a very quality. The visit was very informative and the films very good. And the glass walkway was a great draw.Altogether an excellent tourist facility at a very reasonable cost.

Height of excellence. Tower Bridge will not fail to strike a breath-taking impression on the viewers who gets a peek to the left whilst walking from aisle beside Tower of London. One can see to believe that the iconic symbol of London did not just derive its fame by word-say but by its majestic look over River Thames. We have gulped down the varied scenic photographs from possible angles and taken a stride on the bridge. There is a museum (I remember of entrance fees 4 GBP) which would offer to visit the top of bridge for having good photographic opportunities. As the weather was too windy and chilled, we were not encouraged to take up the same (with regrets).I laughed to myself regarding my ignorance of believing this as London Bridge (since childhood) and departed with that opinion after visiting London. Night view is more impressive too.

The London Bridge. it is as excellent as its name say. stand there, enjoy the River Thames view, London eye on one side and Big Ben, Parliament House on the other and the quite traffic moving on the London Bridge.

Beautiful and Stunning Bridge - A Definite Iconic Structure of UK. We visited London in March and when down visiting the Tower of London we saw this breathtaking bridge. It is a marvel to look at standing so majestically both in daylight and at night when it is lit up. It is a historic bridge to say the least and a wonderful memory for anyone who has had the pleasure of viewing it.

London 2014. Everything! Friendly informative staff, stunning views and impressive historical location. Tower Bridge is a must see for anyone who is interested in history architecture engineering and sight seeing! A thoroughly enjoyable experience for all ages and family orientated

It is NOT falling down…;). It is a bridge. So if you are seeking a trans-dimensional experience, look elsewhere. It is what you think it is, just cooler. See it at night. In December, we crossed after touring the Tower and enjoyed small international shops set up along the Thames. Ate like crazy! Bought a few handmade, high quality items. Enjoyed wonderful British hospitality and fun for all! Enjoy as always! Great vantage point for photos (again, at night).

Majestic Beauty. Just to walk across this wonderful London Bridge and look up at the most amazing structure ever, braving the elements of the windy Thames river deep and dark flowing one side toward the sea the other up towards Oxford. At night the nights dazzle as you go across, with the Tower of London at one end and Borough Market at the other. Tour boats along with working tugs hacking up and down the river, amazing London site.

"Mesmerising". It was my first trip to London and I couldn't have been more awed by the tower bridge. It was raining when we went there but the view was breathtaking. I must say that I saw it at night with all the lightings on and it looked so beautiful. I definitely want to come back here again.
Beautiful!. One of the most iconic structures in UK. Looks more beautiful at night with the lightings on. The cruise experience was wonderful too.

Historic bridge with fine views. blasted by the wind, but oh boy, what views! Behind Canary Wharf, in front the Tower of London, the gherkin, the cheese grater, the block and all the Thames waterfront laid out before us. And wonderful sunshine too!

One of the must do. The perspectives structure the top are extraordinary, there is some fair data on the history and mechanics of the scaffold. The mandatory glass floor is flawless. General worth the visit and charge. One of the must do traveler things. Was completely debilitated to mix up this one for the London span. Anyhow then its such a n structural engineering, to the point that you for get the frustration of being on the real London connect as you go towards this sublime extension. Also get the feel of grandness on the whole.
Fantastic. I didn't enter the tower. I took a lot of photo.Very beautiful. especially the light on it.But for better view, you have to keep the distance.

Great views. The day before we went up The Shard and as we had a couple of hours to kill (and a discount voucher) before our train home we thought we'd have a look and compare the two attractions, at £4.50 with our Days Out In London voucher it was probably better value for money, still brilliant views although obviously not 360degrees.I'm not great with heights and was a bit nervous about the glass floor but there is no need as you can still walk down the edge.The current exhibition with photo's of bridges around the world is very interesting.All in all well worth a visit.

London visit. Really enjoyed the tour and particularly the tour guides. They were knowledgeable but the added humour and wit made it all the more fun. Furthermore number of tours on certain routes dropped dramatically towards the end of the day with no tour guide on the blue route. The river cruise could have been longer. But a good day overall.

How amazing to see this iconic piece of history. I was very pleasantly surprised by this attraction. Very well organised, great historical facts presented very well. Top walkway is brilliant especially the glass floor. Great to watch people appear very worried about falling through! Views are amazing. We went on a very sunny day which added to the fun. Fascinating insight into the workings of possibly the most famous bridge in the World. Not bad value either. Well worth a visit, especially when combined with other very important historical buildings in this area. Great for children too.

Well definitely deserves to be the London bridge. Got a shock to see this bridge parallel to London bridge.Was totally disheartened to mistake this one for the London bridge.But then it's such a n architecture that you for get the disappointment of being on the actual London bridge as you make your way towards this wonderful bridge. And get the feel of grandness in all.

Very nice. One of the must do tourist things. The views form the top are great, there is some decent information on the history and mechanics of the bridge. The obligatory glass floor is neat. Overall worth the visit and fee.

Must do tour. So glad we went here, the tour is very informative, to go up in the lift and then walk across the bridge ( and over the glass floor) is amazing. The views across the London skyline are fabulous but also the view down through the glass floor is awesome, you not only have the movement of the river but also the traffic. Make the effort to then go to the Engine Room which houses all the machinery to lift the bridge. Really interesting with a video showing the construction of the bridge.

Nice Views of the City and River. Went here with my family by public transport. First point I should mention is that if using the Underground Railways, the route from the station to the bridge isn't very wheelchair friendly, there are a lot of steps. Best to head up onto the road and go round the Tower of London. You do need a little longer than you think to see it, as it's not a case of going up one side, crossing then down the other. You go up, walk across, back along the other side, then go back the way you've come. Part of the tour includes the engine room which is further down. Due to having to get the Tube back to our coach we didn't have time to see all of it. Nice views from the top, worth seeing

Grand piece of Architecture. A visit to London would not be complete without going to the Tower Bridge. On our recent trip to London we went under it, over it by Bus & walked across it & also managed to catch it at night with all the lights on-Fantastic.

Great View . We visited in half term with our 8 year old. We had printed off the c2c vouchers so didn't pay full price and I'm glad we didnt. There was a great view from the top but that was it, the rest was pretty boring.

Nice exhibition about bridges. Great exhibition. It starts with a video about the construction of Tower Bridge. After that, you can see interesting facts about many bridges around the world, animals that live by the Thames and facts about some London landmarks. Then you reach the glass you can walk on. It is not that exciting, but it is nice to see cars and people passing by under your feet. At the end you can visit the engine rooms and visit the gift shop.
Spectacular Views. It's not just the glass walkway but the whole experience is fantastic. It's reasonable priced and everyone should do it.

Tower Bridge Exhibition - put it on your list.. We loved our visit to the Tower Bridge Exhibition. I was surprised at how much there is to see. The visit is essentially in two parts; we visited the engine rooms first and then went on to the bridge. The engine rooms are extraordinary and beautifully presented; a photographer's delight. Signage between the two exhibits is not brilliant but we found our way to the lifts to get us up onto the bridge walkway. The internal structure itself is a really impressive sight and of course there are views up and down the river. The visit includes a short film and many displays to enhance the experience. Excellent visit!
Tower Bridge. Trip was well worth while due to the iconic nature of the bridge. We enjoyed the visit and the walk on glass was icing on the cake, we had a wonderful time, great value for money.
Iconic landmark. This icon of London and indeed Great Britain is laid bare in this fascinating tour and exhibition. The new glass walkway throws a new light on this amazing structure.

walking on glass!. As soon as I saw the glass walkway at Tower Bridge on the news I knew I needed to go for a walk on it. But i was surprised at just how much more Tower Bridge has to offer. This is one of the few London attractions which isn't over priced. When you first get out of the lift a short film is playing when that is finished you can walk across the bridge, there are great views down the Thames, but as I suspected the best part was the glass walk way. Feels quite surreal walking across the glass, the glass walk way isn't very long, I thought it would be the whole length of the bridge! You then go down the parallel walkway, no glass on that side, the pictures of bridges on the wall are the same as in the first side. And of course you are offered the chance to have your photo taken, I didn't see anyone agreeing to this. You then get the lift down to the bottom and go up the road to the engineering part. Tower Bridge in London is beautiful bridge and known world wide. I am glad that i have walked across it, but probably will never do it again.

Who Knew You Could Have Business Meetings Upstairs!. While in town on business I was lucky enough to have a meeting in the conference rooms upstairs. Some of the locals didn't even know this was possible so I considered this a treat! While the bridge lifting and lowering for boats will make noise, the facility does have a schedule so you can plan around this if necessary. The bridge itself was also lovely and the tour was interesting!

The most beautiful spot to look at by night time.. Always found this spot the most attractive spot to sit and look endlessly . Sitting in one of the restaurants on the southern bank , or parking near the design centre, and stir at this bridge without ever getting tired of it. You should once go inside and read about it.The Tower hotel has a bar you can sit and have a drink. During the day St Catherine docks is exactly there. The famous huge pub covered with flower boxes in spring and summer days is another point to visit near the bridge.

don't look down!. Fabulous attraction. The majestic bridge in itself is wonderful. To watch it raise and lower to allow boats through is amazing. Then to top it all they have a glass walkway...yes a bit scary to start with but if you can stomach it, it is fantastic. Such a birds eye view of the world. Still not sure about the carpet on one side..I did ask and was told it was to allow for even footfall..I.e. It changes sides every day...hmmm...then you can also go down to the engine rooms. A totally fascinating attraction, and it was warm up there, it's heated. Terrific views either side of London as well.

The glass walkways are good but the rest could be improved. I'm sure most people go on the Exhibition to walk over the glass walkways (I did) and they are great and it's very weird to be looking down on all the cars and people and water below. The views out from the walkways are spectacular too. But the rest of the Exhibition isnt great to be honest. The videos and the Engine Room and the exhibit about bridges around the world are just dull. It is probably hard to come up with things they could fit in the limited space but a few more interesting elements would improve this attraction no end.

Brige everyone in London have to see. On one of our many visits to London we decided to visit Tower Bridge. We only looked around and walked through the bridge but it was nice winter sunny day and it was a great experience. The bridge looks amazing and it is a piece of England history. A definitely place to visit while you are in London. I know there is an option to go up into the glass floor which cost around £8 when you book on line however as we did not know about this prior to our trip the queue on the day was a fair size so maybe this is something we will consider next time as the view from the top must be amazing.
Just as it looks in the pictures. Great walk across, busy with loads of people but that's what you expect in London. Great views on either side with the shard to the left and the gherkin to the right

Disappointing glass floor. I love this bridge, it is really beautiful and it was an engineering example in its days.The exhibition about other remarkable bridges in the the world is quite interesting but the glass floor was a total disappointment, not at all what I expected. The floor is made up of many glass panels, you can see the selas separating each panel so you never get the feeling of being "in the air". My expectations were to high I guess...

Third class exhibit at world class landmark. The new glass walkway floors are a good enough reason to visit Tower Bridge, along with the views from the top. However, the tour used to include fascinating informative exhibits and even an exciting finale in the basement Bascules Room. Now you head up in the elevator to view a shoddy video of the Bridge under construction in which pantomime actors speak so quickly that even I as a native English speaker could not understand a word. It is jokey, embarrassing and a waste of time. Then there are some hideous back-lit displays of other landmark buildings dotted around the South tower as you make your way out. This is a total disgrace to London. Avoid it until someone sorts out this mess.

Glass floor bigger, than blackpool towers. Very very interesting, videos, talks, glass floor everything you needed to know about the bridge. It was a fantastic visit for my grandson to learn, imagine and take pictures. Staff fab thanks

Tower Bridge Exhibition . Decided to visit the Tower Bridge Exhibition now that they have had the glass floor installed and was not disappointed, the view is amazing and you can see up and down the Thames from the walkways and look down onto the road and river below. Even on a Saturday morning it was not that busy that you had to queue for to long.Booking on line cost £8 for adults which also includes a visit to the towers engine rooms. Great value for money.
Beautiful Bridge. Very pretty bridge, well worth taking pictures of and on. In the past I went on the tour of the bridge and I don't think it was worthwhile.
Brilliant!. Looking at this amazing piece of architecture is incredible. I love this bridge, it's incredibly iconic and to stand on it is awesome!

Interesting. I had an amazing experience with the sightseeing of the tower bridge so yea It was a treat. It felt so unreal to me that
I would definitely come here again.

Terrific Tower Bridge. A really interesting experience. We take this bridge for granted living in London, but it is an engineering masterpiece. The glass floor is fascinating and the Engine Rooms are well worth the visit. Amazing views. You are not rushed and told all about the history of the bridge. Worth a visit.

old and new. I love Tower Bridge. It looks amazing, historical and beautiful. I was walking by "More London" to City Hall at night and view was so exciting! Just imagine high, fantastic modern buildings and this attractive bridge! Very beautiful and harmonious structure with a crown on top. Tower of London is on the other side of Thames, London city, Belfast, marvelous City Hall - all together the best city plan I've ever seen. Thank you London!

Loved the glass floor. Every since I was a small boy I've wanted to go across the walkways at the top of Tower Bridge - they closed them to the public because of the suicides. The bridge itself is interesting enough, but the walkway and particularly the glass floor, are really worth the entrance fee. The glass floor is actually quite sppoky, especially when a boat goes under the bridge. Also the view is excellent, you don't get that view from high up in the middle of the river,anywhere else. PS booking online saves you money but doesn't save queueing.

Nice and interesting attraction. Went on a sunny day at end of November and it was a very nice experienceNot sure you could see so much if it was heavily cloudedEntrance is on the bridge, could be better signpostedCan use lift or stairs to go up to the upper bridgeGlass floor is excellent but does not cover a massive areaInformation is good Engine rooms are signed well with a blue line and arrows on the floorOverall good value especially with a family ticket

Good Start. Visited here last Sunday. Good value for money, great experience walking across the glass floor - although it did make my stomach turn a bit. Enjoyable experience but feel they could do a lot more with it, but still early days for them,
Huge . Well worth a look, especially the new glass panels in the walkway. This is a popular spot as everyone wants to take photo there.

Another must do. Personally I like to take friends to Westminster , Big Ben, the London Eye etc , then take the boat from Westminster Pier to Tower Hill, if time permits visit the Tower then after that walk across Tower Bridge and have a meal at one of the riverside Restaurants, even though I am a Londoner this trip never ceases to impress me, as I hope it does the friends that I take, go and enjoy

Great views and scary glass floor. Enjoyed our visit here and got some great views of the London skyline as it was getting dark. We travelled by rail so had 2 for 1 tickets which made it good value. We visited as we had heard about the new glass floor which had been put in on the upper level of the bridge. Quite frightening to walk over and see all the people and water down below. Good photo opportunities from the top.

by far the most beautiful bridge in london. or maybe N2 as albert bridge is also very very cuteI have never been up the tower but I suppose it must have amazing views of the river, tower of London and its surroundingsmake sure to visit it at night, my favorite time to enjoy the viewsome restaurants on the south side of the river will have a direct view of the tower which is also a nice way to enjoy it beauty

Excellent attraction. An insiders view of the history of the bridge, the underground machinery and the views up the Thames. Recently installed glass floor in the top parapet makes a stunning addition to the experience. Beautifully restored steam-driven beam engines in the bowels of the bridge. Not to be missed.

Great hour spent. Visited on a sunny day. Great views from the walkway. Small sliding windows to allow for photographing the views without reflections. Interesting but not longwinded films of the creation and building of the structure. Glass walkway may not be for everyone but you can walk either side of the glass if needs be. I do not like heights but the structure felt so solid that I even enjoyed the experience. £9 per adult is a good price for any attraction in London.

Great views of london. We got a great deal for this, first we got 2 for 1 with our train ticket and the price had also been lowered so it only cost us £7.00 for the two of us. We went while the poppies were on. The views are great, you are not rushed at all. You are told about the history and workings of the bridge. All in all we had a great deal and enjoyed it.
Tower bridge. The most poignant bridge in the world .. Monarchs have past under it,people all over the world have admired it .. I've painted it .. You will enjoy it !

Majestic and beautiful. You really can't visit London and not go to see the tower bridge. The bridge is an amazing piece of architecture. Walking along it you also get great views of the buildings along the Thames river and of course the Tower of London. And of course there's the exhibition in the tower which includes a climb to the upper level and there's a cool glass floor that you can look through it all the way down to the street level. Definitely worth the climb.

Favorite!. Probably our most favorite London landmark....although that's a tough choice to make. Just so incredibly unique and incredible. We walked a cross several time and drove across :) Amazing!!!

london pass- really it is more expensive as to pay entry tickets. The idea was good 60 places free of charge, the truth is, you can't visit more as 3 per day, most museums are free any way, so at the end it is more expensive and doesn't include any bus to hop in and out! We took it for 3 days, we did the tower the Thames cruise, the Globe theater, museum of Modern design, And all the Westminster area historical buildings, the rest we walked to see the city.

Lots to see and do. What can you say about the Tower Bridge that hasn't been said before? For one thing I didn't know it was painted blue.The bridge that filled our story books as kids is as impressive in real life. After visiting the Tower of London walk across and look back on the Tower to get a different perspective. See if you can find a camera angle you haven't seen before. Walk south east and take in the view from Greenwich Pier and grab a bite to eat. After lunch head west along the walkway. You are not so far from Jamie Oliver's favorite Borough Market or the Globe Theater then walk across the Millennium Bridge and visit St Paul's.

Great Views. The Tower Bridge at night offers 2 great views. From the bridge you can see up and down the Thames. Off to the side you can take pictures of the beautifully lit bridge. It is one of the top5 views in London.

Great pictures. The Tower Bridge is a iconic picture spot in London. It's also a nice walk to it along the Thames if you have a little bit of time. It's also nice because it seems to have a little bit less tourist traffic when you want to be somewhere that you're not surrounded. Not a "must-see," but not something that you'll regret taking the time to see.
iconic. when you think on London this is one of the first places that pops into my head. At night it's even more magical. Makes you proud to be British!

The new glass walkway. the glass section on the upper walkway was a real hit with everyone. There are panels with a few explanations on, and the machine room is interesting too. Worth the £9 for adults.

My favourite view. It's a special London land mark and one of my favourites. A beautiful sight along the Thames. Great to view when you walk along the Bridge or from the river or when you're walking along the banks of the Thames.

Imposing and iconic.. Tower Bridge is one of those landmarks that you see on tele or in pictures and think it'll be OK.But when you actually see it in the distance and start to approach it, it's pretty exciting. Amazingly built and great to admire. I didn't bother paying any money for the visitor's centre- it's nice enough to just look at and walk across.PS. For EPL fans from abroad, it's cool to see the old Premier League intro come to life!

Well worth a visit. We arrived at opening time in the morning so it was lovely and quiet, the queue was small and we weren't waiting long for the lift to take us to the top of the tower. There was a short film about the building of the bridge which was interesting then you went for a walk along the walkway. There is only one open at the moment as they are constructing the glass floor in the other one but the view from the right hand walkway was amazing! There is loads of information to read along the way then you reach the glass floor, amazing! You don't feel rushed and can take loads of photos and take in the views of landmarks like St Pauls and The Shard. Once you have left the bridge there is a short walk to the Engine room were you view the engines that used to power the bridge which was interesting. The shop was very reasonably priced even though we felt a bit ripped off with the price of the photographs.

One of our favorites in London! . My wife and I visited London for our 35th anniversary. We rented an apartment for the week only a block from the Tower Bridge. Needless to say we saw the Tower Bridge in the rain, fog, sunshine, day and night. We saw it from walking the bridge, riding over on the bus, from the river cruise, and got to watch it be raised and lowered. We even ate dinner under the Tower in a little place called The Vault. It's an historic part of London and one of our favorite spots.

great views. Me and my partner visited this through our London pass.The guide in the lift that takes you up for the start of the tour was really informative and nice.Great views with opening window slots so your cameras flash doesn't ruin your photos.I enjoyed the glass floor, felt safe.Great look into the making of the bridge. We also did the engine room tour. This was a bit lack luster and took about 10minutes if that to complete.This is the best way to truly experience this landmark.

By far the greatest bridge in the world!. Tower Bridge never ceases to amaze me! Beautiful engineering and style. Plus the bonus of the views from City Hall to the Tower of London. St Catherine Docks and the tall ships!

It was fun!. This past Thanksgiving weekend we flew into Manchester England and drove over to London. One of the main things I wanted to see was the Tower Bridge exhibit. The cost is about 9 pounds or about $14 american. And what you get for these two events. One is a tour of the motor room that shows how they lifted up the bridge in the days of the past. The other is the ability to actually go upstairs to the high level and walk on a glass panel above the roadway and the river. It takes a little bit of energy to finally do it but we finally tried it. It was actually fun to feel like you were floating in the air above the roadway and the River Thames. The whole thing took maybe about 30 minutes but it was definitely worth the time. We had no wait for we arrived on a Friday around noon and the weather was improving so we got a chance to get some good Bridge shots of the River Thames.
lovely. this brick bridge is strong and powerful this is the most best tourist attraction in the uk.the middle of the bridge opens when a tall boat goes through

I love the Golden Gate Bridge and this tops it!. I didn't take the tour to visit the engine room but was still enamored by this bridge. I love the colors including the light blue on the bridge as well as the design of this historical bridge. I also enjoyed walking across it and getting a beautiful view of the River Thames on a rare sunny day in London. Next time, I hope to see the glass walkway that just opened this year!
When in London.... One must do the Tower Bridge. Unfortunately, it was closed when I was there :( The rest of London made up for it!

Great value. Take the time to visit the Exhibition. You can not but admire the foresight of the Architects and the building of this historical bridge. Where did they start? The construction alone is mind boggling and when you see the engine room and the size and complexity of boilers and winding wheels you will understand. Even more amazing when you see how few people where involved in the construction. The introduction of a glass walkway has added to the experience and I hope to pay another visit when the other glass walkway is completed. It has an exhibition of famous bridges of the world and Tower Bridge deserves to be included.

Great Exhibition. We visited this attraction a couple of weeks before the glass floor was installed and nearly a month before it was smashed (whoops!). We went to London at half term to see Matilda and were looking for some fun but not too expensive (given the cost of theatre tickets) attractions to visit. This one fit the bill beautifully. Not only is it the most iconic of the London bridges but the fact that you can get up into the walkways still amazes me. On the cost front, you can go on Tesco vouchers and on the day we went the ticket cost just over £15 for the four of us. Where else can you go for a couple of hours in London for that price? I enjoyed the exhibition even though I had been before (they have added to it over the years) and the children (two 7 year old boys) genuinely found it interesting. To top it all the walkways offer some spectacular views of the Shard and some of the other newer London skyline as well as great views of the poppies at the Tower on a day when it was difficult to get near.

If you love old machines, you love it.. The engine room with beautiful steam engines and giant cogwheels was stunning. It was also rewarding to learn how the bridge works. Although I have already forgot it all.

brilliant experience!. My husband and I went to London to celebrate our wedding anniversary so while we were there we decided to go to the Tower of London to see the poppies and the Crown Jewels and also Tower Bridge. What an experience walking on the glass floor and looking down into the Thames! I have a connection with Tower Bridge as my great grandfather was timekeeper on it when it opened in 1894.

Glass Walkway now open!. Having seen the new Glass Walkway at Tower Bridge being opened and promoted on BBC news, it was the selling point in finally visiting this iconic London landmark. We booked our tickets online a few days in advance of our visit;we had to specify which day we wanted to visit, but were not restricted to a set time. We chose to visit at around 10am on a Staurday morning, soon after the walkway had opened. I had feared the worst in terms of queues, but was suprised to find no queue with almost immediate entry. The Tower Bridge exhibition starts with a brief video around how the bridge construction process played out, and the engineering challenges faced during building, which started in 1886, and was not completed until 1894. The video also details alternative designs for the bridge, and how the final design had to be altered due to engineering issues.We were soon onto the walkway, with the main intention of being on the glass walkway and looking down at the bridge. Given that it wasn't too busy, we were able to find plenty of space and time on the glass walkway to take our pictures of the passing vehicles and tourists below. It was suprising that the glass walkway only measured 11m in length, which means space may become a premium at peak times. Also along the walkway was an exhibition of famous bridges around the world, although with the suprising omission of the Golden Gate bridge, arguably the most famous bridge in the world! The walkway also offers great panoramic views of London, although these views are the same from London Bridge, except for you can get Tower Bridge into your shot from there!The Tower Bridge exhibition also includes entry to the engine room, situated at the far end of the bridge. This is an interesting final part of the visit, highlighting the engineering feat in allowing the bridge to open for larger vessels. All in all, a very enjoyable experience, and particularly worth the visit if you are interested in the engineering achievements of the bridge.
Saw the bridge open. Went to the Tower of London to see the poppies and whilst there we were fortunate enough to see the bridge open for a large ship. Well worth seeing

London Bridge, THAT Glass Floor, and more tips.. Well by now you will know that the easiest way into London is by train; and it can save you money as well. No more looking for expensive parking. Got a Railcard? It becomes even cheaper stil!. So we went down to the railway station a couple of days before we were going; also at a quiet time. Got train tickets that included going to Tower Hill underground. This saves a lot of time queing up to get your tickets there as well. Arrived at Liverpool Street Station, turned left from the barriers; across the station concourse and down the underground. For us it was on the WEST BOUND CIRCLE LINE, and a couple of stops later and we were at Tower Hill. Get out at Tower Hill and head towards the road where you cross over. Straight ahead is the river; and to your left is the Tower Of London. Might just as well take a small Sony Cybershot, which fits neatly into a pocket, and get a few shots of the Tower while you are about it. But as you reach the river; look to your right. Across the river you will see H.M.S. Belfast anchored on the other bank. Just beyond that though, and you can also get a photo of The Shard building. A word of caution to ladies. As you walk towards the bridge you are on cobbled effect pavement. Wear sensible flat shoes; or even trainers. Don't want a twisted ankle to spoil the day out. Why this route you may well ask? All will become crystal clear very shortly. River is on your right, the Tower is on your left. Ahead you will see an underpass that will give you access to the bridge above. There is a place that sells fish and chips and a drink, on your left as you walk through the underpass. As you come out of the other side do NOT turn left to climb the narrow steps to the bridge above. No, because this will leave you on the left side of the bridge as you face south; and this is no good to you at all. Instead look to your right; there you will see wider steps much like those on the underground. There should also be a sign saying "Tower Bridge Exhibition" This is your route. When you get out at the top it may not make much sense. However you are now on the right hand side of the bridge, as it faces south. Look down now to the pavement. Beneath your feet you will see a blue painted line. This is the route you will follow to the first Tower of the Bridge where the tickets are sold. Now if when you bought your tickets you remembered to ask your train operator for a 2 for 1 brochure; again you will save some more money. Make sure that you either fill them in before you leave home, or get them online; and print them off. Basically they just need to know your name, when you intend to travel; from which stationn; and to what attraction you wish the tickets to be valid for. When you go to buy your tickets, give them your vouchers plus your rail tickets. Instead of paying £9 each, both of you get in for that same price. (You get your rail tickets back though.)The savings can go towards paying for a drink later on. By now the blue line will have lead you to where you are to buy your tickets. You move to the left and there you will wait for the lift to take you up to the level you need, just over 40 metres above the road. While you are in the lift; which is bigger than you may think; the lady will show you a diagram on the wall. Level 1, is where you started from, and 2 is where you are going to. Levels 2 to 3 is the walk from one Tower to the other; and over THAT glass floor. Level 4 is where you go back down to road level, but she will also remind you to keep your tickets if you wish to the the original engine rooms where the mechanism is that used to raise and lower the bridge. The engine room is part 5 of your trip. When the lift reaches the top you will get the chance to sit down a visual presentation, and watch why the bridge was built in the first place, and who designed it. Top left isa lady who supposed to be Queen Victoria, top right is the designer of the bridge, and the large screen at the bottom has the narrator. It is also on this large screen that you will see in stop motion display how the different stages of the bridge were constructed. Overall really interesting to know. From leaving here you now come to the really attraction of the bridge as well. THAT glass floor. First though on your left side are various types of bridges built around the world. Some of them truly spectacular. Don't miss at intervals on your right side that there are small windows that can be slid open; so that you can take photo's upstream of the Thames and different angles to the Tower Of London; etc. Now you are walking towards that floor. The one thing above everything else is that to our brain it doesn't make sense. We are confused for a while that we can clearly see people walking by, cars and vans in the traffic, or a boat sailing under the bridge. Our mind knows that when we walk on the path or the road it is used to seeing a solid feature beneath our feet; and well to some this just doesn't fit right. Despite the fact that there were people who could see other people standing on this glass; which by the way is about 3 inches thick in total; they still would not set foot on it. Some even made a point of walking around the edge staying well clear of the glass. All in all though it was a great experience in itself and the views are well worth seeing. Next year they are supposed to be putting a glass floor in the left hand side ot Tower Bridge and this in turn will give us a view of downstream Thames, When you get to point 3 on your travels you can either choose to ge down the stairs; or again wait for the lift to take you back to the street level. On leaving, keep looking down on the path. Here again you will see our familiar friend, the blue line which will then take you down to the engine room. Here you can see the massive engines that worked to raise and lowed Tower Bridge. At the further end you will see one massive spanner laying on the floor; this is about three feet long! This was a treat that followed up after going to the Tower Of London. All in all a really great day out and well worth the effort. Time now for a drink and a bite to eat. Walking back the way you came you will see plenty of places to get something to eat or drink. One thing we did notice after we had bought something, was that as we crossed the road to go back to Tower Hill underground, was that to the left of the Tower Hill Memorial gardens, we could see a Wetherspoons place, where we could have eaten and had something to drink in far more comfort. Still remember it for another day. Only recently did the papers carry the story that the top layer of glass had been broken at some fuction where bottled drink was served. Plus a stilletto heel didn't help either. Sounds as though they need to rethink what drinks are served up in.

Tower Bridge Experience. This is a cheap and value for money attraction. Even cheaper if you get the train into London as it will then be 2for1. I went to the attraction before someone dropped a glass bottle on the glass walkway, it was amazing. I was in a party of nine, the oldest 71 the youngest 12 years and we all enjoyed. Each of us was also given a £2.00 off voucher to use in the gift shop as the west walk was having its glass walk way fitted but it no way effected the visit.

Worth a visit. Well worth a visit if you are in London.Not to much £ s.And the Glass walk over is great.Also the info of the building of the Bridge,videos etc.and the Engine room very interesting,even for children.

The Bridge That America Thought It Had Bought!!. This is the bridge that America thought it had bought, when in fact they purchased the old London Bridge. There is obviously no way this iconic bridge will ever be sold. The best viewing point to see the bridge in it's entirety is from London Bridge, where the photo can also include HMS Belfast and the Tower of London. It is a great bridge to just walk over and marvel at the workmanship that took place over a hundred years ago. There is a new attraction recently added but not visited. The glass floor on the overhead walkway. Not for the faint hearted!!

Running in London. The time in London was a good one. I did a lot of activities, I went to the tower of London, Buckingham palace, Hyde park and the Camden Angel Comedy club. But the thing that I want to share with you is one of my running sessions in London. Running in London is very difficult I experienced but it can also be quite nice. Of course you know the stories about running in the parks of London, especially Hyde park. Hyde park is a nice big park where a lot of runners come through the day. The problem were that Hyde park was way too far from my hostel called Rest-up London. So I had to choose another route for my daily 30minutes run. I started at the hostel and took my way to the Tower bridge and ran over it. In that way I’ve got an beautiful view over the Thames and I could also see the Tower of London on my left side. After that I took the Thames walk way along to the south walk bridge and from there I took the shortest way back to the hostel. During that run you also have a lot of traffic lights, you can’t prevent that. So if you want to run without any traffic lights you have to choose for Hyde park, otherwise you can choose for a run along the Thames and all the different bridges of London.
The most beautiful bridge in London. The Tower Bridge makes for a lovely walk in London, and is undoubtedly the most elaborate and gorgeous bridge there.

Just Amazing. You think England, and you think Tower Bridge. It's iconic, it's majestic, it's stunning. I was lucky enough to have a magnificent view of this beauty from my hotel room. Next time, I'm walking over the new glass floor. Do not miss this bridge.
Great piece of history. We went across the bridge after visiting the Tower of London to see the poppies. It is a really good bridge.

Glass Floor!!!!. Had an interesting tour of Tower Bridge, including the Engine Room but most spectacular will always be the Glass Floor walkway over the bridge itself. Staff are knowledgeable and friendly - a good film is shown before and after the bridge crossing giving plenty of information abut the bridge and the price is reasonable, even more so when combined with The Fire of London Monument.
Loved it. The view is awesome and it's really amazing to view at night. Get the camera ready because you will use it to capture some great moments to share with family and friends.
Bridge that defines historic london. Amazing bridge especially with the lights on at night. Just looking at it is amazing and when the bridge is drawn it feels awsome.

Glass floor is amazing. We visited just after the glass floor was opened to the public. It was a fabulous experience and you can take as long as you like on the glass floor. The whole exhibition on Tower Bridge is excellent and very interesting, showing the history of the Bridge and the building of it. Excellent value for money at £9 per person and very disabled friendly as my husband uses a mobility scooter.

Just amazing to see. I have been there a few times and will always at least go to see it when I'm in London... The history is just so amazing... The bridge itself is amazing to look at. They also offer a self tour that gives you the history of the bridge... Definitely worth seeing.
Great to walk over the glass floor!. We visited today, highly recommend.Great views along the river and the glass floor is excellent!! Well worth a visit if you are in that part of London.
Iconic Bridge. Excellent views along the river from the bridge and at night the bridge itself is very well lit. One of London's most iconic sights. Should be visited whilst in the city.

A Cheap London Attraction!. After seeing the new glass walkway in the newspaper a few days before my visit to London I decided that I must go and visit. Once I arrived I was surprised that I didn't have to queue or pay over the odds. Once I paid I didn't have to wait for the lift which takes you up, they were waiting for me to pay before they left! You watch a short video at the top which takes you through the design of the bridge and then it's onto the walkway. The glass walkway was a bit daunting at first but made the visit fun, there are plenty of photo opportunities of the Thames and London landmarks from the walkway. Once you have been across the walkway you are then taken down by lift and you then get the choice to see the engine rooms which operate the bridge. It's worth going and my advice is go and visit while it's cheap!

Super. Great sense of history. Walking over the glass floor was amazing and we loved the engine room too. The views were amazing from the walkway. Shame the bridge was opening on the day we were there.

Glass walkway over the Thames. We took a visit up and over Tower Bridge yesterday. It consists of five stages with brief visual displays and films explaining the construction and workings of the bascule bridge . You ascend in a lift on the north tower and then walk across the newly laid glass floor. The river and traffic directly below you , quite scary for a lot of people. Once across you descend the south tower and walk over to the engine room which has all the original steam pumps that operated the arms.Very impressive, great views.

The Tower and The Poppies. We were fortunate to visit London Tower while the amazing artwork of Poppies were laid in tribute and respect to those who sacrificed their lives. It is the Centenary of the beginning of WW1 and this spectacle took my breath away. The Tower itself is filled with history and is an impressive structure, as is the Bridge. As you walk over the Bridge the view of the Thames stretches for miles. The new glass walkway is pretty scary at first and certainly gets the adrenaline going! It was the first time that I had visited the Tower and there is so much to take in that I will go again when I have the opportunity. It is an important part of our history for all to share.

Beautiful Bridge, gives great views. Tower Bridge is a beautiful bridge set towards the east of London, very near the Tower of London. When walking across you can get some beautiful views of London and the river. It is well worth doing just for this.There is now a glass walkway at the top of the bridge you can pay to do.

Pretty impressive. They have glass walkways now which make the trip even more fun. There are a whole lot of things at the place to learn and discover about the place and its history. It’s a great idea to visit the place while in London and the sights are wonderful.

Daunting glass walkway was amazing!. After seeing the poppies we made our way up to the Tower Bridge exhibition. Very well organised and a short film followed by exploring the views and experiencing the new glass walk way. The views are Ok, lots of structural obstructions but the glass walk way made up for it with the breath taking views of the Thames and the miniature people crossing the bridge.They take your photo as you leave and we paid £15 for a set of gifts. I'm too gullible not too accept!!The engine rooms are dull unless you're interested in that sort of stuff. Personally I'd recommend for the glass floor and photo opportunities and to day you've been inside one of the most famous bridges in the world :)

Glass floored walk way fascinated my 3 year old. From a distance the Bridge is an imposing yet beautiful sight - ornate yet strong - a true landmark and piece of history - the opportunity to really explore it and see what goes on really was fantastic.I'd booked tickets online ready - fantastic value ticket (under 5s are free) I'd bought my 3 year old son down to the Tower to see the Poppies and the proximity was too good an opportunity to miss. Nice and easy booking system with a printable barcode to take to the front desk.- very straight forward and seamless experience at the desk when we got there - nice helpful guy who presented Nicholas with his children's "passport" and first set up stickers, explaining there were more stickers to collect on the way around - an instant hit with any young child.A very large lit took us and a load of other tourists up to a video room which sounded very interesting but not gripping enough for Nicholas so we quickly moved on to the walkway - stunning views up the river being able to see the Tower where we'd just come from, London Bridge, HMS Belfast, City Hall and all sorts in between. That shortly paled into insignificance though when he realised the glass floor was there. I lost track of how long he spent with the glass floor as he kept going back to it even when pulled away - must have been 20-30 minutes I guess. He was fascinated by it and had a great time walking, crawling and running up and down and watching everything below "They are all small" was a popular comment. There's "normal" floor all around so you dont have to go on it if you don't want to. A really helpful staff member was on hand to answer any questions and plenty were being asked - especially about the strength of the glass!Coming down the other stair well there was more video opportunity but the real highlight is the staircase and surroundings which really make you feel part of history and are really in keeping with expectations of such a monument. The toilets were at the bottom of the stairwell and a welcome stop-off for a toilet training young boy and were clean and modern.Another lift took us the rest o the way down to road level where you follow a painted trail on the ground to find your way around to the engine room. Having something visual to follow like this was a great hit with Nicholas who insisted on leading the way to right down underneath the bridge, a seperate entrance down underneath road level.The engine rooms were fascinating and Nicholas loved seeing all the spinning wheels and regulators and the collection of really large spanners along with much else:) I can't begin to explain how special this whole experience was. If we lived closer we'd be back time and time again but Yorkshire was a bit of a commute just for a day trip. I can't believe that anyone would not enjoy this magical tour. I would have spent a lot longer there but some off the information is a little dry for a child BUT even with that we were there for about an hour and a half in total which is very respectable for the attention span of a young child and incredible value for the ticket price.I can't leave this without mentioning the Biggles film which was a firm child-hood favourite of mine as a child which gave this visit added meaning to me - to get inside this monument really was a childhood fantasy come true.

glass floor!. We took time to walk through and over the top of the Tower bridge which now has a glass floor piece so you get not only the great views of the river and city but if you are lucky, the view of the river when the bridge is open and the boats sail through. It cost 8 pounds per person and is open from 10am

A Must Do. This is a very cool thing to do while in London. The views are great and it provides a nice history of the bridge, why it was built, etc. It took us about 40 minutes to go through the whole thing. It certainly gave me a greater appreciation for this landmark.

TOWER BRIDGE GLASS WALKWAY. Wonderful experience to walk across the new glass walkway, and also to see the displays of bridges from around the world, some of which are quite amazing. The engine room was very interesting and informative. Interesting videos too explaining things about the tower. Enjoyable visit.
Fantastic views. Excellent value for money, amazing views of the Thames and surrounding areas, staff were extremely helpful and it was very informative.

A pics of history. We caught the bus there ,as we were working our way through the different transport systems of London. The bus was so cheap for me to travel and my daughters travelled for free.we drove over the bridge and the bus stopped right in front of the Tower of London,all added bonuses. A piece of history to be seen. We then took the Thames clipper rather than the tour boat,so had another spectacular view and trip along the Thames,back to Covant Garden. It was much cheaper than the tour boat too.

The Tower Experience. We wanted to do the walkway across the top of Tower Bridge and the Tower Experience seemed to be the only way to achieve it. The engine room exhibit was very informative and the new glass walkway was a novel experience. If you can plan your trip, look at the web site to see when the bridge is scheduled to open and watch it from above.

Walking on glass!. The newly opened glass walkway is great. Fantastic views of the river, South bank, Tower of London, City etc. Good exhibits and 2 interesting shortish videos one in each tower. The engine room has some fantastic Victorian engineering. There is something for everyone here, and the gift shop has some London items which were significantly better priced than Amazon for the same item. A great couple of hours.
Fantastic view in night time. Go there when it is dark. This is the best time to take great pictures. You can also head to great pubs around, busy and quiet at the same time.

Tower bridge exhibition. Reasonably priced and very informative. The guides were extremely friendly. There were a couple of short films and then a walk on the new glass walk way. The grand children thought that it was great looking down at the Thames through the glass. Gift shop not too expensive. Would recommend. Seeing the work that went into building it, I was proud to be British
Nice to see. As a tourist you have to walk through the Tower Bridge - you have to be pacient though because it's quite a crowdy place.

Of Course A Must See...... Amazing....... every child knows about this bridge. The Tower Bridge but known as London Bridge. I was in awe........ what an engineering feat at that era of time. You could walk along the river Thames and head north or south with so many activities going on. Food in abundance.

dare you walk on the glass walkway????. Seemed a logical place to visit as I was at the Tower viewing the poppies then going to The Shard.Informative staff and some good information on how the bridge was built and how it operates. The new glass walk way is certainly something else, looking down onto the roadway and footpath. An ideal time to be there would be when the bridge actually opens, I'm sure there will be a list of dates/times somewhere.
Looks just like its photos. One of the few iconic tourist attractions that looks exactly like its photos - and best of all its free and you get an excellent view of the Tower & the river

Iconic Must See Bridge. WOW!I could end the review there, but of course I wont.WOW, is the best thing I can say about this jaw dropping piece of English engineering at it's best.Probably THE best known (and usually wrongly called London Bridge) & photographed bridge in the world.The sight of this bridge from any angle is stunning.Some camera angles take in modern buildings, but get it just right, and you could be looking at an image of the bridge from the 1920's.Doing a bridge tour is a must, and the walk across the top inside the museum area is great.Views are fantastic and the information on display is quite a good (if lengthy) read.The highlight for me was the tour through the original steam & hydraulic machinery rooms, absolutely amazing!Any male or female interested in turn of the (last) century machinery will be blown away.Anyone who isn't, but has a partner who is, well, your in for a long and boring tour through the machinery rooms. Photography is a "little" tough as the lighting isn't so good, and the photography can be a little cramped if you do not have any lens under 24mm.Later afternoon seemed to be good for photography in these engineering spaces as not many people were around. I could only imagine getting good images would be nearly impossible if the rooms had a few visitors.Plenty of more engineering displays, videos and models are great for those of us into engineering, but again boring for those who are not.We did a fun free video email from downstairs, which is worth a look, again, forget it if there are a few visitors.We were on one of the last tours, and I feel this is the best time, if you want to have a good look and not get hurried.I was a bit stunned at how small the roadway is for such a bridge of quite amazing proportions when viewed say from the Tower Of London, but this just adds to it's charm.A piece of history that the Tower Bridge is, really is worth your time for a visit.

Bridge Opening. Thank goodness we saw the list of bridge opening dates and times and went along at 6.30 p.m. to see the bridge being opened for a sailing barge going back down river. We were glad that we arrived early because the opening was brought forward from 6.30 to 6.15 - so be warned! An amazing experience and view from the embankment and next time we intend to do a bit more investigating into the Tower Bridge itself (plus the newly-opened glass floor) and the engine room!

Considering when it was built, this is an engineering marvel. Simply stunning and, when you consider when it was built, this is a marvellous testament to the engineers back then. It appears to be in great condition with clean stone work and pristine paintwork. Couldn't stop taking photo's of it! If you want to see the interior, there is a fee and they have just introduced a new glass walkway where you can look down on the traffic below or, if you're lucky enough, look down to see the two,sections open up towards you and see a larger vessel sailing through.

Explore the hidden history of Tower Bridge. The Tower Bridge Exhibition provides a detailed and interesting view behind the scenes at Tower Bridge. The ticket includes a short film detailing the idea and plan behind the bridge. Another film at the end is a detailed time lapse of the construction of the bridge.The walkways feature different views over London and the windows include handy "slide panels", so those with cameras can take pictures without glass getting in the way.A week after our visit, a glass bottomed walkway was opened on the opposite gantry.The ticket also includes entrance to a gift shop and the engine rooms, which due to lack of time we couldn't visit.Tip - for a different view of London history, keep an eye out for the Victorian postbox, at the steps on the South side of the river, very close to the ticket booth.
