London weekend. Went on right weekend as glass floors open today brill view but scarey, views over Thames great,shard and town lite up by sun, camera windows on both sides for best view 2no on both sides, films and info in bridge very good and helpful, well worth a visit and a good price

Very Interesting. The Tower Bridge can be seen from quite a distance down the Thames. We visited it during our week long trip to London. The bridge is part of a magnificent view and provides great views of the surrounding area as well. The structure of the bridge is painted red, white, blue, and light blue. I am afraid of heights and falling from bridges but the wide pathways allowed me to walk across without feeling too stressed (don't get me started on the Golden Gate Bridge). Half of the tour exhibit at the top was closed during our visit. We were lucky enough to see the road platform raised later in the week so a tugboat could haul a large ship through. It was cool.

Informative and Interesting. We joined the tour using our London Pass which we got. The tour comes with guide on the historical of the bridge and its stages of construction. Very informative. You get to walk from one tower to the other and great view of the Thames from there.

Tower Bridge to me is the ultimate London icon. I love the experience and seem to find myself going back every time I am in London. It was cool last week because the owner of Fulham/Jacksonville Jaguars Shad Khan's yacht the Kismet was anchored beside the bridge. Amazing.

One of the Top 10 attractions to visit in London. Upon your visit the tickets can be bought either at the northern tower of the bridge [entrance to the bridge exhibition] or at the machine room, that can be found on the southern bank under the bridge. Adult tickets cost 9 pounds (they are valid for the bridge as well as the machine room exhibitions). Discounts for students, children and pensioners apply. It actually doesn't matter from where you would like to start your visit. However, i want to stress that the queue to buy the tickets for the exhibition is smaller in the machine room. There are 2 ways to climb the bridge to the top: either by taking an elevator or taking the stairs. You would need to climb over 100 steps though. On the top you would have a chance to acknowledge yourself with the whole history and building process of the bridge, what i find quite interesting. The middle section of the bridge has been modernized and now is covered in glass frames. Unfortunately i found it a bit odd as it has become more difficult to take pictures of the picturesque views. As at most modern attractions, there is a glass see through floor, what makes it possible to see the bridge, cars, boats etc. from above. After you have reached the southern tower, you will be able to buy some souvenirs. An elevator will take you downstairs to the exit from the bridge. There is no way to exit the southern tower by the stairs. If you follow the blue line on your exit, it will lead you to the machine room. The machine room has a souvenir shop as well. Bathroom facilities are available in every part of the exhibition. Have a great visit!
Lots To See. Much more to see then just the bridge. Take the tour and see the history of the bridge and much more.
Check it out!. If your'e in the area this is a nice place to visit. Good views up and down the river. Interesting display of the tower and engine room.

Brilliant. Just a flying visit but still well worth seeing the poppies and the bridge unfortunately I was unable to visit the tower properly but next time maybe but even though I was only there for an hour it was still worth it

A wonderful experience on this fascinating & iconic structure. Cracking visit to this historic and iconic structure. Full of facts on the history of how it came including some whacky ideas for the bridge crossing before settling on this wonderful feat of engineering. And then there is the walk across the river with the amazing vista that looks eastwards to the London skyline. Well worth the price and an essential part of understanding the recent history of London.

Experience Tower Bridge. My great granddaughter & I visited London last week & visited the Tower Bridge Exhibition, & It was worth every penny. We spent almost 3 hours taking it all in, & even though I have been here before, I took great pleasure & enjoyment seeing it all again. We visited on 7/11/14, & I read in the paper a few days later, that a new glass walkway has been opened. I shall definitely be going back to see this as it sounds amazing !!!

the engine room is a must-see. While it's not easy to take a good picture of the tower bridge, the bridge itself is a good place to take pictures of the Thames and the landscape alongside the river. The engine room under the bridge, whose entrance is at the south end of the bridge, is amazing. It shows how the engine lifts the bridge. The exhibition on the bridge, whose entrance is at the north end of the bridge, is just boring. If you want to visit both rooms, you will need to buy only one ticket and use it to check in at both entrances.

Good value. Brought tickets on day £9 each go up in lift to walkway amazing views plenty of time to take photos. Walk over glass panels bit strange but views below of river. Descend tower and ali back over bridge to Engine room a bit boring. Videos good usual shop at end.

An unplanned visit. Decided to have a look at the exhibition after visiting the Tower of London and the poppies display (which was amazing). A lift takes you up to the top of the bridge where there's a platform that takes you from one tower to the other, including a glass floor panel you can walk over. I found the Victorian engine rooms a bit boring though.
Well worth it. More to do here than you might at first think. Walk it, climb and descend all sets of steps and see great views. Visit towers and soon to be a glass walkway suspended between towers.

Great value for money.. We spent all morning exploring Tower Bridge and found that £8 per adult (December 2013, £9 now) was certainly worthwhile. As keen photographers, the views were great. Superb shots of London. The bridge is enclosed but there are ample 'photograph windows' at different heights to ensure a clear picture. The history of the bridge is fascinating and told through a film introduction, as well as various information displays. An added bonus is the engine room at the end of the visit. Must return as they seem to have unveiled a glass floor in the last few days! Expect a bag check on entry.

Incredible achievement. An amazing structure with amazing works inside. The actual construction of this incredible bridge must have been a wonder to see. I think they should put up loads of notices telling the multitude of schoolchildren and numerous foreigners that this is TOWER BRIDGE not London Bridge. I endured a boat trip some time ago where a teacher told her many charges that this is London Bridge ! The kids burst into song 'London Bridge is falling down...' A small boy sitting behind us constantly referred to it as London Bridge. We put him straight and told him to tell all his friends!

Informative & Nice View. The easily recognizable Tower Bridge has spanned the Themes River for 120 years. The Tower Bridge Exhibition invites you to explore the famous structure, enjoy the spectacular panoramic views from the high-level walkway, and visit the engine rooms - all while learning the history of the bridge. Very enjoyable! I was really dissapointed to learn that we missed the new glass floor by a week!! The London Pass was worth every pound!

Great views, surprising history!. Visiting just a day before the glass floor opened to the public was a minor disappointment. However, the sunset pictures from so high above the Thames were worth the good value entry ticket price (£7 adult).With no hurry to 'move along' this allowed photographers plenty of time to get their shots! Some unusual photos are of the roadway beneath, and the very clean engine room with its four hydraulic engines. We left just in time to witness the raising of the bascule bridge sections in just 60 seconds! Wonderful.

Visit to see the Poppies. The Poppies are awe-inspiring and well worth a visit. Plenty to see and do at Tower Bridge - St Katherine's Dock is lovely with pubs & restaurants, there are Thames River Boat trips close at hand, and sightseeing at The Tower.
Glass pass. First day that the glass flloor was opened. Spectacular and super view of the Thames river underneath. It was a far greater experience than expected

Great visit!. Having been to the Tower of London to see the poppies, we decided to use our Great Northern rail 2 for 1 voucher to visit the Bridge. Our luck was in as the new glass floor on the walkway 42 m above was newly opened for us to enjoy! The history of the Bridge is very interesting and the views stunning. The visit to the engine room at the end of the tour is not to be missed.
Tower Bridge. London Experience: Try it, your are taken up 139ft to a walk way across between towers. You have great views of the city and the Thames and its not expensive.

Remembrance day poppy display. worth a visit as one for the history books !it was not as busy as mentioned on tv as not the half term holidays -the only problem was that the tower bridge tube station was closed so had a bit of a walk from the tube -

A hidden gem - in plain sight!. We paid 7 GBP to take the tour across the walkway at the top of Tower Bridge. It was certainly worth the money.Visitors take the elevator up to the first video area, where you learn about the history, then walk across the walkway, peering out at the sights of London underneath. Another talk follows.When we were there, the W side renovations were just being completed. Now it has glass panels in the floor so you can actually see the bridge opening underneath. Fabulous!The tour also includes the machine/engine room.This is a great opportunity to see the Tower of London, walk across Tower Bridge, have lunch at one of the lovely restaurants at Butlers Wharf, then walk along the South Bank, past Southwark cathedral and Vinopolis to the Tate and the Millennium Bridge.

Excellent sightseeing. The tower bridge is a unique bridge with lovely architecture. I did not see any similar bridge in the rest of Britain or in the other countries I visited or heard about. It is accessible from the Tower area. Taking the boat from Westminster Pier to the Tower gives the opportunity to visit both the Tower and the Tower bridge. Walking on the high bridge gives a pleasant scene of the Thames river and other features on the sides.

Tower Bridge at low tide. If you enjoy walking follow the Thames Path for a different view of the landmarks.Today I walked along the Thames Path (south) from London Bridge Station and crossed the Thames at Tower Bridge to view the poppies marking the lost lives during WW1 at the Tower of London. Proceeded to walk along the Thames Path (north) to Westminster and Whitehall for the Armistice Day ceremony.

Be Ware of the Stairs. So I loved the Tour itself, with the London Pass it was a free tour and right next to the Tower of London, it was very interesting a great sight over the Thames. Although I will say this, don't be brave and take the stairs unless you are in amazing shape as there are ton of them up and no wait to try tackle them, Other than the attraction itself is very infomative and most important allows for you to take a breathtaking view of London

Fantastic if you want to get across river but remain dry. I have used this bridge many times and have yet to fall in the river. It is well made with no holes, or trolls lurking underneath. Sometimes opens to let ships through. Don't climb up the road when this is happening! You will fall in the river. Or onto a ship, which could be heading anywhere in the world. Quite an adventure!The bridge caters for those wishing to cross from South London into North London. It also handily works the other way, if you wish to cross from North London to South London (though I don't know why you would want to do that). You can cross with friends or alone, on bicycle, car or foot. If you are in a large ship, remember to go *underneath* the bridge. And call in advance so they can open it.Views are nice. Watch the road if you are driving or cycling. Watch the river if you are the captain of a large ship.

Quaint and well organized attraction.. In September, we were in the area and did not have sufficient time to tour Tower of London. Instead, we decided on Tower Bridge which we expected to be short and sweet. When we got there, even better, as admission was reduced down to 7 pounds. I've seen the spectacular bridge many times from afar and walked across the base so I was really excited to finally go up to see what's inside and experience the tower walkway.The attraction is divided in several stages. In the first stage, you arrive in a mini-theatre to watch a short film on the history on the construction of the bridge. Then we arrived at the walkway across the top with the photo exhibits on world renowned bridges. When I got to the last stage which was the engine room, all my high school science knowledge came rushing back to me. The Victoria engine room was my favorite.

Gorgeous Bridge! Great Photos!. This bridge is absolutely gorgeous! Especially on a sunny day. Fantastic photo ops. The best views of the bridge are from Southwark across from The Tower. In fact, one of our favorite things to do was to walk along the promenade on the south side of the Thames from The Eye to Tower Bridge: theatres, shops, museums, restaurants, attractions all along the waterfront. Walking across the bridge is a lot of fun too! And - it's good exercise!
Great views. Loved the great views! The new glass bottom floor allows you to see water, traffic and pedestrians on the bridge. A great spot to go for a view. Go at dusk to see the city lit up.

dissapointing. I was visiting London with my husband and had a bit of time to spare so we decided to do the Tower Bridge experience. We had been before many years ago and enjoyed it but things had changed and it seemed to have been dumbed down. The view from the top is nice but not worth the entry price. If you are in London seeing Tower Bridge is a must but not paying for the experience

Iconic symbol of London. No visit to London could be complete without viewing Tower Bridge which stands in magnificent splendour spanning the River Thames. Its two towers, joined by a horizontal roadway rise from the water, flanked by suspension sections on either side. The bridge is beautiful and atmospheric in all seasons including winter days when mist swirls from the water. It is also spectacular at sunrise and sunset times of the day. It is well worth taking time to cross the bridge and view it from different angles. Just standing looking at the Bridge and watching the river below will enable happy memories of London.

Superb view from this iconic landmark. We took the visit which was well organised and the staff were helpful and knowledgeable throughout. The views from the walkway are stunning, giving a different perspective to the Thames and showcasing both historic and modern buildings.The walkway is reached by a lift. There was a brief wait. On arrival at the upper level there was a brief visual presentation. Only one walkway was open. The down river one seemed to be undergoing maintenance. The entry cost was reduced to £7, perhaps to reflect this (with a rail ticket you can get in on a two for one deal which is great value). The amount of information in several languages is just enough. There is also an interesting collection of photographs and detail about bridges around the world. Having reached the southern tower we had to walk down a few flights of stairs to an area with toilets and a gift shop. A final lift took us outside again.Following the blue line you reach the engine room which shows off Victorian engineering ingenuity to great effect.There was the option to have a combined ticket to include The Monument.Well worth a visit for all age groups. Allow 20 to 30 minutes in total.

never get fed up of this sight.. I've walk, driven see inside and ran over this bridge. I have such great affection to the classy build if you visit London spend the time to go inside and get the wonderful photos in the day and at night

Majestic.. This is by far the most beautiful and majestic bridge I''ve ever seen. I must have dozens of photos of it. Next time we'll definitely make an effort to find time to see the exhibition. A great place to take photos is from the south side of the Tower of London.

The road to the Poppies. Coming across this wonderful bridge to see the sight of the poppies at the tower of London was amazing.Whether you know of someone who fought, was lost, killed or wounded in a war, or if you have someone still serving this is sooo worth seeing. It is a once in a lifetime chance & we should all take it. If it weren't for the people who fought these wars, I wouldn't have the freedom to write this today, indeed I wouldn't even be here. Wars still go on, & we need the younger generation to know that which has gone before, & to try & prevent more of the same in the future.
The most beautiful bridge. This is without a doubt the most beautiful bridge I've ever seen. Walking across; viewing from the Tower of London and Southbank. Every angle is exquisite.

Great if your an engineer.. We were really looking forward to our visit but left disappointed. Engineers would love it though. We paid £7.00 each which for London is relatively cheap I suppose. Was it worth the money? In one word no. The best part was the engine room but having said that it didn't excite us. Disabled and elderly visitors would not be able to negotiate some areas.

Rather disappointing. I took my son up here during recent half term week as he couldn't remember an earlier visit about 6 years ago. Disappointing really in that it hasn't updated their presentation at all, one of the walk ways was closed and this wasn't detailed at reception at all. Good view the one way, but we left feeling rather underwhelmed after exiting via the gift shop of course!

What a view. We visited the Tower Bridge after a long day put at the tower of London. It was so worth the money. The exhibition was very well presented and the guides showed how to open some of the windows so we could take better photos of the view from the top. We had a reduction because they are preparing a further exhibition experience which is not yet completed. There were interesting videos to watch and the engine room (for a non-technician like myself) was fascinating.
Quick visit. It was a wet Sunday and we saw this advertised. It opened at 9.30am. |The views were amazing and all the Staff were helpful. There were good explanatory boards and video.

Poppies - a Sea of Red. My first trip to see the Tower Bridge, by the time we got through all the poppies it was night, and the bridge was beautiful, all the lights reflecting on the water, we walked from one end to the other and its well worth visiting especially in the late afternoon or evening.

interesting. Loved learning about the history of this iconic landmark and the views from the top were greatOne walkway was closed but we were immediately offered a free souvenir program by way of compensation

Included on the London Pass - so why not?.... the London Pass was a great buy for us - we did lots of things we wouldn't have normally done - this was one of them. I don't like heights and am a bit claustrophobic but we went here on a quiet day and I relied on my husband to take pictures across the high bit while I walked to the other side - not too bad at all really. All very interesting and the engine room was beautifully kept with lovely shiny engine things! As you can tell I'm not that bothered about mechanisms etc but it was still really nice to see!So yes - well worth a visit!...

Weekend in london. Very interesting to see how the bridge worked in the Victorian times, amazing construction. Very good value, only seven pounds per adult. Great views from the enclosed walkway along the bridge, higher than road traffic. Great to see examples of other amazing bridge constructions around the world in the exhibition and it also shows you what birds can be seen along the Thames, kingfishers for example! And also fish found in the Thames, crabs and sea horses! Well worth a visit.

£7 well spent. walked up to this beautiful bridge without realising you can go inside, up the tower and across the walkways, before descending in to the engine room. The whole experience was relaxed, easy and uncrowded with great views across the city, including HMS Belfast

Nice.. We joined the tour. Our first step is the tower bridge. Our hotel is right next to it and can just walk to the bridge. It is nice to walk on it at night to enjoy the view; to see the buildings. Then you can also come down and walk along the Thames river. There are many seafood restaurants along the way. will recommend it.

Beautiful & Historic. One of the prettiest bridges. I'll never forget walking across it on my first day in London, heading to the Tower. Stopping mid-span to take in the views of the city, reveling in the fact that I was finally in London was a heady moment!

A historical icon. Only walked across it to get to The Tower of London for the Blood Swept the Lands and Seas display but never done that before. One of London's and Britain's icons. So nice to so close up. A must visit and do. Pedestrian and vehicular access no issue. Didn't do the Tour this time, will next.

Enchanting at night. I visited at night when all the lights were on. It was just a beautiful sight. We walked on the bridged and then climbed down to the river side and walked along the Thames. It was very beautiful!

Blood Swept Land & Seas of Red. You only have until the 11/11/14 to catch this wonderful tribute to our fallen heroes of the First World War. Go if you can, it is a sight to behold. 888,246 red poppies will eventually span the moat of the most iconic London site, the Tower of London and it makes for a very moving sight indeed.My family and I went early morning (before 10 am) on a Saturday and, though busy, it was quite manageable and orderly. Once you see it, it's easy to see why this tribute has so caught the imagination of the the British public - my whole family (aged 8 - 70 yrs) were extremely impressedWe intend to go back next weekend and see it again under lights. I have been very lucky in being able to buy one of these little ceramic works of art and plan to travel to Normandy next year to plant it on my father's grave. He was killed in WW2 and is buried in a military cemetery near Caen.
Informative. One of the walkways was closed as they were preparing for a new exhibit. It was raining which limited our view. The tour was quite informative and worth the visit.

One of London's most iconic landmarks and a must see attraction.. We have visited London's iconic "Tower Bridge" on numerous occasions over the last couple of years as we've explored London with our two kids. I also remember visiting it about 40 years ago with my Grandma!Built in 1886-1894 the bridge is such a wonderful sight spanning the busy Thames River and it's great to walk across and to stop and 'boat watch' for a while. Also traditional Red London Buses go back and forth across it as well as the famous Black Cab's... It is typical LONDON. There is much to do in this area such as the Tower of London, from which the bridge gets its name, HMS Belfast and a bit further down the river St. Pauls Cathedral and Shakespeare's Globe Theatre can be found.I have yet to go into the engine rooms and up to the top span of the bridge, something I want to do, but just a simple and free walk across and around this magnificent historic bridge is a must.Note: I have included images that I took on visits in Nov 2014 as well as back in Feb 2103 (Very different weather)!

Poppy visit. So so beautiful and worth going to. Went on a Monday at about 11:30am and it was quite busy but worth it, walk around the queue coming out of tower gateway station as it doesn't go anywhere.

Magnificent tribute!. Our main aim for this visit to London was to see the poopies at Tower bridge. There has been so much coverage through the media and because the Legion is very close to our hearts it was important to pay our respects.We were blown away, we caught the tube from Waterloo, got off early as the tube became unbearable, it was half term and everyone was eager I believe to pay their respects as well and tour the tower.From the very start we were mesmerised. The staff, the security, the atmosphere were all pretty amazing. Indeed one needs patience for this, but everyone it seemed did have.We are forever grateful to the men and women that died for us, lest we forget!The ceramic poppies were indeed flooded around the tower's. It was breath taking and one cannot comprehend this unless u viewed it. I believe each poppy has been made with love, they are so unique.A wonderful day out and a magnificent tribute to commemorate WW1, in its centennial.Thank uKas and Richard Westray

Majestic. It is impossible to visit London and not see this amazing masterful bridge. Take a trip under it on a river cruise, walk over it or take a sight seeing bus over it. You wont be disappointed. There is a pub close by on the north side called the Liberty Bounds which sells good priced food and beer and soft drinks.

great day out. very interesting tour. Really enjoyed all the information given Can be packed at certain times. London has so much history that this is interesting for all members of the family. You can easily spend 4 or 5 hours here

Excellent. Excellent attraction well laid out and easy to get around, only snag a lot of stairs. Graphics very good and short videos easy to watch, although a few more seats would have been good. Windows on bridge crossing were very clean and some open so that you could take photos.Engine room also very good with good displays, and again easy to get around, although exit through shop was difficult as it was crowded.Price was reduced because they were doing work - not many places do that!

Fab family day out, very cheap.. This not been our first visit to London we decided to do the historical sights. I wasn't sure what to expect at first but it was way better than I could have imagined. The history and detail of the bridge was fantastic, you could feel the history. The price also made this a bargain, we paid less than £10 for 2 adults and 1child, we had a 2 4 1. I would ask you to show me anywhere else in the city that have fantastic views for such a small cost. Amazing, well worth a visit.

Tower bridge Exhibition. Two tickets £14 booked on line before we went,but easy to get on the day, this included a trip round the engine rooms, very interesting. Better to go early as people tend to be queing a little later in the day.
Really great by night!. Do walk across the Tower Bridge by night. It's so much better then. Lighting and the lit London busses add to the atmosphere.

Make sure you find a 2 for 1 offer to make a visit to Tower Bridge Experience worthwhile.. This really is a lovely way to spend an hour in London, but because it is only an hour (or maybe two), make sure you find a 2 for 1 offer to get the best value for money from this place, it would be expensive at full price! The views along the river and over the Tower are wonderful from the walkway at the top - look out for the little windows to get the best from your photographs without glare from the windows! Lifts are available for those who struggle with stairs although the stairs are wide and solid so perfectly fine for most visitors. My other half found the engine room facinating at the end of the visit but most of it went over my head!

The most beautiful . . .. In my opinion, this is the most beautiful view in London! From the bridge, all the major historical sights can be seen. You can also watch the traffic on the Thames - the heartbeat of the city.

Nice view of london. interesting site, it includes history, and you can spend all the time you want admiring the view of london from top of the bridge. the most famous bridge in the world it you can't miss it.

Very nice. It is a very nice bridge to see. It is not like any other bridge. It is nice to see it at night and during the day. There is no fees to go on the bridge. Many people think this is the london bridge but it's not. The london bridge is a very simple and normal bridge.
Tower Bridge. Tower Bridge, located near the Tower of London, thanks to which its got its name, is a wonderful piece of Victorian design. It's pretty, accessible and close to the Tower!

Superb unknown views. Visited the Tower Bridge experience on 29.10.14. Booked tickets online (good discount) and also combined them with entrance to the Tower of London - well worth a looksee. The queue lasted for about 20 minutes and then we were taken up by lift to the walkways across the River Thames. There were stairs as an option to walk up but we forego these! An information film was shown about the competition and history of the bridge and then we walked across the walkways, taking loads of photos as we did. The east walkway was closed (aware of this on the website before we left) but still the views were superb. We then walked down various levels and exited outside where we were directed to the engine rooms, the original ones from Victorian times. After a visit to the shop (mainly touristy bits) we emerged back into the rain, very impressed by the history and scale of the most famous bridge in the world.
A walk across the River. A bridge is a bridge but Tower Bridge is beautiful, there was a museum type thing you could go and see but we were just passing by

Interesting. This attraction is interesting and provides you with a super view of the Thames. Worth knowing that the start of the tour takes you up to level5 in a lift. There are no toilets up there, so to access toilets you have to go over the bridge walkway and go down stairs and then go back up the stairs before you can carry on with your walking tour. It is worth knowing if you have children with you, as I would suggest toilets before you go in to the attraction!! Other than that, there is a nice passport for kids to complete with stickers, which were well received by my family.

What a Bridge!. Me and my family came to London for the weekend and on the list of "must see's" was London Bridge. It is indeed spectalar up close and from a distance. We got a good photo of us in front on it from the south side of the Thames. It's going to make a good Xmas card! Loved walking over it and then going over it in the bus. Just a wonderful sight to see.

Lovely views. I didn't even know these top bits were walkways!The tour took us about an hour in total... part guided part video information... very informative we went on a rainy day but it was still pretty spectacular :-)
Ground zero for London sightseeing. Beautiful bridge and views of the city. Heavily traveled by both pedistrians and vehicles. Hop on/off busses will let you off there to cross on foot if you like.

My visit of the Tower Bridge. In 2012, I went 5 days to London with my school. There, I had the opportunity to visit the Tower Bridge. In the beginning of the visit, there was a video showing us the construction of this famous bridge. Then, in the two corridors above, there was an exposition with all sort of pictures of the famous bridges in the world. There were also some games. I found it interesting and what I liked most is the fact that we could benefit from a wonderful view of London. I would recommend it to all the visitors of London ;-).

Good, but could've been better. I had been looking forward to touring Tower Bridge for some time & persuaded my wife & kids to join me. We bought tickets online for both the Tower Bridge Exhibition & Monument. The bridge itself was interesting to tour and offered good views of the area, but I was disappointed when I learned that the exhibition didn't allow access to the areas under the bridge where the massive 400-ton bascules are housed - hence only a 3/5 review

Tower of London...a must!. I had always wanted to visit The Tower of London and my visit coincided with the poppy exhibition.....absolutely awesome. I saw it in the darkness of my first evening and again in the sunshine of the following morning before hundreds of visitors did likewise. Breath taking...I felt so humbled.Inside the Tower is like travelling back in time. We were there early and in the morning sunshine and in the absence of the hundreds of visitors about to descend, probably we were very fortunate. What a fabulous place, steeped in history, like a time capsule.The coffee shop is superb, beautiful food and coffee and not over-priced either. We dragged ourselves reluctantly out of the gates and back to 2014.

Tourists everywhere. Expect a lot of tourists, and I mean a lot! It was busier than we expected and if you go to the right side of the bridge you will be standing in line for hours from the looks of it. We decided to take a route to the left side of the bridge where there were way less people and we had all the room and time to take photo's and look at it without people pushing on us. Also on that side you can find restaurants (a bit expensive). Definitely worth it to walk over the bridge to see it up close, it is busy but worth it. An added bonus: When you arrive on the other side you can keep walking and visit Borough Market , it is lovely!

Fabulous view of the Thames - entrance on London Pass. We visited the Tower Bridge Exhibition on our London Pass and were pleasantly surprised. We enjoyed breathtaking views from the walkways of the Thames and its banks. We learnt about the Bridge's amazing history via displays and interesting films and then descended into the Engine Rooms and learnt all about steam engines and how they ran the bridge. Well worth the visit - took us 1-2 hours

too many tourists ruins it. Keep the visit to the outside.the little expo inside gives you infos that you can find in a good travel guide or on internet.yes you can walk through the upper part of the bridge but i dont think it's worst the price of the tour (unless it's included in your London pass)if you want the view of London, go to the London eye, more expensive, but better.but it's the tower bridge, so you have to see itlittle extra tip. from the south side of the bridge, try to go via the road and not via the stairs from the border of the water, you will wait 10min for the tourists to understand that the little stairs can fit only one fat guy at a time without blocking everyone.
poppies. This is a must see if you are going into London was totally amazing!That's it Just go and see for yourselves!

Surprise tour. I did not realise visits to Tower Bridge were possible. We took the tour on the spur of the moment and found the whole experience fascinating and exciting. From the ticket/entrance hall we were whisked up to the top of the bridge to the walkways and into a history of the Thames crossings and the differing designs for the bridge, ending with the design and build of what we see today.The route then takes you across the upper bridge steelwork, which is glassed in with no sheer drops. The views are stunning and give an entirely new perspective to the bridge. The visual displays and diagrams are truly excellent as is the film of the construction.If you are keen to see the "engine room" do follow the Blue line as the Victorian machinery is really well presented.Certainly a "budget beater" tour with prices for 1 adult £7-00. I recommend this tour!

A must! The sea of red poppies is awesome!. Really worth the effort of getting to Tower Bridge to see this truly wonderful, one- off, display of a sea of red poppies; simply beautiful! Very busy though and tube lines down this weekend, comme toujours! But we took a tax there and had a fantastic walk back along the Southbank shimmering in all its glory in the twilight and took in all the sights: St Paul's, Millennium Bridge, Tate Modern & the National Theatre etc. Go see!

Worth a look. Came 'free' with our tickets for the London Eye and Madame Tussauds and to be honest we enjoyed it more than the later!It is being refurbished and we could only visit one walkway, but the views towards the Tower of London were great and the engine room was interesting.

DON'T MISS THIS ICONIC BRIDGE!. this is my 2nd visit to this bridge and i am still in enjoying the stunning view of the bridge itself from afar! it's a bridge like no other! the architectural design is just amazing. it's even more worth the visit when you can witness the bridge lifting (i did it on my first visit) but this time around. you can check the bridge lift schedule/time in their website.

Amazing poppies. The poppies are there for all to see, you don't need to do the Tower they are amazing,we did not have enough time with only 3 hours but very interesting. Do the Crown Jewels before queues get too long!

A Different Walk Across The Thames. Once I found out that you could walk across the top of Tower Bridge it was something I just had to do. It is a really worthwhile " touristy " thing to do. Great fun. Great views of The Thames from a completely different angle & best of all as I am always after a bargain it is really really good value. Have only experienced this once but could easily do again as the views of The Thames are so different at different times of day & year. Give it a go. Families will love it as also very informative.

Lovely Bridge. The Tower Bridge is one of the most iconic attractions in London. A really majestic and beautiful bridge, it offers excellent photo opportunities. Great views of other iconic buildings in London (Gherkin, Tower of London, Canary Wharf). Highly recommended to visit.

Interesting history and tour of the bridge. Visited with family on a very window day and only one of the upper walkways was open due to having a glass floor fitted in the other one (will be a very interesting view once complete). The tour included a couple of short films, walk over the upper walkway (with information boards and views over London), a walk through the old engine rooms, and a visit to the gift shop. The entire tour lasted just long enough to keep an interest and not too long for the kids to get bored. An interesting tour to learn about the history of the bridge.
Great history and views. I went to the Bridge immediately after the Tower. It's well worth a look around and I enjoyed the view. The historical show was worthwhile and not boring by any means.
Worth a Visit. Interesting Landmark of London. Great views of the Shard, Tower of London, the Gerkin and the Thames. West walkway is best for the views.

Great Attraction. I took my three children here today (aged 13, 11 & 7). We had a wonderful time!It was a very busy day as thousands of people had come to see the ceramic poppy exhibit at the Tower at half term, but the Tower Bridge Exhibition was not crowded at all.It was good value (£6 for an adult and £3 for a child I think - reduced because part of the bridge is closed at the moment), took us about 1 hour in total and was interesting, fun and not exhausting.Just the right amount of fun and interest for every age. A great view from the walkway between the two towers. Really good films that show the idea and construction of the bridge. Beautiful engine room. A great, little sticker project for the children to collect stickers which my 7 year old loved (free). There is a lift for going up the tower.I bought the guide book but we didn't need it at all as there is loads of well presented information as you go around the exhibition. Some nice souvenirs in the shop as well as the opportunity for a professional photo and a funny machine that changes 1 pence coins in to special "Tower Bridge" coins! (For £1)We all loved this trip - well worth it if you have a spare hour.

Tower Bridge. I had a joint ticket for the Monument and this. Unfortunately there were at least 3 groups of kids from different elementary schools so it was quite crowded when I visited.I enjoyed the experience nonetheless. The exhibition of the bridges of the world was interesting and also the information about Tower Bridge itself and about how it was built and how the engines work.And needless to say, the bridge is iconic and a must see!
Tower Bridge. Very good. Kids enjoyed the treasure hunt. Had an good section for the kids to understand engineering behind it.

Tower Bridge Experience. Another "if you have a pass and time" place to visit, which is easy to tie with a Tower of London visit. The Tower Bridge Experience starts in the middle of the bridge (same side as the Tower of London) and consists of four main parts. After a ride (can be a bit of a packed elevator), you get to sit and watch a 5 minute, somewhat cheesy video about how the bridge came about. You can then walk along the walkways (only one side is currently open) to experience the rather obscured view, check out placards on one side about the history while the other side shows famous bridges across the world. I found myself more interested in the latter, but that view is even more obscured by the other walkway. At the far end is another video about the building of the bridge (only watched a few second), before you climb down to a level with another elevator that takes you back to the bridge. From here you walk to the end to the engine room building to get a view of steam operations of the bridge (make sure you keep your ticket, since you need it to enter here).I found the engine room the most interesting.

Average. Was my first trip to London, and was down for the England game. I enjoyed the walk over the top of the Bridge, but not sure it was worth the price. The weather wasn't the best either so the view was spoilt a bit. Obviously that isn't there fault, but it's worth considering if it's a bad day and you're thinking about going. The museum and photos weren't my cup of tea, but plenty seemed interested in it.

Excellent at day and night. At night, it was totally awesome to take a walk over the bridge from Tower Hill Station to London Bridge Station. At Day, sitting on a bench at the riverside was totally worth it. The Bridge is beautiful at day and night, but I would not recommend to walk over it before dusk.

Bridge museum on wet day. It's great to walk over bridge but thought "museum" was bland - mainly pics of old London and other famous bridges - to be honest better info on Google! Need more interactive or well defined information - there is a introduction film show with did a reasonable job of showing brief history and construction but felt there should be better construction and history info.Included is visit to the "engine" room which at least had some moving parts .... These guys need to visit SS Great Britain in Bristol to really see how a piece of historical static history can be bought o life - for price - couple is seniors about £7 on this day because it was reduced due to dome refurb work - so maybe improvements on way.With London on of best places in world to visit this particular attraction is ok for passing or quick visit but do not miss out on something else - viewing from outside is the best experience particularly if you lucky enough to see bridge raise.

Tower Bridge from the river. We took a City Cruises tour on the Thames and passed close to Tower Bridge and the Tower of London. This is a spectacular construction with very interesting detail and features. Particular interesting to see from water's level. Well worth a visit.

Very interesting experience. I loved the Tower Bridge Experience which gives info on why and how the tower bridge came to be.You take an elevator to the top of the tower where you watch a movie about the start of the bridge and then you are free to walk through the walkway where there were exhibits on other notable bridges around the world. You proceed down some stairs for more exhibits and eventually you go outside where you follow a blue line down to the engine room. I declined that experience and left at that point.It was not expensive to visit the tower and I felt it was a good use of my time.

Raised above the rest! . I think that this was an enjoyable and insightful trip to one of London's most iconic tourist destinations. The exhibition took us around 45 minutes to complete but I imagine that this could take longer as a section was closed for refurbishment on our visit and there is lots of information posts to read! The climb to the top feels very victorian and there is a mix of videos, signange and views to create a decent experience.In all honesty I think that this is a bit of a hidden gem. The area does get very crowded but the staff were efficient enough to keep things moving and the cost was reduced to match the fact that a small area is closed at the moment. I initially thought that this was going to be a dull look at how a bridge works however there is so much more to it and I left feeling very impressed!
Good view. It wasn't expensive to get in. The displays were nicely done. And the view from the bridge is pretty nice.
Worth doing. Kids loved the views and the pictures. And the bridge opened as we were above it. Was worried they'd be bored but at eight and six they found it interesting.

"London icon". The Tower Bridge one of the landmarks of the British capital, The Tower Bridge is probably the most famous building prägenste and London. Once there, you understand why. The bridge piers stick out like a huge fortress protecting towers in the London sky and keep the giant with a construction of steel and concrete, the drawbridge over the River Thames. Direct lustful next to the Tower of London, it offers a panoramic view of the River Thames. From there you can start as a London-Tourist's walk in the City. For this purpose, the Thames Walk is recommended.

Interesting. My girlfriend and I wanted to walk over tower bridge, when we got there we found you could pay £5 to go up the tower! These was interesting and inspiring! Great views and history! A welcomed surprise!

Interesting and good value. Visited a few months ago with my two young children. The staff were really friendly and helpful which always scores points with me!The exhibition is informative with some interactive points. There's also a couple of videos to watch. The views of course are fantastic.You then go down and back outside and walk along to the engine rooms. Really interesting to see how it all works!Been 2 or 3 times and always enjoyable.

Inspiring. At £7 the Tower Bridge tour is a steal. No reason to add the details as so many others have done, I will just say that it's truly inspirational to walk in the footsteps of giants. The men who conceived and created these elaborate Victorian structures were part of one of the greatest modern generations; a generation that left a tremendous intellectual legacy in the arts and sciences that hasn't been replicated since.These types of structures simply wouldn't be built today. A walk through the Tower Bridge gives one a good perspective on just how amazing the Victorians were, and just how far we have declined since that time. From the walkways one can see a comparison in those hideous concrete monstrosities that represent the nadir of 20th century design.Highly recommend the tour but maybe not during the weekends. There were queues for the lifts even though it was a very slow working day in London.
Tower Bridge Lovely river walk & views. Early evening and late night walk after dinner at Browns in Butlers Wharf. Beautiful view of London and Canary Wharf etc - no cost involved.

Engineering Marvel.. A delight. As an engineer I truly appreciated this exhibition. Other reviewers seem to have thought it tedious. Perhaps they need to spend their time elsewhere! To them. Go ride the EYE! This exhibition is most well done and shows the Victorian engineering excellence of those who saw a need and worked to make it happen. Quite well done. Well worth the time.
very nice. it's the best way to get a look at the city from the river. It offers great views and quite interactive learning how the bridge was build.

Impressive inside and out.. We visited the last week of September 2014. This was included in our London Pass and it is next to the Tower of London. Everyone knows what the outside looks like and the inside is just as amazing. A short elevator ride to the top and the walk along the top provides great views along the Thames east and west. Photos of famous bridges line both sides. A short film on the south side, then walk down to the bridge deck and follow the blue line to stairs that go down at the south bank to the engine room. The engine room is very clean and easy to navigate. I was suprised at the size of the equipment to move such a large bridge deck. This experience is worth the effort.

Classic, free, and full of history.. Tower Bridge (often mistaken for London Bridge) is a must visit on any trip to London. There are great views, lots and lots of history, beautiful architecture, and best of all it is all free! London Bridge is easy to access with so much public transport (tube, DLR, and bus) all being nearby. All of the open top bus tours also go over the bridge and stop on the northern side. It's great to walk across the bridge and take in the sights up and down the river along with the beauty of the bridge itself. Kids will love watching the bridge open an close, you can find out when this will happen (normally several times a day) by searching on Google. But there is more to the bridge than waking across it. There is more to see under either side, including the original steam room on the south side. There is also a museum in the north side of the bridge but you need to pay for this one. If you are travelling by tube your best bet is to get off at Tower Hill and walk down the Tower of London side of the bridge, cross over, and then walk back on the other side. Best time to see the bridge is a sunrise and the sun comes up over the river. The bridge is also one of the best places to get photos of the tower of London from. If you want to get a bus across the bridge but don't want to pay for the open top tours there is a bus stop on the north side of the bridge.

Was not expecting such a nice tour. Took the family on the Tower Bridge Tour - incredible views, cool stuff to see - not very crowded when we went, which was fine with me! Small program at the start of tour after that you're on your own - pretty cool -

Must see attraction in London. A beautiful bridge. The exhibition contains very interesting pictures of various bridges around the world. The tour to engine room is very educational for children and adults. Kids really enjoy watching the bridge open for ships. My son also enjoyed the London Bridge "passport".
Very Nice attraction. Very nice views from the top. The pump room was amazing. I wish I was there to see them work. Worth a look and no need to climb stairs.

By day or by night, what an amazing bridge.. I got to see this by day and by night. It is grand and its structural design and engineering leaves you wondering how it could have been achieved. We chatted to people along here and looked at it from below the bridge and walking along it looking down the Thames. You can see so many places from on the bridge. Photo opportunities galore.

A really memorable experience. Hubby and I decided to go along to visit the Tower of London the other weekend to see the Poppies in the moat 'Blood swept lands seas of red ' display and it was wonderful. We arrived around 4.30pm in order to have a good look round the moat and then walked through to St Katherine's docks on a wonderful evening. We decided to opt for the fish and chips sold right next to the Tower for our tea and at £7 a portion they were hot and good value. We the. Went round the docks which are within easy walking distance of the tower . Seeing the Queens brave on display was a bonus the docks were lovely . Lots of little shops restaurants and cafés . We walked round along the Thames embankment and eventually did a whole circle in order to catch the 'Reading of the names' at sunset being 6.35pm that day and hearing the last post played was so touching.We walked back down along the the embankment past City Hall looking back at Tower Bridge now lit up in all it's glory. A wonderful evening and so memorable

A beautiful craftmanship. I love walking over this bridge with the magnificent Tower Of London in its view.An achievement of engineering and style that will never date. A must see when you are in London. You may be lucky to see the bridge raising for ships to pass. It you are luck to see this try and see this from a different viewpoint..... it truly priceless!!

what a landmark. such a beautiful piece of arhitecture, beautiful views from on the river and below, we saw it from both angels and enjoyed it all. met many people and made friends through enjoying the scenery

Picturesque. My hotel was located in close proximity to the Tower Bridge. Therefore, the first day of our trip we visit the Bridge. My family and I were in awe of the engineering and structural design. The finally day of our trip we revisited the Tower Bridge by night. The views were simply breathtaking.

we loved it. we stayed here in June with our 14 year old granddaughter as she has been selected to sit on the youth advisory council and has to travel from Durham to London once a term, we are travelling to London again at the end of October and have booked the Novotel Tower Bridge again, it is in a lovely spot and easy access to the tube,we travelled to Angel Islington for her meeting, we went to Canden market and went to see Billy Elliot at the Victoria Theatre so absolutley no problem with travel it was all very easy, we had a great time and looking forward to returning

Amazing bridge. Have to admit the Exhibition fell short of my expectations,however some upgrade work was underway during our visit which may improve matters.That said it is worth doing just for the experience of walking the upper walkways between the towers.Fantastic views although photography is limited by the bridge infrastructure.Most interesting exhibits are the engine rooms do not miss this.

Brilliant. This is well worth a visit. But I think you have to be an adult to appreciate the makings of this amazing bridge. Its well worth the money and mind blowing how they actually constructed it and lifts to let ships pass through.

Great views and history. Walked past the exhibition entrance on the bridge many times.Decided to take the time to visit the exhibition. Great staff. Informative presentations and amazing views.The engine room was a great experience too.Well worth a visit

Walking into a wonder!. I'm so impressed what people can do when they are innovators! Noone should miss this sight and the opportunity to see the view of Thames and of course how perfect this bridge used to operate. Really amazing, worth the ticket and to spend some time.
Awesome views. Loved the views of the city, and as my son is Autistic and on disability, we both received free entry

A highlight of our capital. A truly beautiful bridge that i have had the pleasure of driving over as well as sailing under and seeing it opening up too.My personal preference was walking along the thames after we left our lunch cruise and saw it from there.I will visit it internally on our next visit.A must see.

October 2014. On a recent trip to London, I walked passed this exhibition and saw that they had a special offer of £7 entry fee with the engine rooms included. This was a good deal, I have being to visit this exhibition earlier in the year and tickets not including the engine rooms were over £10. You go up in a lift, to watch a short video explaining why there was a need for such a tower. You then walk across the walkway which includes information and photos of towers throughtout the world. You get some amazing shots. This was a really interesting visit and I would recommend this for any visitor to London.

Lovely views. The bridge itself is spactacular, but I was disappointed in the Tower Bridge Exhibition. The views of the City from the top level were amazing! The "engine room" was interesting, but not what I expected, and frankly, not what I wanted to see.
Good views..... It's a great piece of art! It makes Amazing pictures but the True It's That it doesn't have a lot to see inside beside the Amazing views... For me the ticket was expensive....

Stunning piece of English History. I have lived in South London my whole life and Tower Bridge is a short walk from my home. I regularly go down to the bridge with my family and it is simply beautiful to look at. An amazing piece of architecture that you will find no where else. Certainly worth seeing. I have also been on the Tower Bridge Experience where you can go inside the bridge to see how it works etc. This is also very interesting and worth a visit as it is no very expensive and you can go all the way up to the top bridge and from there you get amazing views of the city of London. Give it a go travelers and Londoners!

Beautiful place and romantic. The tower bridge is a very cool place. I was there at night with my cousins and my brother. It's a nice stop, speacially during the night because of the lights of the bridge. A classic from London and a must go place.

From the outside... You hear so much and expect so much.. The tower is great architecture and we didn't get time to go inside but was a little unassuming. Still an icon and worth ticking off the list!

Amazing architectural landmark. Not much too say other than, "Wow!" ... what a piece of work ... in a good way. We took some great pictures from the Tower of London exit. The city has kept it in great shape ... too bad it wasn't sunny!

Good value!. I work in London and can see the Tower Bridge from my office and have been promising myself this day trip for 3 years. Finally I have managed to fulfil my promise and thoroughly enjoyed it. We were lucky to receive a £2 discount as only one of the walkways was open but the views down the river were amazing. It was interesting to read all the information about the bridge and also to see details and pictures of so many other famous bridges.At £9 per person this attraction is a must for anyone visiting London!

Fantastic experience. This is a fabulous monument and if you can go inside it's worth a visit because the building if a fantastic work of architecture and the machine part were you can see how the bridge works is very interesting the best way to see some of the monuments is to get the london pass and it will work out must cheaper and som monuments became free and you get a fast track.

Iconic London Architectural Beauty!. My husband and I walked the Tower Bridge and did the tour of the bridge as part of our London trip. I totally recommend the tour and museum. My husband really enjoyed learning how engineering of the bridge worked. It was interesting learning how the bridge was built. In addition to all of this, the bridge is a wonderful photo opportunity.

Iconic landmark. No pictures can do justice to this iconic and magnificent bridge in London until you have seen it for yourself.The surrounding area along the Thames holds a special, charming and romantic ambience and contributed to everlasting memories. Sitting along the Thames whilst admiring the magnificent bridge was a very special and unique experience!

Well worth a visit for history buffs.. Staff extremely helpful, the lift to the top of the tower is very quick. You would not know how high you were until you looked out of a window at the top. The guide was very informative on the journey up explaining how high we now were above the water.The brief introduction to the bridge was very informative although not to some people's tastes and allowed you to get some idea of what London was like before the bridge was built.Was a little disappointed that both walkways were not open but was still happy enough to walk along the East walkway, they did explain the at the West walkway was undergoing some reconstruction (one guide mentioned a hole in the floor, to which there was some nervous giggling). I enjoyed reading the boards along the walkway picking up little facts I had not known.The engine room was a sight to see, I was amazed that this is what helped the bridge to open and close in the past.Yes it was a little expensive for what there was to see but for the experience itself, I would quite happily pay it again.I, for one, am not good with heights but I felt happy and secure at all times especially as the walkways are enclosed. I do not think I would have attempted this had it not been so.
OK. Yes you need to do this but the Tower is much better to spend your time. The exhibition is out dated. Go see it then go someplace else

A functional monument that is a synonymous with London. Coming from NZ for the first time, I had grown up hearing about and seeing many pictures of Tower Bridge throughout 5 decades of my life. It was a joy to see this magnificent structure, walk over the bridge and view it from the Queen's Walk. I was amazed to realise that it is such a busy thoroughfare for traffic across the Thames and that spans of the bridge can still be opened to allow particularly tall vessels to pass under the bridge. The design and engineering of this bridge is a marvel, especially considering the time when it was constructed.

Disappointing. For such an iconic structure, the exhibition was poor, and there was really little attempt to make the experience interactive. Seeing the bridge from the outside, for free, is really the highlight.
Interesting Insight. An iconic landmark around the world, but how many people have seen the inside? Well-organised, informative, reasonable value and steeped in history (obviously!)

interesting visit. The organization was brilliant -- you could visit the inside of the bridge, while getting to understand how it came about. The design of the architecture was remarkable, and the way of presenting the piece of history and the piece of art was very smart. Walking through the bridge, get to know it inside out, and also get to know other world famous bridges was educational and fun. The trip ended with the engines room, which was impressive as well.
Interesting. We pre-booked our visit on line and saved a couple of pounds on the entrance fee. Interesting bit of history. Some nice views of the Thames and London from the upper walkways.

World famous for a reason!. Id never ever thought of reviewing the Tower Bridge itself. It must be said that this is one of the world's greatest landmarks and on a nice place to walk in the evenings. Would thoroughly recommend to anyone visiting the UK!

Definitely a must see. When you visit London you have to see Tower Bridge (which is often mistaken for London Bridge). There is so much to do nearby also, lots of restaurants and museums.I would recommend going soon to see the poppies, its a lovely display.

Neatest architecture ever!. This bridge is simply amazing! Gorgeous doesn't begin to describe the craftsmanship and care that went into this. You have to go inside and get a look at the old engines that powered this bridge. This is more artwork and than bridgework!

Worth doing. Good views, interesting film at beginning and end and the engine room is fascinating. We are so lazy in the UK though! When we go abroad anything like this is translated, or you are given headphones etc...neither film had anything other than English. Admittedly the information boards were in different languages but I for one thought the films the most informative.

Walk across the centre of London. One of the must do things in London is a walk across Tower Bridge on the upper walkway above the traffic. A short elevator ride up to see the sights and even a visit to the engine room to see how the bridge goes up.

Great atmosphere and amazing monument. Just a few steps out of Tower Hill station, you will find this monument. You will be instantly transported to another time where things were a bit shady... the atmosphere is amazing. No matter how crowded are the streets, you can enjoy a walk, under, over and around the bridge! Try some fish and chips while you admire it.

View the majestic, legendary Tower Bridge. A visit to London is not complete with visiting the Tower Brigde! Go for a late-afternoon stroll along the Thames for the best light of the day to enjoy the views of this bridge.

Nice. Tower Bridge (often mistaken for London Bridge) is a nice little exhibit. A top the tower you get a nice view of the Thames. The exhibit comes with a show about the history of Tower Bridge and the relevant engineering. But it's hardly "mind-blowing". The most interesting sight is when the bridge lifts to let boats pass, but note, that can't be really viewed while at the Tower bridge itself.

Poppies and History!. As a patriotic American I was thrilled to be able to experience the Poppy Exhibition and was humbled by the honor bestowed by the British to the many who gave the ultimate sacrifice in WWI. At this time in our Country when so many do not understand such willingness and sacrifice, it was a moving tribute for me to experience! The history of the Tower of London and The Tower Bridge were also amazing! Not to missed!

So Pretty. I don't know which I liked better, the outside view or the one from the inside! We took the tour and it was really quite amazing how it works and how there couldn't be lights on it during WWII because it was such a landmark. However, the view from the banks of the river at night just amazed me. You really feel like you're someplace special at that time. Great photo ops if you know what you're doing!
Poppies. What an amazing display- very humbling! Visited early on a Saturday morning - got very busy later in the day.

Iconic landmark, but a bit run down inside.. Tower Bridge is a 5 minute walk from the Tower Hill tube station and there is a walkway which also goes past the Tower of London leading onto the bridge itself. A lift takes you to the top of the first tower where there is a short presentation and video on how the Tower was built in the 19th century. Then you go out on to the walkway where there is an exhibition on how the bridges of the world were constructed. This exhibition was surprisingly interesting. The walkway is all enclosed so views of the Thames are restricted and photography is limited because of the iron railings and windows. After that you go down the stairs to the engine room exhibition where you can walk around the bridge lifting mechanism. At the end there is a gift shop with a very good range of London souvenirs. The exit is on the other side of the Thames river and you can walk back over via the road bridge to the other side. Tower Bridge is most spectacular from the outside, while the interior is old and slightly run down. The exhibition is just worth the price of admission. There are toilet facilities at the end of the walkways. On reflection, this attraction may be better combined with a visit to the adjacent Tower of London.

So much to see and absorb!. I was impressed with just how much there was to see at the Tower of London. There was history at every turn and most of the area open to the public. Currently the ceramic poppies in the grassy area around the tower grounds add a bit of newer history and a lot of color. It's definitely a sight worth seeing.

Famous. Nothing,nice surrounding area,and I am standing at the one of famous place on earth.Most of the people misunderstanding as London Bridge...This is Tower Bridge not a London Bridge.London Bridge is on the other side of the river.
Interesting and not too lengthy. We went here after Tower of London and this was more interesting than we thought. Well presented and educational also. Staff were great and overall a good experience.

Love the Tower Bridge. Which ever angle or direction you look at Tower Bridge, it is always amazing to see.But seeing it up close and personal, on a beautiful sunny London day is even more enjoyable.We walked across the bridge so we could see the installation of ceramicPoppies commemorating the fallen solderies of World War I.What an amazing sight and creative installation.It was very moving and touching, looking at the way the poppies would their way around the moat; fell out of some of the windows and down the walls.Also fabulous to know that this installation/idea has generated and raised so much money for charities in the UK - at the time of our visit at end of Sept. it was up to 11M pounds. A fabulous effort.The creators need to be congratulated.

Breathtaking Classic!. Having made two previous trips to London, we were chagrined to miss Tower Bridge at those time, so made certain to visit on our third trip in September 2013. It was our first day in the city, and after hours of walking in Covent Garden, lunch, and time to see the Tower of London, it was at last time for Tower Bridge. There's really not quite any view like it around. Anywhere. The bridge is brilliant and beautiful. An architectural an engineering wonder. One could stand looking at it for hours--from different angles, the same vantage point, or from a location on the bridge itself. We enjoyed taking photos, although it was nearing sunset, and it was fun to see what an incredibly popular spot it is for couples and groups taking photos with the bridge as a backdrop. Visitors seemed in such a happy,upbeat mood around this amazing and inspiring sight. It brings out good feelings in just being around it. And better yet--it's free. It costs nothing to stand along the Thames and just admire what man has made. We even climbed the steps in order to take a walk to the middle of the bridge and look out over the Thames at the London skyline. Regardless of the reputation it may have as a tourist spot, Tower Bridge really is a must see. Anyone visiting the eastern end of London should count it as an essential stop.

Beautiful Bridge. Tower bridge is a beautiful structure. Along with other structures, this one is easily recognisable as London, and a bit of a symbol for the UK really.For the best views/ photo opportunities i would recommend sunset or evening time when the bridge really stands out.

You have to do it simply because it's an icon. So, I was tired of hiking up stairs by the time I got to the top and because it was the end of the day, it was quite crowded, so my mood might have been off a bit - the only reason I didn't give it an average rating is because it is such a world icon. The views from the top of London are wonderful, but the best photos of London have this bridge in it, so I would say it's best to experience the bridge from the bankside, rather than going to the top.

A bit better than expected. We hadn't planned to visit Tower Bridge, but we had some time to kill, and I had always wanted to have a look round. We knew that the western walkway would be closed. The box office is quite small, and fortunately we did not have to wait very long. The film show at the top of the north tower was probably about long enough and fairly light hearted. It was a bit of a grey day, so the views were not fantastic. I liked the little windows where you could poke your camera out and get a better shot. We did not see much point in the film show in the south tower, and proceeded to the engine room. This attraction is fragmented, well it is a bridge, and you need to follow the lines on the pavement. The engine room was very good, although not in use, it is a good exhibition peice.From an accessibility point of view, firstly both the carer and disabled person go free, pleasent surprise. There are stairs, but I think if you contacted the bridge in advance a wheelchair user would be able to see most of the exhibits. On the upper walkways the view would be obstructed for someone who is seated.
An overrated bridge. Is like any other bridge, yes is nice, and important... Is something else?? NOOO only a bridge. I don't see what is the awesome part of the bridge.

fun &informative. a walk &tour around &in, the tower, with a talk from a beefeater, what fun & very interesting, the b.eaters name i dident catch as we were a few mins late joining the tour, it was so interesting, so much to see, so much i dident no, very very good, well worth the trip.

Tower Bridge. I may be biased being a Londoner but I think this is the most beautiful bridge in the world. The Gothic architecture is breathtaking and I was lucky enough on one occasion to witness it opening up, amazing! A lot of people don't realise that for a fee you can go inside and see the mechanics of the bridge and the museum. To see this bridge at its finest it needs to be seen at night when it is completely lit up.

We got our photo and that's about all.. This is definitely one of those attractions that you 'do to say you've done it'. If you aren't planning on doing anything else in the area it really is a bit of a let down. We caught the tube into Tower Hill, the area is nice enough, places to eat, nice greenery and the bridge itself is certainly different, a nice enough structure but once you have walked over it there really is nothing to see. We ended up doing the Queen's walk on the other side just so we felt like we had spent more time there but that too was quite underwhelming.

Fun experience, great views.. I was taken here for my birthday by my parents, we had booked in advance so went straight in and was taken up in the lift. The people working were really friendly and enthusiastic, especially the man in the end room talking about mayors? - made a joke about Boris Johnson!Was a really interesting experience especially to see all the buildings you could see from each side. Really excellent views, would recommend going just for those!Shop is quite cheap too, as we got vouchers for £4 off before going in.
Beatiful. One of my favourite places in London. I took lime 500 photos here. It is a must see during your stay in this city, its better to go at night when fhe bridge is lighted

beautiful structure. Didn't do the tour or anything like that (not our 'cup of tea'). Didn't pay anything or anywhere. To visit the bridge itself, it's free. And it's lovely. Great architecture and engineering marvel just walking around on it. It was a 'check the box' moment to visit, but worth it as the views on the bridge are wonderful. (I do have to say, lots of tourists, but let's be frank, that shouldn't be a surprise to anyone).

Style!. When most see this bridge, they think London Bridge, but that bridge is pretty mundane. The Tower Bridge is gorgeously medieval looking and is a perfect backdrop to the Tower of London. We did not take the tour in the bridge but we did go across and walk along the Thames on a beautiful sunny day that made the colorful bridge really stand out. A must see for any London first-time trip.

Baby friendly and great views of london. We visited on the 120th anniversary so it was very busy. it also only cost £1.20 on this day, I don't think I would pay full price.There are lifts go get up to all the levels, which is important for us as we had a double buggy with us. Also in the lift you get told extra information that you won't receive on the stairs. You learn about the history of the bridge and how it was built. On the actual bridge you can get some great views from a different perspectives on a clear day you can see further.At the end you check out the engine room.It's not a place you would spend hours, but it's interesting enough to check out.

Must visit. This place is beautiful and a must visit for anybody in london, there are many places to visit in the area as well, so explore Tower of London, Greenwich across the river while you there, as there are boats nearby.

Very moving - Thank you for doing this exhibition. We went to see the poppies and were struck by how many lives were lost in War, the sea of red seemed to represent not only the lives but the blood that has been lost in the name of War.The sad thing is that we still haven't learnt that war does not work.Make sure that you walk around all sides, as the cascade in the air over the bridge by the ferry is fantastic art and behind the tower you get the view of the bridge with the poppies.

Waste of Money. We paid the 7 quid (usually 9 but one side of the top corridor is closed) each to do the "tour", they take you into the elevator and to the top where you get to watch a movie and then walk across the corridor at the top that connects the two towers. It has pictures of different bridges around the world and you can read up on them. The tunnel is completely sealed so you are viewing inside of a glass tunnel but with parts of the bridge obstructing your view, terrible for pictures. The whole time the guides mention many times about the gift and souvenir shop, felt like or I should say, total tourist trap. Go to St Pauls and pay to goto the top of that, much better, London Eye or the Monument for other great views. You can also go visit the engine room (included in the price) to see the huge steam engines and pistons, that was some what interesting, which of course funnels you to the gift shop. Unless you are a fan of how bridges work, save your money and take pictures of the outside.
Waste of money. The exhibition is fun, but too short. It's great to see the bridge operating, but you can see it from outside.

A beautiful monument in London. Since I live in East London Tower Bridge and the Castle represents the access to London. From here you can start a tour and discover something of the Medieval history of the city. A walk around this big site surely worth a visit, especially at night when the bridge is illuminated. There are also some really nice places to eat.

Wonderful Engineering. I thoroughly enjoyed my visit here. It was face sting how the bridge was built. The engine house is well worth a visit. Views all the way around are quite incredible and I could watch the lifting of the bridge all day.

Beautiful structure. We chose not to do an organised tour and just see it on our own which was a good choice. We were lucky enough to be there on a sunny day and took pictures from both sides of the river. You only need 30 minutes or so to have a look and walk across.

Worthwhile !. This is a must do while in London, The views of the Thames from the middle of the bridge was amazing, The tour was very informative, I was hoping to see the draw bridge open as that would of been Interesting !

Worthwhile but not amazing. The visit was a little frustrating as you could not go at your own pace. My visit lasted just under an hour and the experience is split into five parts. Firstly you had to wait about ten minutes for the lift going up to get full. Once up there you could watch a short film and then move on to walk across both bridges. One had a general exhibition about bridges and the other had an exhibition about the Sixties. You could then use the toilets and collect a photo if you had had one taken and then it was another ten minute wait for a lift to take you downstairs where once outside on the bridge you had to follow a blue line to the engine room which was the last part of the tour - I saw visitors just leaving the attraction at this point. The engine room was for real ethusiasts but was worth visiting as it had a short film and the gift shop. I used my Time Credit vouchers from voluntary work.
