But I can see why I had never visited the Exhibition before!

Historic Engineering Feat - Great Attraction. This is one of London's greatest attractions. This wonderful tour gives you the opportunity to actually go up the ''Towers'' walk across the span and come down the other side. On the way, there are a variety of displays in relation to the engineering, the history and abundant photographic displays outlining it's lifespan since it was built. Once you have completed the towers display, you are treated to the bowels of the operation where you see how it all operates with the wonderful 18th century steam driven machines that enable the drawbridge to operate to allow the larger vessels access through the Thames. This is an A1 attraction and well worth the fee of entry. This is a world icon and the tour is well organised and demonstrated. Also, there are great views out over the Thames. (The Tower of London, The HMS ''Belfast'' and other great London points of interest). Definitely give this one a go!
Tower Bridge. Very informative tour, it was great to look at the 60's display as well as the view from the 2nd floor.

A must visit!!. If you are a movie buff then you must have seen this location several times on the big screen and if you are a bollywood fan then the view has been seen in almost every movie shot outdoor. The place is so beautiful that sipping a cup of coffee in the perfect London weather can do wonders to you mood. I visited this place several times during my stay in London and I must say you shouldn't miss the night view of this place.The view at night is just spectacular. Also during the day several times the road opens up to give way to the ships/cruise passing by. A must visit for everyone.P.S. enjoy the stroll across thames

Top of the world. We considered ourselves very lucky: the drawbridge went up while we were up on the top, apparently that only happens three times a day. We were tired from a day of sightseeing, but the staff was very friendly. The tour was not guided so we made our way through at our own leisurely pace, with views up and down the Thames. The exhibition is starting to look just a tad faded, but the engine room looks fantastic. I bet someone is going round with the oil can every day. Definitely one of the must-see items. Victorian engineering at its best.

Worth a visit. We had free entry with a London Pass. The short film was spoiled a bit by over-acting. I think they should just tell the story without the actors!, but its definitely worth taking an hour or so to go round. The bridge exhibition along the top of the bridge is interesting.
Great view. Great view of the Tower area and the Thames with the MS Belfast. The bridge was quite crowded and there was a lot of traffic.

Close look at structure, some info not so good. Going into the bridge exhibition is the only way to see its steel core, how it works, and enjoy great views from the high level walkway. We needed Wikipedia for technical information, and some engineering facts presented in the exhibition were inaccurate or confusing.The views from the high level walkway were a splendid way to see the city, and we enjoyed examining the steel structure of the bridge which is hidden by the masonry.There’s only limited information about how the bridge was built and how it works. One film which claims to show how the bridge was built is inaccurate at times, and conflicts with photos of the construction. E.g. a photo taken during construction shows the bascules being built in the vertical position so as not to block the river, while the modern film shows them being built while lowered, thus blocking the river.On entry do check when the bridge will open. If you’re on the high level walkway, you can just see the bridge below, and it’s a unique experience to watch it opening from above.No food is sold here. There’s one block of toilets (excellent cleanliness) which you reach by steps down when you are ready to leave the high level walkway (lift available for the disabled).Overall, the visit to the iconic structure is a delight, and a chance to see it up close, but if the engineering interests you, I’d suggest you’ll also want to read the Wiki article, which will tell you a lot more. It’s rather expensive to visit, but is probably the most famous bridge in the world.Special Warning: when we visited we noted a number of gangs running the 3 cup scam [see shell game in Wiki] around the Bridge. Don’t get involved, you will lose your money.
the bridge on the thames. We could see the bridge from our apt on the Thames. Beautiful at night. We walked over it many times. The nicest bridge in london.

Gorgeous!. What an absolutely gorgeous bridge and definitely an icon of London. We didn't get a chance to actually take the tour of the bridge (which was a shame), but we got to see it from the Tower of London and we walked over it, which was quite fun and allows you to really get a great view of it up close. This is something you have to see while in London because of its icon status, but it's something you'll want to see because of its beauty.

Very nice bridge. This is a very nice bridge, the architecture is good and well design. the bridge well maintenance and it still work until so many years.I love the night view of this bridge from the river Thames.Recomend to have a view from south side of the bridge.

shame about the 60's exhibition. Started really well the views are really good looking down towards the houses of parliament and the other side looking towards the east end. Sadly, I did think the 60's exhibition of 60s stars was very random and a bit strange. Surely the bridge has more to offer than some tacky photos of twiggy and the Beatles? Still worth a visit for the views though!

Highly educational. A must visit for engineering/architecture enthusiasts (or Sherlock holmes film fans). Videos are great, wish they had some more. Self guided tour mainly. Decent price for getting to see the structure from the inside, how many people get to see that! Beware if you visit the bridge after spending 3 hours in the Tower of London (package deals). There are lots of stairs, so make sure you are suitably fit and refreshed. Nice little gift shop at the end to look forward to.
Brilliant. I was surprised we could actually go up tower Bridge. It was fascinating and really enjoyable. Well worth doing.

Now THAT'S a bridge!. Victorian Britain and its "can-do" attitude has left us with this truly magnificent structure. Sure, you've seen countless pictures of it; after all, every TV show or movie you've ever seen set in London has to include the obligatory shot of Tower Bridge. If you're a tourist in London, don't enjoy the Bridge from afar or as a backdrop for family pics; walk on it or better yet, spring for the tour. The view from the upper walkway is most impressive and worth the price of admission. Think about all the cracked, crumbly, and in-need-of-constant-repair bridges you probably drive over weekly. Then, compare it to this breathtaking behemoth with its still-original innards (some still original, anyway), and you'll wish modern engineers and builders would take such pride in their work.
If you like Engineering.... This bridge has next to nothing to do with the Tower except that it is near it. Focused mostly on the steam that made the big pistons work.

Iconic London. We had already seen the bridge open the previous day from the ferry terminal so were very excited to actually climb it and see its innards. We had tickets to climb the pylon (you can take the lift as well). The walkways across have been covered so it was a little disappointing that we could not experience the sounds, smells and wind as well as the sights. It was all a little too comfortable really. The Victorian Gothic pylons are a brick facade. What is behind these are steel girders - all a little to ugly for the Victorians apparently. The Bridge was never bombed in the second WW as the Germans used it as a navigational aid. The engine room is fascinating. A series of boilers were used to burn cola to create steam which in turn ran hydraulic lifts for the bridge road way. It is of course now run by electric engines but the old steam engines are real beauties. TIP: Purchase your tickets on line and you can attend any time on the day.

OK value with the 2-4-1 coupon. IMO the views, history and workings of this draw bridge is interesting for most adults....not sure children would get very excited. The views from the top spans are fairly good but the way to get from one side to the other is a bit bothersome....cannot cross over except at one end then have to retrace your steps to proceed to the mechanical room at the far end of the bridge.

Walking on an Icon. We were not interested in the tour. Instead, we wandered our way along the Thames, enjoying the countless views of the bridge in daylight and after dark. It may not have been around as long as many other landmarks in London, but it is does take ones breath away.

If you ever been in London. This is the right place to go if you ever been in London. As a Civil Engineer I wasn't only fascinated by the outstanding architecture of the bridge, but also by the well ahead structural design at that period of time. Using layers of welded steel plates instead of the cables used nowadays, is a brilliant idea. Oh, forget about my Engineering nonsense, just go and enjoy the view, you won't regret it.

Good visit. Having previously visited decided to go this year with our son. We did 2for1 and our son was free, there was another door for pushchairs and wheelchairs and the staff were pretty quick in noticing me.It's fully accessible though I think a better place to have the disabled toilet would have been anywhere except right by the lift in the second tower especially as the toilet door opens outwards and there was a 'gentleman' in a wheelchair apparently thought it was okay to ram my pushchair as I came out the toilet when it was plain to see that there was nowhere for me to go. Luckily the lift door opened so I was able to escape before I was forced to take action, the staff seemed impotent to intervene even though they were inches away, just looking on and when I told the woman operating the lift what happened she just looked at me blankly.The gift shop was reasonable, I bought my son a magnet and a badge. To get to the engine room/gift shop level you have to follow the blue line to use a small lift which is signed but hardly noticeable, after you go down you continue to follow the blue line to the engine room, one of the engines moves which facinated my son, there was a short film which he also enjoyed. The were models on the wall which he could turn handles to operate which he also enjoyed. They also gave my son a sticker card and he collected stickers from around the bridge and gift shop, but we had to keep a keen eye out for staff to ask even though my son was clutching the card in his hand.However, all in all a nice visit and would come again another year.

someone happened to find a SD card here. 17th of September was the the day of my visit to tower bridge as well as the tower of London. The best and the worse thing happened at the same time.The best thing is I happened to witness the ceremony in remembrance of the british heroes who died during the WWI and there was an centenary event, the venue garden was full with ceramic poppies. After that I went up to the bridge and took out my SD card and replaced with a new one.When I got home from the trip I found the SD card which was taken out was not in my bag! It was gone. The card contained a previous trip with my husband in Italy (our first travel in Europe), and a first time marathon memory in medoc, France, and Lyon with a long-time friend, and my first visit in London. I just despairingly hope if someone happen to find a card around the area will see my message and drop me a reply..

Pretty good, apart from the stupid video. Multimedia is the curse of modern museums - if you don't put a lot of effort in, it's worse than useless - and the video that starts this attraction off is terrible. The rest of the exhibit isn't really about he bridge, more about London history, but it's nice to walk across the top, even though the views are marred by dirty plexiglass (there are sliding camera ports) and you can't go onto outside walkways or see the real guts of the bridge (except for the engine room section). Moderately priced, so worth it.

Boring..... Unless you are in to the engineering aspect of the bridge, which I guess is the only real reason you'd want to go, then don't bother.There are a couple of interactive areas, talking picture frames and the like. I found the place thoroughly boring although it is well laid out and informative for those who could give two hoots about the subject. The views of the Thames from the upper level are fantastic. Other than that, there isn't much to say.Afterthought... The toilets (a sad point I know) were absolutely disgusting, and it wasn't a busy day!

upper level bridge walk. booked in advance on internet so fast track into the attraction, informative lay out and could look out through small open windows for good view of the Thames, engine room worth a visit to see old machinery used to raise the bridge, bought a combo ticket so could do the monument as well

Great views. Decided to visit here as had purchased a London pass and it was included, had a good visit, easily accessible and interesting information, no limit to the time you can stay up and learning about things that I wouldn't normally have looked at. The views where fantastic and it was a warm clear day so got some great photos.Definitely worth a visit.

Great example of what the Victorians did to make London great. I live a stone's throw away and love this bridge. The exhibition on the walkway is great and I was lucky to get a half price deal for £4. I thought I would be finished in 30 minutes but spent 2.5 hours there. Exhibition tells you how this bridge is made - from metal with stone facia. Also shows history of other great bridges throughout the world.The engine room is also pretty impressive.

Wonderful landmark. Tower Bridge is one of London's most iconic locations and it is a wonderful area to spend a few days exploring the historic part of the city. The wonderful Hermitage Community moorings are just downstream from the bridge and make an excellent backdrop for any photo, particularly at high tide. Plenty of small restaurants round here and ancient pubs that Dickens and others may well have sunk a pint or three at.

A Little London History. Great attraction, easily accesed walking around London area. Inexpensive, lots of history and information well presented. Only down side is entrance access not clearly signposted, we walked along left side of bridge hoping to cross at lights at centre, no we had to walk back half the bridge. No big deal.
Tower Bridge amazing. Even better than the pictures. I was amazed by the height and architecture of this masterpiece. Will return again.
awesome in the night lights. Although I had been in London many times, never got a chance to do a night tour until last weekend. Absolutely worth of it!
Scenic. We viewed the Tower Bridge from our Thames River tour. Amazing to see it function. It is well worth to see how impressive as it is.

Lovely bridge and great exhibition inside :D. I walked the bridge quite often, to get from one place to another and at some point, I also went inside to the exhibition. The exhibition was mainly a video about the building of this bridge, photographs of the making and photographs of other famous bridges around the world and some blueprints. It was all very nice and informative and I would suggest it to those who have purchased a London Pass or are not on a budget. Otherwise it's quite expensive and perhaps the money for the entrance are a bit too much for the inside.
Fab views. We loved climbing this bridge and learning all about it, such an icon. We brought a joint money saving ticket to climb the monument too

One of the most amazing bridge I had ever seen. A must see if this is the first time you go to London. What a sight. The color, the architecture itself is amazing. Go to the Tower of London which is close by and you can take picture of the bridge from other vantage point. The Tower of London itself is a sight to be seen.

Iconic and busy. Tower Bridge is iconic and world famous. It's well worth having a wander across it if you're in the vacinity. It's right next to the Tower of London.The bridge itself is impressive with it's huge towers and next time I'll do the tower Bridge exhibition to find out more about it.It's always busy with lots of tourists. It has great views from the bridge.

Beautiful Bridge!!!. Tower Bridge offers a very nice sight of London from the top. With incredible views from either side, it is an iconic symbol of London. I recommend buying the tickets to get to go inside the bridge to the upper level, where you'll see 2 short films of the bridge history and lots of curious information about that bridge and other worldwide famous bridges. Then you'll get to go to the engine room and at last the inevitable gift shop.If you like being and seeing iconic symbols of each city, Tower Bridge is not to be missed!!!

Poppies at the Tower of London. We went to see the poppies at the Tower, Oh what a lovely site. Its a must to visit at this time. I love going to the Tower Bridge and The Tower of London on a sunny day.

Right timing!. We were there for our sightseeing tour and walking cross the bridge leisurely. An iconic symbol of London, it has attracted a large group of people at the very end of this summer. We were lucky to have watched the opening up of tower bridge for a ship crossing underneath. Of cause, this is a must visit place to London!

A True Icon Of London. This is definitely one of the true icons of London. We rode parallel to the bridge on our tour then later rode across. Great views of the bridge and when on the bridge views of London bridge and Tower of London as well as the river Thames. If you have the time I would suggest walking across as we did on a previous trip.

It's a good looking bridge.... As bridges go. What can you say really? It's an iconic London building and you have to see it if your there! It's busy though so pick your times. Good to watch it in action. Got to see that a couple of times staying in London for work.

Must see. I recomend visiting this wonderful bridge and to walk inside. The bridge overlooks nice views from both sides.nice photos can be taken from the bridge, you can cross the bridge to enjoy a nice walk on both sides of the river where you can find many restaurants too..

Must-See Landmark. During my many visits, I have seen the Tower and Tower Bridge too often to keep count. Whether you simply cross the bridge, walk out on it to get a better vantage point for photos of the tower, enter the building to learn about it's history and the way it works or simply sit and enjoy the view, it's always rewarding. My favourite time is when the bridge opens at night to let a ship sail through... you can sit, chat, have a drink and see all the lights and their reflection on the water, and it doesn't cost you a penny. Bridge lift times can be found at http://www.towerbridge.org.uk/TBE/DE/BridgeLiftTimes/
tower bridge,london. I joined the sightseeing tour and the bus crossed the bridge twice.It is a beautiful bridge and could see the london bridge and flyer with the nice cool autumn season

Taxi tower bridge. If you need a Taxi I would recommend Tower Bridge Taxi London as they will not charge high prices, great service from Hotels and apartments. quick service to the airports.I would also recommend visiting Tower Bridge You can climb the stairs up and see the queens state room when they have it open and also they give tours of the bits that make it all work, look for times on the doors.

Don't bother trying to visit as a group - appalling treatment. I have been due to visit this exhibition on a group booking on 3 different dates over the past 2 months. On each occasion our booking has been cancelled, usually with only a few days notice, because they've taken a corporate booking instead. Clearly the only thing that matters to the owners is money.. customer service and honouring existing agreements obviously don't matter at all. Disgusting treatment!! So, still not seen this exhibition and don't intend to bother.

Iconic structure!. Great views from on top of the bridge. Can hike the stairs or take the lift, there are rest spots and info along the way. The views are nice from the pedway at the top and photos of the bridge are terrific both on the ground and from above. Recommended.

Great Views. The tour of the bridge was very interesting, showing how it was constructed etc. The views from the walkways were quite spectacular especially as it was a bright sunny day when I was there.I was also fortunate to see the bridge opening, which was also facinating.

Great Icon of London. Did a tour of the bridge, it was very interesting looking at the old engines and the views from the top walkways were spectacular. While I was there the bridge was raised something I have never seen before.

Photo opportunity. Its is nice to walk over and visit inside but I recommend getting a distance from it on the north or south bank and taking a nice photo/selfie with it in the background. You will receive plenty of likes on Facebook from it

Great pleasure. Whenever you will ho there , U'll forget all the problems in ur life . It's a great place to visit always busy and beautiful..! I have been there few time now and it's always good ..! Happy me..! :-)

Historical view. If you are interested in the history of London and you also like the amazing view from the upper side of the bridge, than you were right here. It's also not so crowded like the Tower of London.

Excellent views of London. Went whilst on a weekend break in London for something interesting to experience, amazing views from the upper levels out over the thames and central London. Also interesting exhibitions on the bridge, it's construction and other varying topics. Nice one to fill a couple of hours between other things, easy to get to and lists of other attractions within easy reach.

A Must for Engineers or Engineering Enthisiasts. The bridge is beautiful and a site to behold, but if you like mechanical things, thr exhibition is a must. The start encompasses the civil engineering and the bridge design, but the old engine room is a marvellous testament to this feat of Victorian engineering.

Wonderful bridge. We did the tour of the Tower Bridge and we were so glad that we did!! It is a very interesting tour and we really liked learning the history of the bridge!! Worth going on while you are in England!!
Nice bridge. Not much to really say but this is a nice quick stop. Just hopped on the underground and took some pictures. Very well done bridge and worth the stop.

Amazing . We took a little skate down to tower bridge from Westminster along the Thames and arrived here, this was a amazing sight and we sat down and had lunch by the side of the river sat facing the bridge and the tower of London. Not many places to eat nearby as far as I could tell we had to travel a line up on the underground but we were in a rush to catch our bus home.

Always a nice experience. I have now visited the Tower Bridge numerous times on each of my visits to London and it is still not boring. The displays inside are always changing and it is just a nice way to have a relxed look at all the new buildung in London.
Lovely. Great place to visit. More interesting to people who like to see how engines work. I found the views of the Thames more thrilling myself.
Amazing! So beautiful!. Nothing says London like the Tower Bridge. A must for any visitor! It is so amazingly beautiful! Whether by boat or on foot or in a classic double decker bus, simply amazing!

Fantastic views of London. We travelled in to London by train so took advantage of the two for the price of one tickets, so it was a very reasonable £9 between us. It is a great way to pass an hour or two, and the views from the top are amazing. Make sure that you don't miss the engine room as the enormous machines are immaculate and fascinating. Brilliant Victorian engineering.

gorgeous giant. I love its rustic,romantic look. Magnificent in daylight, so breathtaking at night. But it is just a bridge- someone will say. For me it was the most exciting place in London. Although, for someone it's just a medieval construction, for me he is the charm and heart of this beautiful city!
Interesting landmark. We were not rushed through, good detail on all aspects of design and build - my 14 year old really enjoyed the visit.

Postcard perfect. First sighted Tower Bridge from the Hop on Hop off bus . What a sight. The architecture us just amazing. Make sure you have your camera on the ready to take photos of this postcard perfect structure.The second and best view was from the River Thames. The River Thames Cruise, comes as part of the Hop on Hop off Bus tour. This combination is the best way to see London and well worth the pride. Time permitting, the 3 day pass is the way to go.

A Unique & Interesting exhibit, but it could be much better.... To visit this exhibit is not cheap, but you do get a unique perspective on Tower Bridge - up on the walkway above the bridge road surface there has been an attempt to create an interesting exhibition about the creation of the Bridge, but it does need some work. The first area as you exit the lifts is a mock up of a meeting between the Bridge Architect and Queen Victoria. Once you have passed through this, you are on the walkway itself where there are simply white display boards with information about the designs proposed, the construction of and then the opening of the bridge, After that there are more boards of pictures of other famous bridges. There is the ubiquitous "photo" area, before a small cinema area situated at the far end of the walkway. Then you pass into the second walkway - which for some bizarre reason is about 60's London?!The children were given a small "passport" to collect stickers of the Bridge.Pretty poor really. After passing swiftly through the large "photo shop" - photos £10 + each - you walk down and out of the Tower, aong the bridge and down underneath the Tower to the engine room (passing buy a much larger shop!) this obviously was very interesting - it has all the old machinery that was once used to power the bascule bridge opening. But it is no longer in use.The most interesting bit was obviously the opening of the bridge itself which we were lucky to see. It really is a fabulous sight! And also seeing the bridge lit up at night!The organizers should visit some other exhibits to see how much more could be made of this opportunity.
MUST. All London tours include Tower Bridge.Spend some time here.Tourist must visit but full of tourists.This is one of the old bridges in Lonfon worth the visit.

Go under, on, and in!. The iconic Tower Bridge (sometimes erroneously thought of as the London Bridge) is certainly worth seeing. I think it's best seen by boat. If you take the Thames Clipper, you can go under the bridge and on the return journey, hop off at the Tower and walk to and on the bridge and go up high inside one of the towers to the Tower Bridge Exhibition which explains how the bridge works and gives - with photographs and interactive kiosks - it's interesting history. Originally, the only crossing for the Thames it had to be a very special bridge to meets London's needs. Two massive piers support the framework for the towers and walkways above. It was clad in stone to protect and beautify it. The see-saw operated by steam powered hydraulics. They only took a minute to raise them nearly vertically. Now oil and electricity is used for power but you can still see the original magnificent steam engines. Visitors can to enter the high walkways, which are fully covered. Their reward is magnificent panoramic views.

Tend to avoid the tourist destinations.. Being in London regularly, we tend to avoid the tourist destinations but I'm glad we decided to give this one a try. What a great, geeky tour! Its full of interesting facts about where the design came from and how the bridge came to be. Wait until you see what powers the whole thing, amazing!

Interesting for families, great to walk over the bridge between the towers. My family and I had a great time at the tower bridge exhibition. It was great to see the short movies about how the bridge was developed, walk across the bridge at the top of the towers and see the engine room. The view was great from the top of the bridge, I'd recommend going on a sunny day to get the most out of the impressive view. I went with young children and at the entrance there is a sticker passport which at each section of the exhibition/ a member of staff will give out stickers so the children can complete their passports. If you miss some of the stickers, ask at the entrance to the engine room and they can give any missing stickers. I'd recommend spenidng 60 - 90 minutes at the exhibition.

Interesting couple of hours!. This is a really good attraction. We visited it a few years ago after going in the Tower of London and really enjoyed the tour and seeing how the bridge works. We went over the top walkways,amazing views along the river. Our kids loved that they had a lego model of the bridge set up on display inside!  Reasonably priced at about £5 per adult and £3 per child. Particularly cool to watch the bridge open for tall ships to pass through. We would recommend doing this if you have a couple of hours.

Iconic Bridge!. Took the hop on hop off Thames River Cruise from City Cruises today and one of the places we cruised to was the Tower Bridge. The bridge is stunning from the water and if you go to the bridge website you'll see the opening times which looks really cool. The HMS Belfast is moored between the Tower bridge and the London Bridge which adds an even nicer pic of the Tower Bridge. Definitely worth a trip down the Thames to see the marvelous world renown bridge from the water.

Worth a visit. Have always been interested in Tower bridge and finally managed to get to visit it properly. Was busy but did not take too long to get the lift up to one of the main walk ways. Good views and you can take as long as you like to explore. Interesting films that tell you about the building of the bridge and the other ideas of crossings across the Thames.

Learn everything you want to know about bridges. A cool little attraction on a beautiful bridge. Free with the London pass. Note: The lift seems to have scheduled times of operation but I think you can take the stairs otherwise. The information is both about Tower bridge as well as other bridges in the world so is quite interesting. The whole thing takes probably 20 minutes.

Worth Visiting. Worth visiting if you have a spare hour or so. Some interesting facts and figures, but it was a little steep for my liking (about £12 for an adult and child), but it's probably cheaper if you pre book. There's a lovely view from up there, it's just a shame that you cannot get out into the open at the top.

another iconic London Attraction. As well as Big Ben you must go a see Tower Bridge , this beautiful steel old lady , has thrilled Londoners and visitors since it was built. It Stands like the Gateway and Guardian to the Docks[which have now all gone} when I was a child I use to stand in awe at this mechanical marvel. Because of the docks, it used to go up and down all day, which as a child I found this very exciting. spanning the River Thames it looks fantastic and when it was built it was designed to blend in with the Tower of London. which it does! Another must for you to say , "I have been there"

Worth visiting. If you are there around, just don't lose the occasion. It does not take a lot. Mostly suggested for a first time / first day visit. Quite "steam punk", a short immersion into the past.
Stunning!. Absolute perfection. This bridge screams "London!" Saw it my land and by water. Jumped on top of a double decker bus and went through it. Absolutely amazing.

A must do. You must see it, walk on it and take pictures with it if you are in London. This place is as beautiful as its pictures or even more. The area surrounding the bridge is interesting and you can spend a whole afternoon in the area if not more

Tower Bridge. I liked this. You can walk up the stairs or get a lift. I walked but it was tiring. Quite a long tour lots to take in. Another cheap experience for London especially for families on a budget. Friendly staff. Some fantastic views from the bridge. The steam room was quite good as it shows how the bridge is raised.

Tower Bridge, London. Can you imagine walking across the Thames River on a walkway way above the water and be able to see the Tower of London almost next door - Wow! The history depicted on the artwork on the walkways was wonderful. Then to see the bridge open upwards to allow a sailing ship with a tall mast pass through was the ultimate!

Excellent Historical Visit. We planned to stroll along the southbank and were not going to visit the Bridge. We were lucky enough to see the bridge going up as a ship was passing. Decided to go in the Bridge... and it was not a mistake at all. The experience from the inside is excellent. The visit is planned in a way that makes you relive the building of the bridge and you get to see London from a different angle. We are not fans of history but the way it is set-up does not make it boring at all. Recommended for those not so savvy after history.

super bridge. I came with all my family after having intended to visit for years. As well as going up the towers and crossing the span of the bridge, it is possible to climb up and down the stairs of one tower and see the stationary steam engine that was used to maintain the hydraulic engine. Lot's of explanation of how the bridge worked including video presentations. Everyone in the family enjoyed their visit.
Nice view of the city. We had the London Pass and were able to use it here at the Tower Bridge. The view was amazing from the top of the bridge. The exhibits were average

Lovely place to visit. I really enjoyed looking around the tower and would recommend it to anyone going to London.The views are amazing the factual films are very good and is the engine room. Staff are very informative and friendly
Brilliant exhibition. Well worth taking a look!! Excellent value for money!! My kids aged 9, 11, 14 and 16 loved it, there was something for everyone xxx
Lovely views up the river.. Amazing to see how the bridge was constructed without all the modern day machinery. Booked in advance, easy access with the option of stairs or lift.

very interesting. Having lived in London as a child I felt it was time to visit the Tower Bridge exhibition. It was well worth the wait! Reasonably priced tickets (for a London attraction) especially if you get the family savers. The staff are friendly and the attraction is interesting. The views of London are amazing, there are fun videos showing the history of the bridge and there is also a bit of London history on one of the walkways. . You can then visit the original engine rooms these were good but I came away with more questions than I had originally as to how it all worked.Even better having never seen Tower Bridge open I got to see it twice that day

Brisge Tour. the Tower Bridge experience was really good, even better if you go by train as you can get 2 for 1 tickets when you show your train ticket (applies to lots in London too!)lots to read and see in the exhibition, you get to walk on the top of the bridge whcih is covered in - my husband wanted to be outside!!the Boiler rooms are really interesting, just to see the engineering that was accomplished in that era - amazing.I think it was good value for the 2 for 1 price, but if we had paid £9 each tehn not so sure it was worth that much.good place to visit.

Very interesting and children friendly. Walking over tower bridge is a different way to see London and not too expensive compared with other attractions. If you have a rail ticket you can get 2 4 1 admissions if you print the form in advance. The bridge has a lift either side of the lifting road in the tower and there were children's activities to keep little ones interested

Great views and great price. The Tower Bridge Experience is ideal for slotting in between a other attractions you are going to. It is right next to the Tower of London so an ideal time to visit.It is very reasonable entry cost. Totally accessible for those with wheelchairs and they are very helpful.Interesting videos and great views.It takes about an hour with the steam room visit too. The steam room isn't that interesting if you are not into that kind of thing but it is good to see it. Kids get a little passport type thing where they get stickers at 4 points during the visit to stick on. My daughter loved that!!It is not as impressive in the towers than outside, but to be honest it was not made for people to tour it. This was the second time we have been in 2 years as my daughter loves going in there.Yes not a big attraction but worth a visit and a cheap attraction to visit in comparison to others in. London!

Raise the Bridge!!. My husband and I really enjoyed our trip to, up and along the iconic Tower Bridge last week while we were in London Aug 16-22. We bought our tickets online in advance for this, which ended up being brilliant, because it was massively crowded the day we visited and we were able to bypass the line (queue) nearly altogether, pick up our tickets at the counter, and go straight up to the high level viewing platforms where we enjoyed an interesting pictorial exhibition chronologizing the bridge's history and also saw some stunning views of the River Thames and London skyline! For the best experience and if you're able to do it, I strongly recommend taking the STAIRS all the way up and down instead of the elevator (lift) because it is far less crowded, affords you an appreciation of how high the bridge really is, and also offers additional wonderful views through the windows on the way up! Of course, the most impressive thing about this bridge is that it's a drawbridge, so it's a real treat to see it raise to allow a large or high masted ship to pass through. TIP: check the Tower Bridge website for the Bridge Lift Times (a tab on the top) before you go so that you can time your visit to be ON THE GROUND to see it best when it lifts and lowers!! It's quite a spectacle and lots of fun to watch front & center (see attached photo). If it wasn't so awfully crowded and they would better limit the number of people that could see it at any given time, I would rate this 5 stars.

Iconic British Landmark!!. I attended Tower Bridge on Thursday 28 August 2014 with my family of 4. After watching a video about why Tower Bridge was built, you can then walk into the high level Walkways, 42 metres above the River Thames.Take your time and wonder around this Spectacular British landmark with outstanding views from inside and outside of the tower including St Paul's Cathedral and the Monument.Whilst i was there i was very lucky to see the bridge lift that was very special.

Great views of the Thames. The Tower Bridge exhibition was very informative and well planned. The route was very methodical, and the pacing was excellent. Even at the height of summer holidays (when I visited), I did not feel rushed or crowded. The two walkways on the upper level give great views of the Thames and London. After the visit to the Engine Room, I walked back over the Bridge on the road level, getting the 'middle gap' photo (where the two halves of the bridge meet). A very nice experience!

Superb views and interesting!. Excellent attraction with helpful staff,The bridge exhibition was well laid out and very informative Spectacular views and the engine room was great and immaculately presentedWell worth the money in my opinion!

Excellent way to see the Thames. It was school holidays but we still had short queses may 5 minutes. You get a lift tothe top and have a short movie or sound and light show. Then you have as much time as you want to roam the two cover walkways on both sides of the bridge with excellent views up and down the Thames. After that you can visit the engine rooms.

Nice & Iconic. Well, it's just iconic, isn't it? Don't miss it, go up the bridge, you will earn a great view of London, and learn about the bridge itself, if you are lucky - you will even see the bridge rises! It is included in London 2FOR1 so you can buy 2 tickets in the price of 1. Much recommended attraction.

Remember to use 2 for 1 when visiting here. If you just want to see the whole tower bridge, then there is no need to go up there. The exhibition there is not that rich but interesting and worthy to see if you use 2 for 1 voucher.Suggest to go there in the morning and sunny day because you can see the shard, city hall on the bright side. You could spend 2 hours there and walk to Borough market for lunch.

Fascinating. I did not pay for the entrance to the tower bridge as the external look of it is fascinating enough. Take a stroll by the riverside of the bridge whether with your loved ones or your friends, it was a wonderful experience as the tower bridge is really beautiful, especially during the night time. I personally went with my friends and never realised its beauty until I see it in real life. It's worth the visit if you have time during the night.

Very interesting. I went with a 6 year old who was getting tired by that stage in the day, and we still enjoyed this. The films are good, the exhibition was interesting, and the engine room was great, with a few 'hands on' displays which children and adults were enjoying. There is a 'sticker hunt' trail for the kids too. To cap it all, we saw the bridge open, not once but twice (once from the pedestrian walkway on the bridge itself, and once from a bar just down the river!) - search Google for 'tower bridge lift times', as they are planned quite well in advance and it's worth seeing.

Fascinating and good value. I'd walked across Tower Bridge many times without thinking about paying to enter the exhibition but on a recent trip, with time on our hands, my family and I decided to try it. We're all very glad we did as it turned out to be a fascinating and informative experience detailing not just the history of the building of this iconic bridge but also a wealth of information about the history of London and bridge building across the world. The views from the walkways at the top of the bridge are spectacular and just to be inside this unique building is exciting in itself. Great value at £9 per adult (buy online). Highly recommended.

London's most famous bridge. The iconic Tower Bridge must be one of the world's most recognisable sights. Do not miss it if you visit London, I have taken countless friends and relatives to enjoy this attraction! You will never forget it whether you see it by day or night (when it is now stunningly lit). It's free to enjoy unless you want to climb up it and learn more about it. The Tower Bridge tour is well worth it and affords you superb views from high up in the structure - up and down stream and across the Tower of London - which would have been even more mind-blowing for the first 19th Century Londoners who had the energy to climb the steps during the many daily bridge lifts then. The Tower Bridge tour also memorably demonstrates the pioneering lifting machinery and other aspects of the workings of this extraordinary structure. If you are walking over it you will be photographed dozens of times as part of the tourists' snaps. Opening times for the drawbridge itself are infrequent - check the internet.

Amazing. I am amazed and confused as to how somebody could give this London landmark one star as being terrible. Tower bridge is an iconic landmark not just for this generation but for years gone by. Every night I drive over it, there are countless thousands posing and taking photographs of themselves and it, to recount their memories of this great city. It is one of the ultimate landmarks of London. It is one of the landmarks that underpins and validates your photo album of your stay in London. Embrace it, how could you not! With so much tourist related hype and money grabbing bunk everywhere. I do not see how you could not be impressed by visiting, walking over and simply marvelling at a piece of architecture that has survived and continues to survive and delight generations because of its sheer presence.

A great way to learn about this icon. A visit to the tower bridge should not be missed. You will learn a lot about it's construction and be treated to some spectacular views. The children enjoyed it as well and now better appreciate its significance.

Don't miss this!. Much more than I thought it would be. You go up into the bridge and walk across between the two bridges…..there are actually 2 paths with a lot of history to look at. When you’re done you go down to the engine room which quite impressive!

Beautiful bridge. The Tower Bridge is an iconic symbol of London. It is lovely to walk in the nearby open areas and see the bridge in all its glory. There is easy pedestrian access and you are greeted by lovely views of the skylines on either bank of the Thames.

Must-see. Maybe Londoners get used to seeing Tower Bridge, not least as a symbol of London. But it is great to see it as one strolls along the South Bank, though it is not particularly historic, for example when compared with the Tower of London. Nevertheless, no visitor to London can claim to have seen the sights without getting up close to this famous landmark

Legendary. The views from the bridge are just as impressive as the views of the bridge. Doesn't matter what time of day or night, I found myself photographing it at sunrise, midday, sunset and at night, truly a marvel.

History of London Bridge. This is a short exhibition of the infamous London Bridge & all the history about the trade & commerce of old London Town. It is worth going just to get some nice photos of the Thames & the Skyline. It is very close to other exhibits in London like HMS Belfast

Good view and informative. When most people think of a London landmark they usually think of either Big Ben or the Tower Bridge. Check out the Bridge Experience and you will get to know the history of the bridge and how it works. You also get to cross between the tower for a great view up and down the river.

Very interesting. Iconic bridge which you can visit. A very interesting tour and exhibition. Well worth a visit but it is a shame that there is no cafe at the top where you can linger over the terrific views.
Fab!. This is a really interesting place! We had been meaning to visit it for ages! Great views too!! A***
A must do.. Great chance to explore an iconic landmark. Silly display of london in the sixties which had no.relevance to the bridge but did not detract from the experience.
Breathtaking. As you turn the corner of the Tower of London you have a WOW moment when you first see the bridge. It's quite breathtaking.
great bridge. Great attraction and lot of history involved. But when you go there ask about the bridge opening timings. It usually changes every day.

Really interesting and informative. Visited today with my wife and two children, aged 11 & 7. We pre-booked our tickets but even on a very busy sunny day the queues for tickets were not that long. When you first arrive don't take the lazy option and go up in the lift, step back outside to the left and go up the stairs the way the Victorians did. It really adds to the feel of the building and sets you up for what is ahead. The tour starts with a short video about the origins, design and building of this iconic bridge. Walk along the East walkway and take in both the views and also the masses of information on display. At the top of the south tower there is a brief video showing the construction of the bridge, remember to look up and see the models of the builders and ask the staff about the facts of figures of the bridge and it's history. Go along the West walkway where there is an exhibition of London icons inc Carnaby St, The Who and others.Head down in the lift and walk the short distance to the Victorian engine rooms, these are fascinating and show just how ingenious the builders and engineers of the time were. Allow around two hours to really take in the full experience.

Tower Bridge. It's one of the most famous landmarks in London: Tower Bridge. The bridge itself is very impressing, but you can also walk between the two towers at the top of the bridge, which gives you a beautiful view of the Thames.

Well worth the visit. If you are neat Tower Bridge don's miss a visit to the exhibit which provides a history of the bridge and then great views from the two walkways between the North and South Towers. Remember to take the last part of the tour to see the machinery that operate the bridge. For the kids there is a passport to fill in as the visit progresses.

Well worth a visit. Very good value for money, paid £1.50 extra to include a trip up The Monument. Spectacular views of the city, very informative and historical. Amazing to see the structure from a different perspective. Includes a visit to the engine rooms, very interesting. Don't worry if your scared of heights like we are, felt totally safe and secure as all enclosed! Definitely recommend a visit.

Its the toursist thing to do. You cannot visit London and not see tower bridge. Interesting to see and its a in an area with some great dining and beside the Tower of London so you can spend a good part of the day exploring nearby.
The best thing in London. This is my favorite place in London. I could spend hours just walking on it. They also have a small museum attached to one of the pillars.

The Landmark You Must See Inside. This famous landmark was well worth the entry. Displays and films cue you in to the amazing history of London's fanciest bridge and the art exhibits and countdown of the world's most unique bridges is truly fascinating. If you are a penny presser, don't forget to come equipped with change as none is available inside. The attraction is equipped with both lifts and stairs which if used will certainly count as your exercise for the day! Once you have exited on the far side, make sure you follow the trail to the engine rooms to check out how the bridge operates. There is also a well equipped gift shop here and even more penny presses. Truly something for everybody.

Wow! A brilliant day out. My first visit (having lived in London all my life) walked from Tower Hill tube pass Tower of London to see the poppies awesome and emotional. Walking along side River Thames and then the view is magnificent , Tower Bridge opened at 11.45am (I had checked the opening times) what a sight.Wonderful views up and down the Thames a great photo opportunity.A very short walk to the Bridge, up the stairs and across the bridge into the entrance, very well organised if you are very fit climb the stairs for an experience or take the lift.A very good experience, inexpensive for a family and worthwhile the views up and down river are great, information is clear and very educational.Take care on the walk, lots of cobblestones if you walk alongside the river and stairs up and down but there are lifts so look for them.Chill out in The coffee shops and watch the world go by with amazing views. Enjoy

TOWER BRIDGE EXPERIENCE. A chance to see behind the scenes of this unique bridge over the Thames. A lift takes you to the "bridge walk" height where a short video of its inception is shown. Then a walk across the uppermost eastern span taking in the sights on the that side of the bridge. Then across the southern tower where there is another video presentation to the western span with sights to the west. Both spans are covered from the elements and contain interesting facts and information relating to this and other famous bridges around the world and also some historical features. The bridge was scheduled to open about 6:30pm when we could experience the "lifting" from the spans. Unfortunately our visit was too early and we missed it. Still, we have travelled through the lifted bridge on the paddle steamer Waverly and seen it from water level.
worth a visit. One of London's most famous landmarks, well worth a visit inside to learn about the history and how it functions. Good views from the walkway above

Striking Structure. You will have seen the Tower Bridge on TV or Film ('Spice World'!) before, but it's even more impressive in reality. It's also in a nice area, obviously by the river, and near the Tower or London, so you can easily spend a good amount of time there and walk around and take in the many sites.

Not just a bridge. It a history, art and lovely walk over it and around its corners! plan to have an afternoon tea, lunch or dinner in one of the places viewing it, you will definitely love it, you get the feeing that, yah I'm in London!

A Must See. No trip is complete without a tour of this famous and technically amazing bridge. Climb up the stairs (a lot) and walk across the bridge for best views. If you're lucky (as we were), you might see it open so a boat can pass under. Be sure to check out the engine room below ground.
Love all the history!. Especially enjoyed the armory & seeing the knights' armor. Our guide made history come alive. Saw where Ann Boleyn & others were beheaded.

Worthwhile, if you enjoy this kind of thing. Included in the London Pass. Neat little experience that gives history on how the bridge was built, why it was built and the mechanics of the bridge itself. And you can get a pretty good workout if you take the stairs instead of the elevator. There aren't any tour guides, so you pretty much are left to look at the exhibitions yourself. There was an annoying little photo booth person that got a surly look from me (i don't like having my picture snapped without warning), but otherwise it was a pretty fun experience.

Iconic London. Tower bridge is worth a visit just for the snapshot of one of London's famous icons. The bridge has been raised twice in the 5 times I've visited it, which is certainly fun to watch. Reading up on the history and mechanics of the bridge beforehand also makes the visit and the view worthwhile. I wouldn't advise paying for the Tower Bridge Experience, though. Although it is interesting being able to walk across the part of the towers originally intended for public use, the view is nothing better than what you could see from the London Eye and I didn't find that the exhibition caught much of my attention. A visit to the Engine rooms is recommended, though, as you get to see the mechanics of the bridge and how it was built.
Unique. We viewed and photographed the bridge from a distance (from the London Bridge). I liked it. Very nice, unique. Probably something everyone should see when in London.
disappointed. We went to try out the glass floor which should have been fitted. Luckily we asked first or we would have spent £9 and got nothing.

“Worthwhile Experience”. Tower of London, this bridge seemed deserted (though it still had its share of visitors). The history of the bridge, and the mechanics of how it raised, are interesting if that's your cup of tea, though it would probably bore younger crowds (some interactive items for kids are available

Worth a visit. The Tower of London is worth a visit if just for the history and the quality of the structure. To see the way it was built and the work involved in maintaining such a iconic structure is interesting. it is part of London's history...

Worthwhile Experience. We took advantage of the 2 for 1 ticket price with our rail tickets.Despite being in mid- August queues moved quickly and staff ensured places didn't get overcrowded.Exhibitions on the walkways feature on one side the history of bridges & bridges around the world, while it is the 60's on the other. The windows could be bigger to take photos from but you can get some great shots of plenty of famous landmarks.The Engine Rooms feature beautifully restored machinery.A great way to spend an hour or so within one of London's iconic landmarks.

A relatively peaceful attraction. Compared to the museums and Tower of London, this bridge seemed deserted (though it still had its share of visitors). The history of the bridge, and the mechanics of how it raised, are interesting if that's your cup of tea, though it would probably bore younger crowds (some interactive items for kids are available). If you are a fan of bridges, the gallery of bridges from around the world will take an extra 30 minutes... not to complain about though, as you standing above the Thames throughout.
One of the most beautiful bridges in the world... Tower Bridge is just amazing. The exhibition is quite interesting. Don't miss it if in London.......

Beautiful bridge, lovely exhibition. The bridge is very beautiful, it's impressive and one of a kind. The exhibition is really educative and fun, they have a short animated movie regarding the history of the bridge which is not only educative, but fun to watch. There is an exhibition of photos of other famous bridges in the world and if you're a bridge-lover, then that's the place for you...Golden Gate, Bosphorus Bridge, Pont Alexandre III and many others have a special spot there. And finally, you get to see the engine room which is stunning. Really worth a visit!
5 star pile on. So many things to do in London,, so many free sites if your on a budget.. If you've heard of it.. GO THERE.. N O stinkers in the bunch ... Skip Paris.. London for me mate

Very interesting place. Very famous and interesting place. Worth visit!
History of Europe was written in those places.
Spirit of knights, Lords and Kings still there.

Definitely worth a visit!. Based on other TA reviews, I knew my husband (the engineer) would enjoy seeing the history and the inner-workings of this beautiful bridge. Plus, we had purchased the London Pass cards and this site was included in that fee. However, I would have paid to learn all we did and walk over the top! There is a small movie on this history, you get to walk through the engine rooms, and then walk (or take an elevator) up to the top and go across the span. You can look out across the city and see several exhibits on London and other world-famous bridges. Even our 18-year old daughter thought it was a fun diversion and only took about an hour. We were lucky to get to watch the bridge raise and lower several times during our visit. It's a very short walk from the Tower of London, and worth a visit!

Catch it raising. It's great to walk across, great photo ops. Find the middle and be creative with your camera. There is a tour of the engine rooms and the upper floor offered (was 8 GBP per person), offers amazing views to both sides of the river. Check out the lift times at: http://www.towerbridge.org.uk/TBE/EN/BridgeLiftTimes/ If you catch it at sunset or even at night, it is wonderfully lit and has a completely different feel to it. Definitely one of the musts in London.

AWSOME BRIDGE. We had the London pass which gave us entry to the Tower Bridge, We walked up the 250 step, (you can get lift if you want)there is a video of the making of the Tower bridge, great history lesson. Then you walk along the middle to the other side, where there is information and photos of other bridges around the world and 70's London. with views of the Thames river. Then you can get a photo if you like.

Good view and cruise. I travel regularly over Tower Bridge and for anyone from abroad I suggest you visit this area there is a lot going on.There are more tourists than locals so it create a good atmosphere

Tower bridge. Seen bridge opening the middle to let the ships to go through and when you imagine history of this place (like any other famous attraction in london),leaves me amazed of this great city.

enjoyable. Although this area is and enjoyable place to visit if you are not interested in the history it is a waste of time. I went for the scenery from the bridge and was dissapointed at how little i could see from the small windows

Must do in London. I think every City has one attraction you must have seen while being there. Tower Bridge is the must do attraction in London. Just walk across the Thames. It doesn´t take very long, but you get a great view and a nice feeling. Especially if you walk it with your girl- or boyfriend.

£9 to look at pictures and take photos. Either £9 or free on a London Pass, so what do you get for your money!A lift or a walk up the stairs to the top of the North tower, were you can enjoy a short film about the history of the bridge. You then have the choice of two walkways at the top; the east one features some great pictures of famous bridges, whilst the western one is an exhibit of 60's pictures. Whilst the pictures are great, the reason for walking to the top was to take photos outside, not to look at them indoors. Yes you can take photos but only through some very small open windows/grills.You can then get a lift down via the South tower to ground floor and a short walk by following a blue line brings you to the Engine Rooms. These are the most interesting part of the tour, but are more of a museum piece. Overall you can do the entire tour in about 60 minutes, but it's pricey for £9. If you have a discount or a London pass I would recommend.
Beautiful!. After a pleasant walk along the river Thames, we reached this beautiful and famous bridge. Absolute fabulous bridge with lots of beautiful sights. Love the skyline of London.

Another of London's Majestic Icons. You must see this up close and personal to appreciate it's beauty. I had taken a free hop-on-and-hop-off 1 hour boat cruise as part of the London Pass. We came closer to the bridge and I just couldn't get enough of it. I took several pictures of it. I also got out at that stop as I was going to see the Tower of London city where the Crown Jewels are housed. I also saw the Tower Bridge Experience that was interesting and then walked along the Tower Bridge for an added bonus. Loved it. Please do the same.

Interesting tour. The Tower Bridge experience is well worthwhile especially if you can use one of the 2 for 1 offers (eg with railway tickets). At the full price of £9 per person it's a bit pricey You begin the tour with a short video about the history and then go up in a lift to the top level where you can walk both sides of the walkways. There is a display about the bridge and other bridges as well as some British "history" from the 60s. The views are great but you are behind glass all the time. It is a shame there is no open section for photographs (even a window that opened!). You then descend in the other tower and follow the blue line to the engine rooms in another building. This part makes the tour worthwhile and the displays are multilingual. There are some lovely steam engines and paraphinallia to see.Ask a member of staff when the next bridge opening is due as this is a sight to behold.

Making the most of a classic location. It helps any attraction when it is an iconic and stunning building. However what impressed as well was me was the way the attraction is run. The pricing is good and the staff efficient. The two exhibitions, on bridges and 60s culture, were appealing to a wide range of ages and well put together. Add that to the superb views and it is well spent hour or so.
Brilliant view of a terrific city. It's one heck of a view, we went a while ago now but we went across a glass bridge with facts all over the place. It's a must go attraction.

Towers above....... When working in London I had to walk across Tower Bridge to get to the office Whether day or night this thing never fails to amaze me. From any perspective:- visual, construction, engineering, history, etc, you name it, there's something in it for everyone. You should get up close ...walk across it, photograph it, look at it, touch it, on the river, both sides of the river, day and night. On weekdays during the evening between 5-7 there a good chance of seeing the bridge deck raised as a ship sails through. Downside..... .? Summer crowds but hey - go early?

This is a must for all lovers of cityscape views.... It is very many years since I have been to the Tower Bridge Exhibition and it has changed almost as much as the London skyline. There are two good video presentations, one in each tower, the first dealing with the need for the crossing and the architecture of the bridge and the second with the innovative building technology. It is, of course, the walkways which command greatest attention and there are a vast number of information boards to identify the sights although the history and development of the bridge (along with the discounted schemes) are also addressed and the second walkway has lots of very interesting cultural information, currently a brilliant 60s exhibition. There are lots of open windows which permit glass-less photographs which is helpful. What still amazes me, though, is the quality of decorative stone and metal features at 150+ feet. The sights are remarkable but demonstrate that London and the City of London haven’t always been quite in tune with getting their new architecture right – no change there, then… Some of the more recent ‘iconic’ buildings are an indifferent bunch whilst the “Shard’ is quite remarkable for its shape and the fact that it is south of the river. It is a shame that those in the City dwarf and spoil the views of the very much more iconic Tower of London although it is interesting to see the other bridges too from this viewpoint. When looking at the river, the views are ever-changing. Many of the tourists I spoke to were surprised to discover that it is very much a working river and could see tugs pulling many barges as well as lots of pleasure craft and river ferries. The photos speak for themselves. The trip ends with a trip to the engine rooms and the shop - although we decided to leave that for the next visit.N.B. The upstream side of Tower Bridge [nearest the Tower of London] faces WNW so if you want to take photos to the West do so in the morning and vice versa. [P.S. Having walked over London Bridge to get to Tower Hill I realised that I must be one of the few who have walked over the Victorian stone arch bridge in London as a teenager and then again in Lake Havasu City in Arizona not that long ago.]
Breath Taking Beauty. The tower bridge measures up to all the hype. It is a very beautiful bridge, located by the tower of London. A great hang out place with lots of small restaurants around.

Magnificent. For those who don't have a lot of money to spend on the tour, just a walk across the bridge from one side to the other should definitely be enough. I think being in the presence of something so well heard of/well known and so magnificent is all it takes. If you're there at the right time, you may see the bridge getting raised to allow a boat to pass through - this is an incredible experience.

One of London's best landmarks. We took advantage of the free tour on our visit. Sean, our guide, was friendly and informative. This bridge is so iconic and has a very interesting history. A definite must see for all visitors to London.

Fabulous Views from an Iconic Structure. London's Tower Bridge is architecturally gorgeous. So glad it survived the Blitz during WWII. We went right when it opened on a Monday, not too much of a line, maybe 10 couples/families. They do accept the London Pass. The entry fee is a bit expensive, but the views from the upper level of the bridge were great. It was also interesting to learn about how they built the bridge and to see the Victorian era engine room restored. You ride an elevator up to the upper level walkway of the bridge. The high level walkways had an exhibit about the 1960's & about other famous bridges around the world. The upper levels are enclosed with glass, but there are small windows that open that you can get clear photographs from.

Over the top!. What a landmark! Over the top, elaborate, ostentatious but very impressive bridge. There are tours to the top of the bridge but super busy on the day we went so a walk across was enough to see the size, design and decoration up close.

Great place to visit for views over the river. Lots of steps to get to the top of the tower, but well worth it. We had a 2 for 1 voucher with our rail tickets.
Official photos are expensive, so we didn't buy.

Classic view!. My son really wanted to see Tower Bridge, so we walked all the way from the Tate Modern (quite a trek - not recommended!)
What can I say - it's a great photo opportunity and the whole world will recognise where you've been!

Great Exhibit of British Engineering. If you are in the least interested in engineering and how things work, don't miss this. The Tower Bridge is a great combination of design and engineering, in the best British tradition of both.

Great value family London outing. The Tower Bridge Exhibition is excellent value for a family outing in London. We passed under the bridge on a river cruise, over it on a bus tour and then to see its exhibition and the brilliant views from inside completed a true experience of such a beautiful icon - we were not disappointed. The kids loved the 'passport' activity.

Well worth it for the experience. Had wanted to go inside the bridge for several years and enjoyed it.Staff at the ticket office were not the friendliest but we got our tickets, passed security check, and made our way into the Tower.There are lots of steps (lift available if required) views getting better as you climb up, the structure inside is amazing, such a shame its all hidden away, very grand staircases as you proceed up to the top.When you reach the top, there is a short video about the history and why/how the bridge was designed, you can then walk through and along the walkways, to the other side.There are display in both sides, neither of which are that interesting, and are starting to fade. The one side had images of other great bridges, and again the history of the bridge. At the other Tower another short video greeted us. Then back along the other walkway to see pictures of images of London. Whilst here we also witnessed the bridge open for a couple of boats to pass through.After returning to the outside world, we had a short walk to the engine room, which was very well presented, the displays here were interesting and simple to read and understand on how the old engines worked. Some of the interactive displays at the end were not working though!Then out into the shop.Would have loved the chance to walk on the outside walkway across the bridge - not sure if this is every available to do or not?

Wow. I have lived in London all my life and just love Tower Bridge, there is just something about it. On Saturday morning I heard the sirens and knew the bridge was about to open, how excited was I, a special moment!!

A great British icon!. Despite being well into my fifties I had never done the Tower Bridge tour before. I was with a group of 20 who all did this tour together. After climbing the 206 stairs (lift u/s) we saw the film which wasn't quite as cheesy as I had feared...it presented the facts in an easily digested fashion for non-techies. For us techies there was plenty to admire in the Victorian structure revealed beneath the Portland Stone skin of the Towers. The walkways afforded spectacular views...Wembley Stadium one way, Crystal Palace TV mast the other. The sun was low in the sky and gave amazing views over HMS Belfast and towards The Shard. The restored but still steam engines were magnificent and, as we left, the bridge opened to let a cruise liner through! It was the icing on the cake of a most interesting experience.

One of the iconic sights of London. An iconic sight, along with Big Ben, which everyone associates with London. Didn't get to cross it, but did go under it twice on a river cruise. Very impressive sight.

Cool views. This attraction takes you up and over the Tower Bridge. It shows you how and why it was built and then down into the 'engine rooms' to show you how it works. It is very specific in its appeal. If you aren't into engineering/mechanical feats this may not be for you but it is well presented and the views as you walk across the high pedestrian bridge are stunning. It is all enclosed so it's not windy or cold or wet. It might be considered an alternative to the Eye since you are afforded lovely views of the city. We enjoyed it.

What a view!. Fairly cheap (compared to other attractions) for the visit. We made the most of the tickets (and the military discount) and viewed not only up the bridge at the lovely views and building. But also underground into the engine rooms. Very interesting and informative visit.

Lovely. It is an awesome tower, every time I go there I get taken aback. Walking on this bridge at night time when there isn't much people was one of my favourite moments. I didn't pay for anything, just walked around the bridge and on it.

Great Views over the river.. This attraction didn't cost too much and you got to go across the upper walkways between the towers, which gave you great views up and down the river.There was also some interesting info and photos along the walkways - not sure why they had an exhibition of a lot of 60's celebrities - and you got chance to look at the engine room.Overall, it was worth the money.

Behind the Scenes. The Tower Bridge Exhibition is a behind the scenes tour of the bridge. After an elevator ride upstairs, you watch a short film about the history of the bridge then walk across the upper walkways which double as an exhibition hall. When I visited it was full of iconic 1960's photos. You exit the bridge and cross to the other side where you get to tour the old stream engine room that powered the bridge during the Victorian era. Just like Disney World you exit through the gift shop.

Tower bridge tour. Did this as part of the London pass. Glad I hadn't paid. Very boring - not much and as another review said it seems like they ran out of stuff. I couldn't wait to get out. Basically paid for the chance to walk up 10 flights of stairs. Not fun. Then at the end they make you stand in a long hot queue for 15 minutes to take the elevator DOWN - why not use that on the way up??? Because it ends in the gift shop that's why. Just admire the lovely bridge and skip the attraction.

Not really worth it. Visited as part of a day out in London. The attraction was reasonable value (good job we had a days out voucher).To reach the top was via a hot and stuffy lift. The introductory film was interesting, as was the film in the other tower. walking across the bridge was not that exciting, a bit of a display of other bridges and a nostalgic trip back to the 60's. The architecture was impressive both inside and out.When we left it was nearly time to raise the bridge, it was decided to sit on a bench near the tower of London and watch the opening of the bridge to allow a tall sailing ship pass through.

Beautiful landmark of London. The view of the Tower of London is symbolic of central London. Walking on across it is very nice and I also had the opportunity to see it with lights at night. Perfect photo stop while visiting London alongside the Big Ben and the red doubledecker London bus.

It's the Tower. dont drive across the brndge, but rather walkit, its quite an experience to see it from top and even from the bottom. the traffice can get hectic, so walk on the side walks and on the embankment to appreciate this tower

Tower bridge (self-guided) tour. I booked the tickets for this tour online. I ended up costing £8 for my adult ticket and £3.50 for my sisters child ticket.Once we arrived we have to queue up inside, the difficult part we found here was actually getting into the building, as there was no signs or notices on the doors.We changed our tickets over and my sister was given a passport, where she would have to collect stickers as we went around the tour.We went up in a lift and then was told to watch an quick video of how the bridge's idea came to life.We then went down the two walk ways to look at the photographs. This part was a little dull, the information was okay but it was as though the had run out of things to put, so decided to put pictures of bridges all over the world up. The 2nd walk way was photos of the 60's,70's etc. This was a little more interesting. We also had our photo taken, which you could then buy at a later date.Once at the end of this part of the tour, we were told to walk out of the building and follow the blue line on the floor. This took us to the engine room. We had a walk around that, though it wasn't anything special. Overall i don't think the tour was worth the money i paid, it killed an hour of time, but it wasn't anything special.

A Photogenic Bridge. Tower Bridge in London is one of the most photogenic bridge I've ever seen. With one tower on each side of the River Thames, this draw bridge can be seen (and photographed) from many different vantage points up and down the river...I think we saw it each day we were in London. We did not experience the Tower Bridge Exhibition so I cannot comment on that attraction. For us, seeing the Tower Bridge and walking across it was enough...and it was free. Make sure you stop by both during the day and at night, as the entire bridge is lit up after dark.

Fantastic view with lots of history..... Very ironic view with fantastic view of the river.
Magnificent Tower. Watched the bridge part. Lovely day out to visit an interesting part of British History.
Lots of interesting food places around the Tower Bridge too.
Definitely worth a visit.....

Great experience. The Tower bridge tour was an excellent choice as we were traveling with a year old and two teenagers.It was fun to walk over the bridge and the exhibition was good.Everyone totally enjoyed it and this iconic landmark now has a deeper meaning for us.

Tower Bridge - A bridge that needs no introduction. Tower Bridge is probably the most easily recognisable bridge in the world. It seems everyone knows the image of Tower Bridge, even those who confuse its name with the nearby London Bridge. It is one of the iconic and worldly images of England and something that all first time visitors should try to experience. Built between 1886 to 1894, Tower Bridge takes its name from the nearby Tower of London, which is literally right next to the bridge on the north side of the River Thames. The bridge features two towers, each 65 meters tall with a central span of 61 meters, which can be raised to allow vessel traffic to pass. Designed by English architect Sir Horace Jones in Baronial style, the two towers resemble and are in harmony with the Tower of London architecture. The structure is quite photogenic during the day when you can take in lovely images of the Tower Bridge and Tower of London together from the promenade in Southwark. At night, the bridge is hit with floodlights, which illuminate it for quite some distance. Again, this makes for lovely opportunities to take memorable photographs of Tower Bridge. You can walk across Tower Bridge, enjoying this iconic landmark as well as many nice views of the city seen from here.
