You can also enter and experience the Tower Bridge Exhibition (£9.00 per adult, £3.90 for children) and walkways which stretch between the two towers. This can be a fun thing to do for families, and it can be conveniently done before or after visiting the Tower of London just a short walk to the north side of the Thames. In the end, this is one of 'true' must-see attractions in London, even if you don't spend much time at or near Tower Bridge. Up there with Elizabeth Tower (Big Ben), Parliament and Buckingham Palace, having a look at Tower Bridge is something everyone should make sure to include in their trip itinerary during your first trip to London.
Walk the bridge!. This is the prettiest bridge I have seen in person. Once you exit the Tower of London take walk across the Tower Bridge. So many picture opportunities.

Iconic. Great addition to the school holiday things to do list. Having crossed this bridge 100's of times we decided to visit it. It's an instantly recognizable icon and is in so many of our childhood photos in the background. I hadn't realised what fantastic views of London up and down the river it gives you by actually standing on it. Fab photo opportunities. The bridge architecture is very grand with its unique design and function. So photogenic and to see this icon bridge lift is impressive close up. It is a quick tour inside to see how it works and to get some of the history of the place. It is perfect as a trip as part of your day out - glad we went. A gruesome fact is this is the area that over the centuries bodies have washed up to due to tidal changes - don't worry you won't see any on your tour.
London means Engineering. A must see, like it or not, you have seen it more than 1 time in your life. Get your jaw dropped with the engineering apparatus more than a century old.

money well spent. Always wanted to walk across the top of tower bridge and finally got the chance. £18 for two adults and a teenager. No long queues or waiting times. The views at the top were fantast ic. It is enclosed by glass but with plenty of open windows at various heights your photos won't get ruined by reflection. The staff were friendly and knowledgeable. I would recommend this to anyone who wants an alternative view of the Thames and London. When you look at cost of some attractions this was a real bargain.

Much more interesting than I thought it would be.. We took the tour, on the advice of the lady selling the tickets. I'm glad we did as our guide, Mandy was really interesting to listen to and by the end of the tour we felt like she was a friend! I had no idea how the bridge lifted up and it was really good to learn. I paid the £14 entry for myself and 2 kids with £4 cash and a Tesco rewards token which cost me £2.50. It took about an hour and a half.

Most photogenic location.... My title says it all. Its just awesome to see the bridge open and close. The bridge stands with so much grandeur, you are sure to skip a beat with its first site. Best visited in the evening.

Exhilirating.. Thanks to our taxi driver, we drove across this London icon and watch the bridge lift up and down river despite heavy traffic. Approximately 45 minutes wait to cross a rather short span rewarded us with an exhilirating view of the Thames. The imposed minimum speed of 20 miles per hour allowed us to roll down our car windows and view the cables, towers and walkways from below.
London Icon. This bridge is what I picture when I think of London. It's a gorgeous bridge and definitely a must see.

a good look at London. Walk across and enjoy the view..especially of the Tower and Shard nearby. Engine room is different and the shop is worth a look in [but thats a freebie anyway] .The bridge is raised to allow river traffic through and we were lucky enough to view this from the South Bank just after we finished the tour.Not really worth the £9 but its nice to say that you have been on Tower Bridge and to take a few photos. If you come by train, look out for the 2 for 1 offer.
nice walk. this lovely to walk across especially on a nice day as you can get to see the landscape from both sides
Fun thing to do. It is fun to walk across, and there is a great view up and down the Thames. A must see and do in London.

Poor experience. We liked to be "on" the bridge but it wasn't really worth the money. You can just as well walk across the road. The engine room was interesting, but have seen various similiar rooms before, therefore it wasn't really a sight to remember. We couldn't be outside "on" the bridge but walked througha passage. Might as well have been any room you walk through. An expensive experience. Wouldn't do it again.
Great attraction. Iconic London attraction conveniently located near the Tower of London. It's a good attraction to stretch your legs to walk across.

Just super cool & iconic. Tower Bridge, more famous looking than the London Bridge (with the more famous name) would be hard to miss on any trip to London. By boat, by bus, or by tour, I'm sure you'll cross it's path eventually. We enjoyed it via bus tour, and by staring at it from the Tower of London, to which it is next door. The bridge itself is just beautiful. I would love to go back and go up the towers - which we didn't have time for.

Not much of an attraction. From the outside Tower Bridge looks awsome but once your actually on the Bridge it's not the same experience as the one you experienced from couple of miles away.Neverthless still a great icon of London.

A Classic must-see landmark. Tower Bridge is a classic attraction and a must-see for any London visitor.If you can, I advice to explore this bridge by foot and by boat.It's a stunning piece of architecture. The upper walkways were originally built to allow pedestrians to cross the river Thames when the lower part of the bridge was opened to let river traffic travel under the bridge. They were closed in 1910 as it wasn't frequently used, possibly due to the fact that it was a popular haunt for prostitutes and thieves. In 1982 they reopened to be part of the Tower Bridge Exhibition.There is a fee for the exhibition but the rest of the bridge is free to visit and cross.
Working Engineering. So much more than just the bridge - the engine room is spectacular and the walk across the walk was is stunning.

Walk across above the streets and see the drawbridge go up!. Did you know you can go inside the bridge? I didn't until just a few weeks ago. The ticket includes going up inside the bridge and walking across the top (inside). You can get some good pictures of London from up there. Interesting history of the bridge. Also don't miss visiting the engine room to see how the steam and hydrolic systems used to raise and lower the bridge. By the way you can watch the drawbridge go up and sailing ships go under the bridge almost daily. The lift schedule can be found at: http://www.towerbridge.org.uk/TBE/EN/BridgeLiftTimes/To watch the bridge, go to the side of the bridge with the ticket office, the go to the drawbridge side near the ticket office. Stand next to the blue metal gate making sure that you are not on the wrong side of the gate! The bridge is cleared during the lift cycle and you have to be behind that gate. Ask the guard if you have any questions. You will get a great view, and everyone else who didn't know the drawbridge was going up will be standing behind you. ;-)

A tribute to Victorian engineering. We were lucky enough to visit the day the bridge was 120 years old so took advantage of the reduced admission, only £1.20! We were able to take the lift to the small movie theatre showing an entertaining short movie about the designing of the bridge, then we walked out on the viewing platforms, and finally down through the engine rooms. Don't miss the engine rooms!

A Must See in London. The Tower Bridge is a must see! We saw it by taking a River City Cruise Tour and it was a great way to see it from all sides. The bridge is an amazing piece of work and is an iconic part of London.

Iconic Bridge. I must accept that I had seen this bridge in so many movies and pictures but did not know its name before visiting it. Thanks to the unlimited bus pass, that we kept looking for it for quite some time(without worrying about the fare) but could not find it as we had been asking people for London Bridge. The fine architecture of the bridge is worth seeing and if you are in London then you must see this attraction. If you want to have pictures of this bridge at the back then you will have to go to the adjacent bridge, as we did.

Iconic Landmark and more. Tower Bridge is well worth seeing in several different ways. First I sailed under it (Thames Clipper River Bus or River tour, stopping at Tower), then I walked over it at street level, then I went into the Exhibition and walked through the two high level walkways. The architecture and insignia markings are wonderful and you get marvellous views up and down the river from both the street level and especially from the upper levels. Both galleries exhibitions were of interest to me – the western gallery with famous bridges of the world and the eastern gallery with the Sixties. After you proceed back to ground level, you can enter the Victoria Engine Rooms. There is also a short video showing construction of the bridge. Try to time your visit with a bridge opening, a wonderful sight; the opening times are available on the internet.

The Tower Bridge experience. This was good and the kids enjoyed. On our London Pass so no extra cost. The crowd was big, arrived just behind a tour group so climbed the stairs - a hard climb. A little crowded but the highlight was seeing the bridge open while we were there

Iconic bridge. I visit this icon on every time.i go to London as the complex of the the Tower of London and bridge a must see every time.on my last visit on a sunny day ,it inspired me with the spirit of old London

A waste of time and money. We visited this as we had a London pass- if I'd paid directly for this attraction I would have been very disappointed. Basically a view of London from a bit of a height, but there are better in the city. Contrived exhibitions just to make it seem like you're seeing something.

Iconic place. Having grown up watching this landmark on TV, It was a must see when visiting London, so I did. You can cross it easily by foot on both sides, and you may visit. If you want to eat something in the area with great view, try the hot dog / hamburgers caravans near the Starbucks, they are great!

Awesome and well worth a visit. The engineering behind the bridge is the reason why we went there. But, what we got in the bargain was a super-duper tour of the bridge. It has some great exhibits and one of the best views of the Thames waterfront. A must do.

Awesome and well worth a visit. The engineering behind the bridge is the reason why we went there. But, what we got in the bargain was a super-duper tour of the bridge. It has some great exhibits and one of the best views of the Thames waterfront. A must do.

Awesome place. Well.. We were in London last summer and as you would have heard.. there's nothing better than English summers !!Walk from my apartment to tower bridge was awesome.. superb weather, nice people, scenic places.. what else to ask for?!With regards to tower bridge, its as scenic as it looks in the pictures.. quite big and historic...that's the reason so many ppl visit it.We also climbed the towers up (to a museum) and view from top was stellar. We could overlook so many beautiful sights from top (along with view of Thames) and it was majestic. I stayed in London for over a month and visited tower bridge close to 20 times. Surprisingly, I didn't get bore with this. Every time I visited tower bridge I found it equally beautiful and charming.So, If you are in London.. don't miss tower bridge.

Original SteamPunk. We arrived late in thr afternoon and there was no line. We were able to use our handy dandy London pass. The first part of the tour was a little Kitschy . The introduction of the architect and the story of the bridge is entertaining. Even my teenage niece and nephew were amused. The rest of the tour was a self guided tour. Several interesting videos and interactive displays. I enjoyed the info of the Amazing Bridges of the World. The very best part of the self guided tour is the original machinery used to raise and lower the bridge is on display. It is restored to perfection. There is delicate beauty to all the gears and gadgets of the machinery . This is SteamPunk at it's best. The views from the Tower Bridge are outstanding. You have a pilots view of the Thames River. The Tower Bridge Tour is definitely worth a visit for all ages

Well worth a visit.. Excellent. You can either leg it up the stairs ( not for the unfit ) or take the lift. The stairs are more interesting, you get to see some of the inner bits, also there are toilets which is always handy if you're doing a bit of exploring / tourist stuff. The short film is about right, does not drag on too long, but you get the info. Great views of the London skyline etc., as you'd expect., good interesting displays if you are interested, pick and choose. Currently £9 a head, but here is top tip, my train company does 2 for 1 offers, check yours before you travel, quite a few offerings. The out of service steam installations are interesting, one is, as usual, driven so you can see it in motion, overall, highly recommended. Personally I'd like the walkways uncovered, but I doubt many would agree!

Awesome to simply walk across!. We didn't have time to actually go up and walk across Tower Bridge but it would have been really awesome to do that and I would highly recommend factoring in time if you can! We had to be content with walking across but it was fantastic! The structure is amazing in itself and we had the added bonus of a sailing ship going through so the bridge had to be hoisted! It was wonderful to watch the workings of this engineering masterpiece!

It hasn't fallen down yet.... As far as the nursery rhyme goes, this is NOT London Bridge. I did not have time to stop and explore this bridge, just a quick drive by. But it's my favorite of them all as it's more ornate then the rest. Best to visit in the morning.

Tower bridge experience . Super enjoyable experience to climb up the towers and learn about the history of the bridge. They had an exhibit of famous bridges around the world which was very interesting.There were some good activities for the kids including a sticker tour and visual timeline of the bridge being built.

Touristy...So What...We are Tourists. The Tower Bridge is colorful and historic. Just walk across it...the pedestrian walkway on the far side ( opposite from Tower of London) is great. This was a relaxing stroll.
Pride of London. One of London's most famous landmarks, well worth a visit inside to learn about the history and how it functions. Good views from the walkway above

A gem of an attraction. I was not aware that you could actually go inside the bridge and it was really good. As 'seniors' it only cost £6.30 and had to be the bargain of the weekend. Marvellous views and very interesting.

You must see it. It is something that must be seen, it is a beautiful bridge, it is right beside the Tower of London so if you visit the latter you can easily take picture and walk over the bridge. We didn't go inside so can't comment on that. You also see the bridge as part of the Big Bus Tour.

Worth an inside look. Inside the towers of Tower Bridge- be sure to look up! There is lots of history in the towers. You can spend an hour or two if you wanted to read and look at all the historical items on display. It's a unique view with lots of great photo ops.

Take the time. Its an easy visit to walk over or take a boat over. If you walk it make sure that you wait to see it raised if possible, as its an amazing engineering feat in action. Be sure that you also take time to see Cleopatras Needle (Obliske) which is a sister to the one in Central Park NY. Its positioned on the shoreline but is so low key thats its possible to miss it.

Tower Bridge Experience. While the Tower Bridge is pretty impressive, the Tower Bridge Experience is not too impressive. It was included with our London Pass. I would not have paid separately to visit this attraction.

Not so great on a hot day. The exhibition starts off with the option to climb or take the lift to the tower, a fun choice. At the top of the stairs or lift there is a lovely dramatic exhibit explaining the origin of the bridge. Across the two spans there is lots of information. On a hot and humid July day there is little air up there (you would expect a great breeze but the bridge spans are covered in). Going down is the problem. On a busy day you are confined into a small, hot, unorganized area where 25 people at a time get to take the lift down because the stairs do not take you to street/bridge level. Not for the claustrophobic or those who don't like the heat.
Great feeling while going across the bridge. Great view, great feeling while going across especially in an open bus or in an river cruise with the bridge as background.

Well worth a visit. This beautiful bridge, which most Americans associate with "London Bridge" (it's not!), is well worth the visit. The London Bridge Experience is a must as well (especially for those with a London Pass). The engineering that was necessary to make this bridge is still impressive, even by today's standards. Don't miss it!

Extraordinary Bridge, OK Exhibition. The bridge itself is iconic without doubt. But that view is for free and easily obtained by a good walk or a million vistas that show it off. The exhibition is worth the time if part of a London Pass, but otherwise in my opinion not worth the ticket price for a family. We had purchased a 1-day London Pass, itself only a good value only if you pack a lot into every day you use it (we toured the War Rooms, Westminster Abbey, Globe Theater, Tower Bridge and the Tower in one day). So something like the Tower Bridge became a sunk cost and worth the view. If you are doing the London Eye (another vista that is expensive for what you get), you will have much better views of the City. I rated the Bridge a 3 and my daughters (age 14, 19 & 23) rated it a 2 for the price / value.

Tower Bridge Experience.. I visited this attraction some years ago with my children. They have cut down on staff who have now been replaced with video screens. This is a shame. It was much better having someone speaking to you in person.The cost is very reasonable and we had a 2 for 1 voucher from the C2C booklet. The best part of the visit is going over the Walkways. The views are good and looking from outside it's difficult to imagine that there are people in there.

Excellent place to walk and very nice views. The most impressive fact was the elevation of the bridge's road to let some ships pass under it. It was a hot and sunny day to enjoy good views and eating outside.

Great View "first thing to start london tour". Amazing views on Thames. First place i visited in London enjoyed alot. Must go place in london.......
:-)

Great displays and movie. This was a great tourist attraction. Lots of history on the construction. informative movies and displays. we particularly like the engine rooms. Less exciting for a 7 year old than some of the other London attractions, but the stickers given out at various locations made sure he also finished the tour. Well done.
And surrounds.... Go to Butlers Wharf or outside the mayor of London's building to get the best view. Great when it opens

Great views. Nice easy entry process. Plenty of time to walk around with great views over the Thames. The engine room is well worth a walk through and is probably more fascinating than the tower itself.

walk the bridge. A great experience to walk along the bridge at any time of the day particularly sunrise or sunset. The bridge itself is beautiful but the views are just superb. I didn't go up as I was told that it is not worth the money but if you have a London Pass check it out for sure.

The iconic bridge. This was on top of the must see lists in London. We reached the bridge by boat. Got off the cruise and had the walk on the bridge that we will never forget. What a view !!! What an artistic landmark !!! Make sure not to miss it.
Beautiful Bridge. We visited the Tower Bridge after visiting Tower of London. We walked around and on the bridge to take pictures. We spent about one hour and a half there.

Not as old as I thought, but still an important landmark. Toured the bridge as part of out London Pass card we orderedElevators going to the upper decks packed! Nice views of city from upper deckBritain in the 60s display was a little skimpy but I learned a few things about Twiggy that I didn't knowGift shop was super packed as it was quite smallOverall glad we did this one
Worth a visit. A nice exhibition. I got it included in my London Pass so that's why we went. Enjoyed it and would recommend it.
Truly Iconic. Went there yesterday, it was one of the hottest days, couldn't resist but walk down to the Thames. It was late evening so saw the sunset and lights come on. Will re-visit tonight :)

Bridge Enthusiasts Delight!. My husband is an engineer and bridge enthusiast. He was in heaven. But even for those of us who aren't classified in that category, we very much enjoyed the tour. The history and engine room are marvels. The staff were very helpful and the London Pass provided quick entry. The views are lovely from this iconic symbol of London.

View from on high. Once you get past the claustrophobic elevator ride to the top you have spectacular views without the crowds. The company running the exhibition could better have spaced out the crowds coming to the top so that new arrivals did not walk across those in the middle of viewing the film on the bridge's history. There should also have been dedicated seats for the elderly to remind self-centered tourists to be courteous of their elders.

An iconic bridge. Once you have your ticket you are taken up by lift and given instructions from the lift operator. There is a short video presentation followed by a walk across the left viewing gantry which takes you across the bridge with pictures and written information not only about London bridge but also bridges around the world. The view down the Thames is incredible, you then see a second presentation which shows the bridge construction. The second gantry when we visited was a display of pop, fashion and English political history in the form of pictures and audio. You make your way to ground level, go outside the tower walk along the bridge footpath to the engine room this is a fascinating display of steam engineering and how the bridge was raised by steam. The took us 1 1/2 hours but you can take longer or less time as you like

Tower Bridge. Have seen it many time in movies etc. It was great to see it "live".Took a stroll across it while on a long walk along the river but now wish we had entered the towers. A great piece of engineering with fabulous views of London thrown in.Kayjohn
Stop here after the tower of london. A quick visit is all you need. If you have the London pass you avoid the lines and can move thru the exhibits in less than an hour.

Neat tour. Other than the little videos they have you watch, the tour is neat. You can see the boiler rooms, and you walk across the bridge and read all about its history. It's worth the time to stop and do this. The toilets are disgusting, so don't drink two pots of tea before coming here.

great to walk around. since i was staying at the hilton next door, couldn't resist a stroll around. Its a famous bridge, so always nice to see such old history and pleasant area on the water for a walk.

Engineering showpiece. The London Tower Bridge is an iconic Feature in London that you can also visit . It is worth a peek as it does not take too much time and suits the different interests of a range of people. Whether you are an engineer who is interested in the bridge's workings or perhaps history is your thing or the social reasons why the bridge was. Built? You pay an entry fee and then enter near the North Tower. You are given a graphic enhanced history lesson on why the bridge was built and by whom. You then see a nice simple quick graphic that shows the bridge being built. This was my favourite part. Then you can view a clip on how the bridge works showing how it opens ad closes. The engine rooms are open for viewing and you are able to walk Round and get a good look at each engine. Then it is onto the Tower Bridge Road that has black and white photographs of influential people from the sixties from England. E.g Twiggy, The Beatles. Rolling Stones. You have the option of visiting the gift shop if that is your thing. Then you are free to go. How fast you go through is really dependent upon the individual.

Great views of London. My husband and I decided to visit Tower Bridge whilst on a day trip to London. Whilst is wasn't quiet what we were expecting it was a very enjoyable experience and would recommend it even if its just so you can experience some fabulous views of London. Seeing how the bridge worked and learning about how it was constructed was very interesting too.

Good value. We visited on a two for one deal with a rail ticket and therfore only paid £4.50 each. It started with a explanation of how and why the bridge came to be, and then you get to the walkways between the two towers. These had a display of other bridges around the world, more detail about the history of the bridge, and an exhibition about the sixties when we visited. Good views across the Thames although photography opportunities are a bit limited as most of the windows are closed and don't allow clear images. We had been on the London Eye earlier the same day and the views were so much better. Anyway the Tour ended with an opportunity to see the huge motors which operate the bridge.

Birthday visit. No not mine,Tower Bridge 120th birthday on 30 June 2014,with a special admission entry of £1.20,to see the exhibition.We went by public transport,as parking almost impossible and had a pleasant Thameside walk from Tower Hill Station.This was one of the places that I always meant to visit.There are wonderful views,up and down river from the covered walkways and to see the engine room,with the original engines,that they used to use.Only downside,there is no catering facilities,to have a coffee and something to eat.

Classic. My vision of London and what most associate with the thought of London Bridge (wrongly). Beautiful bridge, gorgeouse architecture, really a must see when in London. You can take a tub to tower bridged stop and it's a short walk from there. I would suggest doing the tower castle tour while your there.
Nice Walk. This is one of those places that you plan on going but you don't actually write onto your list of places you know? That being said it is a very nice walk. It's a fantastic view!

beautiful bridge to look at, the best looking bridge in London. loved seeing this bridge, a long walk from my hostel by it was worth it, it looks beautiful and has nice views from it, its right next to the tower of London which is a bonus.

Nice visit to the old machines and the history of the bridge. This beautiful bridge is the place of a nice visit where you can know the details about how this bridge was built and how it used to work from its beginning. The engine rooms are very well preserved and you can see all the systems very closely.

Beautiful and great views!!. This was another must see place as part of our 6-day London Pass and walked to it just after our 3 hour visit of the Tower of London. We got in and waited for our elevator ride up. Once up, both sides have splendid views as you walk along. Note that there are a few openings along the window where you can use your camera and not have any window glare! Loved that. After walking along both sides went all the way down to the engine room and marveled at those engines. It was a great visit and really an hour is all you need.

Great and quick attraction for families. Lines for this were fairly short, even in the summer. This was included in our London Pass so we did not have to pay separate admission. We entered the ticket office without having to wait, got our tickets and waited <10 minutes for the elevator ride to the top of the first tower. We saw a brief video narration about the towers origins and then walked across the top span, allowing you to see up and down the Thames. Many wall hangings show you other types of bridges around the world and help you learn about bridge construction and design. At the far tower, there is an animated movie that shows the stages of construction in time lapse which was fascinating (especially for my civil engineer daughter). You finish the above ground tour by crossing back and forth across the upriver span of the bridge which looks west over the city. After taking the stairs back down to street level, you can cross to the bank and continue your tour of the engine room that shows the history of the mechanism that lifts the bridge spans. It only takes a few additional minutes, is worth the time and rarely has long lines.

Tower Bridge Walkway - an excellent evening venue. A former colleague held his retirement party here a couple of weeks back. The walkway is accessed by lift and provides a wonderful backdrop for an evening event. You can hire one or both sides of the bridge. The space is clearly long and narrow but was a superb location.

What a Bridge. It's got to be one of the best value for money attractions in London very informative and you have as much time as you need to take everything in , all the staff are very knowledgable and pleasant .there is,nt anything to dislike about this venue .

Nice view, nice engine. Go visit this place at least to see the view from the top. If you like mechanical things and engines, then more to see. A collection of pictures with all sorts of bridges is shown upstairs

Bring your camera. Walked to the bridge and did the tour. The weather was cold and rainy(shocking) and it was great to be indoors. The pictures of the city from the bridge are the best photo moments of London. The tour is very nice, you can spend a lot of time just viewing the sights over the Thames River.

An interesting History. A ticket for the Tower Bridge Exhibition is worth your time, the history alone is worth half an hour of your time, I was unaware that this was the fourth Bridge built on or very near this site. Along with Big Ben this is probably one of the most iconic landmarks of London. You get an excellent view of the Thames area from the high level walkway between the two towers, if like me you are afraid of heights, this is no barrier, I felt totally safe and at no point worried.

I'm not sold with the blue!. We walked up to the bridge and also passed under it by boat. Not quite convinced with the blue. I was told that you can enjoy the view from one of the towers without necessarily paying by having breakfast at the restaurant but you may have a more significant view from the Tate Museum right in front of Saint Paul Cathedral and without consuming anything (museums are free in London).

Learn more about our iconic bridge. Take some time and do a guided visit where you can go down and see how it all works. It is really interesting and while the are there of course it's a beautiful bridge to walk on and take in the stunning views.

Arguably the finest piece of architectural brilliance of any aqueducts in the world. No trip of London is ever complete without the glimpse of this iconic bridge which defines London. Built over river Thames tower bridge is the most photogenic and 'pleasing to the eye' bridge one can see. Take a walk by the river side from tower of London and all the way to the tower bridge. Walk on the bridge crossing the River Thames taking a glimpse of the warship 'Belfast' in a fair distance. Stop on the bridge just to watch River Thames and the London cityscape. We visited in summer and the weather was absolutely gorgeous. You can take the guided tour as well if you like if you have time.

Going up in the world. 2nd visit in a few months to this brilliant visitor experience and the bonus of the bridge being raised this time.Fascinating displays and well presented original machinery. Worth a visit for anyone not just the engineer.
Most recognized bridge in the world. As you walk across you can go up one tower across the top and down the other side we fund not see the bridge open but I guess it does not do so very often
Walk Across. We didn't do the Tower Bridge experience, £8 per adult online, we just walked across and took photos.

Great looking bridge ... Must see . Good: Iconic structure at thames riverMust see if you are in londonLot of photo opportunity Bad:Somewhat long distance if you are walking to it from the tower hill harbour after alighting from cruise Summary: Bridge will open up if there are ships with certain height passing by if you could see it you are bless !

Tower Bridge. This was a very interesting place to visit. Not only did it show how the opening and closing of the bridge happens but there were also displays. For example there was an exhibition dedicated to Carnaby St. with photos and stories of London in the 70's.This was great. The bridge was certainly a value for money attraction. We spent two hours just taking in all that there was to offer at the Bridge.

Nice for photo shooting. I did not go up to thr tower instead took nice photos with the tower. Thats what most of the people did there. Nearby area was also worth visiting...btw, its a huge bridge and towers wrre nily archtectured..

Iconic bridge. We visited the Tower Bridge as it was included in the London Pass. The history of the bridge and exhibitions were great. The mechanics of the bridge were amazing to see. A must see if only to get a picture of the iconic bridge.

I probably liked this more than most. I'm fascinated by great engineering feats and how people back then built things.
This is kind of a short basic attraction but interesting.
It was part of our london pass so I'm not sure how much it cost. More that 10 pounds would be too much.

Great views. The Tower Bridge Experience gives a good history of the bridge. Great views from the walkways above the bridge but disappointed that there was no outside access. The 'photo' windows were useless, too small & high for most people. Loved the bridges of the world exhibition. Felt the Sixties exhibition rather out of place.The engineering building was interesting and well laid out with plenty of information.Staff all very friendly and helpful.

Iconic just to walk across. This is a review of the Bridge itself, I do have another review of the actual Exibition on a different page. The Tower Bridge is a big beautiful iconic treasure that is FREE to enjoy, so WHY aren't you going? Easily accesible from the Tower of London and a great walk around the Thames, the Bridge is just fun to be on and take hindreds of photos of and from. The views of the city are lovely from here and the atmosphere lively and fun. My 11 yr old just loved walking across and back and forth and viewing the city and the Tower from here. a FREE attraction that should not be missed. At the bottom along the Thames, there are shops and eateries as well. while by the Thames, go to the water and find your own London treasure! The Thames was actually the dumping ground of London before they had sewerage and you can still find ancint treasures pieces in the sand off the Thames. Coins, metal, glass, anything....kids LOVE it!! And it's a piece of history that you can't buy in a shop!
Tower Bridge. I didn't want to pay to go up and see the museum, but just seeing the bridge and getting your picture on it is fun. It is a great piece of architecture.

Wonderful tour disappointed about picture. We bought London Passes and this was included. Was worth the visit. Brief history on bridge enlightening about the times and transports. We had our picture taken and tried to claim it at the end of bridge and they told us it was in main part. We went to where tour started and they told us it was where we had been. It was end of day and we were tired after crossing Thames several times on foot so we opted not to go back to get it so this was disappointing. Otherwise it was a wonderful experience and view.

One people don't often think about.... You can just walk across at ground level but its also good to walk across the high level walkways( there is a charge for this ) but it also gives access to the inside & mechanics of our amazing iconic bridge.

Just Walk It. Both Ways.. Tower BridgeTo say that the Tower Bridge is an "icon" of London is somewhat redundant. It along with the Tower of London and St Paul's and Buckingham Place IS LONDON. The London EYE be damned. I find the "eye" an abonination and an eyesore on what really is London. (But so did traditionals speaking about the Eiffel Tower.) Nevertheless. The Tower Bridge is special and not to be missed. You cannot walk across it and not be humbled by what was once the power of England and it's building andwhat they did. Just a walk across is worth the time. Stroll and enjoy. It's free.

Fantastic to experience Tower Bridge's high walkways on its 120th anniversary!. Arriving at Tower Bridge mid-morning in June, I was expecting a long queue, especially as it was the bridge's 120th anniversary, with tickets at only £1.20 on the day. The ticket office is at the base of the northern tower (on the Tower of London side of the river) & luckily we only waited 10 minutes to get in. The RV1 bus takes you from Waterloo, down Tooley Street, and right across Tower Bridge, or you can travel by Tube. After purchasing your ticket, you go up the north tower, either via the stairs or the lift. A short film is shown at the top, then you can walk along the East and West Walkways above the bridge. On the East side, there are pictures & info about famous world bridges, while on the West there is currently a great 60s exhibition, with large boards depicting fashion, cars, & famous people from that era. Both sides are enclosed by girders and glass, apart from a few small windows which you can open to take photos of the great river views. I was very excited to be up on the walkways on such a special day, especially as Tower Bridge was built around the time that my Grandmother was born near by in the East End of London. From the social history viewpoint, it was easy to imagine her parents & family battling to cross the crowded sole London Bridge, before Tower Bridge was constructed.It takes about 2 hours to look around, and I wouldn't really take young children. Toilets are available inside. 3 short films are shown, at the beginning, middle and end.Without exception the staff were extremely friendly, helpful and cheerful, and nothing was too much trouble. I especially enjoyed the costumed characters who spoke to us & made us laugh as we went around.When you come out, the Engine room is about 50 yards down the road, with a blue line on the ground to follow. I thought the small shop was very well stocked with a wide range of souvenirs. Several other London sights are close by - the Tower of London to the north, and the Shard, City Hall, HMS Belfast, & Old Operating Theatre on the South bank. There are several places for a meal or a snack (Starbucks, Cote etc) and the Globe Theatre and Tate Modern are a 30 minute walk further along the Southbank, towards Waterloo. I thoroughly enjoyed this visit & found it thrilling to be high up on the actual walkways of such an iconic bridge.

A 'must do' for all ages and visitors. I am biased I know, as to me Tower Bridge has always been second to none anywhere in the world since I was a child...... but saying that, for any visitor to London, whether from abroad or from other areas of the UK, it really is an experience not to be missed and, as attractions go it's not unreasonably priced. It was £9 for me as an adult, my husband got £2.50 off for being over 60! The initial film show.. only a few minutes long explaining how the bridge came about is clearly geared for those with short attention spans and is a bit gimmicky but at least you get the idea of why the bridge was needed and how it ended up being a bascule bridge.The 'wow' factor is the view from the walk ways linking the two towers. Looking back down the river towards Strafford and then up the river towards Westminster you get astoundingly clear and good views. The view towards The City and its new buildings - The 'walkie talkie', 'the cheese grater' and 'gherkin' is superb and of course The Shard dominates the south bank views. I personally think you get a better perspective from Tower Bridge... The Shard views are magnificent but everything looks 'model' sized you are so high up, from Tower Bridge is all looks very real and very dramatic.The second video show is about the construction of the bridge and I found that interesting plus the model workers above on the girders showed how dangerous it would have been for them... they say 'only'!! 10 men died during the construction.The engine room is not to be missed.... apart from the pristine condition and glorious paintwork.... it is stunning to see what is needed to raise the spans.There are plenty of places to sit and have a coffee afterwards looking back up at where you have just walked afterwards.

Nothing to fuss about!. This bridge is world famous - but I have never found out why! It is often mistaken for London Bridge. Tower Bridge (built 1886–1894) is a combined bascule and suspension bridge which crosses the River Thames. It is close to the Tower of London, from which it takes its name, and has become an iconic symbol of London.The bridge consists of two towers tied together at the upper level by means of two horizontal walkways, designed to withstand the horizontal forces exerted by the suspended sections of the bridge on the landward sides of the towers. The vertical component of the forces in the suspended sections and the vertical reactions of the two walkways are carried by the two robust towers. The bascule pivots and operating machinery are housed in the base of each tower. The bridge's present colour scheme dates from 1977, when it was painted red, white and blue for Queen Elizabeth II's silver jubilee. Originally it was painted a mid greenish-blue colourTower Bridge is still a busy and vital crossing of the Thames: it is crossed by over 40,000 people (motorists, cyclists and pedestrians) every day.The bridge featured in publicity for the 2012 Summer Olympics being held in London. In June 2012 a set of Olympic rings was suspended from the bridge to mark one month to go until the start of the games.

Amazing Bridge to Walk Across. So, at Tower Bridge, you can simply walk across it if you want, or you can also do the "Tower Bridge" experience.Personally, having done both, I would recommend just visiting the bridge and walking across and taking it in. The Tower Bridge Experience basically is like a video and history lesson like you would get on Wikipedia. I wouldn't say that it is worth paying for to go to! However, walking across the bridge is free of charge and anyone can do. You will get many amazing photos from the bridge. You can also find the schedule of when the bridge opens (it opens usually at least once per day) by the Control Room of the bridge. That's near the center of the bridge.

I CAN SEE IT EVERYWHERE...... With my one-day London Pass, I was able to visit the TOWER OF LONDON, HMS BELFAST and the TOWER BRIDGE.These 3 attractions are near each other, about 5-10 minutes of walking from each other. The tour of the Tower Bridge begins by taking the elevator at the entrance of the attraction. A short film was shown about the construction of the bridge. There are 2 sides of the tower where one can walk to see different views of London. I enjoyed visiting the Engine Room and hearing how it works, the number of times the bridge is lifted, etc. It would be fun had the bridge been lifted while I was visiting it. The tour ends near the Gift Shop - I wonder why.Having visited the Tower Bridge, now I no longer ask myself, "what's up there?" Do visit it and see the answer to this question yourself.

Geeks will be disappointed. Don't get me wrong. This is a fascinating, unique place to visit. I do recommend it. So where's the but? Compared with my review elsewhere of the Cutty Sark at Greenwich, the interpretation of how the bridge worked in steam days is - er - woeful. The film shows explaining its conception are brilliant. And I do know a thing or two about boilers, steam engines and hydraulic pumps and motors. But I found the display boards baffling. I presume that if I knew nothing about how these things worked, I would be utterly puzzled. The texts were OK and accurate, but the graphics were terrible. Once upon a time in my life I was a technical illustrator, so I do have knowledge and experience about how to represent systems (e.g. atomic power electricity generation), plus how stuff works - the machinery.This isn't a plug. but if the Tower Bridge Exhibition curators would like to get in touch with me as to how they could improve things, I wouldn't turn them down.The 60s exhibition in the walkeway was a good retrospective of those times (I was a teenager then so I'm acutely aware of the social impact of the things they chose to highlight). Well done. The display of the most important, groundbreaking bringes, also on the walkway, was also very, very good. What disappointed me was a crowd of a dozen or more Dutch school party trippers (I speak Dutch) who whizzed through end-to-end texting on their mobile phones, took the odd picture out of the walkway windows, and, well, I don't know what great historic place they were going to visit next that they would skim over with the lightest iof touches. The fact that they were all female is not of any relevance to me - even though I'm a man, I'm a feminist. What a missed opportunity for them to learn so much. But that's not Tower Bridge's problem. Just a problem for a visitor taking a lot of interest in the place.

Fabulous views and fascinating exhibition. I had always wanted to visit Tower Bridge and after many years finally fulfilled my wish. It did not disappoint. The climb to the top of the tower was a bit of a fitness test but the exhibitions and videos, showing the Tower's history, on the way kept us going. Once on the walkways the spectacular views, which ever way you turned, were mesmerizing. When we finally went back down the visit was completed by a visit to the Engine Rooms was fascinating and we would have stayed much longer if time had allowed.

Gorgeous landmark..great view from the towers. If there is a photographic symbol of London, this beautiful bridge has to be it. We had purchased the London Pass which includes admission to the Tower Bridge Exhibition. Normal admission is £9.00 for an adult. There are a few short films on the tour and you are able to walk across the upper bridge portion to view exhibits and information on the building of the bridge, other famous bridges in the World, etc. One portion of the exhibit when we were there had to do with the 1960s, just iconic images of that time period. It was ok, but we found ourselves skipping most of that portion. You can get some nice photos through the little windows you can open in the upper bridge portion. We were then able to exist and be escorted over to the Engine Rooms which were also interesting to see. TIP: If you'd like to see the Tower Bridge actually open, then refer to this website for opening dates and times http://www.towerbridge.org.uk/TBE/EN/BridgeLiftTimes/. We checked the schedule ahead of time and planned our visit so we could see it open. Had the pleasure of seeing an old mast ship pass through!TIP: Don't just visit the bridge during the daytime for photo. If you want some spectacular photos, go back to the area at night, cross the bridge and go to the other side of the River to take some beautiful night photos of the bridge lit up (along with the Tower of London). It is absolutely gorgeous at night!

A lot more than you first expect. Visited off the cuff as were passing (we live in central London) with the boys (12 & 10) ... kept them occupied for a couple of hours which was great. Ticket cost very acceptable for London, tour well planned out with a good mix of things to see, do and learn about.

Magnificent structure. We took a stroll down the river and eventually came to this bridge. Before I talk about the bridge I'd like to say that it is such a nice walk down the river, lots of shops and restaurants, very much worth the walk.The bridge itself is absolutely magnificent. It certainly has its own personality which you can almost feel as you walk across it. The view is amazing as well, overlooking the river and the tower of London you get a feel for the age and history of this beautiful city.

Fairlytale bridge . It is just a bridge. One of the must-see's in London. It is closer to Tower of London. The bridge looks like it came from fairytale. I loved the architecture and colours of the bridge. You can also enjoy the bridge when a ship passes under it.

Excellent - we loved it!. We visited the Tower Bridge Exhibition as a family - Mum, Dad, two boys aged 14 & 11 and Gran. We had a fantastic time. We used the national rail 2 for 1 offer and so saved a bit as we had travelled down from Mansfield by train that day. The ticket purchasing was easy and swift and we were soon in the lift bring taken up the first tower of the bridge. The two videos showing you the design and build of the bridge were informative & interesting. The exhibition within the two viewing galleries was excellent too. And the views were amazing! We were also very pleasantly surprised by the fist shop on exiting the Engine room - some really lovely, reasonably priced souvenirs - not your usual cheap tat! Would really recommend this!

Great views, avoid the vendors and pickpockets. Great views and several nearby restaurants in the Butlers Wharf area and in St. Katherine's Docks. One local did tell me to avoid the guy selling candied nuts from pushcarts since they're not licensed and run when police arrive. Around dusk, police start patrolling for pickpockets.
tower bridge london. Great place for an easy walk into london.Stayed at the Tower bridge Hotel.Good landmark for visitors.

An iconic bridge. On any sight seeing visit to London, this is a must. It is located next to the Tower of London and is easily accessed. The best views are from the embankment, outside the Tower of London. You can pay to go inside and view the internal structure, and if you are very lucky, they may need to open the bridge to let the river traffic through. Worth a visit.

Great views and a great story. Great views of that part of the city, from the Eye in the West to the eye in the East. Fun to watch the traffic on the streets, sidewalks and river. An interesting story about London, the early markets, wharfs, ferries, and finally the Bridge. Amazing to think about how recently this bridge was built. An interesting story about how the bridge mechanism works. We'd visited Armstrong's (the developer of the bascule mechanism I believe) mansion in Cragside and learned something about the engineer. To see the mechanisms in action made all that history come alive. I'd recommend a visit especially to people interested in history and how things work. It's not worth the entry fee if all you want is a view. You can get that from the nearby Millenium Bridge or from a walk along the Thames bank.

What fun! Great for young kids especially!. Really enjoyed the Tower Bridge experience! It was educational and fun all at the same time which is rare to find. We had a lovely pub lunch at London Bridge before taking a walk by the river past HMS Belfast & City Hall before climbing up to the Tower. The passport system for kids was great as my son looked forward to getting the stickers at every checkpoint. The exhibition which was on the swinging sixties was very informative and interesting. This was intermixed with information about different kinds of bridges and bridges all over the world. We were trying to guess how many we had been to. A great day out and not too expensive as well.

must be seen. must go see this as well if your down London even if it just to say you have ben on the most famous bridge in the world fancy the yanks thing they were getting this from the UK . You can go inside if you like to do so or just stay on the bridge it self .

A walk to remember.. Walked the London Bridge. Took many pictues, just like all the other visitors on the bridge. Very clean and picturesque walk across the water. A small gift shop at the end of London Bridge. Some of the best pictures to be taken are at the walkway off the bridge.

Beautiful.. You need to take the time to see the bridge. And of course while you are there see the Tower of London. The bridge is worth seeing because it is not the London bridge that you think of, the London bridge is a few blocks away and just a plain old bridge.

Awesome Structure. Well worth a visit, a must see sight with spectacular views of the City of London, Tower of London etc. take a camera for fantastic photo's can't say much more other than a must see!

Another landmark, not to be missed.. Now that I have been there, I recognize this bridge in so many movies and television shows. Walking across it, as I did several times, did not get old. The lights over the river are beautiful at night.

Interesting!. Had the tour given by Gunta , I think her name was & she was so well versed & informed. She was patient & giving as a tour guide. Good value especially with 2 for 1 offer with the train. The engine room machinery was fabulous!!! It took a good hour but there could have been a little more seating available especially at busy times.

Well Worth the Walk. Even though the day was a bit grey, the walk across Tower Bridge was worthwhile. We had a bit of a wait as the bridge opened to let a cruise ship through. fascinating to see how that all worked. Even though it is not very old it is an impressive bridge. Views up and down the Thames were great.

Awesome . I visited the bridge both at night and during the day. It is particularly cool at night. I found it to be an awesome thing to see. Walked bak and forth across and having the tower fortress next to it also helps. I think this is a must do.

A bit cookie cutter. The tower bridge experience was very impersonal. I thought it could've been more informative with a guided tour instead of a corny introduction video and then just a picture gallery to look at.Wonderful view but it needed a more personal element
View of the Thames River and London. Wonderful view of London and the river. It was a rather clear day and we were able to take alot of pics.

A worthwhile visit with history and London views.. A good half day visit leaving time to take in the nearby Tower also.Entry reasonably priced and plenty of time to take in the visit.Features are views, pictorial history and original machinery. And the chance to say you have been up there!Take a camera.

Great view ,nice experience!. It was very interesting to see how the bridge works and learn all its history.The view was amazing.You pay to enter the Exhibition ,but it is not very expensive and for my opinion its worth it.

Tower bridge exhibition. I went several times to the Tower Bridge but never went to the exhibition. We went on saturday and it was actually quite interesting. Take the time to read the stories about the bridge, how it was designed and created... It's sad as it was raining a lot but it was really worth it. Good experience on the most famous bridge in the world ! It's interesting to see the engine room too.

Symbolic Icon. Symbolic icon of London. Mistaken always as the London Bridge but actually called the “Tower Bridge”. You need to cross the bridge to appreciate its splendor. The bridge connects the Tower of London and the City hall.

The amazing Bridge. The recommended time is after the sunset.
You'll get a amazing view, and then you should take a photo.

Tower Bridge Exhibition. The Tower Bridge itself is spectacular. It looks beautiful during the day and especially at night. It's fun to cross the bridge, and it's a great venue for taking pictures. The Tower Bridge Exhibition, which you pay to enter, is what I am rating. Compared to other London attractions, it was not that expensive, but my husband and I both agree that we could easily have done without it. You see videos about its history and about how it was built. You have access to the walkway at the very top of the bridge, but the exhibits up there did not interest either one of us. One interesting part was viewing the original machinery that ran the bridge, but my husband was more interested in that than I was. If you are trying to save money and/or time, enjoy the beautiful bridge for free but pass on the Tower Bridge Exhibition.

Amazing views!. We walked across the bridge and visited the exhibition since it was included as part of our London Pass. We really went for the views, but the exhibition is nicely done and includes a lot of history that we would have otherwise missed. We did wind up skipping the engine rooms because we were on our way to the Tower and would have had to backtrack too much. The best part of course are the views from the top. Just amazing!
London must see site.. A really interesting tourist site, well worth a visit and not too expensive. Don't miss a look at the engine rooms.

Nice Old Bridge. This icon is always mistaken as the London Bridge. It is remarkable and had functions to fold back upwards to allow bigger vessels to pass through. It's a short walk from the Tower of London. Worth to visit and nice pictures could be taken near the river bank right after the Tower of London.
amazing view from the top. it is worth visiting the exhibition, great view, lots of info about London and the Tower, can see the inside of the 2 towers

Amazing view!. We spent most of the time walking on the bridge and admiring the astonishing view. We were glad to discover that from the one bank of Thames it was standing the Tower of London which represents the old London and from the other bank of the river, the contemporary side of London with the skyscrapers and the business world. We were not so interested in visiting the museum and the price was demotivating too. We simply loved it!

Super Bridge. We enjoyed the bridge view from river side. We didnt see the exhibition as we found it to be quite expensive. Check out the website to see bridge opening times. We saw the bridge opening at 7 pm and it was definitely worth. Best way to see tower bridge is by combining tower of london and the bridge together.

Great Time - Fabulous Staff. We love London Bridge so on our 3rd trip to London we decided to go on the London Bridge Experience. It was a beautiful day so the view of London from the top was amazing. But the best part was the staff. We had my 82 year old mother in a wheel chair with us and the care and attention that they gave her was incredible. One of the employees (wish I remembered his name) escorted us down and took the time to make sure we got to the engine room which was a confusing and difficult route since we where unable to take the stairs.

Love it!. I didn´t expect to see that much inside, but since it was included in the londonpass, I decided to give it a go. I really enjoyed it, a very nice presentation with an interactive movie at the beginning, very nicely done and not boring at all, then we went through the walkaways with an exhibition about the bridges of the world, which was really nice and had fantastic views of Thames river. On the other side, the tower with the victorian machines, which is even if you think you won´t be interested at all, really wonderful to see, even my mom who is not interested at all in big machinery, was really into seeing how they used to work and love it! I would definetely recommend it! We bought the souvenir photo at the end! it´s a little bit expensive but totally worth it!

Icon of london. Although I didnt visit the exibition I did visit the bridge if you dont have the time just standing on the river bank photo taking is good enough the bridge is one of the best bridges in london if you do intend taking photos you may consider standing on london bridge to take some

Cool engineering!. We went this morning before 11am & found out that we were just a few minutes away from the lifting of the bridge! Naturally, we got excited for this extra bonus. The bascule is lifted 3x/day on scheduled times. It would be ideal to know the times for the lifting of the drawbridge. You can get this information from the ticket booth. We just got lucky that there was an incoming boat at 11am. It was nice to know the history & some random facts about the Tower Bridge & London in general (icons of music, fashion, modeling, entertainment were featured on one side of the walkway). I liked how they presented & categorized the iconic bridges in the world as to the origin, composition, type of bridge, construction, reconstruction, etc. I like the Tower Bridge exhibition. If you love science, particularly engineering & architecture, you will highly appreciate this iconic bridge. The bridge is still functional up to this day.

Not to be missed - a London icon. Walking across the tower bridge is one of those 'must dos' whilst in London. I enjoyed walking across, thankfully without too much rain! Note however that it does get a little busy, particularly if you're walking along the southern side of the river. To find the times when the bridge is raised, they put out a sign on the bridge masters office on the souther side of the river.

Absolute beauty. This is such a beautiful bridge and really not to be missed. The exhibition is informative and there is a 20% off voucher on the tourist maps which seem to float about in hotel lobbies. We liked the extra information from the exhibition on the structure and people behind the bridge a lot.

Iconic Bridge. We had to walk over it a few times. It is stunning to view it from either bank and get your snaps. It matches the architecture of Tower of London so perfectly. Must be one of the most photographed sites in town.

Most beautiful Icon of London. Visited the Tower Bridge for Photo Taking, didnt visit the exhibition after reading reviews on it.Just standing along the river and looking at the Tower Bridge is impressive enough to let you stare at it for minutes and I'm sure you will take many pictures.A must visit and photo stop for a visit to London.

Tower Bridge Exhibition. The only real advantage of paying for 'The Tower Bridge Exhibition' is firstly to experience the high walkway [which is now safely glassed in] and see the photos and documents on display and secondly [even better] to go into the amazing historic engine rooms and see how the bridge was originally raised. The machinery looks to be in pristine condition.

An iconic London landmark. Despite a lifetime of visiting London I’d never visited Tower Bridge. It turned out to be a brilliant and informative tour on a lovely sunny London day.I’d somehow foolishly (in retrospect) expected we would be in the open when we got to the top walkway but everything is safely enclosed in glass to protect you from the elements and no doubt the pedestrian and river users below from falling visitor items!TOP TIPSGo when it opens in the morning to avoid the crowdsMake sure you also go into the engine rooms and the end of the tour to see the fabulous machines that were used to raise the bridgeIf you buy the joint ticket that takes in a trip up the Monument please note it is a good 20 minute walk to get there. You do however have seven days to use your ticket.
must visit atleast once. London bridge is one of the best attraction one should not miss it.... fantastic view of river thames..... superb place to visit,,,,

They don't build them this way any more!. a very historical old structure. From a a distance, it simply looks like a unique old structure but at its time, it was actually a very sophisticated engineering project!Very interesting!
don't pay the tickect. walk over the bridge, admire it from the distance but in my opinion there is no need to pay the entrance, there is nothing special to see inside

One the planet's greatest sights. It's like something out of a fairy tale and looks great both in daylight and lit up at night. A magnificent structure and if you're lucky you might actually see it open, to let a boat through.

Victorian Engineering. This is a must see to anyone who visits London, it is an icon of the London sights and a bonus would be to see it when the bridge is opened to let shipping through. Take a river trip and get some fantastic photos of it from the river
Great view. I walked along river near Tower Millennium Pier and Tower of London. It was very good view and the bridge looked beautiful.

A tired experience that needs modern input. This is an iconic landmark and tourists will always want to say they have been on the bridge. Because of this, they probably don't feel they need to do much to attract visitors and maybe they are right. Indeed, the views are fab and will always be worth it. BUT, I really feel that the 'experience' needs modernising. You go in a lift (elevator) packed like sardines - not for the claustrophobic! You arrive and there is a short film which is entertaining and interesting. Then you wander across the walkways and admire the views. They have display panels about all the other cool bridges in the world (so good for bridge fans) and for some reason, about London in the 60s. They seem rather desperate to provide something for your money so even have display boards about birds you might see or fish that might live in the Thames below. It's all a bit strained really - as if they are trying to justify the money they have taken off you by providing something, anything. You end with a silent film about the design of the bridge which is yawningly boring. I just feel that something more exciting is needed these days to justify the entrance fee - or else reduce the price and keep it as a plain no frills viewing platform.

Interesting exhibit held at the Tower Bridge. The exhibits of the many famous bridges is something worth seeing, including the exhibits of that things that made London famous, I,e, their famous personalities, the contribution of their famous Londoners in fashion, music and art.
nice place to visit.... London bridge is one of the best attraction , spectacular site, lovely photo scenery.... must visit in summer time....

Beautiful Bridge. This is an iconic bridge to take a stroll on and get some pictures. The best view of the Bridge is from the Tower of London right there by it. There is also a Tower Bridge Exhibition so check that out.

Great tour and insight to a national landmark. Well worth taking the time to go up the north tower and walk across the two walkways, there is a nice audio visual introduction to the bridge and some of the original design concepts.Once down the south tower a short walk takes you to the engine house and the original steam boiler and engines that generated the power to raise the hydraulic accumulators that were the secret to the speed of the bridges opening and closing The views are incredible and it is really something to stand looking down on the Tower of London.

Good visit. Not only interesting to learn about the history of the bridge but also great views down the Thames. Lucky to see bridge lifted too for boats coming up river. Tip: when inside don't forget to look up!

Frustrating tour. Be aware - you really need to start this tour from the London City side of the bridge. We did not know this and the people who charge you for your ticket in the gift shop will not tell you this. Trying to do the tour backwards was really frustrating even though they tell you it's fine.You're told that there are refreshments downstairs but it's actually two vending machines, one of which stole 2 pounds from us (to get our money back, we had to go all the way back to the gift shop in Southbank).Most annoying, they give you a coupon for a good discount for the gift shop when you enter at the correct beginning. Since we started at the gift shop, we'd already spend 20 pounds there. They wouldn't give us the discount after the fact even though it was the gift shop person who told us to do the tour backwards! That really left me mad.The view from the top is nice and there is a cool kid's activity to do, but I can't recommend it because the service was so bad.

Worth a visit. Loved looking round this. You can walk across the road bridge,go in the lift up the towers, walk across both upper walkways(the views are tremendous) and go down to the engine room. Super information video talks and lovely staff.

Pleasant surprise. Yes a great icon to take photos from the river or river bank, but, also worth a visit. Entry gained with London Pass so don't know what the cost to get in is. Good video as an introduction to visitors which explains the original plans and then the final plans for the new bridge (of late 1800s). The presentation on the bridge itself was nice, but had a bonus of a presentation of the 1960;s in London which I quite enjoyed. worth a visit after you have visited the Tower of London.

Worth a photo. The Bridge is well worth the photo opportunity alone- get off at Tower Hill station and walk towards the brige and grab a shot about 50metres from it- great angle.I also got a pic from the other side, standing right near HMS Belfast you can fit in the tower and the bridge in the one cool shot.

My Fairy Tale Bridge. As a child, I recall the song "London Bridge is Falling Down", well... I visited London with a close friend who lives in Wales! I did not take the tour, I missed that somehow. I admired the architect of this bridge! One must see it when visiting London!
Worth it just to see an iconic bridge!. It is a self guided tour. Lots of reading, but well worth it to see the view from the bridge. There's an option of taking the stairs or the elevator up.

Great Views. The Tower Bridge was a great place to see the city. We traveled in January and unfortunately the London Eye was closed so we really enjoyed seeing London from the top of the bridge. The tour was OK, but entrance fee was worth it to get to the top.
excellent exhibit. We had a great time going through the exhibit. The presentation at the beginning was great, and the rest of the exhibits were wonderfully presented. A great historical value!

Great and informative. Great self guided tour, that provides history of the building of the London Tower bridge, other world bridges , in addition to other information on the buildings in London, and the engine room of Tower Bridge.To top it all off, there is some great arial views of London.Affordable attraction to visit.Recommend to all

Tower Bridge. A great trip took about an hour to walk through and view the sights from the top. Various exhibitions dotted around to keep you occupied. An immense structure and a fantastic piece of working history. Well worth a visit.

Not really that impressive. Had always wanted to see this and obviously saw a lot of photos, however was a bit underwhelmed when there in person. Yes it's a nice bridge, but only two lanes wide - when you consider the Sydney Harbour Bridge was finished around 35 years after this it's a much larger bridge. Would still recommend and happy that I went, but certainly not the most memorable attraction in London.

I have always wanted to climb the Tower Bridge. I have always wanted to climb the Tower Bridge and enjoy the views. The exhibition and displays just made the experience even more enjoyable. Really loved it - very great ful for the lifts!

Very good . Had a day out with my kids, when asking them what they wanting to do. Let go to tower bridge, having walk under it for many times thought we would give a shot. Was surprised how much we enjoyed it. Was very busy but it was a Saturday but hey views are interesting but have been on most high things in London.

Excellent views. Visiting the bridge is a must. The views from the walkways are fab and the exhibition about the other bridges of the world is really interesting. They show some videos which I was not that bothered about but they were informative. The restored engine rooms were fantastic.

Well worth a visit not just for tourists. We visited Tower Bridge Exhibition as part of a family day put. Really good value for money. Seeing the history and working of the tower were very interesting for us all. My children are 9 and 13. Also the walkway at the top of the bridge was great. Going back through the decades and all that good things that people associate our great country. All in all a attraction for everyone in the family

Joggers Paradise. An amazing historic bridge which has always been a symbolic representation of London. If you are staying in London for a short period of time. You should not miss an evening walk or a morning Jog. Also, it looks amazing when it opens in half for ships to pass.

Tower Bridge experience. From the outside the view is beautiful of the Tower Bridge. We went to the "Sixties exhibition inside which was not what I really expected. My girls ages 22 and 17 really didn't care for it. If you are interested in the workings of the bridge and your kids are younger they may enjoy. It is a must see.

Amazing historical icon. Very spectacular architecture, prepare your camera, you can get very good shots immediately after exiting London tower and on the Thames river cruise and on the Thames river cruise to Greenwich.
Iconic. Amazing bridge, a must see when in the capital., you can view from a river trip and also on foot. In addition we saw the Bridge from a Big Bus tour which is another way to see the sights.

Fun for kids, beautiful landscape. It would take too much time to read and listen to every content is provided. With kids is almost impossible, but I think it would be interesting for adults. What we liked most is the spectacular view you get from the top of the bridge. Very challenging is the stickers collection for kids: a sort of game that at least obliged them to proceed to complete the game. Anyway it is a great place to visit.

A MUST SEE ATTRACTION IN LONDON - TOWER BRIDGE. I visited London Tower Bridge in March 2014. It was my business trip to London. It was really a very nice trip and that too combined with work and fun. We took out some time on weekend and went to see various attractions in London City. We decided to start our exporation from Tower Bridge as suggested by our London Client. We took a tube train from Canary Wharff and came out at Bermondesy. We walked down towards Tower Bridge and landed on it. It was an awesome view from Tower Bridge. One can not take his eyes off it. You see lot of touriests there. It is a well organised bridge. A huge Thames river below it. There is a museum which has lot of history on London and tower bridge.One must visit this place.I would love to visit this City again.

Very original design of one bridge. The very same day I visited the Tower of London, I also crossed the Tower Bridge. Never before I've seen such beauty of engineering construction. That is a combination of of bascule and suspension bridge.As a matter of fact, bascule bridge is the drawbridge or moveable bridge.This way, to the left and right side off the two towers,that make the unit of the bridge, are the parts of suspension bridges and the reach between the towers represent the drawbridge.The two towers are tied together at the upper level by means of two horizontal walkways.Worth of visit,for sure,is the operating mashinery room with all this hydraulic system for running the bascule pivot on the central part of the bridge.Because of its vicinity to the Tower of London, it also became an iconic symbol of London.When I passed accross the part of the top of the bridge, I recalled the very popular song, London Bridge Is Falling Down, that has nothing to do with Tower Bridge, but only reffers to the collapses of other various London Bridges.I was very fond at the end of that day, since I've seen such two great places in London Town.

Iconic London. Tower Bridge, although new by London standards, is such a treat to see. Walk across it if you can and be aware that there are tours of the engine rooms and a little museum, as well. Great for engineering and history lovers!

So THATS what a bascule is.... I'm fairly certain everyone knows what Tower Bridge is and I'm also fairly certain most people don't know you can walk across the TOP of it instead of the foot paths either side of the roadway. I don't mean literally across the top of it but look up - there's two pedestrian bridges high up. The entry fee was quite reasonable when we went -£9 each. You get a couple of audio visual presentations in the tops of the towers, two galleries (in the east and west foot bridges) and a trip around the original steam powered engine rooms that were used to lift the centre span of the bridge when it was originally built. It was here that I learned (a) what a bascule bridge is and (b) that tower bridge is one of them.Tip 1: if you see a herd of school kids waiting in line, come back later. Tip 2: you can actually do the tour backwards by buying your ticket at the engine room on the south side of the bridge and doing that before going up in the towers. This is what we did to avoid the herd of school kids mentioned in tip 1 above :-)

Nice quick visit while on the way to the Tower of London. We took a a short boat tour on the Thames from the "Big Ben" area down to the Tower of London. Tower bridge is not only beautiful but quite historical and I myself founf the 1.5-2 hour visit worth the time and cost. While not #1 on the must see or do list, it is attractive and my 6 y.o. insisted on going. Happily I agreed. I myself think that the most interesting part of the visit was the old engine room but taking a walk on the upper platforms is neat in and of itself. If you have limited time and this is your first visit, you might want to invest more time at the Tower of London but, Tower Bridge is a nice stop over especially if you can see it being raised/lowered (I'm originally from Chicago so moving bridges are hardly new to me).

Fine views, with interesting displays attached. Tower Bridge is such an icon of London that I couldn't resist the chance to have a closer look. There is a lift up to the viewing platforms but the queue for it was long and unmoving so I decided to take the stairs - all 267 of them. It's a great way to see the structure of the towers, and there are comfy seats at intervals so you can sit down if (or, more likely, when) you get tired, but there's no denying that it's a long, steep climb, so think carefully before allowing your impatience to get the better of you as mine did!At the top there are displays on the history and construction of Tower Bridge (very interesting) and on the history of bridge-building in general (less so, although there are some nice photos of bridges of the world); there is also a temporary display on 60s London which might be of more interest to overseas visitors, as most British people will have seen these photos dozens of times before.
