If in London, you must see The Tower Bridge. While the displays or exhinition inside isnt all that it could be, it is a must see landscape and I am glad to say I have been there.

Great views from above and very interesting below. The Tower Bridge is a worth seeing when in London as it is a key piece of history. The cost is 8 pounds and it starts with a quick elevator ride to the top of one of the towers. There, you get an audio visual display of the builders discussing the tower. You then walk across both the walkways and get great views of london. Pictures are taken through little windows in the clear plastic walls.After you leave the tower, you walk down the bridge to see the engine room which is many ways, is the most interesting part of the tour - don't miss it!
Great Views / Great Tour. This give the history of the bridge and how it was built, you even get to see the mechanics of how the bridge is lifted (but not lifting the bridge!)

Great views but felt a little hustled about. Never been inside but fanscinated by Victorian utopian architecture and technology. You are lead around up and down the structure which can feel a bit hustled. Good film starts of the event and sets the context, children collect stickers for a book although these were not always given out in the right places. Chance to walk over the bridge on the high levels with great views. You then have to 'follow the blue line' for the pumping station on mainland. This gets quite technical which is good for anyone with an engineering bent. Perhaps just a once visit event.
Great day out. Lots to see and do and live action to keep the kids amused. And not too bad on price either. We had a great day here
Behind the scenes. Intersting how the bridge works, and was on the doorstep of our Hotel. Drawback lots of steps to climb not good for the dissabled.

Get your Steam punk on. there is an elevator or stairway up to the pedestrian crossover. The old steam engines used to lift to bridge are open for touring and very interesting for the mechanically curious. The bridge is raised about 3 times a day so time your visit accordingly if you are interested.
brilliant views. up there, you get to see London in a different perspective and a lovely exhibition of the most famous bridges in the world; also interesting, the engineering room.

a quick visit attraction. It was snowing.....in April ! Any excuse to get out of the cold. The Tower bridge experience....that'll do.Cost £16 for two adults and child. Not bad really. Got the lift/elevator up to the platforms. Watched a short film about the history of the bridge. Onto the platforms to view London in all it's cloudy and snowy glory. We could have seen further on a clearer day. It was ok. Enjoyed photos of other notable bridges from across the world. That was very interesting. The views are ok. Nothing amazing.On to the other side next for a view of the other side of London. A much better view on this side (tower of London, the big wheel, the shard, st paul's, etc)Down the stairs and next stop was the engine rooms. For this, you have to leave the attraction and walk to the other end of the bridge before going down some stairs and finding the bit that says 'engine rooms'. Personally, I found this part rather boring. Just walked through it as it was about as interesting as staring into the Thames murky waters for a day or so.No way did we exit through the gift shop! Ha! A pretty good gift shop in ones opinion. Bought a few gifts, some for us and a couple for some American friends who are visiting.Not a long experience at all this one so if the queues/lines are ok, you should be able to fit this in. Not spectacular and not a must see......BUT..........Tower Bridge is iconic and now I know what it looks like inside of just thinking what it looks like and that was the selling point for me.

Tower Bridge. A great starting point for walks along the river. On the south side, you can go to the "BELFAST" and the "TATE MODERN" and the "GLOBE". On the north side, you can go to the "TOWER OF LONDON" and "ST PAUL'S CATHEDRAL" and "THE SAVOY" and of course there are many other places. More than can be expressed in a hundred characters. You can also hop on a boat nearby and go right down to Hampton Court if you wish.

It's BEAUTIFUL!. Looks fantastically majestic in the day, and gets even better at night all lit up! While I was there I ate at a place with a beautiful view of the bridge and the tower of London and it was such a nice evening.

Just ok. Visited because it was included on my london pass, otherwise i would skip it. One of the walkways was closed. It was very cold and rain/ snow was falling when we headed over so not a great day but kept us warm and out of the cold for a while.

A chance to visit a real icon of London!. We loved being able to walk through the high level walkways, and my boys enjoyed the old machinery that used to be used to lift it. I'd recommend going at a time when the bridge is being raised - though make sure you are outside the bridge for that, as the view is interesting but limited from inside the bridge. Or try to see it from both angles! Check their website for Bridge lifting times as it doesn't happen daily.

Dull. Dull is probably the most interesting word I can put to this place. One of the most iconic bridges and attractions in the world, and what is there? £6 lets you go across the high walkway, see two projected videos, and have a look in the engine room. None of these things we found at all inspiring, especially the half hearted attempts at interactivity. Maybe it's our age, and we expect everything to be interactive, in your face, or 'touch screen'. Personally I wouldn't waste my time paying to go in - just having a look from the outside, and a walk down the road would suffice. If you are interested in engineering however, I do feel that this place would have more appeal - but mass commercial appeal for one of London's leading sights? I think not.
impressive. as you would expect. impressive. beautiful at night when it's all lit up. part of the whole London Experience

Must go!. The beauty of the bridge can captivate you for hours & make you stand still to admire this creativity of mankind..... The magic charm of classic architecture, wonderful surroundings & river Thames will engross you in its depth & won’t let you go off…. Really a must visit place. Would highly recommend especially when it rains…. Do carry your camera to capture the beauty!
Worth a visit. Well worth the entry price to see how the bridge was built and the old steam engines that were used to raise the central roadway,good veiws from the walkways between both towers.

A must go see!. The iconic tower bridge. For free and you can get awesome pictures and even walk over it. Sometimes you will see it lift up but not all the time. There is also an attraction or rather a museum once you reach the tower brdige
Pass!. We went in because our London pass made it free and we were walking across the bridge anyway. Not worth the time. Skip it.

Must Go !. In the heart of London, the Tower Bridge is part of the history of this fabulous city. There is a beautiful view up there. Access easy and free with the London Pass. You will discover a beautiful part of the history of London. Allow approximately one hour for a visit. You can take beautiful pictures. The gateway is close with windows, but it is possible to open small windows and to place your camera and take pictures.

feel a part of london. Come to London is not just about Big Ben, Westmister abbey etc, but take a walk ,watch the river,and take nice photo with the bridge as back ground.I come in the afternoon,nice weather at the time.This place must visit.....

Second Bridge crossing River Thames. From 1886-94 this astonishing piece of architecture was build - a second bridge allowing people easily to cross the River Thames. The museum explains the background, shows how it was build and shows an exhibition of a waste number of other bridges build across the globe. Interesting museum (you can skip the shop).

A Bridge of Memories. My visit to Tower Bridge was twofold, since my family history had two distinct links to this famous London landmark. Firstly, I had discovered that two of of my greatuncles, William Temple of Barton, and Robert Temple of Wells Next the Sea, N. Norfolk,who were both Master Mariners had brought their ships to the Port of London for thedelivery of Norfolk produce in the mid - nineteenth century. Secondly, only minutesaway is the Tower Bridge Merchant Navy Memorial for those who died at sea duringWWI. I had travelled first class from Northampton - Euston Station, and taken a bus to TowerBridge, Tuesday, March 26th. My father - in - law, Capt. Owen E. Freemantle had his shipthe 'Marie Elsie' torpedoed by U-28, 10. vi. 1917. Three of his crew were lost at seaas the ship went down. Their names are recorded on the Memorial and I laid a wreath intheior memory having taken a great deal of research to find their names, and the circumstances of the attack by the German U-boat 28. In nearby Trinity House is a registerwhich records all the names of those who died at sea in WWI. The Memorial can be reachedalso by the London Underground. I had chosen the bus rather than an expensive taxi.Sadly, the Memorial garden is also home to London's homeless, who use the area forsleeping off their problems. I can only trust that my wreath is not damaged in any way.Of course, the local ambience is greatly different to the early Edwardian era, and thatof mid - Victorian England when my relatives brought their ships from Norfolk to delivertheir cargoes. One of the crew members of my Great Uncle, was a German, mid - 1850sI will return in better weather.Geoff Hamilton, editor, Anglo-Nordic-Times Intl. / LOOK NORDICTues. 26. iii. 2013,

Really enjoyed the tour. I love walking around Tower Bridge and just looking at it but had never done the tour until recently. It was £6 (slightly reduced rate as they are doing work on one of the walkways) and this also included entrance to 'the Monument' aswel. I really enjoyed it. The views from the walkway are nice and I enjoyed looking at the display on bridges around the world. The engine room was interesting too. You can wander around at your own pace which I liked

Must see. It is what it is- it's a big bridge. The most annoying thing was every other tourist around me calling it London Bridge. Like Big Ben, something you could just photograph over and over from every angle. There's not a lot to see, but what's there is ridiculous.

If you ever get the chance...GO... On a cold, snowy March morning we went to visit London, and Tower Bridge was on the attraction list.It was £6 per person and £3 for the programme souvenir book. The staff were amazing, very helpful, spoke very clearly for others who couldn't understand. The signage was perfectly clear. Photo's were taken at the end, if you wanted to buy them, but rather pricey.So very interesting.

The most famous bridge in the world?. This is a magnificent bridge & one of the major landmarks in London. Built over the Thames, near the Tower of London, it is a wonderment of man's ability to build. It makes you very proud to be British.

Limited but interesting. The mechanism an interesting example of Victorian engineering. The top walkway has a lot of pictures about the bridge. You do better with a guide which you can get with a party
The tower. Enjoyable! Videos, walks and great views. Glad we went.The walk ways are covered so nice in the rain or cold weather.

Amazing View!!. I managed to capture an amazing view of the London Bridge while also exploring the Tower of London and found it to be very appealing to the eye. I great photos of it from the Tower of London, I only wish I had time to explore it more close up. Next time for sure I will.

Most Famous Bridge in the World. Fácil de chegar e com uma bela vista.Com sua característica arquitetura da era Vitoriana, proporciona ao visitante uma vista panorâmica de parte de Londres e de outras atrações do rio Tâmisa, como o HMS Belfast.Easy to reach and with a beautiful view.With its characteristic architecture of the Victorian era, offers visitors a panoramic view of part of London and other attractions of the Thames, like the HMS Belfast.

nice views. combined this with ticket to the Monument and very nice with lift up to the top of the tower and lots of info on the tower and other famous bridges round the world. okay you could quickly rush through it but looking down the view of the thames was rather nice and as you going across bridge you see bits of it from different angles. lift at end to take down again.we managed to do both sides but i know there were closing one side to renovate it.

Family visit to the "Old world"-London and it's histoy. Our family wanted to visit London for a long time and we finally had the chance to do it. We had rented a flat in Chiswick and we travel everyday to central London through the TUBE for the atractions. Despite been freezing weather a couple of days in the city (which is almost always cold) we had a great time. Weather didn't stop us from enjoying lots of attractions that are available to tourism. Of couse we HAD to see the very famous Tower Bridge, Tower of London, London Bridge, Monument, etc, etc. We learned that first you have to take a bus ride (Bus Tour) that will take you almost all over the city and then you can decide were to go and re-visit. Beautiful architecture and history. Beware of time. We didn't feel business schedule is "tourist friendly" but still we enjoyed everything. London is a great city to visit and I would recomend it to anybody who has the chance. If you are planning to be there for a week or so check The London Pass which will give you access to many atracctions but you need to plan it very carefully to the minute to take full advantage of it. Public transport is excellent and no need to rent a car...unless you are going to the country side. Hope you enjoy your stay as much as we did.

OK but partly closed at the moment. Glad to have visited the bridge and been to the top, but was a little disappointed that only one side of the bridge was open due to renovations. I think there was a reduction in entrance fee by £2, but I don't think it would have been worth the £12 entry for two adults. We only paid £6 because we used the 2 for 1 offer so for that price it was fine. Good views of the city but disappointed not to have been able to view both sides.

Tower Bridge. This one should be one of your priority when you are in London..especially if it is your first time like I was. A must see. One of the most important landmarks in London, also considered to be one of the most famous bridges in this world of ours, along with the Brooklyn Bridge in New York and the Golden Gate Bridge in San Francisco. Make sure to walk along the bridge crossing the River Thames. It also has a nice view of London when your in it.

Nice experience. Was a nice experience to go into a bridge that I passed and seen many times already. I personally liked the engine rooms at the end most as it was very fascinating to see how well it was maintained and how much power is required to move the bridge.
gateway to history!. Standing proudly in the middle of river Thames connecting for decades the left to the right quai vise versa making a landmark on the map of old London town.

An enjoyable visit. Lived in London for years and we did a tourist weekend of which part of it was the tower bridge experience. We had a great time. Very informative, clean and reasonably priced. The staff are really helpful and it doesn't take all day. You get an excellent view of London from the viewing gallery.

Engineering Marvel. Did not book in advance turned up on the day - No queue to speak of at all.The history told by a video was first class. The engineering detail was amazing, the shear size of the metal components were awesome.All very well organised.

Magnificent Bridge. A must see for everyone going to London. Magnificent, massive structure and everyone owes it to history to walk across it. It has been well maintained and blends well with all the new architecture - both compliment each other well!

Beautiful bridge. You know the bridge decorated with the Olympic symbol well this is the one and it is beautiful. Really interesting to take the cheap tour to understand how steam was used to raise the levers back when it was originally built. Accompany this tour with The Tower and you have a full day planned, they are adjacent to each other
Refreshing :-). The typical gloomy weather makes this Tower Bridge look mystic and romantic. A must see in London. Beautiful. Love it!
Great views. Enjoyed the animation that showed how the bridge was constructed. Views from the catwalks between towers were amazing.
Combine with a visit to the Tower of London. All visitors to London have to experience the walk across the bridge and the River Thames. Fantastic landmark.
A must when in London!. I visited the Tower Bridge in June 2008... this is a must when in London. Beautiful view. I recommend that anyone who visits this great city visits this spot.

A Great Place for Pictures - Especially at Night. The Tower Bridge, (and castle right next to it) are a great place to visit, especially for pictures at night. The bridge is well lit and there are several great angles to get the bridge and castle in one picture. This is a very safe part of London, even at night. I felt completely safe walking around the bridges and the river walk between the London and Tower bridges. There are also some great restaurants in the area. When in London, this is a must-see.

Magnificent Bridge. Not the biggest bridge in the world but up there for a great construction design and historical value. Can just imagine sailing up the Themes 200 years ago and seeing the heads of traitors adn criminals stuck on the spikes of the bridge. Brilliant.!!

Amazing- well worth a visit!. I go to London regularly but it wasn't until this year that I decided to go into the exhibition. What a great choice! I was so impressed. The bridge itself is spectacular but learning about its history and seeing the engine rooms was amazing. The tour was so well organized. A must for anyone thinking of going to London!

Very Interesting... But if I had to do it again.... It was not a bad display but really there is not too much to it. There are two presentations at the end of each bridge you walk across the top walkway and look at pictures of other famous bridges of the world (obstructing the view of the city). I did it out of curiosity but never would recommend it if you had other things to do in the city on a tight schedule.
beautiful beautiful. My visit there was very short, but I liked the view of it. I had my mobile phone to use as a camera.I hope to go back there for a longer visit.

Really good day out.. Visited as part of a combined ticket with The Monument. I've walked, drove and gone under this bridge hundreds of times but never thought about going up it till my son was learning about the great fire of London so we took him to the Monument whilst there we got a combined ticket for both a family of four was £22 Youngest (4yrs) was free which i think is a bargain for London. The staff are friendly and informed you start with a short film which is just the right length so the kids don't get bored then you can walk between the towers first the east side were you get views of Canary Wharf then another film which we missed then you make your way to the West side for great views of London they have little windows so you can take pictures. then the boiler rooms wich is interesting. If you do the two it will easily last all day.

Breath taking and Stunning!!!. Hands down the most beautiful and breath taking bridge I have ever seen in my life!!!! At night, the beauty of it all lit up is astounding. I could just sit on the bench where I was and stare at it all night. I will never forget that moment for me that night. Ever.

Fascinating Insight into Victorian Engineering. We enjoyed our visit very much, especially the walkway view and the engine rooms at the end where you see and have explained the massive Victorian steam engines and process that opened and closed the bridge. Recommended and reasonably priced.

Tower Bridge prior to 2012 Olympics. I had always wanted to actually see the Tower Bridge of London and I finally got my wish and it was better than anticipated. I saw it just prior to the 2012 Olympics and they had the Olympic rings ready to drop down, once the Olympics started. Fantastic!!!

Well worth a visit. Always wondered what it was like to be on top of the bridge so decided to pay the £8.00 adult fare, cheaper for the old man £5.60. Just paid for the bridge not the Monument as well maybe next time go there. A couple of very short films to watch informing you about how they built the bridge, walking along the top which was closed in but had little windows you could open to hang your camera out off was great, (no mucky windows)Also a very well stocked shop, Look out for vouchers giving you £2.00 off in the shop.

Lost my money. Be very careful buying a ticket through this app. I accidentally entered not valid email address and didn't get the electronic ticket. App doesn't remember anything about the purchase and Tower bridge crew can't check booked tickets by your name.Seller provides support only by phone which is expensive in roaming, so I just purchased the tickets again right on the bridge. Tickets cost the same price as via app and there was no queue at all.

Wonderful. If you are reasonably fit, take a trip up the Bridge on a clear day and marvel at the views. Learn more of the intricacies of the workings of this extraordinary bridge. Well worth the trip, especially if combined with a visit to the Tower and a trip on the river.

Beautiful. The sight of london bridge itself makes you go amazed. The blue color looks magnificent and lovely. It looks cuter from far off and looks wonderful when you are actually on it walking. Loved the feeling of being in London.
Great photo opportunity!. This is a very neat bridge, right next to the Tower of London. So you can check 2 things off your list at once!

Pretty bridge, but nothing much to see up top.. It is a very nice bridge and photographs well. We went up to walk along the top. I like going up things, so glad we did, but nothing much up there and quite an expensive ticket. Only do it if you want to say you have done it.
Londoner View. I see this bridge most days while living in London. Often mistaken by a different name but all in all, one of the famous tourist attraction of the city

My favourite place in London. I have been to London many many times on several occasions, on my own, with family, with friends ...This area attracts me and every time there is something new which makes it even better! I'm not talking about the bridge itself but all the surrounding spots : Battler's wharf, The design museum, Le Pont de la tour restaurant, the view to the Shard and the City Hall, Hay's Galleria...There is something exciting, something very new and now with all the new buildings very "New York like" to the place. The vicinity to the river, St Katherine's Dock on the other side, the fact that it is also a residence place make it very neibourghood like and beautiful at the same time. If I ever lived in London IT would be the place for me...Looking forward to getting back there!

Tower Bridge experience. An amazing way to see the beautiful London skyline. Get beautiful pictures at dusk. As the sun is setting and the buildings are lighting up the entire skyline changes. You can learn a great amount of history here too.
The openibg of tower bridge. We were on a red tour bus up the top, front and tower bridge opened, is was fascinating to see it,we were right there when it happened.
Well worth a visit. Good to visit if your into history. Price includes entry into the old engine rooms too so well worth the price, as it is not overpriced.Nice views of London from the top too!
A great view plus history. Tower bridge is a great way to have a panoramic view of London up and down river. You also learn about the history of the bridge and it's importance to the city

I had no idea you could walk above the Bridge in the upper walkway - great views. We stumbled across this by accident and would thoroughly recommend booking to get a great view of the Thames and surrounding London sights
Great History. The Tower Bridge is well worth the effort. It is one of the oldest bridges in London across the Thames and the engineering is amazing considering when it was built.

So cool at night. We took a boat down the river during the day and went uder the bridge then walked across it at night. What a beautiful bridge. We are so glad put this on our to do list!! If you are in London! Dont miss this Bridge

A must for all visitors to London. Tower Bridge is such a unique feature of London, it should not be missed. After taking some wonderful photos on the bridge, walk back towards the Tower of London and on your right is the Tower Hotel. Go down to the riverside there for more great views then follow the signs to St Katherine's Dock, just to the rear of the hotel. It has lots of fascinating shops, restaurants and bars, where you can enjoy a leisurely rest whilst watching the boats and the locals going about their business.

Really good for money. This was a last minute decision to stop and do the unguided tour, and I am so glad we did! The different pictures, videos, and of course the amazing view from the top for photos was both informative and interesting. The engine rooms were amazing to see. We did this with the Monument attraction as well on the deal.

Interesting Look at the history of the Bridge. The Tower Bridge Experience provides a behind the scenes look at the history and operation of this famous Bridge. You can ride the elevator up to the cross bridge and go from one end to the other. A great photo opportunity looking toward central London from the middle of the Thames! Well worth the £8 - too bad it's not open at night - the view would be stellar!

The integration of modern and historical era. the bridge is unique and the architectural detail is beuatiful. Its like the integration of historic and modern era, so it represents london well. Just walk across it and you may find hundreds of angles that are really nice for photoshoots.

Towering over the Thames. We've gone over (and under) the bridge on a number of occasions, so it was great to get to grips with how the Bridge was built, and see the engineering involved in how the bridge actually works. The views from the walkways are excellent, catching the ever changing London skyline. The little windows you can open as you move along the walkway allow you to take photographs unhindered. Lovely gift shop at the end of the tour.This is another attraction that has 2 for 1 offers in the British Rail 2 for 1 brochure, if you travelled to London by train. Look out for them in Station ticket offices, just remember to keep hold of your rail ticket at your destination, as you need to present them with your voucher from the booklet.

Even if it weren't one of London's iconic buildings. Even if it weren't one of London's iconic buildings it would still be worth a visit. The bridge is incredibly unique and the surrounding views of the Thames are a pleasure to behold.

2 for 1 southern railway ticket worth using to visit this experience. I have worked in London for 30 years, walked over London Bridge and looked at Tower Bridge for this period and never been inside.My husband and I decided to take a weeks holiday and visit some London attractions, this was my first choice of places to go and I was not disappointed. The views are good and the staff very helpful.

Great views and engineering. We visited over the half-term break, so booked online to save queuing. Views from the top are great (go on both sides) as are the engine rooms. On the day we visited they were working on the engines so saw the engines turning!
Worth doing the tour. Well structured tour, able to do it at your own speed. Gives detailed info on history and construction. The part on "world's famous bridges" was interesting too.

Fascinating and a great view. Being the sort of guy who likes clever engineering and a great spot to take pictures, I decided to take the tour on a whim. The little movie about the decision to build the bridge was a bit cute but definitely got the point across. The walk across the top had an amazing view and little windows for taking photos and the huge machinery downstairs in the engine room was very Victorian and impressive. Glad I went.

Another Must-See. After Big Ben this is London's second most famous icon. It's a working bridge so you can walk across it for free, and take pictures of the river Thames, other bridges and London landmarks.
Sometimes it opens, so if you want to see that, go to Google to find out when.
Good value. Interesting with great views! Offer on entrance fee so one of the cheaper places visited in London. If poss, get a 2 for 1 discount with railcard.

Much better than expected!. Well worth a visit...............the views fom the bridge are exceptional and the displays well laid out and well presented.
Great visit well recommended for children

Fantastic experience and views. Really excited to visit this historical monument. Watched a short video on the making of the bridge, then walked along the top of the bridge, before going into see the mechanics that raise the bridge. Some good interactive exhibits for children. Glad I visited this iconic landmark.

Iconic London. This bridge is simply amazing and with the Tower of London you can get some great camera shots in this area of London.
Very much worth a walk along the river, a tube journey to Tower Hill or bus to view the bridge.
Its brilliant, walk across the bridge to see it in all its glory.
In the footsteps of history. Price was discounted to £6 so for London thats fine you can take as long as you like for photographs from inside but you can better photos from the shard or London eye.

A must see icon when in London. It sort of reviews itself, featured in many films and television over the years it is used to depict London. Really worth a walk over to stand and watch the river and the bustling embankments. If you are lucky a tall ship will come along and you will see the bridge lift. You can also google bridge openings as they have a diary of what is coming.
What a veiw.. You get a really good view up and down the river.The Bridge is a lovely building, with wonderful decorative features.

Best audiovisual display I have seen.. You go up in a lift and then sit down to see an audiovisual display about the making of Tower Bridge. It is very well done . I was expecting to see the characters afterwards . The views from the bridge are fantastic .At the bottom and you can see the Victorian engineering involved in making the bridge work. It is excellent. If you are going to visit then get a combined ticket with The Monument ( around 7 minutes walk away) as it works out much cheaper.

Great attraction and very good value for money. We visited in February, not planned, we were just passing and so glad we decided to have a look. It was a very good exhibition and so informative and we really enjoyed the engine rooms as well. Not bad at £6 per person, I thought that was very reasonable. If you don't like lifts you can ask to use the stairs, which we did, but there are alot of them!!

Fantastic. Hadn't expected to enjoy this as much as we did but it was an excellent attraction. The staff were friendly, helpful and amusing. There was a super passport and sticker activity for the kids which gave me time to take in the interesting displays - I particularly enjoyed the one about famous bridges around the world. Thoroughly recommend!

Just Fantastic. This is a sight to behold and makes you smile every time you see the Tower Bridge, on a sunny day, dull day its stands proud on the river Thames and just shouts photograph me, a huge part of London were you can just enjoy the sights and sounds of old father Thames, take a tour inside the bridge, or if you fancy a boat trip a sail under the Tower Bridge, what ever you do enjoy the view, and have a great day at London.

An excellent example of the Victorian Era. When I went I paid for the tour on the inside and to go up on the upper viewing walkway, I however would not recommend doing this (unless you are a bridge junkie). I found the views on the general walkway to be much better and I already was aware of much of the information provided during the tour. If it is all completely new to you by all means it is a good tour, but if you already have some knowledge the time could be spent on one London's many other attractions.

one of the best in london. i enjoyed this and walking over the bridge through the walkway above the public was wonderful, a must for any visitor to london, very expensive to get in and walk about but lovely photo oppotunities outside and views of the river thames

Okay. Go inside the Tower Bridge and there is a series of documentary materials about the history of the bridge. There is also a short video show also for this purpose. The bridge also opens up on certain times when barges pass underneath it.

Photo opportunity. Wat a great landmark to take a picture and say you've been too. It does not fail to make you smile from familia rarity of all the tv coverage. You can get to it by any transport you imagine but the best for me would have to be by river boat, if you want to get off the boat then London bridge pier is. 5 min walk away.

Magical bridge. There is something about Tower Bridge that draws you in and takes your breathe away - I love it.Visit and take a look for yourself and if you have time take the Tower Bridge experience - great little option.

Always wanted to visit. For ages I have loved Tower Bridge and its iconic look. The visit did not disappoint - really interesting to see the engine house and walk across the bridge - loved it. Did the Tower of London on the same day - great day out.

Check out Tower Bridge. Tower Bridge is one of the more recognizable symbols of London - a fabulous example of Victorian engineering, drama & style.There is an exhibition, showing how the machinery that powers the draw span operates, & you can walk across the enclosed walkway. But walking halfway across the bridge, and stopping to take a family photo with the Tower of London in the background, is the way to do it for free.

Very enjoyable. Only one walkway was open when we visited so tickets were discounted to £6.00, which represents great value. the staff are very friendly and we enjoyed our visit - you can stay as long as you like on the walkway and it was very quiet on the Sunday morning that we visited and we had plenty of time to enjoy the views which are stunning. there are also little windows you can open to take photos of the view.I love a view and thought that this was very good value for money. I enjoyed the bit of history and the different plans that were submitted for the bridge. Also included is a visit to the engine rooms.
The MOST beautiful bridge in the world. How can you not love this beautiful design of a bridge. It is so iconic. Always full of tourists it is a must for any guests to London

Great in the summer. Tower bridge is in my opinion the best looking bridge in london. This summer it was better with the games and the great weather. I wish we had more sporting events happening at tower bridge...would be a reason to visit!

london bridge. My husband and I went for a holidy in london.One of the attractions we visited was the london bridge.We were fascinated with it.It is spetecular and one cannot go to london without seeing it.Not to be missed.

Great morning out. This was an interesting experience. The lift was out, so we had to climb the stairs, but i believe this added to the experience because it gave you a real feel for how big the bridge is. At the top they show you a small video about the history of the bridge and then you walk along the top of the bridge. This part had an exhibition about famous bridges around the world which was quite good. The only thing that i think would make this better, in my opinion, is if it had some sort of open air section.

Olympic rings are a nice accessory. Short review because Tower Bridge is one of those iconic must visit sites. You've seen it a million times, from Mary Poppins to any one of the recent Ivory Merchant Hugh Grant films. Yes, it is a bit cliché, but who cares. This summer the Olympic Rings were a beautiful accessory. The view down the Thames and over the Tower of London are priceless. And talking about price, Best offer in town is the London Pass. You can get it for 1,2,3 or 6 days and it provides entry into 60 attractions, including Thames River Cruise, Tower of London, Westminster Abbey, London Bridge Experience!, Windsor Castle, St Paul's Cathedral, Shakespeare's Globe Theatre, Tower Bridge Exhibition, Hampton Court Palace, Churchill War Rooms - all the most popular in London (and just outside London). Plus it gives you fast tract entry into most attractions - especially important during summer. A 6 day pass is £102 for adults, add £54 (£77/99 for kids) for a six day travel card. This give you huge savings and the fast track is worth every penny. I'm not a London Pass salesman on commission, it's just that we always get a lot of visitors and this is what I always suggest to them. Just goggle London Pass.

Beautiful landmark, skip the tour. The Tower Bridge is my favorite landmark in London. I probably have about 500 pictures of it. That being said, don't waste your money taking the tour. You get some awesome pictures of London but the tour itself is boring, unless you're into bridges or engineering.
Beautiful.. If you can at least walk or drive trough it. Beautiful architecture. More beautiful at night. (picture perfect from the right side entrance of the Tower of London)

Very striking landmark. We walked across the Tower Bridge at night for some fantastic photos of the Tower of London and the city lights along the river. It is a very imposing bridge. I didn't take the tour but I imagine it is interesting.

Engine rooms were great!!. Used the London Pass to go in with. We took the stairs up so we could have a good look around. The movie was interesting and it was great to walk across the walkways and look up and down across the city. We then went down to the engine rooms and were pleased to see that they had restored all the engines in working order and placed lots of information around to read. The usual gift shop at the end with all sorts of bits and pieces. All in all a really good attraction to see.
Who know an engine would be so pretty. The history and engineering is impressive and quite lovely. The views from the walkway are very nice.

Incredible engineering. Amazing piece of engineering and architecture. Historically so important and if you're lucky enough to be around when the bridge is elevated for a boat oh wow! Follow up with a boat trip down to the London Eye
Great views. Really enjoyed the views around the Thames!!!Lots of information how the bridge works.Nice to see the bridge lit up at night!would love to see the bridge open!!

The New London Bridge. Again this bridge has great views of both banks of the river Thames, the best view is the view down river towards Tower Bridge. To the right is HMS Belfast which served in world war 2 and is now a floating museum. The New London Bridge replaced the original London Bridge in the late 1960's when an American millionaire bought it and had it taken down brick by brick, and rebuilt in Arizona. The thing is the American thought he was buying Tower Bridge, ( the one you can see from London Bridge).

walk the bridge. Tower Bridge is a great walk & check out the turrets too & go inside & see what is happening in them. very informative & worth taking the time to check it all out. at night stand on the bridge & look up & down the thames at the other bridges when they are lit up - its a great sight.

Disapointing. I understand that there's a long history behind the London bridge, but seeing it, and walking on it doesn't make you feel any of it. The best part about it, is that you can take some nice pics of the Tower bridge and the HMS Belfast. I would recommend going there anyways, after all, it's the famous London bridge!

My favorite. I'm an enthusiast when it comes to bridges. This is the best bridge in London for sure! I just love the way it stands and the history behind it. At the top of the bridge, there's an exhibition that shows the history of the bridge and stages of the build. Another part of the exhibition is about the best bridges in the world. Your pass also takes you into the (old) engine rooms, which is cool, but not a must. If you're into photography, you're gonna enjoy going there, plenty of great photo opportunities, both from and around the tower.

Find the original London Bridge (NB not Tower Bridge). At the city end of London Bridge you can find the strange church of St Magnus the Martyr, here is the start of the first London Bridge - a strange High Anglican mixture of a church it looks like a wren church outside, and a Mediterranean catholic church inside.But the main reason to visit is the magnificent model of the original London Bridge, a fascinating, detailed scale model - great if your looking for medieval London
Walking through London. By sharing your experiences, you're helping travellers make better choices and plan their dream trips. Thank you!

Missing the rings. Beautiful landmark of London, and happy memories of shouting Jessica Ennis, Greg Rutherford and Mo Farah to gold at the big screen outside city hall. Looks bare without the rings though... funny how two viewings can change a lifetime's memories! They just looked like they belonged there...
Wonderful. The best place for history And pray. In the first moment, the gate of catolicsIn the heart of london
Beautiful!. the bridge is lovely to walk over and you can also go under the bridge for an experience which i didnt have time for! its a great back drop for pictures

Tower Bridge tour. I've always wanted to visit the iconic Tower Bridge having seen it back when I was about 12 during a visit to see HMS Belfast - I probably looked at the bridge back then and didn't appreciate it's magnificence so a visit was top of my list during my trip to London a fortnight ago.The view from the top is brilliant, the city of London, Canary Wharf in the distance, St. Paul's, the Shard, City Hall and of course the Tower of London. It was a cold but clear day and the view was excellent.From the animated introduction about the conception and construction of the bridge to the signposts and information boards, a visit to Tower Bridge tells you as much about the history of London (both social and engineering) as the history of the bridge itself.It's one of the more reasonably priced attractions in London and worth it for the view from the top alone.

A masterpiece!. Took the tube to the tower stop. Try to see the tower bridge early evening , I believe that is the best time to vist especially not many people around plus the atmosphere is unbelievable . Walk over the bridge the view is breathtaking. I saw the bridge open and close. A very unique bridge! Great place to visit....

Tower Bridge, London. I finally after many years, got around the Iconic Tower Bridge. It was worth the visit. Access is by the North Tower (Tower of London side). You are taken to the top by lift and then move along the East side walkway, with views out the seaward side of the Thames. The main attraction of this side, is a series of articles about the major bridges of the World. On reaching the South Tower, you then move along the West Walkway. This offers some superb views of London, with the Tower and HMS Belfast the most prominent. After a return to the South Tower, the visit then takes in the most interesting part. You have to leave the Bridge and head about 400 metres down the road to the site of the main workings of the Bridge. This shows all the machinery and hydraulic systems of the bridge (as was). It shows the ingenuity and Victorian engineering at its best.Overall a most enjoyable and fascinating visit and well worth it.

Many thanks to Tower Bridge photographer, Jimmy Brown. We visited the Tower Bridge last year and had a commemorative photograph taken. However, at the end of our visit, the computer equipment malfunctioned and our photograph could not be printed. Jimmy Brown was working the counter that day and he tried his best to get our photo for us, but it was not meant to be on that day. We returned home and were talking about how nice it would have been to get a copy of the picture from our visit. We mailed the Tower Bridge and Jimmy was not only able to locate our picture for us, he sent two copies to us free of charge. We cannot thank Jimmy Brown enough. He went far above and beyond what was necessary and we sincerely appreciate his kindness. Hopefully, he will still be working at the tower Bridge when we return to London this Fall, and we can thank him in person. Thanks again Jimmy, you are the best!

Nice bridge especialy during the night. Since it was my first time in London London bridge was within the landmarks i could not miss. It is a very nice bridge especialy the view from london castle. A little bit expensive the bridge expirience. Recommended to go just before Sunset

Tower Bridge Not So Tower. I was quite disappointed when I first saw the bridge, it was really small to what I expected. I personally think there is a lot of hype about it, however in person it really doesn't look like much. I suppose because we didn't actually walk around it or explore it more is a contributing factor to our disappointment.

Not that interesting. I had done this several years ago and it had seemed fun, but I think that we walked to the top and everything was not enclosed.. Not quite sure how they have improved it, but the attraction has changed. It is easier to get to the top now with an elevator, but everything seems enclosed. Although the bridge has a lovely view of the river it is difficult to take clear pictures through the dirty windows. There is a washroom inside,some technical videos and historic photos. If you study engineering and like this sort of thing, you may really like this attraction. I did not. I enjoyed walking on the regular part of the bridge and buying warm nuts from the street vendors. Unless you have a London Pass and nothing better to do, save your money and take some nice pictures in front of the bridge.

Tower Bridge Exhibition / Tower Bridge. I walk across the bridge on the way to work every day - it's such an amazing construction, a real iconic London sight. In April 2012 I went to the exhibition inside the bridge, which was interesting, made me realise what an engineering challenge it was to build at the time - the design was selected out of several which were submitted for a compeition!
Must see attraction. The famous tower bridge, historical building, signature of London and UK. The long stride along the river is worth looking as well.

The Wonder Bridge. Every day I am lucky enough to view this iconic steel bridge(it is clad with stone) from my office window and recently paid £30 to join an Engineering Tour (that takes place at weekends between January and March) and marvel at the ingenuity of our Victorian forefathers in both designing and building this architectural and engineering masterpiece.Tower Bridge was the delivery of another much needed bridge across the Thames for those on foot or in vehicles whilst also maintaining a river channel for ships of up to a 10,000 tonnage and/or 140 foot height above the river waterline, to transport goods between the coast and the Pool of London at a time when all imports and exports was by sea.Our tour guide begun by telling us of the original winning bridge design by the City of London's Architect Sir Herbert Jones (who also built Billingsgate, Smithfield and Leadenhall Markets) and who was to die in 1887 only one year after construction had begun; the engineer John Wolfe Barry who was able to put Jones' design into practice; Sir William Armstrong whose firm built the amazing bascule lifting machinery and George Stevenson who was able to take the project to completion after 8 years in 1894 when Tower Bridge was opened by Queen Victoria's son, the Prince of Wales, the future Edward V11.The 2 hour tour continued on the two high level pedestrian walkways which cross between the two bridge towers. After being closed in 1910 they were only reopened for visitors in 1982. Originally built for travellers to continue their journey across the river whilst Tower Bridge itself was open, they soon fell into disuse as a result of the bridge opening taking only one minute to achieve its maximum 86 degree opening span. The walkways had also been misused in early years by suicide jumpers, although the walkways are now enclosed.We then visited one of the two bridge pilots cabins and below that a machinery room where the original hydraulic system transferred the power that had been stored in six giant accumulators via a system of pumps and gears, into the lift of the two bascules that carried the roadway, allowing boat access to the riverside wharves near London Bridge. . The 1200 ton bascules work on a see saw basis(hence their name from the french) and pivot in each bridge tower when raised to fill the cavernous space of the piers below which viewing was the highlight of the tour for me. Finally, we visited the southside boiler rooms where 20 tons of coal had been burnt each week to generate the steam power necessary to perform over 150 bascule lifts a week which were required during the time the Port of London prospered before containerisation. Nowadays the bridge only opens a handful of times each week and only after 24 hours notice.So go and enjoy this magnificient Victorian edifice constructed by 432 workers (10 of whom died during the work) and celebrate the wonderful achievement of Britons in days past when this country built an empire and led the world.

I walked the Tower Bridge. When traveling to London, our first stop was at the Tower of London. I have to admit that I was in for a surprise on the way there when I got to the Tower Bridge. As an Americican I always heard stories about London Bridge and as a history lover I was excited to see the Tower of London. Neither was as impressive to me as walking over the historical River Thames and getting my first real look at the Tower Bridge. By coming up close to it by bus, I didn't get to really see the bridge until we arrived at the Tower, so from the vantage point of the Tower of London, I spent my time there just staring at the Tower Bridge.It is an architectural marvel and functional masterpiece! It carries auto traffic and foot traffic accross the bridge and thousands of people a day!On the end of our week there, we got to take a river cruise where we partied and visited with some very nice people, on a chilly night, and the lights from the Tower Bridge told me where I was and the sights around me even the dark of the London Night.

Favorite London Site. The London Tower Bridge was my favorite site to see in London. I suggest taking a boat ride up the Thames,to see the architecture, along the way, as well as 8 other London bridges.

Iconic London landmark. Tower Bridge is one of the iconic London landmarks and a feat of Victorian engineering. Opened in 1894, it stands proud across the Thames near the Tower of London and the Town Hall.The attraction starts off in the north-west tower, where you take the lift up to the walkway level. Here, a short film is shown depicting the history of the bridge. After the film, you head out onto the east walkway, where you have a nice view towards the east (including views of the City of London and Canary Wharf). The walkway also houses an exhibition with further details around the construction of the bridge, life of the river and also a photo exhibition with the theme "Bridges of the World". Beautiful views and intersting exhibits. Once you reach the south tower, there is an amination describing the process of building the bridge. The next part of the visit is to head out onto the west walkway, which has nice views over the Tower of London, City Hall and Westminster (i.e. the West End and central parts of the city). The west walkway also has an exhibit with an Olympic theme. The visit then continues downstairs, with a short walk into the old Victorian engine rooms. This part of the exhibition displays the old Victorian steam engines and machinery that used to operate the bridge. The machinery is very well preserved and well presented, making it an intersting part of the tour.The tour ends up, predictably, in the gift shop where you can buy all sorts of London-associated souvenirs.All in all, a good way to spend an hour or two (not an all-day activity).

Amazing bridge. The tower bridge is a bridge to be proud of as a british citizen,i felt very honoured to be walkiing across it. There are some good views from this area like the tower of London,the Shard,the Gherkin,the City hall,also a stroll along the Thames past the city hall and you can see HMS Belfast.Well worth a visit to these areas of London.
A great sight. No visit to London would be complete without a visit to tower bridge. It can be seen from many different views but there is something magical about walking across it.

Iconic landmark. No trip to London would be complete without visiting the bridge. Although there really isn't a lot to do besides look at it (exhibition was closed when I went), it's good to walk over the bridge and have a look at the structure of it and the views over the Tower of London and the Thames. There are a number of displays about aspects of the bridge such as the control cabin and the "Dead Man's Hole" that can be viewed without going to the exhibition. The views from the bridge aren't very interesting but the views of the bridge itself are good.

One of London's most famous landmarks, Tower Bridge. A truly magnificent structure, not just any old bridge, this is the grade II listed 'Tower Bridge' often mistakenly called London Bridge by overseas visitors. Tower Bridge is one of London's most iconic views. London Bridge shouldn't be forgotten by visitors however as whilst it may not be pretty to look at it is situated just upstream of Tower Bridge and offers the most wonderful vantage point from where you can capture those memorable views of this beautiful bridge spanning the width of the River Thames especially as the sum is setting - amazing. Tower Bridge was built between 1886 and 1894 in a Victorian Gothic style which I think compliments the nearby Tower of London. Tower Bridge lifts to allow tall ships to pass underneath - it an amazing site if you are lucky enough to be there when it happens especially if it is one of the tall masted historic sailing ships as it is like going back in time. The bridge itself played a key role in celebrating the Queens 2012 Golden Jubilee this summer when the bridge was lifted fully open as a fitting salute to the Queen as she passed on her Jubilee Barge. It was also featured in the opening ceremony of the London 2012 summer Olympic Games. So be sure to make some time to go and see this dramatic bridge, walk across it, admire its majestic towers and if you have time visit the museum which tells the history of this famous bridge. I hope you liked reading my review - I am lucky as I get to see it everyday on my way to and from work and never get bored looking at its timeless beauty. Enjoy.
More than a bridge. This is a Majestic bridge !It's definitely worth visiting... there is also lot of things to see around

icon of London. This bridge is the iconic feature of London city. Many people, like myself from Asia, mistakenly thought it was the London bridge. We visited the exhibition above the Tower Bridge. We could glimpse through the windows from the top of the bridge, but the steel trusses had blocked the wide angle view of the city. The exhibition also includes admission to the actual engine room of the bridge. It is a must see place if you are an engineer. The bridge was also drawn up when we were crossing the London bridge. Information on the actual time and date of the bridge being drawn up can be checked from the internet, but I am not sure about the actual website.
Just by my Office. As my office is just by London Bridge I get to see it every day, today its stunning with filming going on with Bruce Willis!

Cheap and cheerful. Especially compared to other attractions in London, the exhbition is very fairly priced. Enough to keep you occupied for an hour or so, lots of detail about the bridge as well as the surrounding buildings that you can view from either walkway. Engine rooms were slightly dull.

Lovely!. Yes I was finally able to see Tower Bridge up close and it sure does not disappoint. What a beauty! While waiting for our boat at Tower Millennium Pier, the Tower Bridge lifted to give way for a yacht to pass by. I guess we got lucky.

One of the "must see's" of London. Whether you climb to the top or simply view it from the embankment, this is a must see if you are in London sightseeing. The drawbridge is magnificant and if you are lucky to witness it being raised/lowered it really is something very special.

Fun and informative tour providing nice views over the city.. I've only toured the span of the bridge once, but have been to bridge many times. It is a very iconic sight of London and a must see for tourists passing through!
During the Olympics they hung a huge sign of the Olympics' logo right from the bottom of the span.
See my pictures of it here!
http://www.daviddeclercq.com/fighting-for-air-at-the-london-olympics-closing-ceremony-at-victoria-park/
like this. i like tower bridge because it is cool when it opens up and big boats go under never actually seen this but it is still a good London attraction

The Tower Bridge Exhibition. The Tower Bridge Exhibition is one of the cheapest entry fees in London and worth it for the views from the bridge and the history on the construction of the bridge. We had a young child with us and she was entertained. They take your photo and allow you to choose from different souvenirs. If you like that kind of momento, the prices were very reasonable.

Tower Bridge Experience - great for the view (go on a clear day!). The view from the top is excellent, and there's a cute little movie at the beginning which talks about how it was made and how it has changed over the years. The engine room was fascinating as well.

The Tower Bridge. I just watched the Tower Bridge from the street across the river. From down there you can take some really nice pictures! :)i didn't go up there which means i did not pay any money for the tour inside since i thought that was not necessary...

Magic Experience. You hear lots about Tower Bridge - but to experience it is another thing. From beginning to end - it was amazing. There are guides who are well informed about the Bridge and we were shown a short video at the start of the tour, which was informative. Unreal views from the top of it, and the engine room at the other side was great too. Friendly staff and great experience - what more could you ask for
For the very sight of it. I love bridges. So this goes to one of the must see bridges in the world for me.It may be best observed during sunset when they start turning on the lights.Iconic.
The gateway to London on the river Thames. The bridge is an absolute work of art, the engineering and architecture is second to none.An absolute great bridge.

A shining example of Victorian engineering and design. My eyes were opened when I was asked to advise a group of distinguished Americans who were coming to England to study Victorian architecture ,engineering and design.Never having visited the bridge seriously I was suddenly plunged into the wonderful world of Victorian excellence in engineering and so much else.The Bridge as a visitor experience is profoundly interesting because it is not just a beautiful bridge it is a complex structure which has to go uo and down to let ships progress up the river!Even if you have no maths or any engineering go under the Bridge,see how it works,but why it works and understand these wonderful men and women who were transforming our country.
It's the must visit!!. So nice bridge..!!!One of the top attractions of London.Pay attention to its great architecture!! It's next to the London Tower.

My fav place!. The Thames River cruise or just holding hands with your loved ones walking all the way up , this is a nice place to be in London. No prob for vegetarians to find quick food as we managed grabbing the carrot chutney sandwich @ Marks & Spencer. Great historical place, beautiful photos if you love photography and the weather.... mind it that showers are common during the autumn season!

Wouldn't bother . I was in London with my boyfriend from Monday-Friday and walking across the bridge we spotted the signs for the tour. Neither of us had been to London before and wanted to try everything but we both agree that this was the only even slightly disappointing part of our trip. The bridge itself is beautiful and the views over the Thames are fabulous. The walkways do not enhance the view at all, it is the same sight but from a bit higher up. The information about who designed and built the bridge was interesting but then you are thrown into an abyss of repetitive information. If you are a real bridge geek you will enjoy it but if not honestly keep the £8 and use it elsewhere! Definitely do walk across the bridge though :)

Olympic Icon. We walked to this London sight from our hotel - so saw a lot of the Thames on the way. It is in fact a great walk along the river to what is now essentially an Olympic Games icon. We were in London and on a dinner cruise which passed below the Tower Bridge - giving us a close up off the Olympic rings tucked up underneath ready to come down. Which they did as we saw on our walking approach to the bridge. The area around the bridge - The Tower of London on one side and on the other a very pretty area for people to walk and sit and wander along the Thames. We took a stack of photos before entering the bridge structure to see it's history and workings. It was interesting to see how the design for the bridge was decided on and view the Thames from it's superstructure.

Above the Clouds. Two tall towers and a stunning drawbridge. What would I be describing? The London Tower Bridge! This beautiful work of art is unique in it's own way inside and out. As you walk through the stunning lobby after paying your tickets, the sirene Thames River reflects against the glass windows. As you go up the elevator and reach your first destination in your tour, you watch an interesting video describing the architecture of the bridge. To your next destination is a massive hallway filled with history of the olympics, paraolympics, and the species' living around the bridge from mammals to amphibians. Inside the hallway, besides the knowledge surrounding you everywhere, the scenery is lush and filled with bursting color like living inside a painting. Turning around and breathing in the salty scent of water makes you feel "above the clouds" and experiencing a wonderful dream. Finally, when visiting the final stops like the engine room, you feel refreshed and in perpective as you wave good-bye to the famous exhibit.
Great engineering. Perhaps a bit expensive for a shortish tour but was interesting all the same, and good views from the walkways.. The engine room is very impressive.

Not bad.. Tower Bridge is good for the history side. It doesn't take long to do so if you have a short time and want to do a bit of history then go for it! You also have your photo taken as you go in so you can spend some more money if you want to! Not bad but I wouldn't go out of my way to visit it again. Nice views up and down the river.

This isn't London Bridge, it's Tower Birdge. Don't be confused here (as tripadvisor clearly has) - London Bridge is a horrible concrete ugly bridge. It does however have good views of Tower Bridge.The pcitrue trip advisro has used is of Tower Birdge, and that is fantasic. You should definitley walk across it, enjoy the views, and the bridge itself. Also right by Tower of London which is great

Sadly the exhibition inside was quite outdated, but still worth a visit if only to see the engine rooms. I was disappointed that the exhibition photos and information inside was out of date (it didn't mention the 2012 Olympics, the photos didn't show the Shard etc.) but it was a different thing to do and the engine rooms were pretty cool.

Fab views. This was a great tour, you get to walk across the bridge with fantastic views of the Thames. Then you get to see how the bridge was designed with a movie and little replica models. Then you get to go down into the lower areas of the bridge and see how the original steam powered engines lifted the bridge. Absolutely fab!
so beautiful. It's 8 pounds to go to the top.I don't know if it's worthy or not, so i didn't go.It's very suit for taking pics there.Wonderful view.
Wauw. It seems amazing from afar and it is !!!What a grand monument !There is a good view over the themes river !

My Tower Bridge. This bridge is a nostalgia. The bridge came in front of my eyes when i was 4 or 5. The snap of the Tower Bridge London , i first saw in my Nursery Rhyme book. This was a dream come true for me. I am standing on the same bridge which i used to see in my school book. The Tower Bridge a Heritage Replica and Nostalgia was just perfect , beautiful , fabulous.

The best part is the basement. I liked this tour. It was reasonably priced and well done. You have the ability to go to the top and get views of the river. The best part was the victorian machines that opened and closed the bridge. That was very interesting and I thought it was more interesting than our gas powered engines now. If you are into that stuff, this is a good trip.
Londons Butler!. If it opens and you catch it, well marvel at the engineering. If it doesn't marvel only at the friend of Londoners. Iconic sight.
Iconic London attraction. Tower Bridge is an iconic site for visitors to London. A not to be missed attraction. Distinctive architecture and fascinating example of engineering.

Visit Tower Bridge before/after the Tower. The beautiful, iconic Tower Bridge is also an engineering marvel. You'll likely be taking lots of pics of the Tower Bridge since it is so represents London - perhaps only 2nd to Big Ben in photos. But while you're there you can tour inside.We always visit the bridge since the committee to build it was chaired by my 2nd great grand uncle, Sir Albert Joseph Altman. We always want to go and take photos of the dedication plaque. I never knew before that there was an exhibition inside the bridge which helps to understand more of its history and workings.Particularly interesting was understanding the need for the bridge at the time in London's history.

Boring. When I went there I was on a School tour from South Africa. I found it extreeeeeeemly boring and they should make it more childish and for teens. The actual bridge is beautiful but the tour is boring.

Amazing Tour. This was a great tour and its really an amazing work of engineering too. You get to see how the bridge was designed and then you get to go down into the lower areas of the bridge and see how the original steam powered engines lifted the bridge. Neat stuff. There is a fun little pub just south of the bridge called The Draft House where lots of locals seem to congregate.

What a great surprise!. Visiting the Tower of London, we had this magnificent views of the Tower Bridge. So our next stop was this great place, that it has a two corridors above ground that conects one tower to the other, where you can enjoy pictures and memorabilia from London and it's hystory! After the tour, you a directed to go across the street, where you will appreaciated the equipment that they used to lift the bridge to let the big ships wo thru! What a surprise!Excellent attraction!! Hyghly recommended!

Interesting and worth a visit. We visited the bridge on a rainy day which was perfect as it is all inside. Interesting film shows and brilliant photos of famous worldwide bridges. Didn't set my on fire but worth a visit, especially on a rainy day! It is probably more of a man thing with the engine room and old workings!

Best seen from the street.. Good views over the Thames and London. I wasn't excited by the exhibitions inside; one walkway showed bridges from around the world (why not just talk about Tower Bridge, instead of advertising other cities?). The other covered the Olymoic Games from around the world. Rather a hammily acted film on the construction of the Bridge that we were forced to watch before being allowed through to the walkways.I actually preferred looking at Tower Bridge from the outside, as you can see it in all its magnificent splendour. It's quite awe inspiring when you see it lifting to allow boats to pass under.

OK. Been here many times due to family living in London and it is a very nice archetectual bridge and gives a nice dated feeling . It reminds me of 1800 times. It is nice for a bridge but not really my cup of tea I find it a good bridge but at the end of the day a bridge is a bridge it helps you get across the water

incredible for joggers. I saw hundreds of joggers across the bridge. Running along the banks of the Thames offers beautiful views of the lit up buildings and bridges along the river. Bring your running shoes!!
Spectacular. This is a definite must for everyone who visits London. Its a beautiful bridge and the views from it are spectacular. Its also very close to the Tower of London.

Wrong picture. London Bridge is just a normal run of the mill cement bridge . There is lots of bars and Restaurants around London Bridge. The super Borough market is also very close. The picture is NOT London Bridge.

Not too expensive, well worth a visit. Fantastic Views - in the warm and the photographs and information on show is really interesting! Also if u buy a ticket to visit the monument aswell it works out a bit cheaper

Disappointing. Had looked forward to get down in the machine room and see the inner workings of the bridge. Assumed that the gigantic cogs would be impressive. However, I was very disappointed to find out that it was a museum of the Victorian steam engine originally used. The view from the walkway was impressive, but again I would rather have had an idea about how they were originally used than having pictures of the world's largest bridges.We bought a combined ticket to see the bridge and "The Monument". We timed the trip to the monument with a scheduled opening of the bridge, and that was a good experience.
Tower Bridge is gorgeous. Such a great walk across this iconic bridge. It is really stunning and sums up central London. Very close the Tower and an easy walk.

Great view. When you get in to the Tower Bridge the view is great up and down the river and you can walk along the exhibits. It wasn't very interesting for me as I really didn't care about how the bridge works or much about the history. I guess the exhibits were less than exciting

Very informative but a little disappointing. Great views from the two walkways and not rushed so could spend time looking at displays of previous olympics and reading information about the bridge as well as looking at the great views from the platforms. The video presentation was good - informative but not too long to become a lecture. A little disappointed by the engine rooms - thought we would see or be told more about how they open the bridge not just look round the old engines.

Love it. I think tower bridge is amazing, especially if you are there when the bridge opens to let a ship through. They did an amazing job with the lighting for the olympics. One of the iconic symbols of London.

Great views. Wonderful iconic bridge with walkway between the towers. Great views of the river and buildings along the banks. The rooms at the base of the tower house the old steam engines and related machines that originally had been used to raise the bridge. They are in pristine condition and they are quite interesting. There are a number of stairs to negotiate and some walking across the bridge. Admission included in London Pass.

A must see. The bridge is raised more often than you'd expect so it's worth taking the kids and planning to have your picnic here so you can await the passing of a tall ship. The interior, if you can get to see it is a breathtaking feat of Victorian engineering.

Pleasant surprise. I'm not much on going to see "attractions" as most seem just a bit disappointing. In truth, we were looking to fill half a day between other things while entertaining some friends from Italy.What a surprise to find just how gripping this was. The reception was good, though even on a cold November day there was a short queue for the lift, so I guess in summer...........? Then an introductory video before the amazing walk on the upper level. They have done it very cleverly - as there are two walkways, the inner side of each is given over to a splendid photographic exhibition, while the outer side gives clear views over London, one side facing east, the other west. There is also another fascinating video between the two walkways.The last part - the engine rooms and bridge mechanism were much more interesting than might appear. In particular the steam engines (I want one!).A really worthwhile attraction which will keep anybody absorbed for at least a couple of hours.

Awesome scenery and a majestic tower. This is a must visit spots in London. No London trip is complete without coming to this awesome bridge. Nearby the bridge, there's tower of London where there's a certain of fee needed to enter. The river thames provide a great views of the popular landmarks. I love this place!

The most magnificent Bridge in Britain. This is a tourist must see, I cross over it to get to the South Bank for my Thames walk, what amazes me is the amount of tourist that either photo it or use it as a backdrop, always well maintained.

Bridge with magnetism. Professional expose of what the bridge stands for and its wonderful history.Includes detailed videos of how it was constructed and why.Walkways, hundred or so feet above the Thames provide great views of the famous landmarks.Each walkway include large photographs of other famous bridges worldwide, and the west walk includes photographic memories of the venues of the Olympics back in history.Returning to ground level involves a short walk to explore the wonders of the original engineering machinery, which raised the arches in a remarkably short time.

Awesome. Pictures just can't do justice to this landmark. You can feel the history as you walk across it. Lots of great shops and restaurants on both sides of the bridge. The mechanical rooms are an incredible engineering feat. Must see in London.

tower bridge - the best. Tower Bridge is a really beautiful structure and impressive any time, but at night it is really spectacular as it is lit up. This makes for a really great photo opportunity. I have taken a cruise that passes under the bridge and it is definitely worth taking one of these cruises if you have the time and budget !

The bridge of London. This is one of my favorite places. What I love the most of it is when I have to cross the bridge to come home at night. If you can, get a cab, at night, and cross the birdge on it. You'll see all the lights on and it'll be pretty cool!

a good place on a cold day. children
could equate the place with the home and school studies, brought it to life.Plus we had a school trip last year, but a family trip meant more time to talk and go over the history with lots of free time. lovely experience!
Really nice. It's more than a brigde, actually it's an amazing achievement in engineering, watching this landscape from a Tames cruise is totally recommendable. Essential.
Quite an experience. Be sure to get the behind-the-scenes view of this engineering marvel of the Victorian era. Great views of the Thames, too.
Good attraction. Good attraction for the small price. Very informative and interesting displays across the bridge, engine room is more for the boys I'd say!

One of the most romantic bridges I have ever seen. It was my first visit to London and although I was on a business trip....I couldnt miss my girl friend more than this one ocassion, when I saw the London bridge at night. It was such a romantic place. It truely is the most iconic place in London..I advise all travelers to London to see it in the evening.

history. The history of tower bridge is interesting. You can get a 2for 1 ticket to go in with a travel card which makes it good value for money. The engine room is quite impressive to look at. You can get some good views from here as well. Not one to take young children

A must see. A true icon of London.. It doesn't take long to stop for a picture opportunity and walk across this London Icon. I have never paid to go up to the top of the Tower Bridge. I'm happy just to stop and take in the site itself.

Stupid follow-up to the Tower of London. After the richly satisfying experience of the Tower of London, it is only natural to visit the Tower Bridge. This is a mistake, however, because there is really nothing to see. First, you take an elevator to the top of one tower, cross over the upper pathway, and take another elevator down. The pathway has an exhibition, of pictures of famous bridges from around the world. Next you proceed down underground to see the steam engine that used to raise and lower the bridge. I am sure that this was fascinating in 1890, but it is not very interesting to modern tourists.

a trip back in time. The fact that you can go inside now and that it is one of the most iconic places in the world makes it worth the trip. You can see the entire city from the top and view history from one location.

Past Times. Great opportunity to see some great Brirish engineering and the expertise and craftmenship of days gone by. Great location in the heart of the Thames with great attractions both sides of the river. A real gateway to London.

Impressive and iconic. Iconic structure, very photogenic. Interesting for the technically minded as well as the general tourist.
We didn't go to the museum, but walking over, under, and around it was worthwhile. It was floodlit in the evening which was attractive.
It's a must see, even if you just sail under it on a ferry.
Wonderful Bridge. The Pride of London excellent to watch , a bridge to remember.I went with my family we spend good few hours my children's enjoyed the day .

A Bridge to remember. We stayed close to Tower Bridge and spent quite a but of time watching it, day and night and crossing it to the beach opposite our hotel down the "horsleydown old stairs" from where we watched the bridge raised as former Humber Ferry "The Waverley" sailed through. You can easily find the regular scheduled times when the bridge will be raised - just google "tower bridge lift times".
