Excellent place to have a quite evening. I visited this place while in London for the first time .View is excellent with river thames flowing majestically .I heard that the bridge opens when the ships pass by but could not see for my self.worth a visit.

OK if you're into engineering - great views of the river. My step father found it fascinating but then he's into all things mechanical. There's lots of information about bridge building all over the world - not really for me - but the walkway gives spectacular views of the Thames and London landmarks and the entrance fee is OK

Amazing bridge!. The most beautiful bridge in the world since 1894. You must see the base of the tower to see how its mechanisms works. Amazing! By the way, tower Bridge is sometimes mistakenly referred to as London Bridge. To get there: The nearest Underground station is London Bridge or Tower Hill.
great place. didn,t know how big this was.great place to visit.children loved it
Probably the oldest bridge in London!. Take a boat down the river Thames, its a grand bridge!

Magnificent!. If traveling by tube, get off at Tower Hill and stroll across the bridge. The view of the bridge is magnificent, and so is that of the river thames. Walk across the bridge, and then stroll down The Queen's Walk towards London Bridge for a very relaxing walk, and stunning views. A choice of some great restaurants is available at Queen's Walk.
great view. Being this close or near this bridge make you feel like a very small person because the massive size. good to see.

Steeped in history. Brilliant experience walking along the walkways at the top of the bridge which is 139ft above the Thames... granted you pay £8 pp, but you can spend as much time as you like up there savouring the views... The olympic rings had been hanged from the bridge on the day we visited and on the east side of the walkways there was a history of all the cities that have hosted the games since they started in 1896.. On the west side there are many pictures and facts about famous and historical bridges from across the world.. Access to the engine rooms is also and included in the ticket price and it's always nice to see how things work... Beautiful British engineering at it's best...

Fascinating. This exhibition is wonderful. Not only are you in/on the most famous bridge in the world, but you get to see two short films which explain how the bridge was conceived and how it was constructed.Truly fascinating. There are also photgraphs and displays of the most iconic and unique bridges throughout the world and specifically other cities which have held the Olympics.The views are spectacular from the top of the bridge and the walk around the engine rooms help ou to grasp the engineering feat that the bridge was and still is. If you visit the website you can find the times the bridge bascules are raised which completes the 'story'. In case you weren't aware, London is hosting the 2012 Olympics and this iconic bridge is now adrned with a model of the Olympic rings which quite frankly, look as though they've always been there! The fact they get raised as the bridge opens is quite an awesome spectacle so get there soon!
Not worth the money. It cost eight pounds to get into this exhibit, and the only thing I really got out of it was the nice views of the city. Surely there are cheaper places to get a nice picture.

Great views!. I only went on the tower bridge for the beautiful views! definitely worth it. There is also alot of information about other bridges around the world and 2 short movies about how the the bridge was made, and also entrance to the engine room. What made it extra special was that just after we finished the exhibition we over heard that the bridge was opening so we stood on the bridge to watch it open! Once in a lifetime experience, we were at the right place at the right time for once.

Excellent and very good value for money. We traveled to London by train and if you go on the 2 for 1 website you can get cheaper entry to the Tower Bridge exhibition. Its normally £8 per adult to get in, which to be fair in London is a good price. You go up to the top by lift and watch a short film detailing the designing of the bridge before you then walk across the top of the bridge through the covered walk ways. Along each walk way there are lots of information boards, interactive screens and small sliding windows where you can take a photo through - an excellent idea! There is another small video you can watch showing the making of the bridge, in a room where the ceiling has been removed exposing all the beams and metalwork to the roof which is an impressive sight. A lift takes you back down and you exit the bridge following a blue line along the floor to the "engine room".The engine room is worth the £8 in itself, its so impressive. The huge boilers and machines which were used to power the bridge are restored so well, and the sheer size of the machinery is well worth a look. We came out feeling the exhibition was well worth the money even at full price, with the 2 for 1 its excellent value for money and well worth a visit.

Another iconic worldwide landmark. I grew up in London, but now live abroad. When I was a child, I would make regular visits to all the usual landmarks, why wouldn't you? when you have such great places on your doorstep! Surprisingly though a lot of Londoners never really go into the touristy places.As a kid I was taught that this was the gateway to London, quite literally, with its massive door opening to let in any visiting ships.As well as being one of the most recognised bridges of the world, it is definitely the most attractive, and whe you stand on it and look around you'll understand why. Please visit this free to use tourist attraction it's really worth it!
Still Impressive. Seen the bridge many times but was away from London for a few years. I took my Fiancee there and it is still an impressive work of art. Well worth the trip.

so neat. we walked to tower bridge from our hotel to see the city lit up at night on our way back. the bankside footpath was amazing! we enjoyed using this path every day! tower bridge is so beautiful!

Great views. Caught this one at the end of a day walking around London. Tickets to the exhibition are cheaper late afternoon and the whole tour takes about 45 minutes if you take it slow and admire the views along the Thames from the overhead walkways.
Well worth a visit!
Imposing work of art!. Try to visit any month but August when it is FILLED with too many visitors. It's a beautiful bridge and well worth looking at.
Victorian Gothic masterpice. looks fine for the olympics, make apoint of going up to the top
Nice.. It was raining that day we visited the bridge. It was bustling with people everywhere. Too crowded. Didn't really feel anything special about the place.

Interesting!. I enjoyed walking along the tower bridge walkways and reading the various boards full of info located along the walkways. The animations and videos were interesting. I got some really good photos and found the engine room interesting. Tower Bridge is so impressive!
A tip would be , do the combined admission with The Monument (a hidden charm of London).
Amazing. This bridge is a work of art in itself its truly amazing and beautiful. A must on your visit to London.
Beautiful. Just looking at it makes you wonder about the history and the hard work put into constructing it.
wonderfull. beautiful bridge and its definatly worrth seeing. so glad its near me.
Breath taking view. the view of london is just amazing new and old merge together!!!
Refreshing!. The architecture of the bridge with its strong structures
Beautiful Bridge. I took some wonderful pictures there, the bridge is really nice, for me much better than at pictures.

Funny it wouldn't come down aligned!. Our bus had to stop on the bridge as a boat was going to pass from under it and the bridge had been split / pulled up. but when they droped the two sides to close the bridge again, it wouldn't come down in proper alignment, so they pulled it up again and dropped - but again it didn't work, took them 4 tries to get it down aligned!!
Superb .A must visit,just to have walked over on the bridges as this isthe only one in the world. It is a great feeling whenlooking at the river known as the pool of london.
Was a bit bored. The best thing about this visit was the view from the bridge. I found the actual exhibits a bit boring I'm afraid.
tourist day. we love going to london and doing the sights even though we only live an hour away. we make sure we visit the tower of london, london bridge, big ben and buckingham palace - great day

Absolutely Beautiful Bridge. Much more beautiful than I remember from my previous London visit a decade earlier. Definitely try to get there at a time when they lift the bridge. It is really interesting to see. The lift times are posted on their website http://www.towerbridge.org.uk/TBE/EN/BridgeLiftTimes/.Great places to take pictures of the bridge in its entirety are near the entrance to the towers of London and on London bridge.
Interesting!. Very interesting! Beautifully and very ingenious built at that time.
Working of Tower Bridge. A fascinating place for Young or Old its well worth a visit when in London

Well worth your time!. June 2012: I was not expecting much from the tour of London’s landmark Tower Bridge. Thankfully, I was mistaken. The tour starts with a 5 minute or so movie – which was quite well done, and helped one understand the history behind the bridge and why it was built. The rest of the tour is ‘on your own’ and done mainly via helpful pictures and well-placed factual texts on both sides of the bridge’s walkways. The views of London from these walkways are just terrific! The tour ends in the engine room of the bridge. I recommend this tour if you have an hour to spare – it proved quite interesting, all in all. It’s not often that one gets to combine history, landmarks, and terrific views.

not a great experience. was there in june and found it boring from start to finish.the bridge is world famous. but can not say the same about the exhibition. its not worth the money. but like everything in life you have to try it. its nice to say you where inside the famous bridge but thats it.

Exterior is amazing..inside tour...well, once is enough. Of course Tower Bridge can be seen from all over London. I feel it should be experience by walking on, driving across and of course you need to take a few photos. The Tower Bridge experience(where you tour the inside)was OK.... I mean I'm glad I did it..one time. When you take the tour you do get to see how the draw bridge works and walk across the top of the bridge(from the inside, of course). I didn't take very long he day I was there...45 min. tops. Something to do if you have time AFTER touring The Tower of London and riding The London Eye.

Painting by numbers. We go and take a look at this sometimes on trips into London as my grandad helped to pain it (probably in the 50s or 60s) but it is a marvellous landmark and a fantastic backdrop for piccies!

Interesting attraction at reasonable price.. very interesting attraction with friendly helpful staff. the entrance price was very reasonable, about half the price of other attractions which we did not enter as a matter of principle.

Unmissable London icon. Try to attend an event on the top walkways.. Tower Bridge is one of those umissable London icons like Big Ben and the Houses of Parliament. It is not commonly known that you get a great view of the bridge from the observation platform at the top of Monument (tube - Monument - or just a few minutes walk from Tower Bridge).If you are very lucky you may see the bridge open. This is still a rather amazing spectacle - there is no other bridge like it in the world.And, if you can, try to attend an event on the walkways at the top of the bridge. They are long and thin with some great views of London over the river. Memorable.
day out in london. it should be seeing, very interesting experience..
Interesting. Good value for money, very interesting to see the workings of the bridge and also a birds eye view of London.

A great landmark. This is an icon of the Thames and a bridge that is a one off.get up close and if you see the bridge being raised thats a bonus.If you visit the tower of london then tower bridge watching is a graet place to stop off for lunch

Walk over and above. Often thought of as 'London Bridge', situated close to The Tower of London. Walk along the south bank of the Thames, many other sights ancient and modern. You can walk over the bridge, through the towers. Although there are guided tours including above the roadway at the top of the towers.You may be lucky to see the roadway lifted to allow tall ships to pass underneath.A walk past the Tower of London, St. Paul's, and down Fleet Street and the Strand will take you about an hour, but worth the effort.

great views of London. It is an amazing piece of engineering and history and the views across the city and down the river are spectacular

Absolutely great!. I would highly reccommend stopping to take pictures here! It is very nice!

enjoyed my visit. This was very neat. The view from the walkway was really good. Bring your camera. I learned a lot about the bridge and the short videos were interesting. my boyfriend liked the engine room.

Must See in London. This is one of England best attractions. The first night of our recent vacation to London we were privy to the Tower Bridge being lit in blue. It was spectacular. Paris-guy. Have the tour arround the whole bridge inc under in the engine house totaly awesome
a special London land mark. can there be any oter bridge like it in the world? Would have loved to see it raised

Tower Bridge London take the tour. This was a great way to spend half a day well worth the £8 entrance fee and some guides have a two for one offer. just go!. at night this is a magestic place to be . the lights from the bridge lend a magical quality to this iconic landmark . the thames flows below and you can see for miles . once opened the bridge is a facinating feat of engineering and you must make sure you see this happening ! go up to the walkways for magnificent views . you wont be disappointed . the working exhibition is interesting to see but i just cant get enough of the views ... mesmerising . potters fields , south side is a lovely park to stroll in and you can walk all the way to westminster from here , still with tower bridge in view . incredible

If you like Really Big Machinery, a Must See!. Excellent self-guided tour, with walking across both upper spans of the bridge, seeing a well-done film on the design contest that created it, and of course the Engine Room for the ultimate in steam and hydraulic power. Totally worth 9 pounds.

One of the best landmarks of London. One of the most popular attractions of London. Tower bridge has drawn attractions to foreign tourists for many years but is often mistakenly known to foreigners as London Bridge.
It looks very attractive at night time when the lights are illuminated .

It's a moving bridge that does not move.. As bridges go, Tower Bridge is iconic but a little dull. You find yourself attracted to it - I think it's the subcomscious thought that it's a cantilever design and the road can actually split and raise up on either side, as many a famous plotline has highlighted. Problem is, they hardly ever open the bridge so, once your hopes of seeing said bridge open are dashed, it's a bit disappointing. And it doesn't lead anywhere - the fact is you're going to find the bridge by accident, approaching it from the North and there really isn't anywhere worth going to at the South side, so you just end up walking back over it, still with the vain hope of seeing it open suddenly and a Hackney cab make a last-minute hurling jump towards you from the other side.

Must walk across for great views of the Thames on either side. Early morning fog on the river is mysterious but the sunsets are georgeous. Every kid must see.

Great landmark. Such a beautiful bridge and lovely to walk along it and seep in the history. Went past the bridge over 10 times during our stay and stopped to take a photo each and every time. A London Icon. Finally visited this wonderful bridge after years of "I'll get round to it one day" , and I'm really glad I did !It's a superb museum of engineering as well as a great place to view London up and down the river.The various stages of construction are well displayed as you wander across the overhead walkways and on the south side you can see the original engine rooms.Worth every penny !

great place to take photo. this place was so great for take photo... so enjoy it... with the bridge, boat, water also this bridge can open and off while the big boat run here...

Wonderful Feat of Engineering. Aesthetically brilliant. An iconic British image. A treat just to walk over it, and back. Superb backdrop for photographs.

Well worth a visit. An inexpensive and very interesting attraction.

Excellent visit to historic bridge. We travelled down by train and as a result could get 2 for 1 vouchers. Well worth a look at this historic bridge. the way they have put the visit together is very good. The views from the walkways are impressive.

A magic monument.. From the first time I walked across and saw it open, and every time I see Tower Bridge it makes me proud to have been bourn in England.

Another Must see in London. This iconic bridge is worth the couple of hours to explore its history and walk across the top.The bridge exhibit includes the history of the bridge itself and how it was built, an exhibit of famous bridges around the world, and Olympics Cities exhibit, a visit to the engine rooms and great views up and down the river.Kids activities are offered through out to keep the attention of younger visitors. Really enjoyed our visit here, it is way more interesting than it sounds in this review!

Fabulous. A great and worthwhile visit to all. The well informed staff/volunteers are always on hand to answer questions. The tour they offer is a must as its very informative. Crown Jewels - wow!
Unfortunately you cannot take photos.
I would recommend this visit

Very Informative with a Great View!. I have been to London many time and always walked across Tower Bridge without ever taking the tour. This time however, I decided to give it a go and I'm glad I did! The best part of the tour is getting to walk across the very top level of the bridge. This was worth the admission price alone as you get a great view across the city. There are very good informational stands laid out too, so you can catch up with a bit of history. The tour also includes a visit to the old engine rooms which explains how the bridge operated in the days before it was electrified. Well worth it!
Experience worth it...for a group of engineers. Interesting to see how the bridge works and that it's still operating with the original designs. Spectacular views from the top of the supports

A must to see.... Good place to get pictures of the Tower of London & all along the Thames. Tower Bridge is well taken care of & it's so majestic to look at. We did not go on theTower Bridge experience.

Famous sight. I didn't bother paying for the Tower Bridge Experience, but even just walking across the bridge is a great experience! You can see a lot of famous sights from the bridge, too. Make sure to have time for this one!

Ok. I found this attraction to be a little overpriced. If you want some great photos (weather permitting), go for it.But be prepared for the canvasseres, who are very pushy, staff who are a little robotic and uninterested, and a rather dull exhibition.

Fantastic views of London. Although I've crossed over the Thames on the Tower Bridge many times, I've never been inside until recently. The views are fantastic from up there and the maps provided help you identify other attractions in London. There is also information on other famous bridges, which is great for bridge lovers like myself! The downstairs room with all the explanations of how the bridge is operated is interesting as well. I think it offered a good value for money and for just a bit under £1.00 (student rate) you can get a ticket for The Monument as well.
Stunning. Just loved the beauty off the bridge and was lucky to enough to see it lifted.

Spectacular!. I probably took a hundred photographs of just this bridge. We added the Tower Bridge Experience this time and thoroughly enjoyed the views from the upper walkway. I did not enjoy the 206 steps up to the walkway. The lift was full and we opted to walk. Next time... I'll wait!
Surprisingly interesting!. There's a museum and guided tours of the bridge which the kids really enjoyed

I live around the area and am still amazed by its beauty. I live around the area and each time I cross the bridge, I'm taken by how beautiful it is. It can get a fairly crowded with tourists, but it is worth visiting.The nice thing about the area is that there are a lot of attractions in the area and many great restaurants as well. So it's easy to combine things and have a great day out. Personally I'd start off the morning with a visit to Borough market (when it's not as crowded as in the afternoon), then I'd walk along More embankment towards Tower bridge (also have a wander around Butler's wharf). You could either cross the bridge and visit the Tower of London or stay south of the river and have a lunch around the picturesque Bermondsey street (for instance Zucca, Jose, Pizarro, Magdalen, etc).Enjoy.
worth a visit. worth seeing while in London, and great to walk along the water nearby. a good site for pictures and lots of nearby places to eat or sit outside and have a coffee.

The most recognised icon of London. The Tower Bridge is to London what the Eiffel tower is to Paris. Easily the most recognised icon, the Tower Bridge is probably more spectacular from the outside than from the inside. If pressed for time, the Tower Bridge tour can be given a miss. Make sure to walk up and down the Tower Bridge and read the plaques that give a brief glimpse into its history. If you have time, do take the Tower Bridge Tour that takes you inside the Bridge. Here are life size working models of the original hydraulic equipment, though the working mechanism now is different. Just looking at the massive pistons is fascinating. You will also get a quick lesson in the physics of the drawbridge, the history, vintage photographs and a short film on the bridge. Not a must do, but if seeing how things work excites you, then go for it. Budget an hour for the tour.
WOW!!. A must see at night!! Amazing!! Do the Tower Bridge Exhibit if you can!

I love this bridge. I viewed this and it's a bit pricey like all things in London.I really enjoyed the inside and information provided. Watching the bridge go up was fab. Walk the bridge. I seen it full with people in the marathon and lucky to run over the main bit three times loved it loved it with Chariots of fire music playing. I love London what can i say.every year if not more

Great views, short stop, interesting. I was pleasantly surprised. I didn't realize you actually walk across the entire bridge on the top! I'd recommend it. We tried to race to everything quickly that day, and we saw the Tower Bridge, London Bridge experience, Jewels, Churches, and shopped easily. The tube system takes you there easily.

Fun to walk across the bridge. Tower bridge - frequently called the London Bridge by accident was a unique attraction in that you can walk along the sidewalk for free, or pay entry to go above. The fee wasn't too steep so we decided to go in and were glad we did. The movies and exhibits are informative and it wasn't too crowded.
Tower Bridge. Interesting and some good views of London, but nothing that makes it stand out as a must see attraction.
Unique. A wonderful structure, you must walk accross it and look upa nd down the river as well as looking up at the structure above your head.
Another London must do. Though the views are ok you must do it. Try the TimeOut 2x1 in conjunction wiht a railway card to offset the price.
LOVELY. if u go on the cruise on the river u get an amazing view of all the bridges and tower bridge ! :)

My favorite site in London. This bridge is beautiful! At first we were just planning on taking pics from a far but its definately worth a walk over the bridge - there is so much detail you can see far away. There are also places to get ice cream and snacks on the side opposite the tower of london which is nice on a warm day. Lots of sitting area over there too. Definately a nice area to take a break and relax for a bit. The bridge is equally beautiful at night as well.

A great family outing. We loved our visit to Tower Bridge. It was great to cross the bridge which we had not expected to be covered. (Our kids loved the touch screen quizes, which gave me time to take photo's.) i was impressed that they had provided windows so you could take photo's with out reflections.The exhibition is clean and well managed, definately worth the time and cost!

The referbished Tower Bridge. The fact that the upper walk ways were now open to the public, giving a great view of the Thames both up and down stream. The walk ways are also enclosed protecting you from the elements, and have exibits on display.

Very interesting and worth the time and effort.. If and when you visit The Tower of London I suggest walking the 500' to Tower Bridge. That bridge is one of London's icons and you will learn much about how it was constructed as well as be able to walk across the top which was cool.

Fascinating, as were the St Katherines docks nearby.. We have a special interest in the bridge and pocess a hand made screw from the original construction in the 1800's and have sailed under the raised bascules a number of times.
A great attraction. We walked down from the London Dungeon and then went up in to Tower Bridge. A great combination for a day out.

You can't really miss it!. Truthfully it's museum was a bit boring, but it was pretty cool walking over it and finding the join halfway - you can see the river through the crack. That fired up a little enthusiasm! And then on to the Tower of London.

Interesting exhibits on the construction of this icon. We found the exhibit on how the bridge was constructed extremely interesting and the old photos an eye opener. The best is the views of the Thames from the top walk way. Our four year son found the engine room exhibit the most hands on with the levers and buttons and loved the 3D reconstruction on how the bridge was built. We liked the bridges of the world and were able to tick off a couple that we'd visited.You easily spend 1 to 2 hours here if its raining outside. Rode over as part of a bike tour. Usually this place is very busy, but on a Sat morning at 10am was quiet enough to stop and take in the views and photos. Great view of the Mayors building (which looks like a take off of NZ capital Wellingtons house of parliament.
Interesting. Good value entry to see the towers plus engine rooms. Informative guides plus stickers kept the kids busy. Good views of London can be had and worth spending a couple of hours there.

Marvellous Victoria engineering. What is fascinating about this iconic landmakr is not just the sheer beauty of its towers, it is the engineering behind it which you get to see on a tour. The non-visible parts which support the building and raise the middle spans, is just as interesting and a testament to victorian engineers

An interesting hour spent on a rainy day. It is a long time since i have visited Tower Bridge. I found the attraction good value for money . Very informative about how the bridge was built. My daughter enjoyed the section on bridges around the world and the stunt cyclist at the end . We are lucky enough to be seasoned travellers always admiring other countries architecture and culture . This trip to London reminded me of just how much we have to offer as a country and our own heritage.

A historical tower. It definitely worth to pay 8 pound to see the view from the Tower Bridge! The tour also includes videos of how the bridge was designed and implemented. In the top of the tower there is an exhibition with bridges around the world. At the end of the tour you go down where there are the machines that used to handle the opening of the bridge.
Beautiful bridge. Tower bridge is beautiful and has an interesting history and engine room.
really great. have a nice walk along the thames and visit this great monument,a great piece of architecture
iconic london feature. great to stroll across and watch the bridge lift to allow large boats under

Iconic. Then walk up to the Monument and climb up those stairs for another fantastic view of London - and you can stay as long as you like!
Spectacular. The history, the views, the experience. Awesome. If the weather is good then the visit will be so much better.

From the south tower, we walked to the engine room which would be fascinating for engineering buffs. The four rating is because the structure itself is so fascining.

great for photos on a sunny day. my kids call this the princess bridge as it looks like 2 princess castles.for years they've been excited at seeing it on the train journey approach to london. Looking right out the window from the south you can see right across it.20 quid for a family of 4you travel up in a lift, watch a video and see lovely detailed models and facts....ie it wasn't bombed in the war as the enemy used it as a landmark. then walk across the top and watch another video and walk back again (but then come back to go back down).the lift down wasn't working while we were there and we weren't warned so do check before you pay as the stairs are quite old and trickyat the top there are penny press machines if your kids are into that.there are 2 diff ones.the walkways have little pigeon hole windows to take great pictures for your scrapbooksthe kids get a passport and 4 sets of stickersthe engjne room was quite jnteresting and the toilets quite cleanI would say a good attraction that takes maybe 1-2 hours...don't bother with the photo they offer. It's just a super-imposed naff gift. Why buy that when you're actually there at a monument of great british building.
Tower Bridge. We really enjoyed this. Went as a family of 4 with 2 teenagers who also loved it.

The queues to get in are never too long despite being a very short walk from The Tower of London. So... Very... Boring.... Look! It's an engine!! (Please read statement in a sarcastic tone)The most exciting part is getting to go up to the walkways, but they've managed to ruin that by putting a box all round them so you can only get a good view through tiny sliding windows.£8 for about 40 minutes of boredom. Nice view to the city. The history of the construction is also very interesting.

Great attraction. We went to the Tower Bridge Experience after visiting the Tower of London, given that they are right next to each other. We paid 8 pounds total for our tickets (normally 8 pounds each) using the 2 for 1 Attractions deal (brochure found at National Rail stations, you need a rail pass or Travelcard to qualify). It was very neat being able to walk above the bridge in the two walkways, which were filled with facts and pictures related to Tower Bridge and other bridges around the world. Your ticket also permits entry into the engine rooms, where you get to see how the bridge was originally powered (hold onto your tickets, you need to produce them to see this room).
Dry Feet. Thanks to this bridge I managed to cross the Thames without getting wet.

Cool views from the top of a London icon.. Great views from the high level walkways of this world-famous bridge. It's quite fun getting to see inside the "castle" bits and learn how the bridge was built.I was surprised to learn that the bridge is nowhere near as old as it looks. The castle bits apparently make it blend in with the nearby Tower of London, but there's a modern steel superstructure underneath!There's also a rather cool "penny cruncher" machine at the top, which will flatten you copper pennies into souvenir tokens...and the old Victorian boiler rooms are pretty impressive as well.

My Two Cents - The Tower Bridge Exhibition. While the Tower Bridge is certainly one of the most impressive and iconic portions of the London skyline, its real value as a “tourist attraction” was, in my opinion, rather limited.The Tower Bridge (not to be confused with London Bridge which is far less aesthetically impressive) is located in close proximity to the Tower of London and the HMS Belfast and is easily recognizable as it links the north and south shore of the Thames. The best way to get to the Tower Bridge is probably by taking either the Circle Line or the District Line on the Underground and getting off at the Tower Hill Station. Disembarking here will let you out just north of the Tower of London and within easy walking distance of the Tower Bridge (2-5 minute walk). There are also a number of Bus Lines which will drop you off in close proximity to the bridge.The bridge itself is visually impressive and it was somewhat surreal to be standing on the same structure I have seen countless times on T.V. and in the movies. There are any number of different views and angles for camera happy tourists to take all the pictures they want, however, I would suggest that visitors avoid actually going into the Tower Bridge Exhibition (TBE) itself.Visitors to the TBE enter on the north shore of the Thames, are taken up an elevator to the top of the north tower and then let off on the upper walkway between the north and south shores. Visitors can pretty much take as much time as they want in the exhibition, however, unless you have a real love of bridges and bridge design (which I do not), the TBE isn’t really anything to write home about. The views from the walkway are OK, but I was very disappointed that you DO NOT GET TO GO OUTSIDE and the views from the walkway are often obstructed by the many photographs lining the walkway which depict famous or historically significant bridges from all over the world. I was hoping to get a couple of really good photographs of the Tower of London, but was unable to do so because of the layout of the “exhibition”. I was actually quite annoyed by the whole thing and was ready to leave almost as soon as I got off of the elevator. Once visitors are finished with the walkway, you descend the south tower into the engine room to see how the drawbridge was designed and how the bridge itself is raised and lowered. While I am certain that there are people out there who are fascinated by this sort of thing, but I thought it was a total waste of time.Looking back, the TBE was far and away my least favorite part of our trip to London. Don’t get me wrong, I loved seeing the bridge, but in truth, I thought that the TBE was a waste of 8 pounds (about $12.50) per person and I would strongly caution anyone other than those who have a very distinct interest in bridges from wasting their time with a tour of the TBE. Instead, consider taking a tour of All Hallows Barking by the Tower, which is a church located on the west side of the Tower of London. Trust me, you’ll take far more away from the church and the history it contains than you will from the TBE.
Interesting history small exibition. There was not a huge amount to see but it was very interesting. Staff were very friendly and helpful.
Tower Bridge. great London landmark. Absolutely beautiful ...................
pics pic and pics.... u can see this from far off and get pics with this background... enjoy the bars around this place on a Friday evening....
Wonderful views. If you get a chance go up in the lift. It's not for the faint hearted but the views are stunning and as it's next to the Tower of London it's a good part of a day out.
Impressive!. A great backdrop to the Tower of London and the nearby St Catherine Docks are lovely in the summer especially for eating and drinking by the river
One of the wonders of the world.... What I could say? I live just around the corner and I am delighted every day when I look at it! Spectacular master piece which you can never get enough.. <3
Stunning Bridge. A Victorian masterpiece in engineering. It can bee seen when you visit the Tower of London, take one of the boats from Westminster.
beauty. The Bridge is beautiful, the exhibition is also great. What I found really usefull: couloured line on the ground helps you to find the right way to the exhibition's entry.
Good to see. Tour takes you across the walk ways. Lots of memorabilia about when the bridge was built and such like. Good to while away a hour or so.
Good to see. Tour takes you across the walk ways. Lots of memorabilia about when the bridge was built and such like. Good to while away a hour or so.
One thing you have to see. Scenically it never lets you down. The position is great, near St Kathatine's Docl
Okay. This place was okay to vist bit boring but would not be at the top of my place to vist next time

Great View from Bridge!. Bridge has a great view of other bridges and filled with historic info. Even has pictures and summaries of other famous bridges around the world -- engine room was fascinating for my engineering family!

Fascinating Visit. I’ve wanted to visit this for a few years but something else always gets in the way so it was great to finally get there.The attraction itself is fairly reasonably priced and you can easily spend a good couple of hours here. There are 2 walk ways facing north and south and each have some great views, the only way you would get a better one is on the eye. Along the walkways there are plenty of bits of information to read about the bridge, other info on London and also about other bridges, there are also some computerised quizzes to take if you wish. In the 2 towers there are videos to watch about the history and construction of the bridge. They are on continuous loop so if its half way through you can wait for it to start again, nobody is rushing you along. Once you have finished in here you then leave the towers and make your way to the engine room where you see historical engine parts and get told about how the bridge opened in the past and present. There is a lot to see here in quite a small space. There is also a lot of interactive things to have a go at here. All in all a great visit and although I wouldn’t go back every day I would definitely do so some time in the future. I would recommend you visit on a clear day as you may not get a good view from the towers if it is misty.
Tower Bridge Experience. Very good value, walking on the walkways above the bridge gives great views of the river, interesting information provided, engine room fascinating
Bridge Bridge Bridge. Great views but all you read, watch and hear about is about bridges!

A must for bridge lovers!. I cannot imagine going to London without walking the Tower Bridge. Unlike the Golden Gate Bridge, it doesn't require a great deal of time or stamina. The views from the bridge were lovely. The best part was discovering that (for a fee) I could go up inside the towers and walk the upper level! Also, this included a tour of the engine room. For an additional 1 pound, I purchased the combined ticket to climb up the Monument ( to the Great Fire). Good exercise and a great way to view the city, it helped compensate for my disappointment that the viewing area from St Paul's dome was not open.
L Love this Bridge. I just love Tower Bridge and although have lived in London my whole life, still get a buzz out of seeing the Bridge all lit up at night. It is just so beautiful.

Going through Tower Bridge. Interesting and completely different from what's seen in London, it combines history with its flashy blue colour...Unfortunately it takes some time to go through it by bus because of traffic jams...

Beautiful bridge. cool looking old bridge. i enjoyed walking over the bridge

a sight to see day or night. great to visit any time at any weather always present itself in a different view

Beautiful bridge- walking across at night is fabulous. The Tower Bridge is beautiful. We took pictures of it during the day, and walked across it at night. Excellent attraction. Engine Rooms are excellent, as is the customer service, and the sticker passport was a nice extra for our son.
Very interesting. A very iconic bridge that says London to me. One thing was that some of the lights were smashed, but it still looked amazing.

An interesting bridge with great views. It is definitely worth crossing the bridge for the views up and down the river, and also to examine the architecture of the bridge itself. Not to be confused with London Bridge!. Tower bridge is the one by the Tower of London and its the one most people probably think is London Bridge - but it isn't. About £25 for a family of 4 ticket and good views and history slides at the high level walkways. Victorian type amusements to keep the children occupied. Victorian design and enginuity at its best.
Just go and see it. Worth seeing closer than the views from central London, only because you can go there when visiting the Tower of London

Good Value with rail offer. Use the booklet vouchers available at stations in conjunction with rail tickets and get two for one. Interesting building with great views and history. Great for adults and children too.
A must see location.. Go and see it when you're in London, one of those things you must see ones in your live.

Iconic Landmark. Tower bridge is such an iconic landmark, you just have to get up close to it and be part of a picture with it. No many people realise that you can actually buy an 'exhibition' ticket (£8) to go inside (!!) the bridge and walk between the towers on the high level walkway.Right next door is The Tower of London so you can do both in one go. if you have any time left you can walk along the river tow path to reach the Milennium Bridge and go to either St Paul's cathedral to the right (North) or the Tate Modern gallery to the left (south).

Across Tower Bridge - on the top.. We were really pleased to be able to see Tower Bridge from the inside. Really interesting for all the family. Wonderful to see the massive iron girders which hold up each side. Victorian engineering at its best. After watching a short video we were able to walk across the top section which had windows all along it and where you could see the best views down the river and down on The Tower of London. There was interesting information about London and the bridge. After coming down on the other side we went to the Engine room where we saw the enormous equipment used to raise the bridge. Something for everyone - Great !

Birthday Special. I thought I should put this review up, its one of the few that I have photos of. Actually though date is not quite right, but I think you would find my views interesting. My wife hired the bridge for my 65th birthday party, you can hire the area above the bridge where there are two, what used to be the walk ways for pedestrians when the bridge was open. Now they are for viewing and also for functions like my Birthday party. We had a couple of hundred people, I have the view that they came for the place rather than my party, and I can not blame them, it is iconic both in terms of what it is and where you are. You can see all the workings, great videos, and fantastic views of London and the Thames both day and night you would have a job to beat it. So as I now say come to my Bridge.

Nice bridge. Everything looks amazing ONLY when it's sunny! Pray and hope you have good sunny weather for all attractions in UK.

Great. I enjoyed this experience and had never before been inside and upstairs. Interesting to see how the bridge works. Worth the entrance fee
A captivating experience. Great views on the river, historical photos and insight into the mechanics/technology of Tower Bridge. A captivating experience.

Pay For The Tour..... Tower Bridge is no doubt one of the top 10 finest icons of London where I would consider taking photo's to be mandatory.  I had never been inside the bridge even though I worked for 7 years on the other side of it, walking over the bridge at least twice per day 6x days per week.This December whilst showing my american partner around London, I finally paid the reasonable fee to go inside and tour the inner workings of the famous Tower Bridge.  What a thrill it was.  The Gantries across the two towers are where the tour really gets going, they have sealed them in with Glass so its warm and protects against the wind.  The views are excellent and the history showing how they built this amazing piece of engineering is impressive.Then there's the stairs down the other side and the short walk into the actual workings underneath with the huge steam pumps and coal burners etc which were used for the cantilever system of the road way.  Well worth the tour!
This is a great. site to see..Amazing just to watch the river boats going up and down the river Thames...so much activity in one area..
really interesting tour. excellent views and a good way to spend an hour or two
Very picturesque bridge. The most iconic bridge is the Tower bridge which is the perfect place for taking pictures along the river.
great shots !!!. if you are a keen photographer, let yourself go and enjoy the beauty and surrounding of the bridge

You must go and see the engine rooms - one of Lord Armstrong's masterpieces of hydraul;ic engineering. the onl;y disappointment was the shop, selling little more than tat - a few quality videos (like the ones shown on the tour), books and perhaps even a book of the photographic exhibition that was running in the walkway would I am sure do well.

Meh. We went over to Tower Bridge right after we had seen the Tower of London, and it was ok. The times on the board said that last admission was at 5pm; we showed up at 4:30 and were rushed through everything. Honestly, right from the point when we paid there was someone constantly behind us saying "move along hurry up" and it was getting on my nerves. We came up on the side that faces downtown, the less scenic side, and when I had walked through there I wanted to see the other side. So when I made it to the other Tower (where you could cross over to the other side) there was this woman standing there telling me to watch some film. I said I wanted to see the other side first and she said "no watch this video, you're running out of time. I just walked past her and went to the other side. I got to take my pictures but had no chance to read any of the info on the side because there was a guy who kept telling you to move along. I don't understand why we were rushed through when the last admission is still half an hour away. I wasn't impressed with the people. The tour is alright but if you don't make it there, don't be too upset, the view is just as nice from the bridge itself. Also, you can get a 2 for 1 deal for this location so keep an eye out for the 2 for 1 pamphlets! I wouldn't do this again if I go back to London.

This is just down the road..what a monument.. This is a real bridge.If you have to cross the Thames then this is the place to do it..even if it means a small trip out of your way..The feeling of just walking across this bridge sends shivers down your back. It also gives you an amazing view up and down the river.

A great landmark that could be improved as an attraction. This was one great landmark that I'd missed, the famous bridge that sometimes gets confused with London Bridge but is as iconic as St Pauls when we think of London. My original thought was simply to see the bridge but once there it's not so easy to appreciate because its busy, it's too close to get much in a photo without a very wide angle lens and it quickly becomes obvios that to get a full sense the structure will involve entering those famous towers and crossing the high walkways above - this means paying for the Tower Bridge Exhibition, entered through the ticket office at the North Tower. Entry was straightforward but annoyingly everyone going in, at the time of writing, was ushered in front of a coloured backdrop and photographed. No explanation was being given but it turned out to be a sales opportunity and you are offered the chance to have your photo superimposed against the tower by the time you come to walk past a stall set up in the South tower. This was starting at around £15 and may be something you would like. To me it looked like basic Photoshop and a little tacky, certainly I didn't appreciate not being asked at the outset but simply being photographed. I think they need to think this one through and there is no reason why the camera couldn't be set up near the stall when you could see what it's for.As for the visit, passing through the ticket area you enter a lift where a very brief outline to the visit is given. On exiting, high up in the North tower, a second guide gives less guidance but was briefly available for questions. From here you are pretty much on your own, there was no guided tour. I quite like that and the fact that there is no restriction on photography because I don't like to be tied to an organised group, but for the money you might expect a little more. From the lift you walk across the high East walkway to the South tower. This gives good views and although the walkways are completely enclosed by some form of plexiglass there are thoughtfully placed little windows positioned every so far along each walkway to allow for phtotography. Once at the South tower you turn right and walk over the West walkway for the views down the Thames including HMS Belfast and beyond. This is a dead end and you have to walk back to the South tower to head down the stairs although I found little to indicate that I was heading in the right direction for the engine room ehibition and there was no-one to ask so I carried on down the winding staircase to find I was outside the gents toilet at another dead end. The exit is back up and past the stall offering photos. Once out and another member of staff appeared who took me and a couple of other visitors down. At the base of the South tower you follow the blue stripe marked on the ground back over the bridge and down below the North tower to enter the engine rooms.Here again you are on your own to walk past the two boilers, the coal bunker and finally around the two original steam engines. These are nicely kept but not so impressive for anyone who has visited a half decent steam museum. Beyond is a small exhibition area including a model of the bridge that can be operated and a few hand on items that the children might like to play with. There are also what I assume to have been two huge couterweights visible leading up into the tower. There was no-one to ask and I didn't want to look for a printed description so there may have been one that I didn't see. These were impressive though just in terms of size. Overall I thought the towers could be made more of. The emphasis is on the engines, but the structure of the towers themselves, visible in parts, seems to be largely neglected. It's as though the working of the bridge and not its architecture is seen as the only point of real interest. It's half the price of St.Pauls if you want to go in but for that I wasn't that impressed with the arrangements. To cross those walkways and experience Tower Bridge you have to go through the exhibition, but I wouldn't say it was great value. Do it to say you've been in and crossed the higher walkways on the bridge and not for the 'exhibition'.

Landmark. Visited the Tower Bridge experience and it was really cheap and included an interactive experience. This is another London landamrk that you should capture to remember your trip by. Although the attraction is quite cheap and gives some great views along river if your time is limited in London there are plenty of better attractions but if you have the time then visit as it is good and informitave, would be good for families with children.

Beautiful bridge and interesting tour. Take some time to go visit Tower Bridge and take the tour. The architecture of the bridge is beautiful, and the history of it is very interesting. A. It is so difficult to describe London and its Monuments and Museums and History ! But visit guided to this Bridge is veru nice and the engine machines together with the view form up to the Bridge. I truly recommend.
One of the best views (and photos) of London. One of the "great day out for the kids - young and old -" catergory. Climb to the top and you have...LONDON!

Amazing History. Having seen tower bridge in tv and films all my lift i was excited to go there and it didnt disappoint. Nice but not necessary. The Tower Bridge Experience was included in my London Pass. I wouldn't recommend people to see that if it wasn't "on the way" out of the Tower of London. You see some short movies about the history of the bridge and its buiding, you walk over the bridge and see photos left and right but that's basically all. The real London Bridge. London Bridge is falling down, falling down, falling down...falling off my chart of expectations I must say. Indeed, both Tower Bridge and the real London Bridge (not worth seeing, believe me) are disappointing. Tower Bridge, visible from the Tower of London area, is a dull, grayish bridge. Interesting visit. I like engineering, and this one is a masterpiece, taking into account when it was constructed. Viewing it from the outside is OK, but with the visit to the exhibition you get to see the walkways on the top, the views from them, some illustrations about bridges and facts about this particular one, and then the engine room, with explanations of the (very ingenous) original workings of the bascules (only at the end there is a little explanation on the current system).

Good views and better than I expected.. I visited the Tower Bridge Experience with my wife and two children aged 4 and 9 during the half term holidays.We arrived shortly after it opened at 10am and it was quiet with no queues. We had 2 for 1 vouchers and found the entry fee very reasonable.There were some Victoria games to amuse the children. The videos were informative and short enough not to bore children.Great views from the top walkways.The engine house has some interesting interactive exhibits which realy helped the children understand how the bridge worked.The children had a sticker chart to fill which kept them amused and was a good souviner.My expectations were exceeded and we passed an enjoyable couple of hours here. Very interesting for young children..
