Pretty but disappointing. Lovely painted bridge, looks very pretty but not really much else to look at.

So Beautiful. This was a very neat trip I took when I had a layover in London,,, Instead of sitting in my hotel room and doing nothing, I got onto a Night Tour for the evening which was SO COOL.. on the tour we got to go everywhere, one stop was the tower bridge! Very Very Neat!!! I wish I could have gotten down from the bus and walked aroud a bit.. enjoy the little pictures from the night tour.

cannot miss it. It is wonderful. I liked this attraction the most in London. However it is not a new bridge, it still works, opens and closes quite quickly. You can go up to the top and enjoy the view besides the history of the bridge.
Amazing views. The views are definately the best thing about tower bridge. The exhibition itself was, we felt, quite weak. Both in its layout and content.

Great to see from all angles. The Tower Bridge is immediately recognisable and a very impressive structure. London provides visitors the opportunity to view the bridge from all angles - the view from Lower Thames Street on the north side of the river is particularly good, whilst a ride on a river ferry gave me the opportunity to photograph the bridge as we sailed underneath it.  A unique and iconic bridge - worth a visit.

Must See!. Tower Bridge is a Must See attraction in London. The first time you see it, you'll be absolutely awestruck! Its such an amazing sight that first time it comes into your view. If you're there at the right time you may even get to see it open up for a ship to pass through.I also recommend doing the exhibition so you can walk up and over the bridge and learn about the building of it.A must see, and recommended to all!

Really Boring Museum, but Nice Walk. The Tower Bridge Experience is a great way to walk across the bridge with some great views of London. This is the only way to go inside the bridge and up on the catwalks. That said, the "museum" or exhibits they have are really bad. They could have done so much more with this.The videos are about as boring as you get. Honestly they should be embarassed to show these.The exhibits on either side are very similar....actually they may have been identical. The exhibit on the engine room was okay.Its only 7 GBP, which compared to other attractions isnt that bad. That said, they could have done a much better job of this.

Great Site & Views, Easy Walk. Tower Bridge has some of the best views of the London skyline you'll find. It also has great views of the Tower of London, so if you want good photos of either Tower Bridge is a good place to try.The bridge itself is easy to get to by walking....it is near both the HMS Belfast and the Tower of London, so if you are visiting either (or both) have this on your list.Easy walk across with large pedestrian paths. There is a museum, which I will review separately (I recommend doing the museum tour....).Overall, a must see in London!

Breathtaking. Tower Bridge is just breathtakingly beautiful! It's nice to see during the day because you can take the tour, but the real magic is in seeing it when it's all lit up on a clear London night. You can take a romantic stroll across it and then stop in for a drink/meal at one of the restaurants on the pier. A must see attraction on your London vacation!

One of the best I'd ever seen. One tip, take your own food and booze. You can take it what you like and leave when you want, but if it's an easy, low key, spontaneous and cultural kinda night then go along and see what's going on. Worth a glance even if you're not expecting much. And you may just end up staying all night.

A must see!. The tower bridge is one of the oldest and most beautiful bridges in England. It is a draw bridge with 2 massive high towers. For a small fee, you can take an elevator ride to the walkway between the towers for a fantastic view of the city of London and the river Thames. The bridge sits besides the Tower of London which is a historic castle and now holds the crown jewels. I would recommend seeing this bridge for some fantastic pictures and learning about it's history. It would entertain children and be a romantic setting for couples. It is a must see if you ever visit London.

Secret: take Tower Bridge pictures from Potters Fields Park!. From Victoria Station, take bus C10, then bus 343. The end of the line is at little-known Potters Fields Park! You have to trust on me on this one. The park has free admission and provides a spectacular view of Tower Bridge, plus the Tower of London is directly across the River Thames. Just walk around to find street performers, food services and toilets. You may keep walking towards the London Eye if you like. Simply marvelous!

Great Views Of London At Half The Price. We choose to go up Tower Bridge because the price is much more reasonable than the London Eye. Although one of the platforms is down for maintenance, and they have change the price accordingly you get a panoramic view of the city and can take your time, if you get in before closing. Also there are 2 for 1 admission coupons if you have a paper travelcard and print the coupons of the travelcard website. Also you do get some history of the bridge and the city itself in small video presentations.

A great attraction to see in central london. A great attraction to see in central london zone 1, quite close to tower bridge station. Surrounded by skyscrapers, and Thames flowing below it. Heard that the bridge opens sometimes but couldnt manage to see the same.....................

Fascinating - a hidden treasure. An excellent exhibition.I can't think of anywhere I've been where I've been able to get inside and see how it all works to this extent. Even if you're a Londoner I'll bet you don't know 80% of what you'd learn about the bridge in an hour's visit.You go in at the foot of one tower, up in a lift and walk across one of the covered walkways to the second tower; back down in a lift, then a walk along the bridge and down into the engine rooms. Truly a masterpiece of engineering.Some short and really informative films on the way round.Currently it's only £6 per adult (under 5s free) which makes it one of the cheapest attractions in London. Probably an hour would be fine, and you should find time to fit this in.Hints: 1) Do a search online to check scheduled bridge opening times and you might see it in operation. 2) When you come out the engine rooms, if you head towards city hall there are some nice cafes and restaurants (and public toilets), or you can go the other way where there are some excellent sandwich shops.A minor negative re access - The lift in tower 1 takes you to the top, the lift in tower 2 is accessed by going down 4-5 flights of stairs. More stairs down to the engine room entrance, and I couldnt see any disabled/pushchair ramps. But I guess you can go up and down in the Tower 1 lift... check before you buy your tickets.

A nice view over London and the Thames. If you are in London and you have just a few hours, the first and best place to go is the most famous Bridge in the world. In a few minutes walk from it there is so much to see that a visit to it is worth a journey to London. The tower of London is right there, the docklands too, the City is just around the corner and the same it is for the nice Council building.To get there you can use the bus. the tube or the train and if you don't mind walking the Sheakspera Globe is really close. Enjoy a visit to the Bridge museum too and a nice ice cream in the park near the council.

It's Cheap and It's Something to Do in Under a Half Hour. It's cheap and it's something to do in under a half hour. If you're lucky, you can even catch the bridge going up. The walkways are entirely closed and covered in photos. There are little windows to slide open and stick a camera out, but I was very disappointed to find the area completely enclosed. The ticket price was cheap, there was NO line and we got some really good pictures. We did this instead of waiting forever at London Eye. Plus, it was something short to do at the end of a very busy morning at the Tower of London.
Very Informative. I really enjoyed the visit. Learned a lot about the construction and operation of the Bridge. It was well worth it.

a must see site. We went through the tower bridge exhibit with our 9 year old grandson and had a wonderful time it was very informative well laid out site. I got a 2 for 1 coupon from the national railway site to use that help with the cost. If you bought your daily transit pass from the railroad then you could use it at some sites for half off deals.

Something you just need to do. Went with 2 OAPs, and family with 2 kids (girl 11, boy 8).We visited this right at the end of a day, so only had about 45 minutes to see everything. That said, we didn't miss much of it so I wouldn't expect to be there for much more than an hour unless you have an unhealthy fascination with bridges. The exhibition is essentially in two parts - the walkways at the top of Tower Bridge, and then the engine rooms at the base. The bit you have to do is the walkway - if you've ever walked under the bridge, getting a chance to walk on the top bits is probably the main reason you'll go here - but actually it is the engine room that is more spectacular. The walkways are okay - with a light but interesting exhbition on bridges at the moment (one of the walkways is closed for refurb at the moment, with cheaper tickets as a result). The views are okay, but pictures are difficult due to the large amounts of metalwork in the way. We whizzed through these to be honest, and thought we might not get our money's worth. But when we went to the engine room we were pleasantly surprised - the engines are great and then there are lots of fun things to play with, including models of the bridge. The kids (and the adults...) really enjoyed this bit.The gift shop is overpriced and underwhelming.The staff were all friendly and helpful.If you are going, get the 2 for 1 tickets from National Rail. We didn't know whether to rate this "average" or "very good" because we thought it was "good" for the money we paid with the discount. If you pay full price, I doubt you'll feel it was value for money.
Its a really cool bridge!!. It was so great. I got a 3D model of the Tower bridge. Which looks almost as good.

It's ok...Something to do. The tower bridge was an ok attraction, has some interesting information along the walkways. excellent view's of the area from the towers.Would I do it again... No... did I enjoy it, yes. It was part of the London Pass we bought so nothing lost or gained. I would not have done it if it was not part of the pass

Places that I saw only in Calendars during Childhood. London bridge, Tower Bridge, the parliament house are some places which I saw only in my childhood on calendars. I used to wonder how clean and sophisticated this place would be. As I grew up, and opportunities walked my way, I was able to to see these places in person with my wife.This is an amazing place, one can keep going on and on with the photography and still you will strive to get the best photograph. Pan cakes are little expensive, but they are worthy to be told about once you have them.I wish you all the best for this spendid experience of life time. Take care.

The most beautiful bridge in London town!!!. I loved the Tower bridge. so much that I went there twice! It's just so cute, and cartoonish... really should be the visit card of the city, because it's wonderful.The awesome part is that you can actually cross it, and it's close to the Design Museum and the Tower of London|

Dissapointed.. We were really looking forward to visiting the tower of London as we'd been once before many years ago and had realy enjoyed it. This time we took our sister who had never been and our childreen aged 11 and 14. We all thought it was quite boring and not at all that we had remembered they previously had a "show" about the making of the bridge but have since closed that attraction. Now you have are information boards to read and an animated video on how the bridge was constructed. Both my husband and 11 year old son love history and information but felt the presentation in this attaction was basic and unfulfilling. The "amazing " view that they claim to have from the top was also dissapointing.We won't be back and we don't reccomend it.
very interesting!. we went to visit the tower bridge for the first time.It is very well explained and the exihibition is worth going

Has to be seen. Try to go on a clear day and walk the Bridge. Make sure to walk the east side, which is less crowded. There is an exhibit/musuem on the west side of the bridge. Photo opportunities abound!

Interesting,lnexpensive exhibition. My husband and I really enjoyed seeing the Tower Bridge and learning it's background and how it was built. The most interesting thing was the engine room that operates the drawbridge. The bridge is located near the Tower of London so it is easy to get to. Cost is about $ 13 US Dollars a person. One of the highlights was while we were walking across the bridge after the tour the drawbridge had to go up to let a boat through! This is a random event so you never know when it will happen. The timing was perfect!

Beautiful View of Thames River. I really loved to visit Tower Bridge and learn a little bit about this beautiful and imponent architecture, I wasn´t tired to look at this bridge all the time and walk around through its interior, or walk around and cross the bridge more than once. Plus, if you got any boat at Thames Clippers which pass under the bridge, you have the opportunity to take pictures from a different angle. I think it worth a while to visit ;)

good views. I visited here back in September and enjoyed myself, however the exhbits it is slightly shabby and could do with a refurb. They have put it a lot of information in a small space.The engine rooms were very interest too

looking through glasses. First of all, you have a beautiful view looking down to amazing London from the Tower bridge. Although I have been disappointed. You only can look through small windows, always with reflections. It is worth to walk up the stairs and marvel at the interesting construction. They also show you a little movie about the construction, pretty interesting.it cost you 8 Pounds.

Very intersting tour and those afraid of heights need not worry!. My two sons and I finally plucked up the courage to visit the Tower Bridge Exhibition today and are now really glad we did. The entrance is a short walk from Tower Hill tube station (and the Tower of London). It wasn't that expensive for the 3 of us - £12.50 in total. You don't have a chance to worry about the height of the walkways because the exit from the admissions desk is straight into a lift which very gently takes you straight up to the top (you don't even feel it moving). You come out still inside the tower, and after watching a short film, you then walk onto the first walkway. Now we had fears of being able to see all the way down, it being open to the elements etc, but it is not - there is a carpeted floor, fully glazed windows, and you can't even see straight down outside the windows (ie you can't see the bridge below you, and in fact we missed it opening while we were "upstairs"!). The views are wonderful! First you go down one side and look out towards Docklands, Canary Wharf, o2 Arena etc. Then you go into the building at the other end and come back along the second walkway and look out towards HMS Belfast, St Pauls, etc. Having retraced your steps back to the 2nd tower you then walk down some steps, past another film, to another lift which returns you to street level. You then walk off the bridge to go and view the old steam engine rooms and mechanism that used to lift the bridge. The tour ends in the obligatory shop.All in all a very enjoyable and memorable trip which we would recommend for some great views and very interesting history.

Amazing structure and incredible views from the top!. I went to the Tower Bridge with my dad after we visited the Tower of London. We used the London pass to go up the escalator to the top of the bridge. There is a windowed walkway connected the east side from the west, and the views are amazing. Other than that, there isn't much to do. There are engine rooms in the basement, but we were low on time and didn't have time to see those, but the visit to the top was extraordinary. Visit if youre going to the Tower of London, but don't make a special trip to the bridge. It is a London icon that shouldn't be missed but going up isn't necessary, just a cool experience if you have extra time.

Interesting history, beautiful views. Beside the magnificent towers and the bridge itself, inside the bridge you can find an interesting exhibition about the history of the bridge, how it was built, design propositions for the bridge, lots of facts and photos. Also, the exhibition goes through both of the hallways from which the most of the London is visible. The exhibition ends with the visit to the engine room and the whole tour costs 8 Pounds.

One of the most recognizable buildings in the world. The Tower Bridge is definitely one of the most important, unique and most recognizable buildings in London (or in the world). I definitely think it is worth to spend some time and visit that landmark. I've seen it few times already, but never had a chance to see it from the top deck and balcony. I'm sure views are stunning. Bridge itself is still in use; you can walk or drive through. Great views are from the banks of the river or cruise boats.

Great Views; Tag this onto another visit. The Tower Bridge is iconic and there are great views of the city. By itself, though, it is not something I would make a special trip for. It is right next to The Tower of London, so tack this onto that visit if possible.The history is interesting, and the views of London and the Thames are great. The Mechanical Rooms are worth visiting if you have time. The biggest downside - getting in and getting out. I visited this ten years ago, and we just walked up the stairs. Now you have to take an elevator (the stairs are blocked off), and the elevator does not have enough capacity for the busy days. We waited for three elevators to go up, and for four elevators to go down.
Iconic bridge. The tour is informative. Elevator takes you up to walkway. Great views! Try to time your visit with raising of bridge. Great photo op.

interesting. The Tower Bridge became one of the symbol of the City of London and you sure have to see it. But actually visit it is not that impressive. it is around 8 pounds sterling to get inside which is affordable. you will have a nice view and a bit of history about the bridge. one hour is enough to finish the visit. after climbing the Harbour Bridge in Sydney ... no wonder why I found this one a bit "boring". I was though surprised to be very excited when the bridge open to let a boat under pass it. It happens only 3 times a day and you are quiet lucky if you are around when it does take place ! unic experience

nice views of the Thames. Went to visit the Tower Bridge today and enjoyed the visit. The views of the Thames are outstanding with the HMS Belfast and Tower of London below. St. Paul's is not far away and can also be seen. The walkway displays information on many of the world's most famous bridges and also includes a visit to the old steam power house that was mused until the 1970s to lift the bridge. If you are visiting the Tower of London or HMS Belfast, you should include the Tower Bridge in your plans.

Disappointing. The biggest disappointment with the experience was the walkway across the top of the bridge which for me would be the highlight for me was covered. I expected it to be open to the elements with striking views down and either side of the thames. However it's covered with glass and carpeted and this takes away the actual feel of being up high. The engine rooms were of a little interest probably more for your Fred Dibnah types. Overall . Okay.

An icon of London. If you are in the vicinity of Tower Bridge, then you have to stop and take time to view this fantastic symbol of London. This can be done from the banks of the Thames, from a boat, from one of the many attractions nearby, or actually spending time on/in the Bridge. You may say 'it's just a bridge' but it isn't. There is so much history behind it and it really is a truly impressive piece of architecture.I found their website really helpful and its give some great information on the history of the bridge and it's worthwhile reading this before you view it. You can also purchase admission tickets from here.Definitely take time out to view the bridge at the very least if you are in London
This is one bridge you don't need to cross.. This was disappointing. Nothing spectacular at all. The only good thing was that you had a view of the London Tower. Don't put this on your bucket list.

This one is really the most interesting bridge in London..till' now.. I didn't go inside and I'm really happy because staying out I met some wonderful people (like anywhere in London) I had the opportunity to talk to them and exchange some opinions on London.The Tower Bridge is a famous landmark so many people will go there, take picture and go further.What I did was to attend a street performance, near the city hall and play with some little children near the Riverside Estate.:)The Tower Bridge is close to London Tower but not so close to the "London Bridge" tube station so if you experience walking difficulties you might want to take the RV1 bus which will leave you just on the bridge.Good luck!

Perfect stop after Tower Bridge. Right next to Tower of London, Tower Bridge is an amazing sight. Views from the top are second only to The Eye, and put you on the other side of the Thames at The Queens Walk.

Cool. Beyond the amazing beauty of this bridge, doing the Experience is really neat. There is an exhibit about the building of the bridge on one side and famous bridges on the other. Taking a stroll through workings of the bridge down below is cool for anyone that is all interested in how things work. And of course the views at the top are unbelievable. We skipped the London Eye so we were glad to see the city from this perspective.
Great Attraction. Tower bridge was lovely and was close to lots of other attractions.

Sterile, unimaginitive, and just not very engaging...... We used supermarket reward vouchers to try during a weekend in London recently - and were really disappointed with this one (but glad we hadn't handed over sterling!). Granted, it was a cold February day, but the whole experience was quite sterile - especially according to our ten-year-old, who when asked for his opinion denounced it as "tacky". Quite. Firstly a wait for a group lift, rather pointlessly accompanied on the way up by a cheesy guide (we would have been happy to climb stairs, if there had been the choice...), and then two videos, plus a walk across and back at the top on carpet (randomly scattered with a rather sad 'exhibition' of reproduction children's toys) and with the construction itself behind perspex or glass, mostly obscured by a photographic exhibition of the world's bridges, so that the view itself was only partial. it was as if we were walking down the corridor of an underfunded school artroom just before closing time, rather than thrilling at the sights, sounds and the bracing elements - a nod to Health and Safety, no doubt.We were all expected to follow a series of numbers like sheep, one of which took you back along the other wing of the bridge only to turn round again at a dead end - we asked if we could skip this bit but were told we had to do it. The young multinational staff seemed as bewildered and disengaged with the whole thing as we were. The engine room was more aesthetically interesting but no better displayed, again roped off so that us sheep had to follow the route as if we were in Ikea (which is free) - it's also an outside walk along a blue-painted line across the road bridge, and then once finished we were left with no choice but to cross an extremely busy road at a point where the pavement finished due to roadworks, to double back and, yes you guessed it, cross to the other side again. Overall the exhibition content, the formulaic presentation, the lack of excitement and the numbing of the sense at the top made this the one dull experience of an otherwise fantastic weekend. Sorry Tower Bridge, but this really was badly organised and a bit lame.

Great Value Activity!. We decided to do this as its such a well know landmark and we were not disappointed.It only cost £7.00 per adult to get inm which we thought was very cheap for london. All the staff were very friendly and very informed. The views from the Top were brilliant, and theres lots of information to tell you all about the history of this bridge from design through to the modern day. Lots to read and pictures to see. The engine rooms were interesting too.A great activity to fill an hour or two for people that like this sort of thing!
Great Bridge. We used our 2FOR1 coupon and rail tickets to recieve half-priced admission. I've always wanted to see this bridge and we had a great visit. Be sure to visit the engine room afterwards.

Great for the boys!. We took my nearly five year old son to Tower Bridge as part of a trip to London for his Christmas present. We used Tesco vouchers to pay for us (under 5s are free) so it didn't really cost us anything. We went on 30th December and it was a foggy day but not too cold. We didn't have to queue to get in, so within a couple of minutes we were at the top of the tower. We were given a 'passport' for our son and you could collect stickers around the bridge to stick on this to make your own bridge picture, which he really enjoyed doing later that day.Although it was a bit foggy to see everything clearly, we still really enjoyed it. All the information is heavily picture based and at a low level so our son was able to learn quite a lot about the history of the bridge with a little help from us.The engine rooms were not quite as interesting to begin with, although there are some good interactive activities for everyone to do that explain how the bridge works, and they were easy enough for our son to do. He also enjoyed seeing the part about stunts on the bridge.A great attraction for a family who is interested in that sort of thing.....our son is and his father is a design teacher/was architect so it was really good for them.

Suprisingly nice and near many attractions. The Tower Bridge connects what I like to call the old and the new part of London. I had never been to London, and I thought that the London Bridge was more like this one. Many photo opportunities and beautiful columns. There was a guy playing bagpipes, it was a nice ambiance.

Famous attraction. Tower Brigde is one of the beautiful bridges in the world. And must-see attraction in London. Tickets can be bought online and costs 7 punds for adult ticket. Inside the bridge you can see an engine rooms and nice views of Themes river and London Eye. Good news that photo is permitted inside. My general expirience is very good after visit and I definitely recommend this site for visit.

Nothing great to see about; except good view of Thames. I have been there few times; but it is like something to see in London which is not so great thing. People just come and take pictures and the view of Thames river is quite good. One can enjoy things around like the river cruise, etc.

Not so popular, but worth it.. The bridge innards are not too extensive, so visiting it doesn't take too much time, but it's quite interesting. You start with the history and construction details of the Tower Bridge, then you take a ride upstairs and walk along the upper walkway, enjoying the panoramic views of the river with HMS Belfast moored nearby, the Tower of London and the City. It's fun to see various concept sketches and different designs of the bridge, and also to see the cars driving beneath you.You can have your photo made at the entrance and then photoshopped into the Bridge's photo and printed on a fridge magnet or stuff like that, but it's so expensive that we let this unique opportunity pass.When leaving this place, don't forget walking down to the basement to see the engines that used to lift and lower it before the modernization.

Worth while for the view alone. We had visited the Tower Bridge Experience a few years ago, and found it fascinating. However, that was in high season and a guided tour was available. Visiting this year in September, there were no guides and much of what we saw a few years back was unavailable. If you've never been, then it's worth a visit if only for the stunning views from the top, but much was lost with the absence of a guide. Those staff who were available seemed indifferent toward answering questions.

A Must See!. One of the most beautiful bridges! The Tower Bridge Exhibition was a good tour. It's a little cheesy but you get to go inside, see the engine rooms and go through the walkway on the top of the bridge. The walkway has a very good view of the London skyline. The Tower of London is right “next door”.

A British Icon - across from the Tower of London. After we visited the Tower of London, we walked over to see the bridge. It is a must see in London, you get great views of London along the Thames there.

Beutiful. The tower bridge is verry beautiful. you can see the thames river from there and the tower of london, the famous london eye and much more.there are, even, often exibitions at the top flor, so you can visit the bridge and see how it worked in the past, all the mecanisms are still there and enjoy the view.

Great attraction, perfectly priced. Went here on a day trip to London with our 8yr old son. Having done a bridge topic at school he was really interested and excited to be going. I used Tesco vouchers, but even oif we'd paid cash I wouldn't have been disappointed. At £14 for 3 of us I felt it was excellently priced and didn't disappoint. (Why can't more attractions take note adn charge appropriately, they'd get more people through the door then). There are a couple of short films to watch, one at either end, both are short, so you're not bored watching them. You can walk along both sides of the bridge offering fantastic views along the Thames and each side has an exhibition, about bridges in general, the Thames and specifically, of course, about Tower Bridge. My son found this very interesting and loved finding out about all the landmarks that we could see. Afterwards you walk along Tower Bridge to the engine rooms. There is information and hands on exhibits along here and you are not restricted at all from taking pictures. However we were expecting it to be working, but it isn't, it's just now a display, but interesting all the same.It is not guided which is great as it means you can take as long as you like and we spent much longer than I expected - over 2 hours. Overall very happy and would definitely recommend to others as a must-see experience.

Have to be there when sightseeing London. The Tower Bridge is one of the most well known landmarks in London. In addition to admiring it from the outside, you can also take a trip inside, learn the history of the place and have a walk on top of it. I would recommend taking a camera as the upper walkway is a really good place to take panoramic pictures over the river. There is also an exhibition showing other famous bridges across the world. The waiting time is not too long and you can use a London Pass card to get tickets without any further charges.

A dull attraction for the price you pay. Cross the bridge walkway for free instead. The Tower Bridge Experience in my opinion was a bit of a letdown. As students, we bought a join ticket for the Tower Bridge and the Monument for 5.50 pounds and were done with the exibition in about 45 mins with no rush. First, you view a short video on the constuction of the bridge, which was pretty interesting, then an elevator takes you up to one of two upper walkways. The views are great, but nothing special, many places in London offer the same for less. The exibitions were boring and did not have much information on the bridge, as it relied on other facts such as the Plague, Great Fire of London and other bridges of the world...You then desend via stairs and follow the blue line outside the bridge to the Engine Rooms and the shop. If you are pushed for time, dont bother with the exibition, just admire and take your photos of the bridge on the foothpath like all other pedestrians and from afar.

A must see and must cross. Tower Bridge undoubtedly is one of the sights you have to see when in London. Crossing it from the Tower Hill tube station side will lead you to Southwark. Turn to the right to see the Greater London Assembly, the brain-like town hall designed by Norman Foster's office, or - more interestingly - to the left and explore Butler's Wharf, an area redeveloped in the 1990s that also houses the Design Museum at Shad Thames.

Great view from the Bridge. For 7 pounds you’ll cross the bridge facing each side of the river, learn why and how the bridge was constructed and saw the engines room. It’s a great sightsee for the view and what it represents.

Great view. We took our kids here on a day trip to London as our youngest has always been obsessed with Tower Bridge ever since she was a toddler. We had been promising her for ages that we would take her inside the bridge, and so it was with extreme excitement that she came with us to the Tower Bridge Museum. It’s probably fair to say that she was more interested than us because of her complete obsession with this place, but that is not to say that we didn’t enjoy it too. The views from the walkway along the top were absolutely super....and cheaper than some of the more known high rise view points in London. My favourite bit, however, was after we came out and saw the bridge lift. It was my turn to be a kid then...I’ve been to London countless times but never saw TowerBridge open. It was amazing to see. The exhibits could be a little more interactive perhaps, but this is an inexpensive (for London anyway) must-do that didn’t disappoint. How could you pass the most famous bridge in the world and not have a look inside?

Tower Bridge from the middle ages. There's a great little garden behind potter's field which gives a lovely view of Tower Bridge that makes you imagine what things could have looked like hundreds of years ago.

Amazing views. I visited the tower bridge in May 2010. I walked up steps to the pedestrian walkway (there are toilets on the way up). There was a short movie at the top of the steps about the building of the bridge. Then I walked across the bridge and took in the beautiful views. There were also story boards set up along the walkway that told about the building and other interesting facts about the bridge. The opposite side is where you exit, but I wanted to see the other side of the view so I walked the length of the bridge 1.5 times to see both sides of the view. Then I took the elevator down on the opposite side and went to see the room with the mechanical equipment that runs the bridge in it. I'm not interested in the mechanical parts, but it looked like others were really enjoying learning how the bridge is powered. Overall this is a really worthwhile attraction, great views and an interesting story to learn.

Recommended. The views were great, and no two+hours wait like for the Eye! The teenagers thought it was facinating. Yes, a lot of stairs to climb but well worth it and heck keeps you in shape. Be sure and stay for the movie and chat with the guys at the end of the tour, they are interested in answering questions. It is on teh 2-4-1 Days out Guide so take advantae and same some!

Inexpensive and oh so cool!. I've seen the Tower Bridge before, but never realized you can go in and experience the upper walkways. It wasn't too expensive and my husband, teen daughter and I all enjoyed this attraction. There are great views from the enclosed walkways and the historical data in the short films and posted along the walkway are interesting. Don't forget to go to the engine room underneath the bridge after you exit the walkways. The machinery is impressive.

Interesting if you are an architect. We visited the Tower Bridge on a whim as we were walking across the Bridge and thought it would be fun to climb to the top. Climb you must--if there are lifts they are not apparent. The views are nice, but honestly the views from the Monument and the Eye or even St. Paul's gallery are just as good. The exhibit was comprehensive and interesting, but I would imagine that if you aren't keenly interested in engineering and architecture all the technicalities would be pretty dry.I like the idea of being able to say I've been to the top of the Tower Bridge, but I wouldn't visit again.

Save your money. The bridge itself is of course quite impressive and it's free to admire.The Tower Bridge Exhibition, on the other hand, is not free. If it were free, it would be worth visiting. However, for 7 pounds (if I correctly recall the price) you don't get much. LOTS of stairs to climb. Lots of useful information about the bridge, however it's nothing you can't read on Wikipedia or elsewhere. Not much of a view. And that's about it. I think we spent more time passing the security checks and negotiating the stairs than on the walkway itself.

Nice way to see the sites. We took the public bus from Covent Garden to Tower Bridge - great low cost way to see some of the sites around the embankment (£3 all day ticket).Entrance to the Tower Bridge Experience was only £7 (no queues!) and included short films on the history / construction of the bridge, a walk down both "arms" (couple of hundred feet above Thames) and then a winding walk back down stairs. Nothing too exciting, but the view from the top gives you a great sense of your surroundings and lets you pin point all the must see attractions.

Interesting. If you have pounds and time to kill in London, check out the Tower Bridge Exhibition, including the inside of the bridge as well as the engine room. It's not a must-see, as you can enjoy the sight of the bridge itself from thousands of points around the city, but it's worth some time if you have it to spare.

Perhaps the most beautiful London landmark. Something about Tower Bridge just captures my heart every time I see it. You an get wonderful pictures any time of day, but it's especially beautiful from the Tower of London at sunset. Walk across the bridge at night and take in the beauty that is London!

Nice exibition!. Well, there are some buildings that are concidered a city's landmark, their presence is well-known to residents and visitors alike, but sometimes even if they are a familiar figure to people, lots of these people don't have a clue about their history and the facts about them.I guess Tower Bridge may be one of those landmarks! That's why Tower Bridge exibition worths a visit. To learn a bit more about this magnificent structure. There are some very informative videos about how the decision was taken for the Bridge to be built, and how much effort was put on its construction. The views are magnificent too, and worth to take some time just to look around you on both Thames' directions! The engine rooms are included in the entrance fee, so you can have a look there too. Although I am not very much into mechanic staff, I found them to be quite fascinating! It's intresting to see how such a huge structure was made and then could be opened for ships to pass under, on eras that technology was not so developped, and lots of human effort should be put in the task,Take some time to admire the outside too. Nice architecture, and bridge colours with its light blue and some red and white are beautiful (although the original colour was brown).

An attraction everyone can appreciate. There is something for everyone on the Tower Bridge. The pros: It is easily accessible with no long wait in line. It is also inexpensive. The walkways between the Towers afford excellent views of the surrounding city and river. There are also numerous interactive displays and such about how the bridge works, in addition to displays on the history behind its construction, maintenance, and ceremonial use. You can learn about one of London's most iconic attractions while crossing it!The cons: Months later I still can't think of any. Well worth a visit for solo-travellers, couples, or families of all ages.

The World Famous - Tower Bridge. What an experience it was!!!! It's like a fulfillment of lifetime dream!!Tower Bridge situated on the Thames River in the Central London, UK is one of the rare but still very excellent and fantastic monuments in the Current World. A person visiting Europe or London must visit the Tower Bridge. It is situated in the central London which is easily Accessible through all public transportations ( e.g. Tubes, London buses & Cruses) as well as private vehicles. It becomes a special moment when the bridge is lifted from center when the boats/ships with large booms (height) passes under the bridge. The road traffic on bridge stops for the time being!!!!!!!!!!The bridge still looks superb and stronger for performing daily functions even after no. of years of operation. Thanks to London Mayor...Good Maintenance!!!!!There is an Exhibition gallery at the top of bridge, which is remained open from 10. 00 AM to 5.00 PM in normal summer seasons. The exhibition contains the details of tower bridge history and construction. Worth to watch at nominal prices...Also the elevation gives nice & cool views of Thames and surrounding London.At end, it is a great place to capture cool photos!!!!!! A real nice and life time good experience!!!!!!

An interesting hour or two. Whilst not particularly interested in the mechanical bits of this tour, I did feel it worth the money toget an insiders look into this iconic building. The overhead walkways were really cool, as were the models and drawings of early concepts of the bridge. I think this was well worth the admission fee which isn't much by London standards. Shame about the tacky gift shop, though.

Best monument in London. The Tower Bridge is a beautiful monument that's fun to walk accross. Go down alongside the Thames for some memorable pictures. I would highly recomend timing your visit when they show the bridge going up and down. You can find the lift schedule on the internet. The exhibition cost L6.00 per adult. It's cool to say you've walked accross the bridge above, but I wasn't impressed with the views too much. The bridge is actually kind of far from all the main attractions so there isn't much to recognize. You don't get big, open windows up there that take your breath away, there's always metal beams in the way as you peek out a little section. The exhibition is good for the history of the bridge though. There's a couple of short videos and models of rejected proposals which I found interesting since I knew nothing of the bridge. You'll also get to see the old engine room with all the big brass steam compressors. It's worth a quick look even if you're not into old marvel technologies. In summary, your day will be much more memorable if you time it right for a lift schedule.

Tremendous views. This hundred year old marvel draws everyone along the Thames to it like a magnet. Its majesty and beauty are unmistakable. A stroll across the 800 ft span is a treat, admiring both the iconic design as well as the beautiful views of both riverbanks. The Tower Bridge Exhibition is a worthwhile diversion housed in the twin towers of the structure. It details how and even why the bridge was built, and delves through its fascinating history and provides stunning panoramas of the city from the dual walkways 14 stories above the river. Be aware that the queues for this may be very long as the elevators are small and the exhibit area space limited.
worth a visit. Actually really enjoyed this. Great to see the "real" information and history. Walk along the top is a great way to really experience the bridge.

Love this bridge!. No queues, inexpensive (L6.00). It's really something up close. Great views (some windows in the walkways open for better picture taking). Feels much bigger inside than it appears from outside. Talk an elevator to top of one tower, walk across walkways, and down the other tower (there's a giftshop at the bottom). Short walk from Tower Hill underground station, past Tower of London (great views!).

Dream come true. A master piece, indeed. The Tower Bridge is worth crossing, not only for its amazing structure, but also for the view that offers. The River Thames and the Tower Bridge united for ages that will last forever.

Lovely hotel. I went to this hotel with mixed feeling because of reading peoples review on here and when i got there is was very nice hotel it was clean and the rooms where lovely .Very close to every thing me and my family really enjoyed it here and will be coming back again in the summer .The staff were helpful and friendly

Loved It!. Everything an attraction should be. No gimics, no queues, low cost, value for money, and very interesting plus offering some great photo opportunities. The bridge itself is impressive plus the views are fantastic, the heavy lifting gear is great, I thoroughly enjoyed explaining to my kids the heavy engineering principles that powered the raising of the bridge.

inside it isn´t so interesting but you can take beautiful pictures. the bridge is beautiful and we could see it opening to let a big boat pass, but inside, there isn´t too much. just a lot of steps, then you get to the top and the views are great, so it´s well worth for the good pictures that you can take upstairs.

great activity. I was pleasantly surprised by our experience at the Tower Bridge. It was easy to get to, it didnt set us back a ton of money, and my husband loved the engineering exhibit. There are great views of Londonfrom the catwalk. It is a good activity to do in the beginning of the day, its quick so there is time to do something else (e.g. the Tower of London) before lunch.

Pleasant Surprise. London was a brief stop-over on our way from New Zealand to Ireland so we were incredibly jet-lagged, sunburnt from few days in Thailand and fuming from BA losing half of our luggage but we had some time to walk around London and the Tower Bridge was definitely a sight worth seeing!We had no guidebook and didn't expect to see much of London while we were there but we looked at a map and thought we'd go to London Bridge...mainly because of that song of London Bridge falling down.... we had no idea where we were going so just ended up wandering around and found Tower Bridge by complete accident! Sounds silly I know.... Immediately we recognised the bridge from images of London and were thrilled to actually be there. The architecture and design is very impressive and for the first time in my life I was actually interested in the history and background of the structure. We walked across the bridge and considered doing the exhibition but with the sterling to the NZ dollar we decided not to and we're probably lucky we didn't having read some reviews about it. You get enough information in a guide book.We witnessed the bridge being drawn up for a ship to go through which was very impressive - especially with the speed and efficiency of the whole procedure. I would definitely recommend seeing the Tower Bridge - one of my favourite sights in London - and then to see the Tower of London as well.

A great view. The Tower Bridge exhibition, in itself is a let off. Few items on display & divided into 2 parts - - one has to walk to the other side of the bridge for end of the exhibition.However, if one wants to get a view of the Tower from the top of the bridge, is okay.So, if one decides to see this attraction, one must remember that he is paying for the view and the elevator ride, not for the exhibition.

Great views heavy machinery. For strange high level views over London this is a great place. If you are a person interested in how the bridge moves aside for shipping this is a must. The inside offers viewing of the previous hydraulic mechanisms, a tribute to Victorian and early 20th century engineering. All indoors. Good visit with children.
Amazing views. The best time to see the Tower Bridge is at night. The whole bridge is lit up and the view is just amazing. Walk, don't take a cab, to get the full experience.
